author: Adi Sunderam
title: Segmented Arbitrage
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We use arbitrage activity in equity, fixed income, and foreign exchange markets to characterize the frictions and constraints facing intermediaries. The average pairwise correlation between the 32 arbitrage spreads that we study is 22%. These low correlations are inconsistent with canonical intermediary asset pricing models. We show that at least two types of segmentation drive arbitrage dynamics. First, funding is segmented—certain trades rely on specific funding sources, making their arbitrage spreads sensitive to localized funding shocks. Second, balance sheets are segmented—intermediaries specialize in certain trades, so arbitrage spreads are sensitive to idiosyncratic balance‐sheet shocks.</jats:p>
research_question: What frictions and constraints face financial intermediaries in arbitrage activity across equity, fixed income, and foreign exchange markets?
answer: Two types of segmentation drive arbitrage dynamics: (1) funding segmentation, where certain trades rely on specific funding sources making spreads sensitive to localized funding shocks, and (2) balance sheet segmentation, where intermediaries specialize in certain trades making spreads sensitive to idiosyncratic balance-sheet shocks.
positioning_statement: The paper challenges canonical intermediary asset pricing models by showing that the low average pairwise correlation (22%) between 32 arbitrage spreads is inconsistent with existing theoretical frameworks, revealing previously uncharacterized segmentation effects in arbitrage markets.

author: Adrien Verdelhan
title: A Habit‐Based Explanation of the Exchange Rate Risk Premium
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>This paper presents a model that reproduces the uncovered interest rate parity puzzle. Investors have preferences with external habits. Countercyclical risk premia and procyclical real interest rates arise endogenously. During bad times at home, when domestic consumption is close to the habit level, the representative investor is very risk averse. When the domestic investor is more risk averse than her foreign counterpart, the exchange rate is closely tied to domestic consumption growth shocks. The domestic investor therefore expects a positive currency excess return. Because interest rates are low in bad times, expected currency excess returns increase with interest rate differentials.</jats:p>
research_question: How can the uncovered interest rate parity puzzle be explained through investor behavior and preferences?
answer: The uncovered interest rate parity puzzle can be explained through a habit-based model where investors have external habit preferences, which generates countercyclical risk premia and procyclical real interest rates endogenously, leading to positive expected currency excess returns that increase with interest rate differentials.
positioning_statement: This paper presents a new behavioral explanation for the well-known uncovered interest rate parity puzzle by introducing a habit-based preference model that endogenously generates the observed patterns in exchange rate risk premia and interest rate differentials.

author: Adi Sunderam
title: The Cross-Section of Bank Value
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We study the determinants of value creation in U.S. commercial banks. We develop novel measures of individual banks’ productivities at collecting deposits and making loans that we relate to bank market values. We find that deposit productivity is responsible for two-thirds of the value of the median bank and most variation in value across banks. Variation in productivity is driven by differences across banks in technology, customer demographics, and market power. We also find evidence of synergies between deposit-taking and lending. Our findings suggest that there is significant heterogeneity in banks’ ability to capture value by manufacturing safe assets.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the determinants of value creation in U.S. commercial banks?
answer: Deposit productivity is responsible for two-thirds of the value of the median bank and most variation in value across banks, with variation driven by differences in technology, customer demographics, and market power, plus evidence of synergies between deposit-taking and lending.
positioning_statement: The paper develops novel measures of individual banks' productivities at collecting deposits and making loans to study bank value creation, suggesting significant heterogeneity in banks' ability to capture value by manufacturing safe assets.

author: Adi Sunderam
title: The Impact of Minority Representation at Mortgage Lenders
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We study links between the labor market for loan officers and access to mortgage credit. Using novel data matching mortgage applications to loan officers, we find that minorities are underrepresented among loan officers. Minority borrowers are less likely to complete mortgage applications, have completed applications approved, and to ultimately take up a loan. These disparities are reduced when minority borrowers work with minority loan officers. These pairings also lead to lower default rates, suggesting minority loan officers have an informational advantage with minority borrowers. Our results suggest minority underrepresentation among loan officers reduces minority borrowers’ access to credit.</jats:p>
research_question: How does minority representation among loan officers affect minority borrowers' access to mortgage credit?
answer: Minority underrepresentation among loan officers reduces minority borrowers' access to credit, as minority borrowers have better outcomes (higher completion rates, approval rates, loan take-up, and lower default rates) when working with minority loan officers who appear to have informational advantages with minority borrowers.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes novel evidence linking the labor market for loan officers to mortgage credit access by using unique data that matches mortgage applications to individual loan officers, providing new insights into how demographic representation in lending affects credit outcomes.

author: Adi Sunderam
title: The Fed, the Bond Market, and Gradualism in Monetary Policy
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We develop a model of monetary policy with two key features: the central bank has private information about its long‐run target rate and is averse to bond market volatility. In this setting, the central bank gradually impounds changes in its target into the policy rate. Such gradualism represents an attempt to not spook the bond market. However, this effort is partially undone in equilibrium, as markets rationally react more to a given move when the central bank moves more gradually. This time‐consistency problem means that society would be better off if the central bank cared less about the bond market.</jats:p>
research_question: How does a central bank's aversion to bond market volatility and private information about its long-run target rate affect monetary policy implementation?
answer: Central banks engage in gradualism when implementing monetary policy changes to avoid spooking bond markets, but this creates a time-consistency problem where markets rationally react more strongly to gradual moves, partially undoing the intended effect and making society worse off than if the central bank cared less about bond market reactions.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the monetary policy literature by developing a new theoretical model that combines two key elements - central bank private information about target rates and aversion to bond market volatility - to explain gradualism in monetary policy, revealing an unrecognized time-consistency problem in central bank behavior.

author: Adrien Verdelhan
title: Deviations from Covered Interest Rate Parity
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We find that deviations from the covered interest rate parity (CIP) condition imply large, persistent, and systematic arbitrage opportunities in one of the largest asset markets in the world. Contrary to the common view, these deviations for major currencies are not explained away by credit risk or transaction costs. They are particularly strong for forward contracts that appear on banks' balance sheets at the end of the quarter, pointing to a causal effect of banking regulation on asset prices. The CIP deviations also appear significantly correlated with other fixed income spreads and with nominal interest rates.</jats:p>
research_question: Do deviations from covered interest rate parity (CIP) exist in major currency markets, and if so, what explains these deviations?
answer: Large, persistent, and systematic deviations from CIP exist in major currency markets that create arbitrage opportunities. These deviations are not explained by credit risk or transaction costs, but are particularly strong for forward contracts appearing on banks' balance sheets at quarter-end, suggesting banking regulation has a causal effect on asset prices.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the common view in existing literature by demonstrating that CIP deviations for major currencies cannot be explained away by traditional factors like credit risk or transaction costs, instead proposing banking regulation as a key explanatory factor.

author: Albert Menkveld
title: Information Revelation in Decentralized Markets
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>How does information get revealed in decentralized markets? We test several hypotheses inspired by recent dealer‐network theory. To do so, we construct an empirical map of information revelation where two dealers are connected based on the synchronicity of their quote changes. The tests, based on the euro to Swiss franc spot rate (EUR/CHF) quote data including the 2015 crash, largely support theory: strongly connected (i.e., central) dealers are more informed. Connections are weaker when there is less to be learned. The crash serves to identify how a network forms when dealers are transitioned from no‐learning to learning, that is, from a fixed to a floating rate.</jats:p>
research_question: How does information get revealed in decentralized markets?
answer: Information is revealed through dealer networks where strongly connected (central) dealers are more informed, with connections weakening when there is less information to be learned, as demonstrated through the synchronicity of quote changes in the EUR/CHF market.
positioning_statement: This paper tests several hypotheses inspired by recent dealer-network theory by constructing an empirical map of information revelation based on quote synchronicity, using the EUR/CHF market including the 2015 crash as a natural experiment to examine network formation during transitions from no-learning to learning environments.

author: Alan Moreira
title: Volatility‐Managed Portfolios
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Managed portfolios that take less risk when volatility is high produce large alphas, increase Sharpe ratios, and produce large utility gains for mean‐variance investors. We document this for the market, value, momentum, profitability, return on equity, investment, and betting‐against‐beta factors, as well as the currency carry trade. Volatility timing increases Sharpe ratios because changes in volatility are not offset by proportional changes in expected returns. Our strategy is contrary to conventional wisdom because it takes relatively less risk in recessions. This rules out typical risk‐based explanations and is a challenge to structural models of time‐varying expected returns.</jats:p>
research_question: Do managed portfolios that reduce risk exposure when volatility is high generate superior risk-adjusted returns and utility gains for investors?
answer: Yes, volatility-managed portfolios that take less risk when volatility is high produce large alphas, increase Sharpe ratios, and generate substantial utility gains for mean-variance investors across multiple factors including market, value, momentum, profitability, and currency carry trades.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges conventional wisdom and typical risk-based explanations by showing that volatility timing works because changes in volatility are not offset by proportional changes in expected returns, and the strategy takes relatively less risk in recessions, which poses a challenge to existing structural models of time-varying expected returns.

author: Albert Menkveld
title: Competition for Order Flow and Smart Order Routing Systems
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We study the rivalry between Euronext and the London Stock Exchange (LSE) in the Dutch stock market to test hypotheses about the effect of market fragmentation. As predicted by our theory, the consolidated limit order book is deeper after entry of the LSE. Moreover, cross‐sectionally, we find that a higher trade‐through rate in the entrant market coincides with less liquidity supply in this market. These findings imply that (i) fragmentation of order flow can enhance liquidity supply and (ii) protecting limit orders against trade‐throughs is important.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the effect of market fragmentation on liquidity supply, specifically examining the rivalry between Euronext and the London Stock Exchange in the Dutch stock market?
answer: Market fragmentation can enhance liquidity supply, as evidenced by the deeper consolidated limit order book after LSE's entry, and protecting limit orders against trade-throughs is important for maintaining liquidity supply in competing markets.
positioning_statement: This paper tests theoretical hypotheses about market fragmentation effects by empirically examining a specific case of exchange competition, contributing to the literature on how multiple trading venues affect overall market liquidity.

author: Alan Moreira
title: News implied volatility and disaster concerns
abstract: We extend back to 1890 the volatility implied by options index (VIX), available only since 1986, using the frequency of words on the front-page of the Wall Street Journal. News implied volatility (NVIX) captures well the disaster concerns of the average investor over this longer history. NVIX is particularly high during stock market crashes, times of policy-related uncertainty, world wars and financial crises. We find that periods when people are more concerned with a rare disaster, as proxied by news, are either followed by periods of above average stock returns, or followed by periods of large economic disasters. We estimate that the disaster probability has a half-life of four to eight months and annual volatility of 4% to 6%. Our findings are consistent with the view that hard to measure time-varying rare disaster risk is an important driver behind asset prices.

author: Adrien Verdelhan
title: The Share of Systematic Variation in Bilateral Exchange Rates
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Sorting countries by their dollar currency betas produces a novel cross section of average currency excess returns. A slope factor (long in high beta currencies and short in low beta currencies) accounts for this cross section of currency risk premia. This slope factor is orthogonal to the high‐minus‐low carry trade factor built from portfolios of countries sorted by their interest rates. The two high‐minus‐low risk factors account for 18% to 80% of the monthly exchange rate movements. The two risk factors suggest that stochastic discount factors in complete markets' models should feature at least two global shocks to describe exchange rates.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the share of systematic variation in bilateral exchange rates and what risk factors can explain the cross-section of currency excess returns?
answer: A slope factor based on dollar currency betas, combined with the traditional carry trade factor, accounts for 18% to 80% of monthly exchange rate movements and explains the cross-section of currency risk premia. These two orthogonal risk factors suggest that stochastic discount factors in complete markets models should feature at least two global shocks to describe exchange rates.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces a novel approach to understanding currency returns by sorting countries by their dollar currency betas rather than just interest rates, revealing a new slope factor that is orthogonal to the traditional carry trade factor and providing a more comprehensive framework for explaining systematic variation in exchange rates.

author: Alan Moreira
title: When Selling Becomes Viral: Disruptions in Debt Markets in the COVID-19 Crisis and the Fed’s Response
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We document extreme disruption in debt markets during the COVID-19 crisis: a severe price crash accompanied by significant dislocations at the safer end of the credit spectrum. Investment-grade corporate bonds traded at a discount to credit default swaps; exchange-traded funds traded at a discount to net asset value, more so for safer bonds. The Federal Reserve’s announcement of corporate bond purchases caused these dislocations to disappear and prices to recover. These facts inform potential theories of the disruption. The best explanation is an acute liquidity need for specific bond investors, such as mutual funds, leading them to liquidate large positions.</jats:p>
research_question: What caused the extreme disruptions in debt markets during the COVID-19 crisis, and how did the Federal Reserve's response affect these disruptions?
answer: The disruptions were caused by acute liquidity needs of specific bond investors (such as mutual funds) leading them to liquidate large positions in a viral selling pattern. The Federal Reserve's announcement of corporate bond purchases eliminated these dislocations and restored price recovery.
positioning_statement: This paper documents and explains previously unobserved market disruptions during COVID-19, specifically focusing on dislocations at the safer end of the credit spectrum and the effectiveness of Fed intervention, contributing new empirical evidence to the literature on crisis-period market functioning and central bank responses.

author: Alan Moreira
title: The Macroeconomics of Shadow Banking
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We build a macrofinance model of shadow banking—the transformation of risky assets into securities that are money‐like in quiet times but become illiquid when uncertainty spikes. Shadow banking economizes on scarce collateral, expanding liquidity provision, boosting asset prices and growth, but also building up fragility. A rise in uncertainty raises shadow banking spreads, forcing financial institutions to switch to collateral‐intensive funding. Shadow banking collapses, liquidity provision shrinks, liquidity premia and discount rates rise, asset prices and investment fall. The model generates slow recoveries, collateral runs, and flight‐to‐quality effects, and it sheds light on Large‐Scale Asset Purchases, Operation Twist, and other interventions.</jats:p>
research_question: How does shadow banking affect macroeconomic dynamics, particularly the transformation of risky assets into money-like securities and the resulting implications for financial stability and economic cycles?
answer: Shadow banking economizes on scarce collateral and expands liquidity provision, boosting asset prices and growth in quiet times, but builds up systemic fragility. When uncertainty spikes, shadow banking collapses as institutions switch to collateral-intensive funding, leading to reduced liquidity provision, higher discount rates, falling asset prices and investment, and slow economic recoveries.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by building a comprehensive macrofinance model that explains shadow banking's dual role in enhancing liquidity provision during normal times while creating systemic fragility, and demonstrates how this framework can explain various crisis phenomena and policy interventions like Large-Scale Asset Purchases and Operation Twist.

author: Albert Menkveld
title: High‐Frequency Trading around Large Institutional Orders
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Liquidity suppliers lean against the wind. We analyze whether high‐frequency traders (HFTs) lean against large institutional orders that execute through a series of child orders. The alternative is HFTs trading with the wind, that is, in the same direction. We find that HFTs initially lean against these orders but eventually change direction and take positions in the same direction for the most informed institutional orders. Our empirical findings are consistent with investors trading strategically on their information. When deciding trade intensity, they seem to trade off higher speculative profits against higher risk of being detected and preyed on by HFTs.</jats:p>
research_question: Do high-frequency traders (HFTs) lean against the wind or trade with the wind when large institutional orders execute through a series of child orders?
answer: HFTs initially lean against large institutional orders but eventually change direction and take positions in the same direction for the most informed institutional orders, suggesting strategic behavior where institutions trade off speculative profits against the risk of detection by HFTs.
positioning_statement: This paper builds on the established principle that liquidity suppliers lean against the wind by specifically examining HFT behavior around large institutional orders, contributing to the literature on strategic trading and the interaction between institutional investors and high-frequency traders.

author: Albert Menkveld
title: Does Algorithmic Trading Improve Liquidity?
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Algorithmic trading (AT) has increased sharply over the past decade. Does it improve market quality, and should it be encouraged? We provide the first analysis of this question. The New York Stock Exchange automated quote dissemination in 2003, and we use this change in market structure that increases AT as an exogenous instrument to measure the causal effect of AT on liquidity. For large stocks in particular, AT narrows spreads, reduces adverse selection, and reduces trade‐related price discovery. The findings indicate that AT improves liquidity and enhances the informativeness of quotes.</jats:p>
research_question: Does algorithmic trading improve market quality, and should it be encouraged?
answer: Algorithmic trading improves liquidity by narrowing spreads, reducing adverse selection, and reducing trade-related price discovery, particularly for large stocks, while also enhancing the informativeness of quotes.
positioning_statement: This paper provides the first analysis of whether algorithmic trading improves market quality, using the NYSE's automated quote dissemination in 2003 as an exogenous instrument to measure the causal effect of algorithmic trading on liquidity.

author: Albert Menkveld
title: Equilibrium Bitcoin Pricing
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We offer a general equilibrium analysis of cryptocurrency pricing. The fundamental value of the cryptocurrency is its stream of net transactional benefits, which depend on its future prices. This implies that, in addition to fundamentals, equilibrium prices reflect sunspots. This in turn implies multiple equilibria and extrinsic volatility, that is, cryptocurrency prices fluctuate even when fundamentals are constant. To match our model to the data, we construct indices measuring the net transactional benefits of Bitcoin. In our calibration, part of the variations in Bitcoin returns reflects changes in net transactional benefits, but a larger share reflects extrinsic volatility.</jats:p>
research_question: What determines the equilibrium pricing of cryptocurrencies, specifically Bitcoin, and what explains the volatility in cryptocurrency prices?
answer: Cryptocurrency prices are determined by both fundamental value (stream of net transactional benefits) and sunspots, leading to multiple equilibria and extrinsic volatility. For Bitcoin specifically, while part of price variations reflect changes in net transactional benefits, a larger share reflects extrinsic volatility unrelated to fundamentals.
positioning_statement: This paper provides the first general equilibrium analysis of cryptocurrency pricing, offering a theoretical framework that explains cryptocurrency price volatility through both fundamental factors and non-fundamental sunspot equilibria, distinguishing it from existing literature by formally modeling the dual nature of cryptocurrency price determination.

author: Albert Menkveld
title: Computational Reproducibility in Finance: Evidence from 1,000 Tests
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We analyze the computational reproducibility of more than 1,000 empirical answers to 6 research questions in finance provided by 168 research teams. Running the researchers’ code on the same raw data regenerates exactly the same results only 52% of the time. Reproducibility is higher for researchers with better coding skills and those exerting more effort. It is lower for more technical research questions, more complex code, and results lying in the tails of the distribution. Researchers exhibit overconfidence when assessing the reproducibility of their own research. We provide guidelines for finance researchers and discuss implementable reproducibility policies for academic journals.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the level of computational reproducibility in finance research, and what factors influence whether empirical results can be reproduced when running researchers' code on the same raw data?
answer: Only 52% of empirical finance research results are computationally reproducible when running the original code on the same data. Reproducibility is higher for researchers with better coding skills and more effort, but lower for technical questions, complex code, and extreme results. Researchers are overconfident about their own work's reproducibility.
positioning_statement: This paper provides the first large-scale empirical analysis of computational reproducibility in finance research by systematically testing over 1,000 results from 168 research teams, filling a gap in understanding reproducibility issues specific to finance and offering practical guidelines for researchers and journals.

author: Alexi Savov
title: Asset Pricing with Garbage
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>A new measure of consumption, garbage, is more volatile and more correlated with stocks than the canonical measure, National Income and Product Accounts (NIPA) consumption expenditure. A garbage‐based consumption capital asset pricing model matches the U.S. equity premium with relative risk aversion of 17 versus 81 and evades the joint equity premium‐risk‐free rate puzzle. These results carry through to European data. In a cross‐section of size, value, and industry portfolios, garbage growth is priced and drives out NIPA expenditure growth.</jats:p>
research_question: Can garbage-based consumption measures improve asset pricing models' ability to explain equity market phenomena compared to traditional NIPA consumption expenditure measures?
answer: Yes, garbage-based consumption is more volatile and more correlated with stocks than NIPA consumption, enabling a garbage-based CCAPM to match the U.S. equity premium with much lower relative risk aversion (17 vs 81) and solve the joint equity premium-risk-free rate puzzle, with results confirmed in European data and cross-sectional portfolio tests.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as offering a novel solution to well-established puzzles in asset pricing literature by introducing an alternative consumption measure (garbage) that outperforms the canonical NIPA consumption expenditure measure used in traditional consumption capital asset pricing models.

author: Alex Gershkov
title: ASEAN Corporate Governance Scorecard and Firm Value
abstract:
Purpose: This research is aimed to examine the effect of ASEAN corporate governance scorecard on firm value. 
 Design/Methodology/Approach: Research sample consists of 491 manufacture firms listed in stock market of Thailand, Singapore, Philippines, Indonesia, and Malaysia. ASEAN corporate governance scorecard is measured by dummy variable, which is big 50 and non-big 50 firm's rank of highest ASEAN corporate governance scorecard. Firm value measured by Tobin's Q.  Hypothesis test uses country fixed-effect regression analysis.
 Findings: This research finds that the big 50 of highest ASEAN corporate governance scorecards have positive effect on firm value. Higher ASEAN corporate governance scorecard as improvement of rights of shareholders, equitable treatment of shareholders, role of stakeholders, disclosure and transparency, responsibilities of the board, will improve firm's value. 
 Practical Implications: Management could make firm policy about optimal corporate governance, so management could maximizes shareholders' wealth by firm value increasing. Investors, who have interest send their investment abroad especially in ASEAN, have to see condition of corporate governance of public-listed firms, so investors' wealth could be maximized. 
 Originality/Value: This research provides early evidence about new corporate governance formulation, especially in ASEAN, and its effect on firm value in stock markets in ASEAN.

author: Albert Menkveld
title: Asset Price Dynamics with Limited Attention
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We identify long-lived pricing errors through a model in which inattentive investors arrive stochastically to trade. The model’s parameters are structurally estimated using daily NYSE market-maker inventories, retail order flows, and prices. The estimated model fits empirical variances, autocorrelations, and cross-autocorrelations among our three data series from daily to monthly frequencies. Pricing errors for the typical NYSE stock have a standard deviation of 3.2 percentage points and a half-life of 6.2 weeks. These pricing errors account for 9.4$\%$, 7.0$\%$, and 4.5$\%$ of the respective daily, monthly, and quarterly idiosyncratic return variances.</jats:p>
research_question: How do limited attention and inattentive investors affect asset price dynamics and create pricing errors in financial markets?
answer: The model identifies significant long-lived pricing errors with a standard deviation of 3.2 percentage points and a half-life of 6.2 weeks for typical NYSE stocks, accounting for 9.4%, 7.0%, and 4.5% of daily, monthly, and quarterly idiosyncratic return variances respectively.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by developing a structural model that incorporates inattentive investors arriving stochastically to trade, and validates this model using empirical data on NYSE market-maker inventories, retail order flows, and prices across multiple time frequencies.

title: The price of skill: Performance evaluation by households

author: Alexi Savov
title: A Model of Monetary Policy and Risk Premia
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We develop a dynamic asset pricing model in which monetary policy affects the risk premium component of the cost of capital. Risk‐tolerant agents (banks) borrow from risk‐averse agents (i.e., take deposits) to fund levered investments. Leverage exposes banks to funding risk, which they insure by holding liquidity buffers. By changing the nominal rate the central bank influences the liquidity premium, and hence the cost of taking leverage. Lower nominal rates make liquidity cheaper and raise leverage, resulting in lower risk premia and higher asset prices, volatility, investment, and growth. We analyze forward guidance, a “Greenspan put,” and the yield curve.</jats:p>
research_question: How does monetary policy affect the risk premium component of the cost of capital through its impact on bank leverage and liquidity decisions?
answer: Lower nominal interest rates reduce the cost of liquidity, which encourages banks to increase leverage, resulting in lower risk premia and higher asset prices, volatility, investment, and growth. The central bank influences risk premia by changing the liquidity premium through the nominal rate, which affects banks' cost of taking leverage.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a new dynamic asset pricing model that explicitly links monetary policy to risk premia through a banking sector mechanism involving leverage and liquidity buffers, extending beyond traditional models to analyze specific monetary policy tools like forward guidance and the 'Greenspan put.'

author: Albert Menkveld
title: Information Asymmetry and Asset Prices: Evidence from the China Foreign Share Discount
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We examine the effect of information asymmetry on equity prices in the local A‐ and foreign B‐share market in China. We construct measures of information asymmetry based on market microstructure models, and find that they explain a significant portion of cross‐sectional variation in B‐share discounts, even after controlling for other factors. On a univariate basis, the price impact measure and the adverse selection component of the bid‐ask spread in the A‐ and B‐share markets explains 44% and 46% of the variation in B‐share discounts. On a multivariate basis, both measures are far more statistically significant than any of the control variables.</jats:p>
research_question: How does information asymmetry affect equity prices in China's dual-listed A-share (local) and B-share (foreign) markets?
answer: Information asymmetry measures based on market microstructure models explain a significant portion of cross-sectional variation in B-share discounts, with price impact measures and adverse selection components of bid-ask spreads explaining 44-46% of the variation in B-share discounts.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by using market microstructure-based measures of information asymmetry to explain pricing differences between local and foreign shares in China's segmented equity markets, providing empirical evidence for the role of information asymmetry in asset pricing.

author: Alexi Savov
title: Banking on Deposits: Maturity Transformation without Interest Rate Risk
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We show that maturity transformation does not expose banks to interest rate risk—it hedges it. The reason is the deposit franchise, which allows banks to pay deposit rates that are low and insensitive to market interest rates. Hedging the deposit franchise requires banks to earn income that is also insensitive, that is, to lend long term at fixed rates. As predicted by this theory, we show that banks closely match the interest rate sensitivities of their interest income and expense, and that this insulates their equity from interest rate shocks. Our results explain why banks supply long‐term credit.</jats:p>
research_question: Why do banks engage in maturity transformation and how does it affect their exposure to interest rate risk?
answer: Maturity transformation does not expose banks to interest rate risk but actually hedges it, because banks use their deposit franchise (which provides low, interest-rate-insensitive funding) to match the interest rate sensitivities of their income and expenses, thereby insulating their equity from interest rate shocks.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the conventional view that maturity transformation exposes banks to interest rate risk, instead arguing that it serves as a hedging mechanism due to the unique properties of the deposit franchise that allows banks to pay rates that are low and insensitive to market rates.

author: Allan Timmermann
title: Firm Size and Cyclical Variations in Stock Returns
abstract: <jats:p>Recent imperfect capital market theories predict the presence of asymmetries in the variation of small and large firms' risk over the economic cycle. Small firms with little collateral should be more strongly affected by tighter credit market conditions in a recession state than large, better collateralized ones. This paper adopts a flexible econometric model to analyze these mplications empirically. Consistent with theory, small firms display the highest degree of asymmetry in their risk across recession and expansion states, which translates into a higher sensitivity of their expected stock returns with respect to variables that measure credit market conditions.</jats:p>
research_question: Do small and large firms exhibit asymmetric variations in risk and stock returns over economic cycles, particularly in relation to credit market conditions?
answer: Small firms display the highest degree of asymmetry in their risk across recession and expansion states, with higher sensitivity of their expected stock returns to credit market conditions compared to large firms.
positioning_statement: This paper empirically tests predictions from recent imperfect capital market theories using a flexible econometric model to analyze firm size-related asymmetries in risk variation over economic cycles.

author: Allan Timmermann
title: Can Mutual Fund “Stars” Really Pick Stocks? New Evidence from a Bootstrap Analysis
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We apply a new bootstrap statistical technique to examine the performance of the U.S. open‐end, domestic equity mutual fund industry over the 1975 to 2002 period. A bootstrap approach is necessary because the cross section of mutual fund alphas has a complex nonnormal distribution due to heterogeneous risk‐taking by funds as well as nonnormalities in individual fund alpha distributions. Our bootstrap approach uncovers findings that differ from many past studies. Specifically, we find that a sizable minority of managers pick stocks well enough to more than cover their costs. Moreover, the superior alphas of these managers <jats:italic>persist</jats:italic>.</jats:p>
research_question: Can mutual fund managers actually pick stocks well enough to generate superior risk-adjusted returns that persist over time?
answer: Yes, a sizable minority of mutual fund managers can pick stocks well enough to more than cover their costs, and the superior alphas of these managers persist over time.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges many past studies by applying a new bootstrap statistical technique that accounts for the complex nonnormal distribution of mutual fund alphas, uncovering findings that differ from previous research on mutual fund performance.

author: Allan Timmermann
title: Cash Flow News and Stock Price Dynamics
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We develop a new approach to modeling dynamics in cash flows extracted from daily firm‐level dividend announcements. We decompose daily cash flow news into a persistent component, jumps, and temporary shocks. Empirically, we find that the persistent cash flow component is a highly significant predictor of future growth in dividends and consumption. Using a log‐linearized present value model, we show that news about the persistent dividend growth component predicts stock returns consistent with asset pricing constraints implied by this model. News about the daily dividend growth process also helps explain concurrent return volatility and the probability of jumps in stock returns.</jats:p>
research_question: How do different components of cash flow news (persistent, jumps, and temporary shocks) extracted from daily firm-level dividend announcements affect stock price dynamics and return predictability?
answer: The persistent cash flow component significantly predicts future dividend and consumption growth, news about persistent dividend growth predicts stock returns consistent with asset pricing model constraints, and daily dividend growth news helps explain return volatility and jump probabilities in stock returns.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a new approach to modeling cash flow dynamics by decomposing daily cash flow news into distinct components and connecting these to stock price dynamics through a log-linearized present value model, providing a novel framework for understanding the relationship between cash flow news and asset pricing.

author: Allan Timmermann
title: Break Risk
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We develop a new approach to modeling and predicting stock returns in the presence of breaks that simultaneously affect a large cross-section of stocks. Exploiting information in the cross-section enables us to detect breaks in return prediction models with little delay and to generate out-of-sample return forecasts that are significantly more accurate than those from existing approaches. To identify the economic sources of breaks, we explore the asset pricing restrictions implied by a present value model which links breaks in return predictability to breaks in the cash flow growth and discount rate processes.</jats:p>
research_question: How can stock returns be modeled and predicted more accurately when breaks simultaneously affect a large cross-section of stocks?
answer: By exploiting cross-sectional information, breaks in return prediction models can be detected with little delay and generate out-of-sample return forecasts that are significantly more accurate than existing approaches, with breaks in return predictability linked to breaks in cash flow growth and discount rate processes.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a new approach that improves upon existing methods by using cross-sectional information to better detect and handle structural breaks in return prediction models, offering superior forecasting accuracy compared to current approaches.

author: Allan Timmermann
title: Pockets of Predictability
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>For many benchmark predictor variables, short‐horizon return predictability in the U.S. stock market is local in time as short periods with significant predictability (“pockets”) are interspersed with long periods with no return predictability. We document this result empirically using a flexible time‐varying parameter model that estimates predictive coefficients as a nonparametric function of time and explore possible explanations of this finding, including time‐varying risk premia for which we find limited support. Conversely, pockets of return predictability are consistent with a sticky expectations model in which investors slowly update their beliefs about a persistent component in the cash flow process.</jats:p>
research_question: Is return predictability in the U.S. stock market constant over time, or does it vary temporally in distinct patterns?
answer: Short-horizon return predictability in the U.S. stock market is local in time, occurring in short periods of significant predictability ('pockets') that are interspersed with long periods of no return predictability, and this pattern is consistent with a sticky expectations model where investors slowly update beliefs about persistent cash flow components.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the conventional approach of assuming constant predictive relationships over time by using a flexible time-varying parameter model, and positions itself as providing an alternative explanation (sticky expectations) to the commonly studied time-varying risk premia framework for understanding return predictability patterns.

author: Allan Timmermann
title: Investor Information Acquisition and Money Market Fund Risk Rebalancing during the 2011–2012 Eurozone Crisis*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We study investor redemptions and portfolio rebalancing decisions of prime money market mutual funds (MMFs) during the Eurozone crisis. We find that sophisticated investors selectively acquire information about MMFs’ risk exposures to Europe, which leads managers to withdraw funding from information-sensitive European issuers. That is, MMF managers, particularly those serving the most sophisticated investors, selectively adjust their portfolio risk exposures to avoid information-sensitive European risks, while maintaining or increasing risk exposures to other regions. This mechanism helps to explain the occurrence of selective “dry-ups” in debt markets where delegation is common and returns to information production are usually low. (JEL G01, G21, G23)</jats:p>
               <jats:p>Authors have furnished an Internet Appendix, which is available on the Oxford University Press Web site next to the link to the final published paper online.</jats:p>
research_question: How do investor information acquisition and money market fund portfolio rebalancing decisions interact during financial crises, specifically examining the relationship between sophisticated investor behavior and fund manager risk adjustment during the 2011-2012 Eurozone crisis?
answer: Sophisticated investors selectively acquire information about money market funds' European risk exposures, which causes fund managers (especially those serving sophisticated investors) to withdraw funding from information-sensitive European issuers while maintaining or increasing exposures to other regions.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to understanding the mechanism behind selective 'dry-ups' in debt markets characterized by delegation and typically low returns to information production, providing insight into how information acquisition by sophisticated investors drives portfolio rebalancing during crisis periods.

author: Allan Timmermann
title: Decentralized Investment Management: Evidence from the Pension Fund Industry
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Using a unique data set, we document two secular trends in the shift from centralized to decentralized pension fund management over the past few decades. First, across asset classes, sponsors replace generalist balanced managers with better‐performing specialists. Second, within asset classes, funds replace single managers with multiple competing managers following diverse strategies to reduce scale diseconomies as funds grow larger relative to capital markets. Consistent with a model of decentralized management, sponsors implement risk controls that trade off higher anticipated alphas of multiple specialists against the increased difficulty in coordinating their risk‐taking and the greater uncertainty concerning their true skills.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the trends and mechanisms driving the shift from centralized to decentralized investment management in the pension fund industry?
answer: Two secular trends characterize decentralization: (1) sponsors replace generalist balanced managers with better-performing specialists across asset classes, and (2) within asset classes, funds replace single managers with multiple competing managers following diverse strategies to reduce scale diseconomies as funds grow larger relative to capital markets. Sponsors implement risk controls that balance higher anticipated alphas from multiple specialists against increased coordination difficulties and greater uncertainty about manager skills.
positioning_statement: This paper provides novel empirical documentation of decentralization trends in pension fund management using a unique dataset, contributing to the literature by identifying specific mechanisms through which funds restructure their management approach and by developing a theoretical framework that explains how sponsors balance the benefits of specialization against the costs of coordination and skill uncertainty.

author: Alon Brav
title: Hedge Fund Activism, Corporate Governance, and Firm Performance
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Using a large hand‐collected data set from 2001 to 2006, we find that activist hedge funds in the United States propose strategic, operational, and financial remedies and attain success or partial success in two‐thirds of the cases. Hedge funds seldom seek control and in most cases are nonconfrontational. The abnormal return around the announcement of activism is approximately 7%, with no reversal during the subsequent year. Target firms experience increases in payout, operating performance, and higher CEO turnover after activism. Our analysis provides important new evidence on the mechanisms and effects of informed shareholder monitoring.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the mechanisms and effects of hedge fund activism on corporate governance and firm performance?
answer: Activist hedge funds achieve success or partial success in two-thirds of cases through strategic, operational, and financial remedies, generating approximately 7% abnormal returns around announcement with sustained improvements in payout, operating performance, and CEO turnover, while being largely nonconfrontational and not seeking control.
positioning_statement: This paper provides important new evidence on the mechanisms and effects of informed shareholder monitoring using a large hand-collected dataset, contributing novel empirical insights to the literature on hedge fund activism and corporate governance.

author: Alon Brav
title: Shareholder Monitoring through Voting: New Evidence from Proxy Contests
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We present the first comprehensive study of mutual fund voting in proxy contests. Among contests where voting takes place, passive funds are 10 percentage points less likely than active funds to vote for dissidents. The gap shrinks significantly when accounting for votes withheld from management nominees, settled contests, and votes by non-“Big-Three” fund families. Passive and active funds are equally informed about firm fundamentals, although passive funds view contest-related SEC filings more often than active funds during contests, in absolute levels and incrementally relative to noncontest periods. We conclude that passive funds are engaged shareholders in high-stakes voting events.</jats:p>
               <jats:p>Authors have furnished an Internet Appendix, which is available on the Oxford University Press Web site next to the link to the final published paper online</jats:p>
research_question: How do passive mutual funds compare to active mutual funds in their voting behavior and engagement during proxy contests?
answer: Passive funds are engaged shareholders in high-stakes voting events - while they are 10 percentage points less likely to vote for dissidents than active funds, this gap shrinks significantly when accounting for various factors, and passive funds are equally informed about firm fundamentals and actually view contest-related SEC filings more often than active funds during contests.
positioning_statement: This paper presents the first comprehensive study of mutual fund voting in proxy contests, filling a gap in the literature by providing new evidence on shareholder monitoring through voting behavior in these high-stakes situations.

title: An Empirical Analysis of Analysts' Target Prices: Short‐term Informativeness and Long‐term Dynamics
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Using a large database of analysts' target prices issued over the period 1997–1999, we examine short‐term market reactions to target price revisions and long‐term comovement of target and stock prices. We find a significant market reaction to the information contained in analysts' target prices, both unconditionally and conditional on contemporaneously issued stock recommendation and earnings forecast revisions. Using a cointegration approach, we analyze the long‐term behavior of market and target prices. We find that, on average, the one‐year‐ahead target price is 28 percent higher than the current market price.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the short-term market reactions to analysts' target price revisions and how do target prices and stock prices move together over the long term?
answer: There is a significant market reaction to information contained in analysts' target prices both unconditionally and when controlling for contemporaneous stock recommendations and earnings forecasts. Long-term analysis shows that one-year-ahead target prices are on average 28 percent higher than current market prices, and target and stock prices exhibit cointegrated long-term relationships.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing comprehensive empirical analysis of both short-term informativeness and long-term dynamics of analysts' target prices using a large database from 1997-1999, employing cointegration methodology to examine long-term price relationships.

author: Alon Brav
title: Access to Capital, Capital Structure, and the Funding of the Firm
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Based upon a large data set of public and private firms in the United Kingdom, I find that compared to their public counterparts, private firms rely almost exclusively on debt financing, have higher leverage ratios, and tend to avoid external capital markets, leading to a greater sensitivity of their capital structures to fluctuations in performance. I argue that these differences are due to private equity being more costly than public equity. I further examine the private firms subsample to show that private equity is more costly than its public counterpart due to information asymmetry and the desire to maintain control.</jats:p>
research_question: How do capital structure decisions and financing patterns differ between public and private firms, and what explains these differences?
answer: Private firms rely almost exclusively on debt financing, have higher leverage ratios, avoid external capital markets, and show greater sensitivity of capital structures to performance fluctuations compared to public firms. These differences are explained by private equity being more costly than public equity due to information asymmetry and the desire to maintain control.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the capital structure literature by providing empirical evidence on financing differences between public and private firms using a large UK dataset, and extends existing theory by identifying information asymmetry and control considerations as key drivers of higher private equity costs.

author: Alon Brav
title: Inference in Long‐Horizon Event Studies: A Bayesian Approach with Application to Initial Public Offerings
abstract: <jats:p>Statistical inference in long‐horizon event studies has been hampered by the fact that abnormal returns are neither normally distributed nor independent. This study presents a new approach to inference that overcomes these difficulties and dominates other popular testing methods. I illustrate the use of the methodology by examining the long‐horizon returns of initial public offerings (IPOs). I find that the Fama and French (1993) three‐factor model is inconsistent with the observed long‐horizon price performance of these IPOs, whereas a characteristic‐based model cannot be rejected.</jats:p>
research_question: How can statistical inference be improved in long-horizon event studies given that abnormal returns are neither normally distributed nor independent?
answer: A new Bayesian approach to inference overcomes the difficulties of non-normal distribution and dependence in abnormal returns and dominates other popular testing methods. When applied to IPOs, the Fama-French three-factor model is rejected while a characteristic-based model cannot be rejected.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a fundamental methodological problem in long-horizon event studies where existing statistical inference methods are hampered by violations of normality and independence assumptions, presenting a superior Bayesian alternative that dominates other popular testing methods.

author: Alp Simsek
title: Fire Sales in a Model of Complexity
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We present a model of financial crises that stem from endogenous <jats:italic>complexity</jats:italic>. We conceptualize complexity as banks' <jats:italic>uncertainty</jats:italic> about the financial network of cross exposures. As conditions deteriorate, cross exposures generate the possibility of a domino effect of bankruptcies. As this happens, banks face an increasingly complex environment since they need to understand a greater fraction of the financial network to assess their own financial health. Complexity dramatically amplifies banks' perceived counterparty risk, and makes relatively healthy banks reluctant to buy risky assets. The model also features a novel <jats:italic>complexity externality</jats:italic>.</jats:p>
research_question: How does endogenous complexity in financial networks, characterized by banks' uncertainty about cross exposures, contribute to financial crises and fire sales?
answer: Endogenous complexity dramatically amplifies banks' perceived counterparty risk and makes relatively healthy banks reluctant to buy risky assets, thereby contributing to fire sales during financial crises. The model also identifies a novel complexity externality that emerges from this process.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces a novel conceptualization of complexity as banks' uncertainty about financial network cross exposures, presenting a new model that explains financial crises through this endogenous complexity mechanism and identifying a previously unrecognized complexity externality.

author: Alp Simsek
title: Monetary Policy and Asset Price Overshooting: A Rationale for the Wall/Main Street Disconnect
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We analyze <jats:italic>optimal</jats:italic> monetary policy and its implications for asset prices when aggregate demand has inertia. If there is a negative output gap, the central bank optimally overshoots aggregate asset prices (above their steady‐state levels consistent with current potential output). Overshooting leads to a temporary disconnect between the performance of financial markets and the real economy, but accelerates the recovery. When there is a lower bound constraint on the discount rate, good macroeconomic news is better news for asset prices when the output gap is more negative. Finally, we document that during the COVID‐19 recovery, the policy‐induced overshooting was large.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the optimal monetary policy response when aggregate demand has inertia, and what are the implications for asset prices and the disconnect between financial markets and the real economy?
answer: When there is a negative output gap and aggregate demand has inertia, the central bank should optimally overshoot aggregate asset prices above their steady-state levels consistent with current potential output. This overshooting creates a temporary disconnect between financial markets and real economy performance but accelerates economic recovery.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a theoretical rationale for the observed Wall Street/Main Street disconnect by analyzing optimal monetary policy in the presence of aggregate demand inertia, offering a normative framework that justifies asset price overshooting as an optimal policy response rather than treating it as a market inefficiency or policy error.

author: Alp Simsek
title: A Model of Endogenous Risk Intolerance and LSAPs: Asset Prices and Aggregate Demand in a “COVID-19” Shock
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We theoretically investigate the interaction of endogenous risk intolerance and monetary policy following a large recessionary shock. As asset prices dip, risk-tolerant agents’ wealth share declines. This decline reduces the market’s risk tolerance and triggers a downward loop in asset prices and aggregate demand when the interest rate policy is constrained. In this context, large-scale asset purchases are effective because they transfer unwanted risk to the government’s balance sheet. These effects are sizable when the model is calibrated to match the estimates of aggregate asset demand inelasticity. The COVID-19 shock illustrates the environment we seek to capture.</jats:p>
research_question: How do endogenous risk intolerance and monetary policy interact following a large recessionary shock, and what is the effectiveness of large-scale asset purchases in this context?
answer: When asset prices decline, risk-tolerant agents lose wealth share, reducing overall market risk tolerance and creating a downward spiral in asset prices and aggregate demand when interest rate policy is constrained. Large-scale asset purchases are effective because they transfer unwanted risk to the government's balance sheet, with sizable effects when calibrated to match aggregate asset demand inelasticity estimates.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by theoretically modeling the interaction between endogenous changes in market risk tolerance and monetary policy effectiveness during large recessionary shocks, using the COVID-19 shock as an illustrative example of the economic environment being analyzed.

author: Alp Simsek
title: Structural Shifts in Credit Rating Standards
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>I examine the time‐series variation in corporate credit rating standards from 1985 to 2007. A divergent pattern exists between investment‐grade and speculative‐grade rating standards from 1985 to 2002 as investment‐grade standards tighten and speculative‐grade loosen. In 2002, a structural shift occurs toward more stringent ratings. Holding characteristics constant, firms experience a drop of 1.5 notches in ratings due to tightened standards from 2002 to 2007. Credit spread tests suggest that the variation in standards is not completely due to changes in the economic climate. Rating standards affect credit spreads. Loose ratings are associated with higher default rates.</jats:p>
research_question: How do corporate credit rating standards vary over time, specifically examining changes in rating stringency from 1985 to 2007?
answer: Credit rating standards exhibit a divergent pattern between investment-grade (tightening) and speculative-grade (loosening) from 1985-2002, followed by a structural shift in 2002 toward more stringent ratings across all grades, resulting in an average 1.5 notch drop in ratings from 2002-2007 when holding firm characteristics constant.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the credit rating literature by documenting time-series variation in rating standards and demonstrating that changes in rating stringency are not completely explained by economic climate changes, while also establishing the relationship between loose rating standards and higher default rates.

author: Amiyatosh Purnanandam
title: Did Banks Pay Fair Returns to Taxpayers on TARP?
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Financial institutions received investments under the Troubled Asset Relief Program in a bad state of the world but repaid them in a relatively good state. We show that the recipients paid considerably lower returns to taxpayers compared to private‐market securities with similar risk over the same investment horizon, resulting in a subsidy of over $50 billion on the preferred equity investment by the government. Ex‐post renegotiation of contract terms limited the upside gains received by taxpayers in good times and contributed to the subsidy. These findings have important implications for the design and implementation of future bailouts. Our simple methodology for calculating the subsidy can be applied to evaluate the financial costs of other bailouts.</jats:p>
research_question: Did banks pay fair returns to taxpayers on their TARP investments, and what was the magnitude of any subsidy provided?
answer: Banks paid considerably lower returns to taxpayers compared to private-market securities with similar risk over the same investment horizon, resulting in a subsidy of over $50 billion on the preferred equity investment, with ex-post renegotiation of contract terms limiting taxpayer upside gains.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing a methodology for calculating bailout subsidies and demonstrating how contract renegotiation affected taxpayer returns, with implications for designing future bailout programs and evaluating financial costs of government interventions.

author: Amiyatosh Purnanandam
title: Can Markets Discipline Government Agencies? Evidence from the Weather Derivatives Market
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We analyze the role of financial markets in shaping the incentives of government agencies using a unique empirical setting: the weather derivatives market. We show that the introduction of weather derivative contracts on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange (CME) improves the accuracy of temperature measurement by 13% to 20% at the underlying weather stations. We argue that temperature‐based financial markets generate additional scrutiny of the temperature data measured by the National Weather Service, which motivates the agency to minimize measurement errors. Our results have broader implications: the visibility and scrutiny generated by financial markets can potentially improve the efficiency of government agencies.</jats:p>
research_question: Can financial markets discipline government agencies and improve their performance through increased scrutiny and visibility?
answer: Yes, financial markets can discipline government agencies. The introduction of weather derivative contracts on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange improved the accuracy of temperature measurement by 13% to 20% at underlying weather stations operated by the National Weather Service, demonstrating that market-generated scrutiny motivates agencies to minimize measurement errors.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on government agency efficiency by providing novel empirical evidence from the weather derivatives market, demonstrating that financial market visibility and scrutiny can serve as an external disciplining mechanism for government agencies - a relationship that has broader implications beyond the specific case of weather measurement.

author: Anastasia Zakolyukina
title: Information versus Investment
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We quantify the real implications of trade-offs between firm information disclosure and long-term investment efficiency. We estimate a dynamic equilibrium model in which firm managers confront realistic incentives to misreport earnings and distort their real investment choices. The model implies a socially optimal level of disclosure regulation that exceeds the estimated value. Counterfactual analysis reveals that eliminating earnings misreporting completely through disclosure regulation incentivizes managers to distort real investment. Lower earnings informativeness raises the cost of capital, which results in a 5.7$\%$ drop in average firm value, but more modest effects on social welfare and aggregate growth.</jats:p><jats:p>Authors have furnished an Internet Appendix, which is available on the Oxford University Press Web site next to the link to the final published paper online.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the real implications of trade-offs between firm information disclosure and long-term investment efficiency?
answer: The socially optimal level of disclosure regulation exceeds the estimated current value, and eliminating earnings misreporting completely through disclosure regulation incentivizes managers to distort real investment, leading to lower earnings informativeness, higher cost of capital, a 5.7% drop in average firm value, but more modest effects on social welfare and aggregate growth.
positioning_statement: This paper quantifies the real implications of disclosure-investment trade-offs using a dynamic equilibrium model that incorporates realistic managerial incentives for both earnings misreporting and real investment distortion, providing a comprehensive framework to evaluate optimal disclosure regulation.

author: Amiyatosh Purnanandam
title: Banks’ Risk Dynamics and Distance to Default
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We adapt structural models of default risk to take into account the special nature of bank assets. The usual assumption of lognormally distributed asset values is not appropriate for banks. Typical bank assets are risky debt claims with concave payoffs. Because of the payoff nonlinearity, bank asset volatility rises following negative shocks to borrower asset values. As a result, standard structural models with constant asset volatility can severely understate banks’ default risk in good times when asset values are high. Additionally, bank equity return volatility is much more sensitive to negative shocks to asset values than in standard structural models.</jats:p>
research_question: How should structural models of default risk be adapted to accurately capture the special nature of bank assets and their impact on banks' default risk assessment?
answer: Standard structural models with constant asset volatility severely understate banks' default risk during good times because bank assets (risky debt claims with concave payoffs) exhibit rising volatility following negative shocks to borrower asset values, and bank equity return volatility is much more sensitive to negative asset value shocks than standard models predict.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the standard structural models of default risk by arguing that the usual assumption of lognormally distributed asset values with constant volatility is inappropriate for banks, and proposes adaptations that account for the unique characteristics of bank assets as risky debt claims with nonlinear payoffs.

author: Andra Ghent
title: The Imitation Game: The Imitation Game: How Encouraging Renegotiation Makes Good Borrowers Bad
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We show that commercial mortgage borrowers behave opportunistically to attempt to obtain principal reductions. We develop a model in which lenders cannot perfectly observe borrowers’ use values and renegotiation is costly. We then exploit a tax rule change that reduced the cost of renegotiation. Consistent with the model predictions, borrowers with high private use values of the property are more likely to transfer into special servicing when lenders have a higher capacity to negotiate principal reductions after the rule change. Our results suggest adverse consequences of principal forgiveness for lenders.</jats:p>
research_question: How does reducing the cost of renegotiation affect commercial mortgage borrower behavior, particularly regarding strategic default and principal reduction attempts?
answer: Commercial mortgage borrowers behave opportunistically when renegotiation costs are reduced - borrowers with high private use values of properties are more likely to strategically transfer into special servicing to attempt to obtain principal reductions when lenders have higher capacity to negotiate, demonstrating that encouraging renegotiation can cause good borrowers to behave badly.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on mortgage renegotiation by developing a model that incorporates imperfect observability of borrowers' use values and costly renegotiation, then empirically testing the model's predictions using a tax rule change as a natural experiment to demonstrate the adverse consequences of principal forgiveness policies for lenders.
