author: Amir Kermani
title: Stock Market Returns and Consumption
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>This paper employs Swedish data on households' stock holdings to investigate how consumption responds to changes in stock market returns. We instrument the actual capital gains and dividend payments with past portfolio weights. Unrealized capital gains lead to a marginal propensity to consume of 23% for the bottom 50% of the wealth distribution and about 3% for the top 30% of the wealth distribution. Household consumption is significantly more responsive to dividend payouts across all parts of the wealth distribution. Our findings are consistent with households treating capital gains and dividends as separate sources of income.</jats:p>
research_question: How does household consumption respond to changes in stock market returns, specifically distinguishing between capital gains and dividend payments across different wealth distributions?
answer: Unrealized capital gains lead to a marginal propensity to consume of 23% for the bottom 50% of the wealth distribution and about 3% for the top 30% of the wealth distribution, while household consumption is significantly more responsive to dividend payouts across all parts of the wealth distribution, indicating that households treat capital gains and dividends as separate sources of income.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by using Swedish household-level data on stock holdings and employing an instrumental variables approach with past portfolio weights to investigate consumption responses to stock market returns, specifically examining the differential effects of capital gains versus dividends across wealth distributions.

author: Andra Ghent
title: Informational Efficiency in Securitization after Dodd-Frank
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We analyze how Dodd-Frank-mandated risk retention affects the information investors extract from issuers’ retention choices in the CMBS market. We show that the required retention level is both binding and stringent. Although this implies issuers cannot signal using the level of retention, we provide a model showing that signaling can occur by varying the retention structure. The model is consistent with spreads being empirically lower in deals with a purely first-loss retention structure. A stated concern of rulemakers is asymmetric information. However, we show that, post-crisis, the level of asymmetric information in this market is quite low.</jats:p>
research_question: How does Dodd-Frank-mandated risk retention affect the information investors extract from issuers' retention choices in the CMBS market?
answer: Although mandatory risk retention prevents issuers from signaling through retention levels, they can still signal through retention structure, with purely first-loss retention structures resulting in lower spreads, and post-crisis asymmetric information levels in this market are quite low.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses rulemakers' stated concern about asymmetric information in securitization markets by examining how mandatory risk retention rules under Dodd-Frank change signaling mechanisms, finding that while traditional level-based signaling is eliminated, structure-based signaling remains viable.

author: Andra Ghent
title: Asset Insulators
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We construct a new data set tracking the daily value of life insurers’ assets at the security level. Outside of the 2008–2009 crisis, a ${\$}$ 1 drop in the market value of assets reduces an insurer’s market equity by ${\$}$ 0.10. During the ?nancial crisis, this pass-through rises to ${\$}$ 1. We explain this pattern by viewing insurance companies as asset insulators, institutions with stable, long-term liabilities that can ride out transitory dislocations in market prices. Illustrating the macroeconomic importance of insulation, insurers’ market equity declined by ${\$}$50 billion less than the duration-adjusted value of their securities during the crisis.</jats:p>
research_question: How do changes in asset values affect life insurers' market equity, and does this relationship vary during financial crises versus normal times?
answer: Outside of crises, a $1 drop in asset market value reduces insurer market equity by only $0.10, but during the 2008-2009 financial crisis this pass-through increased to $1. This demonstrates that insurance companies normally act as 'asset insulators' but lose this capacity during severe market stress.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces the novel concept of insurance companies as 'asset insulators' - institutions with stable, long-term liabilities that can ride out transitory market price dislocations, contributing new empirical evidence on the macroeconomic role of insurers during financial crises.

author: Andrea Eisfeldt
title: Organization Capital and the Cross‐Section of Expected Returns
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Organization capital is a production factor that is embodied in the firm's key talent and has an efficiency that is firm specific. Hence, both shareholders and key talent have a claim to its cash flows. We develop a model in which the outside option of the key talent determines the share of firm cash flows that accrue to shareholders. This outside option varies systematically and renders firms with high organization capital riskier from shareholders' perspective. We find that firms with more organization capital have average returns that are 4.6% higher than firms with less organization capital.</jats:p>
research_question: How does organization capital affect the cross-section of expected stock returns?
answer: Firms with more organization capital have average returns that are 4.6% higher than firms with less organization capital, because the outside options of key talent make these firms riskier from shareholders' perspective.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces organization capital as a production factor embodied in key talent with firm-specific efficiency, developing a new model where the outside options of key talent determine shareholders' cash flow claims, thereby providing a novel explanation for cross-sectional variation in expected returns.

author: Andrea Eisfeldt
title: Endogenous Liquidity in Asset Markets
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>This paper analyzes a model in which long‐term risky assets are illiquid due to adverse selection. The degree of adverse selection and hence the liquidity of these assets is determined endogenously by the amount of trade for reasons other than private information. I find that higher productivity leads to increased liquidity. Moreover, liquidity magnifies the effects of changes in productivity on investment and volume. High productivity implies that investors initiate larger scale risky projects which increases the riskiness of their incomes. Riskier incomes induce more sales of claims to high‐quality projects, causing liquidity to increase.</jats:p>
research_question: How is the degree of liquidity in asset markets with long-term risky assets determined endogenously, and what factors influence this liquidity?
answer: Higher productivity leads to increased liquidity because it causes investors to initiate larger scale risky projects, which increases income riskiness and induces more sales of claims to high-quality projects. Additionally, liquidity magnifies the effects of productivity changes on investment and volume.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by developing a model where liquidity is determined endogenously through the amount of trade for reasons other than private information, rather than treating liquidity as exogenous in asset markets with adverse selection.

author: Andrea Eisfeldt
title: Complex Asset Markets
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Investors' individual arbitrage models introduce idiosyncratic risk into complex asset strategies, driving up average returns and Sharpe ratios. However, despite the attractive risk‐return trade‐off, participation is limited. This is because effective Sharpe ratios in complex asset markets vary with investors' expertise. Investors with higher expertise, better models, and lower resulting idiosyncratic risk exposures realize higher Sharpe ratios. Their demand deters entry by less sophisticated investors. As predicted by our model, market dislocations are characterized by an increase in idiosyncratic risk, investor exit, and persistently elevated alphas and Sharpe ratios. The selection effect from higher expertise agents' more favorable Sharpe ratios is unique to our model and key to our main results.</jats:p>
research_question: Why do complex asset markets exhibit limited participation despite attractive risk-return trade-offs, and how does investor expertise affect market outcomes?
answer: Effective Sharpe ratios in complex asset markets vary with investors' expertise - higher expertise investors with better models achieve higher Sharpe ratios and lower idiosyncratic risk, while their demand deters entry by less sophisticated investors, leading to limited participation despite attractive average returns.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces a novel selection effect where higher expertise agents achieve more favorable Sharpe ratios, which is unique to their model and distinguishes it from existing literature on complex asset markets and investor participation.

author: Andrea Eisfeldt
title: OTC Intermediaries
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We study the effect of dealer exit on prices and quantities in a model of an over-the-counter market featuring a core-periphery network with bilateral trading costs. The model is calibrated using regulatory data on the entire U.S. credit default swap (CDS) market between 2010 and 2013. Prices depend crucially on the risk-bearing capacity of core dealers, yet unlike standard models featuring a dealer sector, we allow for heterogeneity in dealer risk-bearing capacity. This heterogeneity is quantitatively important. Depending on how well dealers share risk, the exit of a single dealer can cause credit spreads to rise by 8 $\%$ to 24$\%$.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the effect of dealer exit on prices and quantities in over-the-counter markets?
answer: The exit of a single dealer can cause credit spreads to rise by 8% to 24%, depending on how well dealers share risk, with prices crucially depending on the risk-bearing capacity of core dealers.
positioning_statement: Unlike standard models featuring a dealer sector, this paper allows for heterogeneity in dealer risk-bearing capacity in a core-periphery network model with bilateral trading costs, which is shown to be quantitatively important.

author: Andrea Eisfeldt
title: Bonds versus Equities: Information for Investment
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We provide a simple model of investment by a firm funded with debt and equity and empirical evidence to demonstrate that, once we control for the debt overhang problem with credit spreads, <jats:italic>asset</jats:italic> volatility is an unambiguously <jats:italic>positive</jats:italic> signal for investment, while <jats:italic>equity</jats:italic> volatility sends a mixed signal: Elevated volatility raises the option value of equity and increases investment for financially sound firms, but exacerbates debt overhang and decreases investment for firms close to default. Our study provides a simple unified understanding of the structural and empirical relationships between investment, credit spreads, equity versus asset volatility, leverage, and Tobin's .</jats:p>
research_question: How do different types of volatility (asset volatility versus equity volatility) affect firm investment decisions, particularly when considering the debt overhang problem?
answer: Asset volatility is unambiguously positive for investment, while equity volatility sends mixed signals - it increases investment for financially sound firms by raising option value, but decreases investment for firms close to default due to exacerbated debt overhang effects.
positioning_statement: This study provides a simple unified understanding that reconciles structural and empirical relationships between investment, credit spreads, equity versus asset volatility, leverage, and Tobin's Q, offering a framework that explains previously mixed findings in the literature.

author: Andrea Eisfeldt
title: The Cross Section of MBS Returns
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We present a simple, linear asset pricing model of the cross section of Mortgage‐Backed Security (MBS) returns. MBS earn risk premia as compensation for their exposure to prepayment risk. We measure prepayment risk and estimate risk loadings using prepayment forecasts versus realizations. Estimated loadings on prepayment risk decrease monotonically in securities' coupons relative to the par coupon, consistent with the predicted effect of prepayment on bond value. Prepayment risk appears to be priced by specialized MBS investors. The price of prepayment risk changes sign over time with the sign of a representative MBS investor's exposure to prepayment shocks.</jats:p>
research_question: How does prepayment risk affect the cross section of Mortgage-Backed Security (MBS) returns and what drives the risk premia in MBS markets?
answer: MBS earn risk premia as compensation for exposure to prepayment risk, with risk loadings decreasing monotonically in securities' coupons relative to the par coupon. Prepayment risk is priced by specialized MBS investors, and the price of prepayment risk changes sign over time based on a representative MBS investor's exposure to prepayment shocks.
positioning_statement: This paper presents a simple, linear asset pricing model for MBS returns that focuses specifically on prepayment risk as the key pricing factor, using prepayment forecasts versus realizations to measure risk and estimate loadings in the cross section of MBS securities.

author: Andrea Eisfeldt
title: When Uncertainty Blows in the Orchard: Comovement and Equilibrium Volatility Risk Premia
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We provide novel evidence for an equilibrium link between investors' disagreement, the market price of volatility and correlation, and the differential pricing of index and individual equity options. We show that belief disagreement is positively related to (i) the wedge between index and individual volatility risk premia, (ii) the different slope of the smile of index and individual options, and (iii) the correlation risk premium. Priced disagreement risk also explains returns of option volatility and correlation trading strategies in a way that is robust to the inclusion of other risk factors and different market conditions.</jats:p>
research_question: How does investor disagreement affect the equilibrium relationship between volatility risk premia, correlation risk premia, and the differential pricing of index versus individual equity options?
answer: Belief disagreement among investors is positively related to the wedge between index and individual volatility risk premia, the differential slope of option smiles between index and individual options, and the correlation risk premium. Priced disagreement risk explains returns of option volatility and correlation trading strategies robustly across different market conditions.
positioning_statement: This paper provides novel evidence for an equilibrium link between investor disagreement and option pricing differentials, contributing new empirical findings to the literature on volatility risk premia and correlation risk pricing in options markets.

author: Andrea Vedolin
title: Model‐Free International Stochastic Discount Factors
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We provide a theoretical framework to uncover in a model‐free way the relationships among international stochastic discount factors (SDFs), stochastic wedges, and financial market structures. Exchange rates are in general different from the ratio of international SDFs in incomplete markets, as captured by a stochastic wedge. We show theoretically that this wedge can be zero in incomplete and integrated markets. Market segmentation breaks the strong link between exchange rates and international SDFs, which helps address salient features of international asset returns while keeping the volatility and cross‐country correlation of SDFs at moderate levels.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the relationships among international stochastic discount factors (SDFs), stochastic wedges, and financial market structures in a model-free framework?
answer: Exchange rates differ from the ratio of international SDFs in incomplete markets due to stochastic wedges, but this wedge can be zero in incomplete and integrated markets. Market segmentation breaks the strong link between exchange rates and international SDFs, which helps explain international asset return patterns while maintaining moderate SDF volatility and cross-country correlation.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a theoretical framework to uncover relationships among international stochastic discount factors in a model-free way, addressing salient features of international asset returns that existing literature has struggled to explain while keeping SDF characteristics at realistic levels.

author: Andrea Vedolin
title: Exchange Rates and Monetary Policy Uncertainty
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We document that a trading strategy that is short the U.S. dollar and long other currencies exhibits significantly larger excess returns on days with scheduled Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) announcements. We show that these excess returns (i) are higher for currencies with higher interest rate differentials vis‐à‐vis the United States, (ii) increase with uncertainty about monetary policy, and (iii) increase further when the Federal Reserve adopts a policy of monetary easing. We interpret these excess returns as compensation for monetary policy uncertainty within a parsimonious model of constrained financiers who intermediate global demand for currencies.</jats:p>
research_question: How does monetary policy uncertainty, particularly around FOMC announcements, affect exchange rate returns and currency trading strategies?
answer: A trading strategy that is short the U.S. dollar and long other currencies exhibits significantly larger excess returns on FOMC announcement days, with these returns being higher for currencies with greater interest rate differentials, increasing with monetary policy uncertainty, and further increasing during Federal Reserve easing periods.
positioning_statement: The paper interprets these excess returns as compensation for monetary policy uncertainty within a parsimonious model of constrained financiers who intermediate global demand for currencies, providing a theoretical framework to explain the empirical patterns in currency markets around monetary policy announcements.

author: Andrea Vedolin
title: Short-Run Bond Risk Premia
abstract: <jats:p> In the short-run, bond risk premia exhibit pronounced spikes around major economic and financial crises. In contrast, long-term bond risk premia feature cyclical swings. We empirically examine the predictability of the market variance risk premium — a proxy of economic uncertainty — for bond risk premia and we show the strong predictive power for the one-month horizon that quickly recedes for longer horizons. The variance risk premium is largely orthogonal to well-established bond return predictors — forward rates, jumps, and macro variables. We rationalize our empirical findings in an equilibrium model of uncertainty about consumption and inflation which is coupled with recursive preferences. We show that the model can quantitatively explain the levels of bond and variance risk premia as well as the predictive power of the variance risk premium, while jointly matching salient features of other asset prices. </jats:p>
research_question: What is the predictive power of the market variance risk premium (a proxy for economic uncertainty) for bond risk premia across different time horizons?
answer: The variance risk premium has strong predictive power for bond risk premia at the one-month horizon that quickly diminishes for longer horizons, and this predictor is largely orthogonal to well-established bond return predictors like forward rates, jumps, and macro variables.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the bond return predictability literature by introducing the variance risk premium as a novel predictor that is orthogonal to existing predictors (forward rates, jumps, macro variables) and focuses specifically on short-run predictability, which contrasts with the cyclical nature of long-term bond risk premia that has been the focus of prior research.

author: Andreas Fuster
title: Understanding Mortgage Spreads
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Because most mortgages in the United States are securitized in agency mortgage-backed securities (MBS), yield spreads on MBS are a key determinant of homeowners’ funding costs. We study variation in MBS spreads in the time series and across securities and document that MBS spreads show a pronounced cross-sectional smile with respect to the securities’ coupon rates. We present a new pricing model that uses “stripped” MBS prices to identify the contribution of non-interest-rate prepayment risk to spreads and find that this risk explains the smile, whereas the time-series spread variation is mostly accounted for by nonprepayment risk factors.</jats:p>
               <jats:p>Received March 30, 2015; editorial decision November 21, 2018 by Editor Leonid Kogan. Authors have furnished an Internet Appendix, which is available on the Oxford University Press Web site next to the link to the final published paper online.</jats:p>
research_question: What factors explain the variation in mortgage-backed securities (MBS) yield spreads both across different securities and over time?
answer: Non-interest-rate prepayment risk explains the cross-sectional smile pattern in MBS spreads with respect to coupon rates, while nonprepayment risk factors primarily account for time-series variation in spreads.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes a new pricing model that uses 'stripped' MBS prices to separately identify the contribution of non-interest-rate prepayment risk to spreads, providing a novel approach to decompose the sources of MBS spread variation that was not previously available in the literature.

author: Andreas Fuster
title: The Time‐Varying Price of Financial Intermediation in the Mortgage Market
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We introduce a new measure of the price charged by financial intermediaries for connecting mortgage borrowers with capital market investors. Based on administrative lender pricing data, we document that the price of intermediation reacts strongly to variation in demand, reflecting capacity constraints of mortgage originators. This positive comovement of price with quantity reduced the pass‐through of quantitative easing. We also find a notable upward trend in this price between 2008 and 2014, likely due to increased legal and regulatory burden in the mortgage market. The trend led to an implicit cost to borrowers of nearly $100 billion over this period.</jats:p>
research_question: How does the price charged by financial intermediaries for connecting mortgage borrowers with capital market investors vary over time, and what factors drive this variation?
answer: The price of financial intermediation in the mortgage market reacts strongly to demand variation due to capacity constraints of mortgage originators, shows an upward trend between 2008-2014 due to increased legal and regulatory burden, and this trend imposed an implicit cost of nearly $100 billion on borrowers while reducing the effectiveness of quantitative easing.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces a new measure of intermediation pricing in the mortgage market based on administrative lender pricing data, contributing novel empirical evidence on how intermediary capacity constraints and regulatory changes affect the transmission of monetary policy and borrowing costs.

author: Andreas Fuster
title: Predictably Unequal? The Effects of Machine Learning on Credit Markets
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Innovations in statistical technology in functions including credit‐screening have raised concerns about distributional impacts across categories such as race. Theoretically, distributional effects of better statistical technology can come from greater flexibility to uncover structural relationships or from triangulation of otherwise excluded characteristics. Using data on U.S. mortgages, we predict default using traditional and machine learning models. We find that Black and Hispanic borrowers are disproportionately less likely to gain from the introduction of machine learning. In a simple equilibrium credit market model, machine learning increases disparity in rates between and within groups, with these changes attributable primarily to greater flexibility.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the distributional effects of machine learning technology on credit markets across racial groups, particularly regarding access to credit and interest rates for Black and Hispanic borrowers compared to traditional statistical methods?
answer: Machine learning in credit screening disproportionately disadvantages Black and Hispanic borrowers, who are less likely to benefit from ML adoption. ML increases disparity in interest rates both between and within racial groups, with these effects primarily driven by the greater flexibility of ML models to uncover structural relationships rather than triangulation of excluded characteristics.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses concerns about the distributional impacts of statistical technology innovations in credit screening across racial categories, contributing to the literature on algorithmic bias in financial services by empirically examining how machine learning affects credit market outcomes using U.S. mortgage data and equilibrium modeling.

author: Andrei Shleifer
title: Money Doctors
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We present a new model of investors delegating portfolio management to professionals based on trust. Trust in the manager reduces an investor's perception of the riskiness of a given investment, and allows managers to charge fees. Money managers compete for investor funds by setting fees, but because of trust, fees do not fall to costs. In equilibrium, fees are higher for assets with higher expected return, managers on average underperform the market net of fees, but investors nevertheless prefer to hire managers to investing on their own. When investors hold biased expectations, trust causes managers to pander to investor beliefs.</jats:p>
research_question: How does trust between investors and money managers affect portfolio delegation, fee structures, and investment outcomes?
answer: Trust reduces investors' perception of investment risk and enables managers to charge fees above cost, resulting in higher fees for higher expected return assets and systematic underperformance net of fees, yet investors still prefer professional management over self-investing.
positioning_statement: This paper presents a new model of portfolio delegation based on trust, offering an alternative explanation for why investors pay fees to underperforming managers and why fee competition doesn't drive fees to cost levels.

author: Andrei Shleifer
title: Diagnostic Expectations and Credit Cycles
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We present a model of credit cycles arising from diagnostic expectations—a belief formation mechanism based on Kahneman and Tversky's representativeness heuristic. Diagnostic expectations overweight future outcomes that become more likely in light of incoming data. The expectations formation rule is forward looking and depends on the underlying stochastic process, and thus is immune to the Lucas critique. Diagnostic expectations reconcile extrapolation and neglect of risk in a unified framework. In our model, credit spreads are excessively volatile, overreact to news, and are subject to predictable reversals. These dynamics can account for several features of credit cycles and macroeconomic volatility.</jats:p>
research_question: How can diagnostic expectations based on Kahneman and Tversky's representativeness heuristic explain the formation and characteristics of credit cycles?
answer: Diagnostic expectations, which overweight future outcomes that become more likely given incoming data, can generate credit cycles where credit spreads are excessively volatile, overreact to news, and exhibit predictable reversals, thereby accounting for key features of credit cycles and macroeconomic volatility.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as providing a unified framework that reconciles extrapolation and neglect of risk in explaining credit cycles, using a forward-looking expectations formation rule that is immune to the Lucas critique, building on Kahneman and Tversky's representativeness heuristic.

author: Andrei Shleifer
title: Family Firms
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We present a model of succession in a firm owned and managed by its founder. The founder decides between hiring a professional manager or leaving management to his heir, as well as on what fraction of the company to float on the stock exchange. We assume that a professional is a better manager than the heir, and describe how the founder's decision is shaped by the legal environment. This theory of separation of ownership from management includes the Anglo‐Saxon and the Continental European patterns of corporate governance as special cases, and generates additional empirical predictions consistent with cross‐country evidence.</jats:p>
research_question: How does a firm founder decide between hiring a professional manager or leaving management to his heir, and what fraction of the company to float on the stock exchange, given different legal environments?
answer: The founder's succession decision is shaped by the legal environment, with professional managers being better than heirs but the optimal choice depending on institutional factors that explain different corporate governance patterns across countries.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a theory of separation of ownership from management that encompasses both Anglo-Saxon and Continental European corporate governance patterns as special cases, providing a unified framework that generates empirical predictions consistent with cross-country evidence.

author: Andrei Shleifer
title: Bubbles for Fama

author: Andrei Shleifer
title: Diagnostic Expectations and Stock Returns
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We revisit La Porta's finding that returns on stocks with the most optimistic analyst long‐term earnings growth forecasts are lower than those on stocks with the most pessimistic forecasts. We document the joint dynamics of fundamentals, expectations, and returns of these portfolios, and explain the facts using a model of belief formation based on the representativeness heuristic. Analysts forecast fundamentals from observed earnings growth, but overreact to news by exaggerating the probability of states that have become more likely. We find support for the model's predictions. A quantitative estimation of the model accounts for the key patterns in the data.</jats:p>
research_question: How can the finding that stocks with optimistic analyst long-term earnings growth forecasts have lower returns than stocks with pessimistic forecasts be explained through the dynamics of fundamentals, expectations, and returns?
answer: The phenomenon can be explained by a model of belief formation based on the representativeness heuristic, where analysts overreact to news by exaggerating the probability of states that have become more likely when forecasting fundamentals from observed earnings growth.
positioning_statement: This paper revisits and provides a theoretical explanation for La Porta's empirical finding by developing a new model based on the representativeness heuristic to explain the joint dynamics of fundamentals, expectations, and returns, offering both theoretical framework and quantitative validation for previously documented patterns.

author: Andrei Shleifer
title: X-CAPM: An extrapolative capital asset pricing model

author: Andrei Shleifer
title: A Model of Shadow Banking
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We present a model of shadow banking in which banks originate and trade loans, assemble them into diversified portfolios, and finance these portfolios externally with riskless debt. In this model: outside investor wealth drives the demand for riskless debt and indirectly for securitization, bank assets and leverage move together, banks become interconnected through markets, and banks increase their exposure to systematic risk as they reduce idiosyncratic risk through diversification. The shadow banking system is stable and welfare improving under rational expectations, but vulnerable to crises and liquidity dry‐ups when investors neglect tail risks.</jats:p>
research_question: How does shadow banking function as a system where banks originate, trade, and securitize loans while financing portfolios with external debt, and what are the stability and welfare implications of this system?
answer: Shadow banking creates a system where outside investor wealth drives demand for riskless debt and securitization, leading to correlated bank assets and leverage, increased interconnectedness through markets, and higher systematic risk exposure despite reduced idiosyncratic risk. The system is stable and welfare-improving under rational expectations but becomes vulnerable to crises and liquidity dry-ups when investors neglect tail risks.
positioning_statement: This paper presents a theoretical model of shadow banking that explains key empirical features of the system, including the relationship between securitization demand and investor wealth, the co-movement of bank assets and leverage, market-driven interconnectedness, and the trade-off between idiosyncratic and systematic risk in diversified portfolios.

author: Andrei Shleifer
title: Government Ownership of Banks
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We assemble data on government ownership of banks around the world. The data show that such ownership is large and pervasive, and higher in countries with low levels of per capita income, backward financial systems, interventionist and inefficient governments, and poor protection of property rights. Higher government ownership of banks in 1970 is associated with slower subsequent financial development and lower growth of per capita income and productivity. This evidence supports “political” theories of the effects of government ownership of firms.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the patterns and effects of government ownership of banks around the world?
answer: Government ownership of banks is large and pervasive globally, more prevalent in countries with lower income and weaker institutions, and higher government bank ownership in 1970 is associated with slower subsequent financial development and lower economic growth.
positioning_statement: This paper supports 'political' theories of government ownership effects over alternative theoretical perspectives, providing empirical evidence that government ownership of firms (specifically banks) has negative economic consequences.

author: Andrei Shleifer
title: Diagnostic bubbles

author: Andrei Shleifer
title: What Works in Securities Laws?
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We examine the effect of securities laws on stock market development in 49 countries. We find little evidence that public enforcement benefits stock markets, but strong evidence that laws mandating disclosure and facilitating private enforcement through liability rules benefit stock markets.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the effect of securities laws on stock market development across countries?
answer: Laws mandating disclosure and facilitating private enforcement through liability rules benefit stock markets, while public enforcement shows little evidence of benefiting stock markets.
positioning_statement: This paper examines securities laws effectiveness across 49 countries to determine which specific legal mechanisms actually work for stock market development, distinguishing between public enforcement versus disclosure requirements and private enforcement mechanisms.

author: Andrei Shleifer
title: Predictable Financial Crises
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Using historical data on postwar financial crises around the world, we show that the combination of rapid credit and asset price growth over the prior three years, whether in the nonfinancial business or the household sector, is associated with a 40% probability of entering a financial crisis within the next three years. This compares with a roughly 7% probability in normal times, when neither credit nor asset price growth is elevated. Our evidence challenges the view that financial crises are unpredictable “bolts from the sky” and supports the Kindleberger‐Minsky view that crises are the byproduct of predictable, boom‐bust credit cycles. This predictability favors policies that lean against incipient credit‐market booms.</jats:p>
research_question: Are financial crises predictable based on historical patterns of credit and asset price growth?
answer: Financial crises are predictable: the combination of rapid credit and asset price growth over three years increases the probability of a financial crisis to 40% within the next three years, compared to only 7% in normal times.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the prevailing view that financial crises are unpredictable 'bolts from the sky' and instead supports the Kindleberger-Minsky theoretical framework that crises are predictable outcomes of boom-bust credit cycles.

author: Andrei Shleifer
title: Investor protection and corporate governance

author: Andrei Shleifer
title: Investor Protection and Corporate Valuation
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We present a model of the effects of legal protection of minority shareholders and of cash‐flow ownership by a controlling shareholder on the valuation of firms. We then test this model using a sample of 539 large firms from 27 wealthy economies. Consistent with the model, we find evidence of higher valuation of firms in countries with better protection of minority shareholders and in firms with higher cash‐flow ownership by the controlling shareholder.</jats:p>
research_question: How do legal protection of minority shareholders and cash-flow ownership by controlling shareholders affect corporate valuation?
answer: Firms have higher valuations in countries with better protection of minority shareholders and when controlling shareholders have higher cash-flow ownership stakes.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a theoretical model and provides empirical evidence on the relationship between investor protection mechanisms and firm valuation, contributing to the literature on corporate governance and its impact on firm value.

author: Andrei Shleifer
title: Agency Problems and Dividend Policies around the World
abstract: <jats:p>This paper outlines and tests two agency models of dividends. According to the “outcome model,” dividends are paid because minority shareholders pressure corporate insiders to disgorge cash. According to the “substitute model,” insiders interested in issuing equity in the future pay dividends to establish a reputation for decent treatment of minority shareholders. The first model predicts that stronger minority shareholder rights should be associated with higher dividend payouts; the second model predicts the opposite. Tests on a cross section of 4,000 companies from 33 countries with different levels of minority shareholder rights support the outcome agency model of dividends.</jats:p>
research_question: How do agency problems and minority shareholder rights affect dividend policies across different countries?
answer: The outcome agency model of dividends is supported - stronger minority shareholder rights are associated with higher dividend payouts, indicating that dividends are paid because minority shareholders pressure corporate insiders to disgorge cash rather than as a substitute mechanism for establishing reputation.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the dividend policy literature by outlining and testing two competing agency models of dividends (outcome model vs. substitute model) using international data, providing empirical evidence to distinguish between these theoretical explanations for why firms pay dividends in different institutional environments.

author: Andrei Shleifer
title: Trust and Insurance Contracts
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We assemble homeowner insurance claims from 28 independently operated country subsidiaries of a multinational insurance firm. We propose a new insurance model, in which consumers can make invalid claims and firms can deny valid claims, as is common in the data. In the model, trust and honesty shape equilibrium insurance contracts, disputes, and claim payments, especially when disputes are too small for courts. We test the model by investigating claim incidence, dispute, rejection, and payment, as well as insurance costs and pricing across countries. The evidence is consistent with the centrality of trust for insurance markets, as our model predicts.</jats:p>
               <jats:p>Authors have furnished data/code, which are available on the Oxford University Press Web site next to the link to the final published paper online.</jats:p>
research_question: How do trust and honesty affect insurance contracts, disputes, and claim payments in insurance markets?
answer: Trust and honesty are central to shaping equilibrium insurance contracts, disputes, and claim payments, especially for small disputes that don't reach courts. The evidence from 28 country subsidiaries confirms that trust significantly affects claim incidence, dispute rates, rejection rates, payments, and insurance costs and pricing across countries.
positioning_statement: This paper proposes a new insurance model that accounts for the reality that consumers can make invalid claims and firms can deny valid claims, which is common in practice but not adequately addressed in existing insurance literature.

author: Andrew Patton
title: On the High‐Frequency Dynamics of Hedge Fund Risk Exposures
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We propose a new method to model hedge fund risk exposures using relatively high‐frequency conditioning variables. In a large sample of funds, we find substantial evidence that hedge fund risk exposures vary across and within months, and that capturing within‐month variation is more important for hedge funds than for mutual funds. We consider different within‐month functional forms, and uncover patterns such as day‐of‐the‐month variation in risk exposures. We also find that changes in portfolio allocations, rather than in the risk exposures of the underlying assets, are the main drivers of hedge funds' risk exposure variation.</jats:p>
research_question: How do hedge fund risk exposures vary at high frequencies (within-month and across months), and what drives this variation?
answer: Hedge fund risk exposures vary substantially both across and within months, with within-month variation being more important for hedge funds than mutual funds. The variation follows patterns such as day-of-the-month effects, and is primarily driven by changes in portfolio allocations rather than changes in the risk exposures of underlying assets.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces a new methodological approach to modeling hedge fund risk exposures using high-frequency conditioning variables, addressing a gap in the literature by focusing on within-month variation that has been less explored compared to traditional lower-frequency risk exposure analysis.

author: Andrew Patton
title: Risk Price Variation: The Missing Half of Empirical Asset Pricing
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Equal compensation across assets for the same risk exposures is a bedrock of asset pricing theory and empirics. Yet real-world frictions can violate this equality and create apparently high Sharpe ratio opportunities. We develop new methods for asset pricing with cross-sectional heterogeneity in compensation for risk. We extend k-means clustering to group assets by risk prices and introduce a formal test for whether differences in risk premiums across market segments are too large to occur by chance. We find significant evidence of cross-sectional variation in risk prices for almost all combinations of test assets, factor models, and time periods considered.</jats:p>
research_question: Do real-world frictions cause cross-sectional heterogeneity in risk price compensation across assets, violating the fundamental asset pricing assumption of equal compensation for the same risk exposures?
answer: Yes, there is significant evidence of cross-sectional variation in risk prices across almost all combinations of test assets, factor models, and time periods, indicating that equal compensation for risk exposures is frequently violated in practice.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges a fundamental assumption in asset pricing theory and empirics - that assets receive equal compensation for the same risk exposures - by developing new methods to detect and measure cross-sectional heterogeneity in risk prices that existing literature has largely overlooked as the 'missing half' of empirical asset pricing.

author: Andrew Patton
title: What you see is not what you get: The costs of trading market anomalies

author: Andrey Malenko
title: Proxy Advisory Firms: The Economics of Selling Information to Voters
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We analyze how proxy advisors, which sell voting recommendations to shareholders, affect corporate decision‐making. If the quality of the advisor's information is low, there is overreliance on its recommendations and insufficient private information production. In contrast, if the advisor's information is precise, it may be underused because the advisor rations its recommendations to maximize profits. Overall, the advisor's presence leads to more informative voting only if its information is sufficiently precise. We evaluate several proposals on regulating proxy advisors and show that some suggested policies, such as reducing proxy advisors' market power or decreasing litigation pressure, can have negative effects.</jats:p>
research_question: How do proxy advisory firms, which sell voting recommendations to shareholders, affect corporate decision-making?
answer: The effect of proxy advisors on corporate decision-making depends on the quality of their information: low-quality information leads to overreliance and insufficient private information production, while high-quality information may be underused due to profit-maximizing rationing. Proxy advisors only improve voting informativeness when their information is sufficiently precise.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on proxy advisory firms by providing a theoretical framework that analyzes the economics of information selling to voters, and evaluates existing regulatory proposals, showing that some commonly suggested policies may have unintended negative consequences.

author: Andrey Malenko
title: Creating Controversy in Proxy Voting Advice
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We analyze how a profit‐maximizing proxy advisor designs vote recommendations and research reports. The advisor benefits from producing informative, unbiased reports, but only partially informative recommendations, biased against the a priori likely alternative. Such recommendations induce close votes, increasing controversy and thereby the relevance and value of proxy advice. Our results suggest shifting from an exclusive emphasis on recommendations, highlighting the importance of both reports and recommendations in proxy advisors' information provision. They rationalize the one‐size‐fits‐all approach and help reinterpret empirical patterns of voting behavior, suggesting that proxy advisors' recommendations may not be a suitable benchmark for evaluating shareholders' votes.</jats:p>
research_question: How does a profit-maximizing proxy advisor design vote recommendations and research reports?
answer: A profit-maximizing proxy advisor produces informative, unbiased reports but only partially informative recommendations that are biased against the a priori likely alternative, creating close votes that increase controversy and thereby the relevance and value of proxy advice.
positioning_statement: This paper shifts from the existing literature's exclusive emphasis on recommendations to highlighting the importance of both reports and recommendations in proxy advisors' information provision, rationalizes the one-size-fits-all approach, and suggests that proxy advisors' recommendations may not be a suitable benchmark for evaluating shareholders' votes as commonly assumed in empirical studies.

author: Andrew Patton
title: Change You Can Believe In? Hedge Fund Data Revisions
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We analyze the reliability of voluntary disclosures of financial information, focusing on widely‐employed publicly‐available hedge fund databases. Tracking changes to statements of historical performance recorded between 2007 and 2011, we find that historical returns are routinely revised. These revisions are not merely random or corrections of earlier mistakes; they are partly forecastable by fund characteristics. Funds that revise their performance histories significantly and predictably underperform those that have never revised, suggesting that unreliable disclosures constitute a valuable source of information for investors. These results speak to current debates about mandatory disclosures by financial institutions to market regulators.</jats:p>
research_question: How reliable are voluntary disclosures of financial information in publicly-available hedge fund databases, specifically examining whether and why hedge funds revise their historical performance data?
answer: Historical returns in hedge fund databases are routinely revised in ways that are not random corrections but are partly predictable based on fund characteristics, and funds that significantly revise their performance histories predictably underperform those that never revise, making unreliable disclosures a valuable information source for investors.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to current debates about mandatory disclosures by financial institutions to market regulators by providing empirical evidence on the reliability and information content of voluntary financial disclosures in the hedge fund industry.

author: Andrey Malenko
title: Strategic and Financial Bidders in Takeover Auctions
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Using data on auctions of companies, we estimate valuations (maximum willingness to pay) of strategic and financial bidders from their bids. We find that a typical target is valued higher by strategic bidders. However, 22.4% of targets in our sample are valued higher by financial bidders. These are mature, poorly performing companies. We also find that (i) valuations of different strategic bidders are more dispersed and (ii) valuations of financial bidders are correlated with aggregate economic conditions. Our results suggest that different targets appeal to different types of bidders, rather than that strategic bidders always value targets more because of synergies.</jats:p>
research_question: How do valuations differ between strategic and financial bidders in takeover auctions, and what factors determine which type of bidder values a target company more highly?
answer: While strategic bidders typically value targets higher, 22.4% of targets (specifically mature, poorly performing companies) are valued higher by financial bidders. Strategic bidders show more dispersed valuations, while financial bidders' valuations correlate with aggregate economic conditions.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the conventional wisdom that strategic bidders always value targets more due to synergies, instead demonstrating that different types of targets appeal to different types of bidders based on company characteristics and market conditions.

author: Andrey Malenko
title: Real Options Signaling Games with Applications to Corporate Finance

author: Andrey Malenko
title: Advising the Management: A Theory of Shareholder Engagement
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We study the effectiveness of shareholder engagement, that is, shareholders communicating their views to management. When shareholders and management have different beliefs, each shareholder engages more effectively when other shareholders engage as well. A limited shareholder base can thus prevent effective engagement. However, a limited shareholder base naturally arises under heterogeneous beliefs because investors who most disagree with management do not become shareholders. Passive funds, which own the firm regardless of their beliefs, can counteract these effects and improve engagement. When shareholders’ and management’s preferences are strongly misaligned, shareholders’ engagement decisions become substitutes and the role of ownership structure declines.</jats:p><jats:p>Authors have furnished an Internet Appendix, which is available on the Oxford University Press Web site next to the link to the final published paper online.</jats:p>
research_question: What determines the effectiveness of shareholder engagement when shareholders communicate their views to management?
answer: Shareholder engagement is more effective when multiple shareholders engage simultaneously, but heterogeneous beliefs naturally limit the shareholder base as investors who disagree with management avoid becoming shareholders. Passive funds can improve engagement effectiveness by owning firms regardless of their beliefs, though when preferences are strongly misaligned, engagement decisions become substitutes and ownership structure matters less.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a theoretical framework to analyze shareholder engagement effectiveness, contributing to the literature by examining how belief heterogeneity and ownership structure (particularly passive funds) affect the coordination and substitutability of shareholders' engagement decisions.

author: Andrey Malenko
title: A Bayesian Approach to Real Options: The Case of Distinguishing between Temporary and Permanent Shocks
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Traditional real options models demonstrate the importance of the “option to wait” due to uncertainty over future shocks to project cash flows. However, there is often another important source of uncertainty: uncertainty over the permanence of past shocks. Adding Bayesian uncertainty over the permanence of past shocks augments the traditional option to wait with an additional “option to learn.” The implied investment behavior differs significantly from that in standard models. For example, investment may occur at a time of stable or decreasing cash flows, respond sluggishly to cash flow shocks, and depend on the timing of project cash flows.</jats:p>
research_question: How does uncertainty over the permanence of past shocks affect real options investment decisions, beyond the traditional uncertainty over future shocks?
answer: Adding Bayesian uncertainty over whether past shocks are temporary or permanent creates an additional 'option to learn' that significantly changes investment behavior - causing investment to occur during stable or decreasing cash flows, respond sluggishly to shocks, and depend on timing of cash flows.
positioning_statement: This paper extends traditional real options models that focus on the 'option to wait' due to uncertainty over future shocks by incorporating a previously understudied dimension - uncertainty over the permanence of past shocks - which adds an 'option to learn' component to investment decisions.

author: Andrey Malenko
title: The Timing and Method of Payment in Mergers when Acquirers Are Financially Constrained

author: Andrey Malenko
title: Auctions with Endogenous Initiation
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We study initiation of takeover auctions by potential buyers and the seller. A bidder's indication of interest reveals that she is optimistic about the target. If bidders' values have a substantial common component, as in takeover battles between financial bidders, this effect disincentivizes bidders from indicating interest, and auctions are seller‐initiated. Conversely, in private‐value auctions, such as battles between strategic bidders, equilibria can feature both seller‐ and bidder‐initiated auctions, with the likelihood of the latter decreasing in commonality of values and the probability of a forced sale by the seller. We also relate initiation to bids and auction outcomes.</jats:p>
research_question: How do potential buyers and sellers decide whether to initiate takeover auctions, and what factors determine who initiates these auctions?
answer: Auction initiation depends on the degree of common versus private value components in bidders' valuations. When values have substantial common components (as with financial bidders), bidders avoid indicating interest because it reveals optimism to competitors, leading to seller-initiated auctions. In private-value settings (strategic bidders), both seller- and bidder-initiated auctions can occur in equilibrium, with bidder initiation becoming less likely as value commonality increases or when forced sales are more probable.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a gap in auction theory by endogenizing the initiation decision in takeover auctions, distinguishing between different types of bidders (financial vs. strategic) and examining how the common versus private value nature of bidder valuations affects who initiates auctions - a question not previously addressed in the takeover auction literature.

author: Andrey Malenko
title: Investment busts, reputation, and the temptation to blend in with the crowd

author: Andrey Malenko
title: Communication and Decision-Making in Corporate Boards

author: Andrey Malenko
title: The Labor Market for Directors and Externalities in Corporate Governance
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>This paper studies how directors' reputational concerns affect board structure, corporate governance, and firm value. In our setting, directors affect their firms' governance, and governance in turn affects firms' demand for new directors. Whether the labor market rewards a shareholder‐friendly or management‐friendly reputation is determined in equilibrium and depends on aggregate governance. We show that directors' desire to be invited to other boards creates strategic complementarity of corporate governance across firms. Directors' reputational concerns amplify the governance system: strong systems become stronger and weak systems become weaker. We derive implications for multiple directorships, board size, transparency, and board independence.</jats:p>
research_question: How do directors' reputational concerns in the labor market affect board structure, corporate governance, and firm value?
answer: Directors' desire to be invited to other boards creates strategic complementarity of corporate governance across firms, where reputational concerns amplify the governance system - making strong governance systems stronger and weak governance systems weaker.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the corporate governance literature by introducing a novel equilibrium framework that endogenizes the relationship between director labor market incentives and governance outcomes, showing how reputational concerns create externalities across firms that amplify existing governance systems.

author: Andrey Malenko
title: Deadlock on the Board
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We develop a dynamic model of board decision-making akin to dynamic voting models in the political economy literature. We show a board could retain a policy all directors agree is worse than an available alternative. Thus, directors may retain a CEO they agree is bad—deadlocked boards lead to entrenched CEOs. We explore how to compose boards and appoint directors to mitigate deadlock. We find board diversity and long director tenure can exacerbate deadlock. We rationalize why CEOs and incumbent directors have power to appoint new directors: to avoid deadlock. Our model speaks to short-termism, staggered boards, and proxy access.</jats:p>
research_question: How can board decision-making processes lead to suboptimal outcomes where directors retain policies or CEOs they agree are inferior to available alternatives?
answer: Boards can become deadlocked and retain policies all directors agree are worse than available alternatives, leading to CEO entrenchment even when all directors agree the CEO is bad. Board diversity and long director tenure can exacerbate this deadlock problem.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a dynamic model of board decision-making that draws from dynamic voting models in the political economy literature, extending these concepts to corporate governance to explain board deadlock and CEO entrenchment phenomena.

author: Andrey Malenko
title: The Role of Proxy Advisory Firms: Evidence from a Regression-Discontinuity Design

author: Andrey Malenko
title: Nonbinding Voting for Shareholder Proposals
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Shareholder proposals are a common form of shareholder activism. Voting for shareholder proposals, however, is nonbinding since management has the authority to reject the proposal even if it received majority support from shareholders. We analyze whether nonbinding voting is an effective mechanism for conveying shareholder expectations. We show that, unlike binding voting, nonbinding voting generally fails to convey shareholder views when manager and shareholder interests are not aligned. Surprisingly, the presence of an activist investor who can discipline the manager may enhance the advisory role of nonbinding voting only if conflicts of interest between shareholders and the activist are substantial.</jats:p>
research_question: Is nonbinding voting an effective mechanism for conveying shareholder expectations in the context of shareholder proposals?
answer: Nonbinding voting generally fails to convey shareholder views when manager and shareholder interests are not aligned, unlike binding voting. However, the presence of an activist investor who can discipline the manager may enhance the advisory role of nonbinding voting, but only if conflicts of interest between shareholders and the activist are substantial.
positioning_statement: This paper analyzes the effectiveness of nonbinding voting mechanisms in shareholder activism, specifically examining how the nonbinding nature of shareholder proposal voting affects the communication of shareholder expectations to management, with particular attention to the role of activist investors in this process.

author: Andrey Malenko
title: Trading and Shareholder Democracy
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We study shareholder voting in a model in which trading affects the composition of the shareholder base. Trading and voting are complementary, which gives rise to self‐fulfilling expectations about proposal acceptance and multiple equilibria. Prices and shareholder welfare can move in opposite directions, so the former may be an invalid proxy for the latter. Relaxing trading frictions can reduce welfare because it allows extreme shareholders to gain more weight in voting. Delegating decision‐making to the board can help overcome collective action problems at the voting stage. We also analyze the role of index investors and social concerns of shareholders.</jats:p>
research_question: How does trading affect the composition of the shareholder base and what are the implications for shareholder voting outcomes and welfare?
answer: Trading and voting are complementary activities that create self-fulfilling expectations about proposal acceptance and lead to multiple equilibria. Prices can move in opposite directions from shareholder welfare, making prices an invalid proxy for welfare. Reducing trading frictions can actually harm welfare by allowing extreme shareholders to gain disproportionate voting influence.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by modeling the interaction between trading and voting decisions, showing that the traditional assumption of prices as welfare proxies may be invalid, and providing new insights on how trading frictions and shareholder composition affect corporate governance outcomes.

author: Anna Cieslak
title: Information in the Term Structure of Yield Curve Volatility
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Using a novel no‐arbitrage model and extensive second‐moment data, we decompose conditional volatility of U.S. Treasury yields into volatilities of short‐rate expectations and term premia. Short‐rate expectations become more volatile than premia before recessions and during asset market distress. Correlation between shocks to premia and shocks to short‐rate expectations is close to zero on average and varies with the monetary policy stance. While Treasuries are nearly unexposed to variance shocks, investors pay a premium for hedging variance risk with derivatives. We illustrate the dynamics of the yield volatility components during and after the financial crisis.</jats:p>
research_question: How can conditional volatility of U.S. Treasury yields be decomposed into volatilities of short-rate expectations and term premia, and what information do these components reveal about economic conditions and monetary policy?
answer: Short-rate expectations become more volatile than term premia before recessions and during asset market distress, the correlation between shocks to these components varies with monetary policy stance and averages near zero, and while Treasuries have minimal exposure to variance shocks, investors pay premiums for hedging variance risk through derivatives.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces a novel no-arbitrage model that uses extensive second-moment data to decompose yield volatility into previously unexamined components, providing new insights into the information content of yield curve volatility that extends beyond existing term structure literature.

author: Anna Cieslak
title: Short-Rate Expectations and Unexpected Returns in Treasury Bonds

author: Andriy Zapechelnyuk
title: The World&apos;s Key Reserve Currency: Challenges and Threats - BRICS Is Close to Create Its Own Currency
abstract: <jats:p xml:lang="en">&lt;i&gt;The object&lt;/i&gt; &lt;i&gt;of the research&lt;/i&gt; is to deepen the scientific understanding of reserve currencies in a historical and modern context. This study examines the evolution of the global reserve currency system, with a particular focus on the dominance of the U.S. dollar and the growing roles of the euro, Chinese yuan, Japanese yen, and British pound over the past two decades. &lt;i&gt;The investigated problem&lt;/i&gt; lies in the transformation of the essence and function of reserve currencies over the last 25 years, driven by structural shifts in the global economy, financial markets, and geopolitical dynamics. Previously unresolved aspects of this broader issue include the increasing challenges to the U.S. dollar&apos;s status as the sole global anchor currency, especially from emerging powers such as BRICS. &lt;i&gt;The analysis of recent research and publications&lt;/i&gt; highlights a wide range of scholarly and institutional perspectives, including works by Bertaut, Gopinath, Eichengreen, Rogoff, Bracke, and Bunda, along with research conducted by the IMF, Federal Reserve, World Bank, ECB, and BIS. These sources provide the basis for a deeper examination of monetary anchoring and global exchange rate behavior. &lt;i&gt;The main scientific results include&lt;/i&gt; an updated application of the Frankel and Wei (2008) methodology to assess currency anchoring patterns in 149 emerging and developing countries during 2010–2024. The study also presents forecasts based on purchasing power parity, indicating the increasing economic weight of BRICS in global GDP. The area of practical application involves policy planning by governments that continue to rely on the U.S. dollar as an anchor currency. Innovative technological approaches identified include enhanced prudential oversight by central banks and the development of adaptive exchange rate policies in response to growing financial risks. &lt;i&gt;The scope of these innovations&lt;/i&gt; also includes strategies to redirect European savings into high-tech sectors that stimulate sustainable growth and reduce systemic dependence on the dollar. This research contributes to the global discourse on the transition toward a more multipolar reserve currency system and offers insights into how monetary sovereignty and stability can be maintained in a changing world economy.</jats:p>
research_question: How has the transformation of reserve currencies over the last 25 years, driven by structural shifts in the global economy and geopolitical dynamics, challenged the U.S. dollar's dominance as the sole global anchor currency, particularly with the emergence of BRICS and other alternative currencies?
answer: The study finds that there is an increasing challenge to the U.S. dollar's status as the dominant reserve currency, with BRICS countries gaining economic weight in global GDP and emerging economies showing evolving currency anchoring patterns. The research indicates a transition toward a more multipolar reserve currency system, with the euro, Chinese yuan, Japanese yen, and British pound playing growing roles over the past two decades.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as building upon and extending existing scholarly work by prominent researchers (Bertaut, Gopinath, Eichengreen, Rogoff, Bracke, and Bunda) and institutional research from the IMF, Federal Reserve, World Bank, ECB, and BIS. It specifically applies an updated version of the Frankel and Wei (2008) methodology to examine currency anchoring patterns in 149 emerging and developing countries during 2010-2024, contributing new empirical evidence to the global discourse on reserve currency transitions.
