author: Anna Cieslak
title: The Economics of the Fed Put
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Since the mid-1990s, negative stock returns comove with downgrades to the Fed’s growth expectations and predict policy accommodations. Textual analysis of FOMC documents reveals that policy makers pay attention to the stock market. The primary mechanism is their concern with the consumption wealth effect, with a secondary role for the market predicting the economy. We find little evidence of the Fed overreacting to the market in an ex post sense (reacting beyond the market’s effect on growth expectations). Although policy makers are aware that the Fed put could induce risk-taking, moral hazard considerations appear not to significantly affect their decision-making ex ante.</jats:p>
research_question: How and why does the Federal Reserve respond to stock market movements, and what are the mechanisms and implications of the 'Fed put' phenomenon?
answer: The Fed responds to negative stock returns primarily through concern about the consumption wealth effect, with stock market movements predicting policy accommodations when they coincide with downgrades to growth expectations. The Fed does not overreact to markets beyond their effect on growth expectations, and moral hazard considerations do not significantly affect Fed decision-making despite policymakers' awareness of potential risk-taking incentives.
positioning_statement: This paper provides empirical evidence and textual analysis to systematically examine the Fed put phenomenon that has been observed since the mid-1990s, offering a comprehensive analysis of the mechanisms behind Fed responses to stock market movements and addressing concerns about potential overreaction and moral hazard that have been debated in existing literature.

author: Anna Pavlova
title: A Model of Financialization of Commodities
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We analyze how institutional investors entering commodity futures markets, referred to as the financialization of commodities, affect commodity prices. Institutional investors care about their performance relative to a commodity index. We find that all commodity futures prices, volatilities, and correlations go up with financialization, but more so for index futures than for nonindex futures. The equity‐commodity correlations also increase. We demonstrate how financial markets transmit shocks not only to futures prices but also to commodity spot prices and inventories. Spot prices go up with financialization, and shocks to any index commodity spill over to all storable commodity prices.</jats:p>
research_question: How does the entry of institutional investors into commodity futures markets (financialization of commodities) affect commodity prices?
answer: Financialization increases all commodity futures prices, volatilities, and correlations, with stronger effects on index futures than nonindex futures. It also increases equity-commodity correlations, raises spot prices, and creates spillover effects where shocks to any index commodity affect all storable commodity prices.
positioning_statement: This paper analyzes the financialization of commodities by modeling how institutional investors who care about their performance relative to commodity indices affect commodity markets, providing a theoretical framework to understand the transmission of financial market shocks to both futures and spot commodity prices.

author: Anna Dreber Almenberg
title: Computational Reproducibility in Finance: Evidence from 1,000 Tests
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We analyze the computational reproducibility of more than 1,000 empirical answers to 6 research questions in finance provided by 168 research teams. Running the researchers’ code on the same raw data regenerates exactly the same results only 52% of the time. Reproducibility is higher for researchers with better coding skills and those exerting more effort. It is lower for more technical research questions, more complex code, and results lying in the tails of the distribution. Researchers exhibit overconfidence when assessing the reproducibility of their own research. We provide guidelines for finance researchers and discuss implementable reproducibility policies for academic journals.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the level of computational reproducibility in finance research, and what factors influence whether empirical results can be reproduced when running researchers' code on the same raw data?
answer: Only 52% of empirical finance research results are computationally reproducible when running the original code on the same data. Reproducibility is higher for researchers with better coding skills and more effort, but lower for technical questions, complex code, and extreme results. Researchers are overconfident about their own work's reproducibility.
positioning_statement: This paper provides the first large-scale empirical analysis of computational reproducibility in finance research by systematically testing over 1,000 results from 168 research teams, filling a gap in understanding reproducibility issues specific to finance and offering practical guidelines for researchers and journals.

author: Anna Cieslak
title: Stock Returns over the FOMC Cycle
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We document that since 1994, the equity premium is earned entirely in weeks 0, 2, 4, and 6 in Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) cycle time, that is, even weeks starting from the last FOMC meeting. We causally tie this fact to the Fed by studying intermeeting target changes, Fed funds futures, and internal Board of Governors meetings. The Fed has affected the stock market via unexpectedly accommodating policy, leading to large reductions in the equity premium. Evidence suggests systematic informal communication of Fed officials with the media and financial sector as a channel through which news about monetary policy has reached the market.</jats:p>
research_question: How do stock returns vary systematically over the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting cycle, and what causes this pattern?
answer: Since 1994, the equity premium is earned entirely in weeks 0, 2, 4, and 6 of the FOMC cycle (even weeks starting from the last FOMC meeting). This pattern is causally linked to the Fed's unexpectedly accommodating monetary policy, which has led to large reductions in the equity premium, with systematic informal communication between Fed officials and the media/financial sector serving as the transmission channel.
positioning_statement: This paper documents a previously unidentified systematic pattern in stock returns over the FOMC cycle and provides causal evidence linking this pattern to Federal Reserve policy actions and communication, contributing new evidence on how monetary policy affects asset prices through both formal policy changes and informal communication channels.

author: Anna Pavlova
title: Retail Trading in Options and the Rise of the Big Three Wholesalers
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We document a rapid increase in retail trading in options in the United States. Facilitated by payment for order flow (PFOF) from wholesalers executing retail orders, retail trading recently reached over 60% of total market volume. Nearly 90% of PFOF comes from three wholesalers. Exploiting new flags in transaction‐level data, we isolate wholesaler trades and build a novel measure of retail options trading. Our measure comoves with equity‐based retail activity proxies and drops significantly during U.S. brokerage platform outages and trading restrictions. Retail investors prefer cheaper, weekly options with average bid‐ask spread of 12.6%, and lose money on average.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the patterns and characteristics of retail trading in options markets in the United States, particularly in relation to payment for order flow and wholesaler concentration?
answer: Retail trading in options has rapidly increased to over 60% of total market volume, facilitated by payment for order flow from three dominant wholesalers who control nearly 90% of PFOF. Retail investors prefer cheaper weekly options with high bid-ask spreads (12.6% average) and lose money on average.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by exploiting new flags in transaction-level data to isolate wholesaler trades and build a novel measure of retail options trading, documenting previously uncharacterized patterns in retail options activity and its relationship to market structure.

author: Anna Pavlova
title: Benchmarking Intensity
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Benchmarking incentivizes fund managers to invest a fraction of their funds’ assets in their benchmark indexes, and such demand is inelastic. We construct a measure of inelastic demand a stock attracts, benchmarking intensity (BMI), computed as its cumulative weight in all benchmarks, weighted by assets following each benchmark. Exploiting the Russell 1000/2000 cutoff, we show that changes in stocks’ BMIs instrument for changes in ownership of benchmarked investors. The resultant demand elasticities are low. We document that both active and passive fund managers buy additions to their benchmarks and sell deletions. Finally, an increase in BMI lowers future stock returns.</jats:p><jats:p>Authors have furnished an Internet Appendix, which is available on the Oxford University Press Web site next to the link to the final published paper online.</jats:p>
research_question: How does benchmarking affect fund manager investment behavior and what are the implications for stock demand elasticity and returns?
answer: Benchmarking incentivizes fund managers to invest inelastically in benchmark stocks, with both active and passive managers buying benchmark additions and selling deletions, resulting in low demand elasticities and lower future returns for stocks with higher benchmarking intensity.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces a novel measure called 'benchmarking intensity' (BMI) to quantify the inelastic demand that stocks attract from benchmarked investors, using the Russell 1000/2000 cutoff as an identification strategy to establish causal relationships between benchmarking and investment flows.

author: Anthony DeFusco
title: Homeowner Borrowing and Housing Collateral: New Evidence from Expiring Price Controls
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>I empirically analyze how changes in access to housing collateral affect homeowner borrowing behavior. To isolate the role of collateral constraints from that of wealth effects, I exploit the fully anticipated expiration of resale price controls on owner‐occupied housing in Montgomery County, Maryland. I estimate a marginal propensity to borrow out of housing collateral that ranges between $0.04 and $0.13 and is correlated with homeowners' initial leverage. Additional analysis of residential investment and ex‐post loan performance indicates that some of the extracted funds generated new expenditures. These results suggest a potentially important role for collateral constraints in driving household expenditures.</jats:p>
research_question: How do changes in access to housing collateral affect homeowner borrowing behavior?
answer: The marginal propensity to borrow out of housing collateral ranges between $0.04 and $0.13 and is correlated with homeowners' initial leverage, with some extracted funds generating new expenditures.
positioning_statement: This paper isolates the role of collateral constraints from wealth effects by exploiting the fully anticipated expiration of resale price controls, providing new evidence on the potentially important role of collateral constraints in driving household expenditures.

author: Anthony DeFusco
title: No Job, No Money, No Refi: Frictions to Refinancing in a Recession
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We study how employment documentation requirements and out‐of‐pocket closing costs constrain mortgage refinancing. These frictions, which bind most severely during recessions, may significantly inhibit monetary policy pass‐through. To study their effects on refinancing, we exploit a Federal Housing Administration policy change that excluded unemployed borrowers from refinancing and increased others' out‐of‐pocket costs substantially. These changes dramatically reduced refinancing rates, particularly among the likely unemployed and those facing new out‐of‐pocket costs. Our results imply that unemployed and liquidity‐constrained borrowers have a high latent demand for refinancing. Cyclical variation in these factors may therefore affect both the aggregate and distributional consequences of monetary policy.</jats:p>
research_question: How do employment documentation requirements and out-of-pocket closing costs constrain mortgage refinancing, particularly during recessions?
answer: Employment documentation requirements and out-of-pocket closing costs dramatically reduce refinancing rates, with unemployed and liquidity-constrained borrowers having high latent demand for refinancing that is blocked by these frictions, which may significantly inhibit monetary policy pass-through during recessions.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on monetary policy transmission by identifying specific institutional frictions (employment documentation and closing costs) that constrain refinancing during recessions, suggesting that cyclical variation in these factors affects both the aggregate and distributional consequences of monetary policy.

author: Antoinette Schoar
title: Banking Deregulation and Industry Structure: Evidence from the French Banking Reforms of 1985
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We investigate how the deregulation of the French banking industry in the 1980s affected the real behavior of firms and the structure and dynamics of product markets. Following deregulation, banks are less willing to bail out poorly performing firms and firms in the more bank‐dependent sectors are more likely to undertake restructuring activities. At the industry level, we observe an increase in asset and job reallocation, an improvement in allocative efficiency across firms, and a decline in concentration. Overall, these findings support the view that a more efficient banking sector helps foster a Schumpeterian process of “creative destruction.”</jats:p>
research_question: How did the deregulation of the French banking industry in the 1980s affect the real behavior of firms and the structure and dynamics of product markets?
answer: Banking deregulation led to banks being less willing to bail out poorly performing firms, increased restructuring activities in bank-dependent sectors, higher asset and job reallocation at the industry level, improved allocative efficiency across firms, and reduced market concentration.
positioning_statement: This paper supports the view that a more efficient banking sector helps foster a Schumpeterian process of 'creative destruction,' contributing to the literature on how financial sector reforms impact real economic outcomes and market dynamics.

author: Antoinette Schoar
title: Private Equity Performance: Returns, Persistence, and Capital Flows
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>This paper investigates the performance and capital inflows of private equity partnerships. Average fund returns (net of fees) approximately equal the S&P 500 although substantial heterogeneity across funds exists. Returns persist strongly across subsequent funds of a partnership. Better performing partnerships are more likely to raise follow‐on funds and larger funds. This relationship is concave, so top performing partnerships grow proportionally less than average performers. At the industry level, market entry and fund performance are procyclical; however, established funds are less sensitive to cycles than new entrants. Several of these results differ markedly from those for mutual funds.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the performance of private equity partnerships and how do capital inflows relate to this performance?
answer: Private equity fund returns (net of fees) approximately equal S&P 500 returns on average, but show substantial heterogeneity across funds. Performance persists strongly across subsequent funds of the same partnership, and better performing partnerships are more likely to raise follow-on funds and larger funds, though this relationship is concave with top performers growing proportionally less than average performers.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as providing novel findings that differ markedly from mutual fund research, particularly regarding performance persistence and the relationship between performance and capital flows in private equity versus mutual funds.

author: Antoinette Schoar
title: Stressed, Not Frozen: The Federal Funds Market in the Financial Crisis
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We examine the importance of liquidity hoarding and counterparty risk in the U.S. overnight interbank market during the financial crisis of 2008. Our findings suggest that counterparty risk plays a larger role than does liquidity hoarding: the day after Lehman Brothers' bankruptcy, loan terms become more sensitive to borrower characteristics. In particular, poorly performing large banks see an increase in spreads of 25 basis points, but are borrowing 1% less, on average. Worse performing banks do not hoard liquidity. While the interbank market does not freeze entirely, it does not seem to expand to meet latent demand.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the relative importance of liquidity hoarding versus counterparty risk in explaining the dysfunction of the U.S. overnight interbank market during the 2008 financial crisis?
answer: Counterparty risk plays a larger role than liquidity hoarding in explaining interbank market dysfunction during the crisis. After Lehman's bankruptcy, loan terms became more sensitive to borrower characteristics, with poorly performing large banks facing 25 basis point higher spreads while borrowing 1% less on average, and worse performing banks did not hoard liquidity.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on financial crisis transmission mechanisms by empirically distinguishing between two competing explanations for interbank market dysfunction - liquidity hoarding versus counterparty risk - and providing evidence that counterparty risk was the dominant factor in the federal funds market during the 2008 crisis.

author: Antoinette Schoar
title: Effects of Corporate Diversification on Productivity
abstract: <jats:p>Using plant‐level observations from the Longitudinal Research Database I show that conglomerates are more productive than stand‐alone firms at a given point in time. Dynamically, however, firms that diversify experience a net reduction in productivity. While the acquired plants increase productivity, incumbent plants suffer. Moreover, stock prices track firm productivity and this tracking is equally strong for diversified and stand‐alone firms. Therefore, lower transparency of conglomerates is unlikely to explain the discrepancy between productivity and stock prices on average. Finally, I offer some evidence that this discrepancy may arise because conglomerates dissipate rents in the form of higher wages.</jats:p>
research_question: How does corporate diversification affect firm productivity, and why might there be a discrepancy between productivity performance and stock price performance for conglomerates?
answer: Conglomerates are more productive than stand-alone firms at a given point in time, but firms that diversify experience a net reduction in productivity dynamically. While acquired plants increase productivity, incumbent plants suffer. The discrepancy between productivity and stock prices may arise because conglomerates dissipate rents in the form of higher wages, rather than due to lower transparency.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on corporate diversification by using plant-level data to examine productivity effects and addressing the puzzle of why conglomerates trade at discounts despite productivity advantages, challenging the transparency explanation and proposing rent dissipation through wages as an alternative mechanism.

author: Antoinette Schoar
title: Smart Institutions, Foolish Choices: The Limited Partner Performance Puzzle
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>The returns that institutional investors realize from private equity differ dramatically across institutions. Using detailed, hitherto unexplored records, we document large heterogeneity in the performance of investor classes: endowments' annual returns are nearly 21% greater than average. Analysis of reinvestment decisions suggests that endowments (and to a lesser extent, public pensions) are better than other investors at predicting whether follow‐on funds will have high returns. The results are not primarily due to endowments' greater access to established funds, since they also hold for young or undersubscribed funds. Our results suggest that investors vary in their sophistication and potentially their investment objectives.</jats:p>
research_question: Why do institutional investors realize dramatically different returns from private equity investments, and what explains this heterogeneity in performance across different types of institutions?
answer: Endowments significantly outperform other institutional investors in private equity, achieving nearly 21% greater annual returns than average, primarily due to their superior ability to predict which follow-on funds will generate high returns rather than simply having better access to established funds.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the previously unexplored puzzle of performance heterogeneity among institutional investors in private equity by using detailed, hitherto unexplored records to demonstrate that performance differences are driven by varying levels of investor sophistication and investment objectives, rather than just differential access to top-tier funds.

author: Antoinette Schoar
title: Can Unemployment Insurance Spur Entrepreneurial Activity? Evidence from France
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We evaluate the effect of downside insurance on self‐employment. We exploit a large‐scale reform of French unemployment benefits that insured unemployed workers starting businesses. The reform significantly increased firm creation without decreasing the quality of new entrants. Firms started postreform were initially smaller, but their employment growth, productivity, and survival rates are similar to those prereform. New entrepreneurs' characteristics and expectations are also similar. Finally, jobs created by new entrants crowd out employment in incumbent firms almost one‐for‐one, but have a higher productivity than incumbents. These results highlight the benefits of encouraging experimentation by lowering barriers to entry.</jats:p>
research_question: Can unemployment insurance spur entrepreneurial activity, and what are the effects on firm quality and market dynamics?
answer: Unemployment insurance significantly increases firm creation without decreasing quality of new entrants. New firms have similar employment growth, productivity, and survival rates to pre-reform firms, though they start smaller. Job creation by new entrants crowds out incumbent employment nearly one-for-one but with higher productivity.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on barriers to entrepreneurship by providing large-scale empirical evidence on how downside insurance affects self-employment decisions, highlighting the benefits of encouraging business experimentation through policy interventions that lower entry barriers.

author: Antoinette Schoar
title: Retail Financial Innovation and Stock Market Dynamics: The Case of Target Date Funds
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Target date funds (TDFs) are designed to provide unsophisticated or inattentive investors with age‐appropriate exposures to different asset classes like stocks and bonds. The rise of TDFs has moved a significant share of retirement investors into macrocontrarian strategies that sell stocks after relatively good stock market performance. This rebalancing drives contrarian flows across equity mutual funds held by TDFs, stabilizing their funding, and reduces stock returns for stocks disproportionately held by these funds when stock market returns are relatively high. Continued growth in TDFs and similar investment products may dampen stock market volatility and increase the transmission of shocks across asset classes.</jats:p>
research_question: How do target date funds (TDFs) affect stock market dynamics through their rebalancing strategies and impact on equity mutual fund flows?
answer: The rise of TDFs has created macrocontrarian strategies that sell stocks after good performance, driving contrarian flows across equity mutual funds, stabilizing their funding, and reducing stock returns for stocks disproportionately held by these funds during periods of high market returns. Continued TDF growth may dampen stock market volatility and increase cross-asset shock transmission.
positioning_statement: This paper examines the previously understudied market-level effects of retail financial innovation, specifically how TDFs designed for unsophisticated investors create systematic rebalancing patterns that influence broader stock market dynamics and cross-asset relationships.

author: Antoinette Schoar
title: Belief Disagreement and Portfolio Choice
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Using proprietary financial data on millions of households, we show that likely‐Republicans increased the equity share and market beta of their portfolios following the 2016 presidential election, while likely‐Democrats rebalanced into safe assets. We provide evidence that this behavior was driven by investors interpreting public information based on different models of the world. We use detailed controls to rule out the main nonbelief‐based channels such as income hedging needs, preferences, and local economic exposures. These findings are driven by a small share of investors making big changes, and are stronger among investors who trade more ex ante.</jats:p>
research_question: How do political beliefs and partisan differences affect household portfolio allocation decisions following major political events?
answer: Following the 2016 presidential election, likely-Republicans increased their equity share and market beta while likely-Democrats rebalanced into safe assets, driven by investors interpreting public information through different partisan models of the world rather than through income hedging, preferences, or local economic factors.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on belief disagreement and portfolio choice by providing large-scale empirical evidence using proprietary household financial data, controlling for non-belief-based explanations, and demonstrating that political partisanship creates systematic differences in how investors interpret public information when making portfolio decisions.

author: Antoinette Schoar

author: Arthur Korteweg
title: The Net Benefits to Leverage
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>I estimate the market's valuation of the net benefits to leverage using panel data from 1994 to 2004, identified from market values and betas of a company's debt and equity. The median firm captures net benefits of up to 5.5% of firm value. Small and profitable firms have high optimal leverage ratios, as predicted by theory, but in contrast to existing empirical evidence. Companies are on average slightly underlevered relative to the optimal leverage ratio at refinancing. This result is mainly due to zero leverage firms. I also look at implications for financial policy.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the market's valuation of the net benefits to leverage for firms?
answer: The median firm captures net benefits of up to 5.5% of firm value from leverage, with small and profitable firms having high optimal leverage ratios, and companies being on average slightly underlevered relative to optimal leverage ratios at refinancing (mainly due to zero leverage firms).
positioning_statement: This paper provides new empirical evidence that contrasts with existing literature by showing that small and profitable firms have high optimal leverage ratios, which aligns with theoretical predictions but contradicts previous empirical findings.

author: Antoinette Schoar
title: Household Portfolios and Retirement Saving over the Life Cycle
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Using account‐level data on millions of U.S. middle‐class investors over 2006 to 2018, we characterize the share of investable wealth that they hold in the stock market over their working lives. Relative to the 1990s, this share has both risen by 10% and become age‐dependent. The Pension Protection Act (PPA)—which allowed target date funds (TDFs) to be default options in retirement plans—played an important role: younger (older) workers starting at a firm after TDFs became the default option post‐PPA invested more (less) in stocks, in line with the TDF glidepath. In contrast, contribution rates changed little following the PPA.</jats:p>
research_question: How has the share of investable wealth that U.S. middle-class investors hold in the stock market changed over their working lives, and what factors have influenced these changes?
answer: Relative to the 1990s, the share of investable wealth held in stocks has risen by 10% and become age-dependent. The Pension Protection Act, which allowed target date funds to be default options in retirement plans, played an important role: younger workers starting at firms post-PPA invested more in stocks while older workers invested less, following the target date fund glidepath.
positioning_statement: This paper uses comprehensive account-level data on millions of U.S. middle-class investors from 2006 to 2018 to provide updated empirical evidence on household portfolio allocation patterns, contrasting findings with earlier research from the 1990s and identifying the specific impact of the Pension Protection Act on investment behavior.

author: Arthur Korteweg
title: Attracting Early‐Stage Investors: Evidence from a Randomized Field Experiment
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>This paper uses a randomized field experiment to identify which start‐up characteristics are most important to investors in early‐stage firms. The experiment randomizes investors’ information sets of fund‐raising start‐ups. The average investor responds strongly to information about the founding team, but not to firm traction or existing lead investors. We provide evidence that the team is not merely a signal of quality, and that investing based on team information is a rational strategy. Together, our results indicate that information about human assets is causally important for the funding of early‐stage firms and hence for entrepreneurial success.</jats:p>
research_question: Which start-up characteristics are most important to investors in early-stage firms?
answer: Information about the founding team is causally important and strongly influences investor decisions, while firm traction and existing lead investors do not significantly affect investor responses.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the entrepreneurial finance literature by providing causal evidence through a randomized field experiment that information about human assets (founding teams) is crucial for early-stage funding decisions, demonstrating that team information represents more than just a quality signal and constitutes a rational investment strategy.

author: Arthur Korteweg
title: Risk‐Adjusting the Returns to Venture Capital
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We adapt stochastic discount factor (SDF) valuation methods for venture capital (VC) performance evaluation. Our approach generalizes the popular Public Market Equivalent (PME) method and allows statistical inference in the presence of cross‐sectionally dependent, skewed VC payoffs. We relax SDF restrictions implicit in the PME so that the SDF can accurately reflect risk‐free rates and returns of public equity markets during the sample period. This generalized PME yields substantially different abnormal performance estimates for VC funds and start‐up investments, especially in times of strongly rising public equity markets and for investments with betas far from one.</jats:p>
research_question: How can venture capital performance evaluation be improved by adapting stochastic discount factor (SDF) valuation methods to better account for risk adjustment and market conditions?
answer: The generalized Public Market Equivalent (PME) method that relaxes SDF restrictions yields substantially different abnormal performance estimates for VC funds and start-up investments, particularly during periods of strongly rising public equity markets and for investments with betas far from one.
positioning_statement: This paper generalizes the popular Public Market Equivalent (PME) method by adapting stochastic discount factor valuation methods for venture capital performance evaluation, allowing for statistical inference with cross-sectionally dependent, skewed VC payoffs and relaxing SDF restrictions to better reflect actual market conditions.

author: Arthur Korteweg
title: Sequential Learning, Predictability, and Optimal Portfolio Returns
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>This paper finds statistically and economically significant out‐of‐sample portfolio benefits for an investor who uses models of return predictability when forming optimal portfolios. Investors must account for estimation risk, and incorporate an ensemble of important features, including time‐varying volatility, and time‐varying expected returns driven by payout yield measures that include share repurchase and issuance. Prior research documents a lack of benefits to return predictability, and our results suggest that this is largely due to omitting time‐varying volatility and estimation risk. We also document the sequential process of investors learning about parameters, state variables, and models as new data arrive.</jats:p>
research_question: Can investors achieve statistically and economically significant out-of-sample portfolio benefits by using models of return predictability when forming optimal portfolios?
answer: Yes, investors can achieve statistically and economically significant out-of-sample portfolio benefits when using return predictability models, but only when they account for estimation risk and incorporate key features including time-varying volatility and time-varying expected returns driven by payout yield measures that include share repurchase and issuance.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges prior research that documents a lack of benefits to return predictability by demonstrating that the absence of benefits in previous studies is largely due to omitting time-varying volatility and estimation risk from the analysis.

title: Risk-Adjusted Returns of Private Equity Funds: A New Approach
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>This paper introduces a new metric, α, to benchmark the performance of individual private equity funds. Our metric is substantially less sensitive to noise in fund cash flows compared to the popular public market equivalent (PME) and its generalization (GPME), while having the same aggregate pricing implications as GPME. For a large data set of fund cash flows, α estimates have much lower standard deviation across funds than does (G)PME. For buyout funds, PME and α are close, but deviate in certain subsamples. Using α increases power in regressions involving fund performance and improves performance predictability of future funds.</jats:p>
research_question: How can we develop a better metric to benchmark the performance of individual private equity funds that is less sensitive to noise in fund cash flows?
answer: The paper introduces a new metric called α that is substantially less sensitive to noise in fund cash flows compared to existing metrics like PME and GPME, while maintaining the same aggregate pricing implications as GPME and providing improved performance predictability.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as improving upon existing popular performance metrics in private equity, specifically the public market equivalent (PME) and its generalization (GPME), by offering a less noisy alternative that maintains theoretical consistency while providing better empirical properties for performance analysis and prediction.

author: Asaf Manela
title: Negative Home Equity and Household Labor Supply
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Using U.S. household‐level data and plausibly exogenous variation in the location‐timing of home purchases with a single lender, I find that negative home equity causes a 2% to 6% reduction in household labor supply. Supporting causality, households are observationally equivalent at origination and equally sensitive to local housing shocks that do not cause negative equity. Results also hold comparing purchases within the same year‐metropolitan statistical area that differ by only a few months. Though multiple channels are likely at work, evidence of nonlinear effects is broadly consistent with costs associated with housing lock and financial distress.</jats:p>
research_question: Does negative home equity causally affect household labor supply?
answer: Negative home equity causes a 2% to 6% reduction in household labor supply, with evidence suggesting this operates through channels including housing lock and financial distress.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes causal evidence to the literature on negative home equity and labor market outcomes by using plausibly exogenous variation in the location-timing of home purchases with a single lender, addressing identification challenges in previous research.

author: Asaf Manela
title: Does Finance Benefit Society? A Language Embedding Approach
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We measure popular sentiment toward finance by applying a large language model to millions of books published in eight countries over hundreds of years. We extensively validate this measure both internally and externally. We document persistent differences in finance sentiment across countries despite ample time-series variation. Books written in the languages of more capitalist countries discuss finance in a more positive context. Finance sentiment is correlated with survey-based measures of financial market participation and income inequality. Finance sentiment declines one year before rather than after financial crises. Positive shocks to finance sentiment are followed by higher output and credit growth.</jats:p>
research_question: How does popular sentiment toward finance vary across countries and time, and what are the economic implications of these sentiment variations?
answer: Popular sentiment toward finance differs persistently across countries, with more capitalist countries having more positive finance sentiment. Finance sentiment is correlated with financial market participation and income inequality, declines before financial crises, and positive sentiment shocks predict higher output and credit growth.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces a novel methodology using large language models applied to millions of books across countries and centuries to measure finance sentiment, providing a new empirical approach to understanding the relationship between public perception of finance and economic outcomes.

author: Asaf Manela
title: Business News and Business Cycles
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We propose an approach to measuring the state of the economy via textual analysis of business news. From the full text of 800,000 <jats:italic>Wall Street Journal</jats:italic> articles for 1984 to 2017, we estimate a topic model that summarizes business news into interpretable topical themes and quantifies the proportion of news attention allocated to each theme over time. News attention closely tracks a wide range of economic activities and can forecast aggregate stock market returns. A text‐augmented vector autoregression demonstrates the large incremental role of news text in forecasting macroeconomic dynamics. We retrieve the narratives that underlie these improvements in market and business cycle forecasts.</jats:p>
research_question: Can textual analysis of business news be used to effectively measure the state of the economy and improve forecasting of macroeconomic dynamics and stock market returns?
answer: Yes, business news text analysis can effectively measure economic conditions - news attention closely tracks economic activities, can forecast aggregate stock market returns, and provides large incremental improvements in forecasting macroeconomic dynamics when incorporated into vector autoregression models.
positioning_statement: This paper proposes a novel approach to economic measurement and forecasting by applying topic modeling to large-scale business news text, demonstrating that textual analysis can provide substantial incremental value beyond traditional econometric methods for understanding and predicting business cycles and market dynamics.

author: Asaf Manela
title: The Partisanship of Financial Regulators
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We analyze the partisanship of Commissioners at the SEC and Governors at the Federal Reserve Board. Using recent advances in machine learning, we identify partisan phrases in Congress, such as “red tape” and “climate change,” and observe their usage among regulators. Although the Fed has remained relatively nonpartisan throughout our sample period (1930–2019), we find that partisanship among SEC Commissioners rose to an all-time high during the 2010-2019 period, driven by more-partisan Commissioners replacing less-partisan ones. Partisanship at the SEC appears in both the language of new SEC rules and the voting behavior of SEC Commissioners.</jats:p>
               <jats:p>Authors have furnished an Internet Appendix, which is available on the Oxford University Press Web site next to the link to the final published paper online.</jats:p>
research_question: How partisan are financial regulators at the SEC and Federal Reserve Board, and how has this partisanship evolved over time?
answer: The Federal Reserve has remained relatively nonpartisan from 1930-2019, while partisanship among SEC Commissioners reached an all-time high during 2010-2019, driven by more-partisan Commissioners replacing less-partisan ones, with this partisanship manifesting in both SEC rule language and Commissioner voting behavior.
positioning_statement: This paper uses recent advances in machine learning to identify partisan language patterns from Congress and applies this methodology to analyze financial regulators' communications, providing a novel quantitative approach to measuring regulatory partisanship over a long historical period (1930-2019).

author: Asaf Manela
title: Information Acquisition in Rumor‐Based Bank Runs
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We study information acquisition and dynamic withdrawal decisions when a spreading rumor exposes a solvent bank to a run. Uncertainty about the bank's liquidity and potential failure motivates depositors who hear the rumor to acquire additional noisy signals. Depositors with less informative signals may wait before gradually running on the bank, leading to an endogenous aggregate withdrawal speed and bank survival time. Private information acquisition about liquidity can subject solvent‐but‐illiquid banks to runs, and shorten the survival time of failing banks. Public provision of solvency information can mitigate runs by indirectly crowding‐out individual depositors' effort to acquire liquidity information.</jats:p>
research_question: How do depositors' information acquisition decisions and dynamic withdrawal behaviors affect bank runs when rumors spread about a solvent bank's potential failure?
answer: Private information acquisition about bank liquidity can cause runs on solvent-but-illiquid banks and accelerate the failure of genuinely failing banks, while depositors with less informative signals may wait and gradually withdraw, creating endogenous withdrawal speeds and bank survival times. Public provision of solvency information can mitigate runs by crowding out depositors' individual efforts to acquire liquidity information.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the bank run literature by incorporating endogenous information acquisition decisions by depositors who face uncertainty about both bank solvency and liquidity, moving beyond existing models that typically assume fixed information structures or focus solely on coordination failures.

author: Benjamin Keys
title: Moral Hazard during the Housing Boom: Evidence from Private Mortgage Insurance
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We provide novel evidence of misaligned incentives fueling a portion of the 2000s mortgage boom. We document that private mortgage insurance (PMI) companies expanded insurance issuance on high-risk mortgages purchased by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac at the tail end of the housing boom, without changing pricing and despite knowledge of heightened housing risk. The expansion of PMI facilitated an unprecedented increase in Fannie and Freddie’s risky purchases, extending the mortgage boom into 2007 and precipitating their collapse. We argue that this unraveling reflects a general moral hazard problem in insurance, coupled with misaligned incentives in the government-backed mortgage market.</jats:p>
research_question: What role did misaligned incentives in private mortgage insurance play in fueling the 2000s mortgage boom?
answer: Private mortgage insurance companies expanded insurance issuance on high-risk mortgages purchased by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac at the end of the housing boom without changing pricing, despite knowledge of heightened housing risk. This facilitated an unprecedented increase in risky purchases by the GSEs, extending the mortgage boom into 2007 and precipitating their collapse.
positioning_statement: This paper provides novel evidence of misaligned incentives in the mortgage market by focusing on the previously understudied role of private mortgage insurance companies, arguing that their behavior reflects a general moral hazard problem in insurance coupled with specific misaligned incentives in the government-backed mortgage market.

author: Benjamin Keys
title: What Determines Consumer Financial Distress? Place- and Person-Based Factors
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We use credit report data to study consumer financial distress in America. We report large, persistent disparities in financial distress across regions. To understand these patterns, we conduct a “movers” analysis. For collections and default, there is only weak convergence following a move, suggesting these types of distress are not primarily caused by place-based factors (e.g., local economic conditions and state laws) but instead reflect person-based characteristics (e.g., financial literacy and risk preferences). In contrast, for personal bankruptcy, we find a sizable place-based effect, which is consistent with anecdotal evidence on how local legal factors influence personal bankruptcy.</jats:p>
               <jats:p>Authors have furnished an Internet Appendix, which is available on the Oxford University Press Web site next to the link to the final published paper online.</jats:p>
research_question: What determines consumer financial distress - place-based factors (such as local economic conditions and state laws) or person-based factors (such as financial literacy and risk preferences)?
answer: Consumer financial distress is primarily determined by different factors depending on the type of distress: collections and default are mainly driven by person-based characteristics rather than place-based factors, while personal bankruptcy shows a sizable place-based effect influenced by local legal factors.
positioning_statement: This paper uses a novel 'movers' analysis approach with credit report data to empirically distinguish between place-based and person-based determinants of financial distress, building on anecdotal evidence about how local legal factors influence personal bankruptcy while providing new systematic evidence across different types of financial distress.

Fama and French three factor model is perceived as a revision of CAPM, although it stills has severe weaknesses. CAPM theory solves relationship between asset return and asset risk for potential investment project by CML and SML.</jats:p>

answer: The Fama-French three factor model is perceived as a revision of CAPM, but it still has severe weaknesses in explaining variations in expected stock returns.

author: Brett Green
title: Due Diligence
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We propose a model of due diligence and analyze its effect on prices, payoffs, and deal completion. In our model, if the seller accepts an offer, the winning bidder (or “acquirer”) can gather information and chooses when to complete the transaction. In equilibrium, the acquirer engages in “too much” due diligence. Our quantitative results suggest that the magnitude of the distortion is economically significant. Nevertheless, allowing for due diligence can improve both total surplus and the seller's payoff compared to a setting without due diligence. We use our framework to explore the timing of due diligence, bidder heterogeneity, and breakup fees.</jats:p>
research_question: How does due diligence affect prices, payoffs, and deal completion in acquisition transactions?
answer: The acquirer engages in 'too much' due diligence in equilibrium, creating economically significant distortions, but allowing for due diligence can still improve both total surplus and the seller's payoff compared to settings without due diligence.
positioning_statement: The paper proposes a new model of due diligence to analyze its effects on transaction outcomes, exploring previously understudied aspects including the timing of due diligence, bidder heterogeneity, and breakup fees.

author: Camelia Kuhnen
title: Asymmetric Learning from Financial Information
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>This study asks whether investors learn differently from gains versus losses. I find experimental evidence that indicates that being in the negative domain leads individuals to form overly pessimistic beliefs about available investment options. This pessimism bias is driven by people reacting more to low outcomes in the negative domain relative to the positive domain. Such asymmetric learning may help explain documented empirical patterns regarding the differential role of poor versus good economic conditions on investment behavior and household economic choices.</jats:p>
research_question: Do investors learn differently from gains versus losses when processing financial information?
answer: Yes, investors exhibit asymmetric learning - being in the negative domain leads individuals to form overly pessimistic beliefs about investment options because they react more strongly to low outcomes in the negative domain compared to the positive domain.
positioning_statement: This paper provides experimental evidence for asymmetric learning that helps explain existing documented empirical patterns regarding how poor versus good economic conditions differentially affect investment behavior and household economic choices.

author: Brett Green
title: An Information‐Based Theory of Time‐Varying Liquidity
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We propose an information‐based theory to explain time variation in liquidity and link it to a variety of patterns in asset markets. In “normal times,” the market is fully liquid and gains from trade are realized immediately. However, the equilibrium also involves periods during which liquidity “dries up,” which leads to endogenous liquidation costs. Traders correctly anticipate such costs, which reduces their willingness to pay. This foresight leads to a novel feedback effect between prices and market liquidity, which are jointly determined in equilibrium. The model also predicts that contagious sell‐offs can occur after sufficiently bad news.</jats:p>
research_question: What causes time variation in market liquidity and how does it relate to patterns in asset markets?
answer: Market liquidity varies over time due to information-based mechanisms where traders' anticipation of future liquidation costs creates a feedback effect between prices and liquidity that are jointly determined in equilibrium, leading to periods where liquidity 'dries up' and endogenous liquidation costs emerge, with contagious sell-offs occurring after sufficiently bad news.
positioning_statement: This paper proposes a novel information-based theory to explain time-varying liquidity, introducing a new feedback mechanism between prices and market liquidity that differs from existing literature by showing how traders' foresight of liquidation costs jointly determines prices and liquidity in equilibrium.

author: Brett Green
title: Adverse selection, slow-moving capital, and misallocation

author: Brett Green
title: Securitization, Ratings, and Credit Supply
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We develop a framework to explore the effect of credit ratings on loan origination. We show that ratings endogenously shift the economy from a<jats:italic>signaling</jats:italic>equilibrium, in which banks inefficiently retain loans to signal quality, toward an<jats:italic>originate‐to‐distribute</jats:italic>equilibrium with zero retention and inefficiently low lending standards. Ratings increase overall efficiency, provided that the reduction in costly retention more than compensates for the origination of some negative net present value loans. We study how banks' ability to screen loans affects these predictions and use the model to analyze commonly proposed policies such as mandatory “skin in the game.”</jats:p>
research_question: How do credit ratings affect loan origination behavior and the efficiency of credit markets?
answer: Credit ratings endogenously shift the economy from a signaling equilibrium (where banks inefficiently retain loans to signal quality) toward an originate-to-distribute equilibrium (with zero retention and inefficiently low lending standards). Ratings increase overall efficiency when the reduction in costly retention more than compensates for the origination of some negative net present value loans.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a new theoretical framework to analyze the relationship between securitization, credit ratings, and lending behavior, contributing to the literature by showing how ratings can simultaneously improve efficiency through reduced retention costs while creating inefficiencies through lowered lending standards, and by examining policy implications such as mandatory 'skin in the game' requirements.

author: Briana Chang
title: Selection versus talent effects on firm value

author: Briana Chang
title: The Market for Conflicted Advice
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We present a model of the market for advice in which advisers have conflicts of interest and compete for heterogeneous customers through information provision. The competitive equilibrium features information dispersion and partial disclosure. Although conflicted fees lead to distorted information, they are irrelevant for customers' welfare: banning conflicted fees improves only the information quality, not customers' welfare. Instead, financial literacy education for the least informed customers can improve all customers' welfare because of a spillover effect. Furthermore, customers who trade through advisers realize lower average returns, which rationalizes empirical findings.</jats:p>
research_question: How do conflicts of interest affect the market for financial advice, particularly regarding information provision, competition among advisers, and customer welfare?
answer: The competitive equilibrium features information dispersion and partial disclosure, where conflicted fees distort information quality but do not affect customer welfare. Banning conflicted fees improves information quality but not welfare, while financial literacy education for the least informed customers can improve welfare for all customers through spillover effects.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on conflicted advice by developing a competitive market model that explains the empirical finding that customers who trade through advisers realize lower average returns, while providing new insights on the welfare effects of regulatory interventions and financial literacy education.

author: Briana Chang
title: Sorting out the effect of credit supply

author: Brett Green
title: Designing Securities for Scrutiny
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We investigate the effect of scrutiny (e.g., credit ratings, analyst reports, or mandatory disclosures) on the security design problem of a privately informed issuer. We show that scrutiny has important implications for both the form of security designed and the amount of inefficient retention of cash flows. The model predicts that issuers will design informationally sensitive securities (i.e., levered equity) when scrutiny is sufficiently intense. Otherwise, issuers opt for a standard debt contract. Scrutiny increases efficiency by decreasing issuers’ reliance on retention to signal quality and, perhaps counterintuitively, decrease price informativeness.</jats:p>
research_question: How does scrutiny (such as credit ratings, analyst reports, or mandatory disclosures) affect the security design decisions of privately informed issuers?
answer: Scrutiny significantly influences both the type of security designed and the level of inefficient cash flow retention. When scrutiny is sufficiently intense, issuers design informationally sensitive securities (levered equity), otherwise they choose standard debt contracts. Scrutiny improves efficiency by reducing issuers' need to retain cash flows as a quality signal, while counterintuitively decreasing price informativeness.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the security design literature by introducing the role of external scrutiny as a key determinant of optimal security structure, extending beyond traditional models that focus primarily on asymmetric information between issuers and investors without considering the moderating effect of external monitoring and information production.

author: Camelia Kuhnen
title: Noncognitive Abilities and Financial Delinquency: The Role of Self‐Efficacy in Avoiding Financial Distress
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We investigate a novel determinant of financial distress, namely, individuals' self‐efficacy, or belief that their actions can influence the future. Individuals with high self‐efficacy are more likely to take precautions that mitigate adverse financial shocks. They are subsequently less likely to default on their debt and bill payments, especially after experiencing negative shocks such as job loss or illness. Thus, noncognitive abilities are an important determinant of financial fragility and subjective expectations are an important factor in household financial decisions.</jats:p>
research_question: How does self-efficacy (individuals' belief that their actions can influence the future) affect financial distress and delinquency outcomes?
answer: Individuals with high self-efficacy are more likely to take precautionary measures that mitigate adverse financial shocks and are subsequently less likely to default on debt and bill payments, especially after experiencing negative shocks such as job loss or illness.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces self-efficacy as a novel determinant of financial distress, positioning noncognitive abilities and subjective expectations as important but previously understudied factors in household financial decisions and financial fragility.

author: Camelia Kuhnen
title: Business Networks, Corporate Governance, and Contracting in the Mutual Fund Industry
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Business connections can mitigate agency conflicts by facilitating efficient information transfers, but can also be channels for inefficient favoritism. I analyze these two effects in the mutual fund industry and find that fund directors and advisory firms that manage the funds hire each other preferentially based on the intensity of their past interactions. I do not find evidence that stronger board‐advisor ties correspond to better or worse outcomes for fund shareholders. These results suggest that the two effects of board‐management connections on investor welfare—improved monitoring and increased potential for collusion—balance out in this setting.</jats:p>
research_question: How do business connections between fund directors and advisory firms affect agency conflicts and investor outcomes in the mutual fund industry?
answer: Fund directors and advisory firms hire each other preferentially based on past interaction intensity, but these stronger board-advisor ties show no net positive or negative effect on fund shareholder outcomes, suggesting that improved monitoring benefits and increased collusion potential cancel each other out.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on business networks and corporate governance by examining both the positive effects (efficient information transfers and improved monitoring) and negative effects (inefficient favoritism and collusion potential) of board-management connections, specifically within the mutual fund industry context.

author: Camelia Kuhnen
title: Socioeconomic status and learning from financial information

author: Camelia Kuhnen
title: Wealth and Insurance Choices: Evidence from U.S. Households
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Using administrative data for 63,000 individuals across 2,500,000 person‐month observations, we find that wealthier individuals have better life insurance coverage, controlling for the value of the asset insured, namely, the consumption needs of dependents. This positive wealth‐insurance correlation, which is surprising given the prevailing view that wealth substitutes for insurance, persists after allowing for wealth‐related differences in risk or bequest preferences, pricing, background risk, education, employment, or liquidity constraints. Our findings call for further investigation of this wealth‐coverage correlation but support theories emphasizing the consumption‐smoothing role of insurance across not only states of the world, but also time.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the relationship between wealth and life insurance coverage choices among U.S. households?
answer: Wealthier individuals have better life insurance coverage even after controlling for the value of the asset being insured (consumption needs of dependents) and other wealth-related factors, showing a positive wealth-insurance correlation that persists across various controls.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the prevailing view that wealth substitutes for insurance by documenting a surprising positive correlation between wealth and insurance coverage, and supports theories that emphasize insurance's consumption-smoothing role across both states of the world and time.

author: Carola Binder
title: The Effect of Banking Relationships on the Firm's IPO Underpricing
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>This paper investigates the effects of pre‐IPO banking relationships on a firm's IPO. Using a new and unique data set, which compares the firm's pre‐IPO banking relationships to the underwriters managing the firm's new issue, I test whether banking relationships established before the firm's IPO ameliorate asymmetric informa tion problems behind high IPO underpricing. The results show that firms with a pre‐IPO banking relationship with a prospective underwriter face about 17% lower underpricing than firms without such banking relationships. These results are robust to controlling for the firm's endogenous selection of the pre‐IPO banking institution.</jats:p>
research_question: Do pre-IPO banking relationships between firms and their prospective underwriters affect IPO underpricing?
answer: Firms with pre-IPO banking relationships with their underwriters experience approximately 17% lower IPO underpricing compared to firms without such relationships.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the IPO underpricing literature by investigating whether pre-existing banking relationships can ameliorate asymmetric information problems that are commonly cited as a cause of high IPO underpricing, using a new and unique dataset that directly compares pre-IPO banking relationships to IPO underwriters.

author: Camelia Kuhnen
title: Socioeconomic Status and Macroeconomic Expectations
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We show that individuals’ macroeconomic expectations are influenced by their socioeconomic status (SES). People with higher income or higher education are more optimistic about future macroeconomic developments, including business conditions, the national unemployment rate, and stock market returns. The spread in beliefs between high- and low-SES individuals diminishes significantly during recessions. A comparison with professional forecasters and historical data reveals that the beliefs wedge reflects excessive pessimism on the part of low-SES individuals. SES-driven expectations help explain why higher-SES individuals are more inclined to invest in the stock market and more likely to consider purchasing homes, durable goods, or cars.</jats:p>
               <jats:p>Received November 13, 2017; editorial decision February 12, 2019 by Editor Wei Jiang. Authors have furnished an Internet Appendix, which is available on the Oxford University Press Web site next to the link to the final published paper online.</jats:p>
research_question: How does socioeconomic status (SES) influence individuals' macroeconomic expectations?
answer: Higher-SES individuals (those with higher income or education) are more optimistic about future macroeconomic developments including business conditions, unemployment, and stock returns, with the belief gap narrowing during recessions and reflecting excessive pessimism among low-SES individuals rather than excessive optimism among high-SES individuals.
positioning_statement: This paper establishes a new empirical relationship between socioeconomic status and macroeconomic expectations, demonstrating that SES-driven expectations help explain differential investment behaviors and consumption decisions across socioeconomic groups.

author: Carola Frydman
title: The Impact of Salience on Investor Behavior: Evidence from a Natural Experiment
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We test whether the display of information causally affects investor behavior in a high‐stakes trading environment. Using investor‐level brokerage data from China and a natural experiment, we estimate the impact of a shock that increased the salience of a stock's purchase price but did not change the investor's information set. We employ a difference‐in‐differences approach and find that the salience shock causally increased the disposition effect by 17%. We use microdata to document substantial heterogeneity across investors in the treatment effect. A previously documented trading pattern, the “rank effect,” explains heterogeneity in the change in the disposition effect.</jats:p>
research_question: Does the display of information causally affect investor behavior in a high-stakes trading environment?
answer: The salience shock causally increased the disposition effect by 17%, demonstrating that how information is displayed does causally affect investor behavior even without changing the investor's information set.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing causal evidence of salience effects on investor behavior using a natural experiment and high-stakes real trading data, while also documenting substantial heterogeneity across investors and connecting this heterogeneity to the previously documented 'rank effect' trading pattern.

author: Caroline Pflueger
title: Sovereign Debt Portfolios, Bond Risks, and the Credibility of Monetary Policy
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We document that governments whose local currency debt provides them with greater hedging benefits actually borrow more in foreign currency. We introduce two features into a government's debt portfolio choice problem to explain this finding: risk‐averse lenders and lack of monetary policy commitment. A government without commitment chooses excessively countercyclical inflation ex post, which leads risk‐averse lenders to require a risk premium ex ante. This makes local currency debt too expensive from the government's perspective and thereby discourages the government from borrowing in its own currency.</jats:p>
research_question: Why do governments whose local currency debt would provide them with greater hedging benefits actually borrow more in foreign currency?
answer: Governments without monetary policy commitment choose excessively countercyclical inflation ex post, which leads risk-averse lenders to require a risk premium ex ante, making local currency debt too expensive and discouraging borrowing in their own currency.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces two novel features - risk-averse lenders and lack of monetary policy commitment - into the government's debt portfolio choice problem to explain the counterintuitive empirical finding that contradicts conventional wisdom about optimal hedging behavior.

author: Caroline Pflueger
title: Inflation Risk in Corporate Bonds
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We argue that corporate bond yields reflect fears of debt deflation. When debt is nominal, unexpectedly low inflation increases real liabilities and default risk. In a real business cycle model with optimal but infrequent capital structure choice, more uncertain or procyclical inflation leads to quantitatively important increases in corporate log yields in excess of default‐free log yields. A panel of credit spread indexes from six developed countries shows that credit spreads rise by 14 basis points if inflation volatility or the inflation‐stock correlation increases by one standard deviation.</jats:p>
research_question: How does inflation risk affect corporate bond yields and credit spreads?
answer: Corporate bond yields reflect fears of debt deflation - when inflation is unexpectedly low, real liabilities increase and default risk rises. More uncertain or procyclical inflation leads to quantitatively important increases in corporate credit spreads, with empirical evidence showing credit spreads rise by 14 basis points when inflation volatility or inflation-stock correlation increases by one standard deviation.
positioning_statement: The paper argues that corporate bond yields reflect fears of debt deflation, positioning this as a key mechanism that explains how inflation uncertainty affects corporate credit risk, using both theoretical modeling (real business cycle model with optimal capital structure choice) and empirical evidence from six developed countries to demonstrate this relationship.

author: Cary Frydman
title: Insensitive Investors
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We experimentally study the transmission of subjective expectations into actions. Subjects in our experiment report valuations that are far too insensitive to their expectations, relative to the prediction from a frictionless model. We propose that the insensitivity is driven by a noisy cognitive process that prevents subjects from precisely computing asset valuations. The empirical link between subjective expectations and actions becomes stronger as subjective expectations approach rational expectations. Our results highlight the importance of incorporating weak transmission into belief‐based asset pricing models. Finally, we discuss how cognitive noise can provide a microfoundation for inelastic demand in the stock market.</jats:p>
research_question: How do subjective expectations transmit into actions, specifically asset valuations, and why might this transmission be imperfect?
answer: The transmission of subjective expectations into actions is far too insensitive compared to frictionless model predictions, driven by a noisy cognitive process that prevents precise computation of asset valuations, with the link becoming stronger as subjective expectations approach rational expectations.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to belief-based asset pricing models by highlighting the importance of incorporating weak transmission mechanisms and provides a microfoundation for inelastic demand in stock markets through cognitive noise, addressing gaps in existing frictionless models.

author: Cary Frydman
title: The Impact of Salience on Investor Behavior: Evidence from a Natural Experiment
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We test whether the display of information causally affects investor behavior in a high‐stakes trading environment. Using investor‐level brokerage data from China and a natural experiment, we estimate the impact of a shock that increased the salience of a stock's purchase price but did not change the investor's information set. We employ a difference‐in‐differences approach and find that the salience shock causally increased the disposition effect by 17%. We use microdata to document substantial heterogeneity across investors in the treatment effect. A previously documented trading pattern, the “rank effect,” explains heterogeneity in the change in the disposition effect.</jats:p>
research_question: Does the display of information causally affect investor behavior in a high-stakes trading environment?
answer: The salience shock causally increased the disposition effect by 17%, demonstrating that how information is displayed does causally affect investor behavior even without changing the investor's information set.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing causal evidence of salience effects on investor behavior using a natural experiment and high-stakes real trading data, while also documenting substantial heterogeneity across investors and connecting this heterogeneity to the previously documented 'rank effect' trading pattern.

author: Cary Frydman
title: Rolling Mental Accounts

author: Christopher Jones
title: A Nonlinear Factor Analysis of S&P 500 Index Option Returns
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Growing evidence suggests that extraordinary average returns may be obtained by trading equity index options, and that at least part of this abnormal performance is attributable to volatility and jump risk premia. This paper asks whether such priced risk factors are alone sufficient to explain these average returns. To provide an answer in as general as possible a setting, I estimate a flexible class of nonlinear models using all S&P 500 Index futures options traded between 1986 and 2000. The results show that priced factors contribute to these expected returns but are insufficient to explain their magnitudes, particularly for short‐term out‐of‐the‐money puts.</jats:p>
research_question: Are priced risk factors (volatility and jump risk premia) alone sufficient to explain the extraordinary average returns obtained by trading equity index options?
answer: Priced factors contribute to expected returns but are insufficient to explain their magnitudes, particularly for short-term out-of-the-money puts.
positioning_statement: This paper builds on growing evidence of abnormal performance in equity index options trading that is partially attributable to volatility and jump risk premia, but extends the analysis by testing whether these known priced risk factors can fully account for the observed returns using a more general nonlinear modeling approach.

author: Chenzi Xu
title: Real effects of supplying safe private money
abstract: Privately issued money often bears default risk, which creates transaction frictions when used as a medium of exchange. The late 19th century US provides a unique context to evaluate the real effects of supplying a new type of money that is safe from default. We measure the local change in "monetary" transaction frictions with a market access approach derived from general equilibrium trade theory. Consistent with theories hypothesizing that lowering transaction frictions benefits the traded and inputs-intensive sectors, we find an increase in traded goods production, in the share of manufacturing output and employment, and in innovation.

author: Christopher Jones
title: Option Mispricing around Nontrading Periods
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We find that option returns are significantly lower over nontrading periods, the vast majority of which are weekends. Our evidence suggests that nontrading returns cannot be explained by risk, but rather are the result of widespread and highly persistent option mispricing driven by the incorrect treatment of stock return variance during periods of market closure. The size of the effect implies that the broad spectrum of finance research involving option prices should account for nontrading effects. Our study further suggests how alternative industry practices could improve the efficiency of option markets in a meaningful way.</jats:p>
research_question: Why are option returns significantly lower over nontrading periods (primarily weekends) and what causes this pattern?
answer: Option returns are significantly lower over nontrading periods due to widespread and highly persistent option mispricing caused by the incorrect treatment of stock return variance during periods of market closure, rather than being explained by risk factors.
positioning_statement: This paper identifies a previously unrecognized systematic mispricing in option markets that has broad implications for the spectrum of finance research involving option prices, suggesting that existing literature may need to account for nontrading effects that have been overlooked.
