author: Cary Frydman
title: Using Neural Data to Test a Theory of Investor Behavior: An Application to Realization Utility
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We conduct a study in which subjects trade stocks in an experimental market while we measure their brain activity using functional magnetic resonance imaging. All of the subjects trade in a suboptimal way. We use the neural data to test a “realization utility” explanation for their behavior. We find that activity in two areas of the brain that are important for economic decision‐making exhibit activity consistent with the predictions of realization utility. These results provide support for the realization utility model. More generally, they demonstrate that neural data can be helpful in testing models of investor behavior.</jats:p>
research_question: Can neural data be used to test the realization utility theory as an explanation for suboptimal investor trading behavior?
answer: Yes, brain activity in two key economic decision-making areas exhibits patterns consistent with realization utility predictions, providing neural evidence supporting the realization utility model for explaining suboptimal trading behavior.
positioning_statement: This paper demonstrates a novel methodological approach by using neural data (fMRI) to test existing theories of investor behavior, specifically applying neuroscience techniques to validate the realization utility model and establishing neural evidence as a useful tool for testing models of investor behavior.

author: Christopher Jones
title: Out-of-Sample Performance of Mutual Fund Predictors
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We analyze the out-of-sample performance of variables shown to forecast future mutual fund alphas. The degree of predictability, as measured by alpha spreads from quintile sorts or cross-sectional regression slopes, falls by at least half post-sample. These declines appear to be primarily the result of changes in the level of arbitrage activity in the market, with mutual fund competition appearing to play a secondary role. We find no evidence that the declines are the result of data snooping or learning by investors or fund managers. Finally, we show that corporate bond fund performance exhibits similar dependence on measures of bond market arbitrage activity.</jats:p>
research_question: How well do variables that have been shown to forecast mutual fund alphas perform when tested out-of-sample?
answer: The predictive power of mutual fund alpha forecasting variables falls by at least half when tested out-of-sample, primarily due to changes in arbitrage activity levels in the market rather than data snooping, learning effects, or mutual fund competition.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the robustness and practical applicability of existing mutual fund performance prediction literature by testing whether previously identified predictive variables maintain their forecasting power in out-of-sample periods, filling a gap in the literature regarding the stability of these predictive relationships over time.

author: Clemens Sialm
title: Currency Management by International Fixed‐Income Mutual Funds
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Investments in international fixed‐income securities are exposed to significant currency risks. We collect novel data on currency derivatives used by U.S. international fixed‐income funds. We document that while 90% of funds use currency forwards, they hedge, on average, only 18% of their currency exposure. Funds' currency forward positions differ substantially based on risk management demands related to portfolio currency exposure, return‐enhancement motives such as currency momentum and carry trade, and strategic considerations related to past performance and fund clientele. Funds that hedge their currency risk exhibit lower return variability, but do not generate inferior abnormal returns.</jats:p>
research_question: How do U.S. international fixed-income mutual funds manage currency risk through derivatives, and what factors influence their hedging decisions?
answer: While 90% of U.S. international fixed-income funds use currency forwards, they hedge only 18% of their currency exposure on average. Funds' currency hedging decisions are driven by risk management needs, return-enhancement motives (momentum and carry trades), and strategic considerations related to past performance and fund clientele. Currency hedging reduces return variability without harming abnormal returns.
positioning_statement: This paper fills a gap in the literature by providing novel empirical evidence on currency derivative usage by international fixed-income funds, an area that has received limited attention compared to equity fund studies, using newly collected data on currency forwards to document previously unknown patterns in currency risk management practices.

author: Clemens Sialm
title: Mutual Fund Tax Clienteles
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Mutual funds are held by investors in taxable and tax‐qualified retirement accounts. We investigate whether the characteristics, investment strategies, and performance of mutual funds held by these diverse tax clienteles differ. Examining both mutual fund distributions and mutual fund holdings, we find that funds held primarily by taxable investors choose investment strategies that result in lower tax burdens than funds held primarily in tax‐qualified accounts. Despite these differences, we find no evidence that any investment constraints that may arise from these tax‐efficient investment strategies result in performance differences between funds held by different tax clienteles.</jats:p>
research_question: Do the characteristics, investment strategies, and performance of mutual funds differ based on whether they are held by investors in taxable accounts versus tax-qualified retirement accounts?
answer: Funds held primarily by taxable investors choose investment strategies that result in lower tax burdens compared to funds held primarily in tax-qualified accounts, but these tax-efficient investment strategies do not result in performance differences between the two types of funds.
positioning_statement: This paper investigates the previously unexplored question of how mutual fund tax clienteles (taxable vs. tax-qualified account holders) influence fund characteristics and strategies, examining both fund distributions and holdings to provide comprehensive evidence on this relationship.

author: Clemens Sialm
title: On the Industry Concentration of Actively Managed Equity Mutual Funds
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Mutual fund managers may decide to deviate from a well‐diversified portfolio and concentrate their holdings in industries where they have informational advantages. In this paper, we study the relation between the industry concentration and the performance of actively managed U.S. mutual funds from 1984 to 1999. Our results indicate that, on average, more concentrated funds perform better after controlling for risk and style differences using various performance measures. This finding suggests that investment ability is more evident among managers who hold portfolios concentrated in a few industries.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the relation between industry concentration and the performance of actively managed U.S. mutual funds?
answer: More concentrated funds perform better on average after controlling for risk and style differences, suggesting that investment ability is more evident among managers who hold portfolios concentrated in a few industries.
positioning_statement: This paper examines how mutual fund managers may deviate from well-diversified portfolios to concentrate holdings in industries where they have informational advantages, contributing to the literature on active portfolio management and fund performance.

author: Clemens Sialm
title: Tax‐Efficient Asset Management: Evidence from Equity Mutual Funds
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We investigate the relation between tax burdens and mutual fund performance from both a theoretical and an empirical perspective. The theoretical model introduces heterogeneous tax clienteles in an environment with decreasing returns to scale and shows that the equilibrium performance of mutual funds depends on the size of the tax clienteles. Our empirical results show that the performance of U.S. equity mutual funds is related to their tax burdens. We find that tax‐efficient funds exhibit not only superior after‐tax performance, but also superior before‐tax performance due to lower trading costs, favorable style exposures, and better selectivity.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the relation between tax burdens and mutual fund performance?
answer: Tax-efficient funds exhibit superior both after-tax and before-tax performance due to lower trading costs, favorable style exposures, and better selectivity, with fund performance depending on the size of tax clienteles in equilibrium.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing both theoretical and empirical analysis of the relationship between tax efficiency and mutual fund performance, introducing a theoretical model with heterogeneous tax clienteles and decreasing returns to scale to explain how tax considerations affect fund performance.

author: Clemens Sialm
title: Home Bias and Local Contagion: Evidence from Funds of Hedge Funds
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Our paper analyzes the geographical preferences of hedge fund investors and the implication of these preferences for hedge fund performance. We find that funds of hedge funds overweigh their investments in hedge funds located in the same geographical areas and that funds with a stronger local bias exhibit superior performance. Local bias also gives rise to excess flow comovement and extreme return clustering within geographic areas. Overall, our results suggest that while funds of funds benefit from local advantages, their local bias also creates market segmentation that can destabilize the underlying hedge funds.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the geographical preferences of hedge fund investors and what are the implications of these preferences for hedge fund performance?
answer: Funds of hedge funds overweight investments in hedge funds located in the same geographical areas, and funds with stronger local bias exhibit superior performance, but this local bias also creates market segmentation that can destabilize underlying hedge funds through excess flow comovement and extreme return clustering.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by examining home bias specifically in the context of funds of hedge funds and their investment in underlying hedge funds, analyzing both the performance benefits and systemic risks created by geographical investment preferences.

author: Clemens Sialm
title: Defined Contribution Pension Plans: Sticky or Discerning Money?
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Participants in defined contribution (DC) retirement plans rarely adjust their portfolio allocations, suggesting that their investment choices and consequent money flows are sticky and not discerning. However, participants’ inertia could be offset by DC plan sponsors, who adjust the plan's investment options. We examine these countervailing influences on flows into U.S. mutual funds. We find that flows into funds from DC assets are more volatile and exhibit more performance sensitivity than non‐DC flows, primarily due to adjustments to the investment options by the plan sponsors. Thus, DC retirement money is less sticky and more discerning than non‐DC money.</jats:p>
research_question: Are investment flows from defined contribution (DC) pension plans sticky and non-discerning, or are they volatile and performance-sensitive?
answer: DC retirement money flows are less sticky and more discerning than non-DC money flows, exhibiting higher volatility and greater performance sensitivity, primarily due to plan sponsors' adjustments to investment options rather than individual participant behavior.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the conventional view that DC plan money is sticky and non-discerning by examining the countervailing influence of plan sponsors who actively adjust investment options, offsetting the well-documented inertia of individual participants.

author: Clemens Sialm
title: Pension fund flows, exchange rates, and covered interest rate parity

author: Constantine Yannelis
title: Increasing Enrollment in Income‐Driven Student Loan Repayment Plans: Evidence from the Navient Field Experiment
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We report evidence from a randomized field experiment conducted by a major student loan servicer, Navient, in which student loan borrowers received prepopulated applications for income‐driven repayment (IDR) plans. Treatment increased IDR enrollment by 34 percentage points relative to the control group. Using the random treatment assignment as an instrument for IDR enrollment, we furthermore provide local average treatment effect (LATE) estimates of the effects of IDR enrollment on new delinquencies, monthly student loan payments, and consumer spending. Our study is the first field‐experimental evaluation of a U.S. government program designed to address the soaring debt burdens of U.S. households.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the effect of providing prepopulated applications for income-driven repayment (IDR) plans on student loan borrower enrollment and subsequent financial outcomes?
answer: Providing prepopulated IDR applications increased enrollment by 34 percentage points, and the study provides causal estimates of IDR enrollment effects on delinquencies, monthly payments, and consumer spending using the randomized treatment as an instrument.
positioning_statement: This is the first field-experimental evaluation of a U.S. government program designed to address the soaring debt burdens of U.S. households, filling a gap in causal evidence on income-driven repayment plan effectiveness.

author: Clemens Sialm
title: It Pays to Set the Menu: Mutual Fund Investment Options in 401(k) Plans
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>This paper investigates whether mutual fund families acting as service providers in 401(k) plans display favoritism toward their own affiliated funds. Using a hand‐collected data set on the menu of investment options offered to plan participants, we show that fund deletions and additions are less sensitive to prior performance for affiliated than unaffiliated funds. We find no evidence that plan participants undo this affiliation bias through their investment choices. Finally, we find that the subsequent performance of poorly performing affiliated funds indicates that this favoritism is not information driven.</jats:p>
research_question: Do mutual fund families acting as service providers in 401(k) plans display favoritism toward their own affiliated funds when making fund deletion and addition decisions?
answer: Yes, mutual fund families show favoritism toward their affiliated funds - fund deletions and additions are less sensitive to prior performance for affiliated funds compared to unaffiliated funds, plan participants do not correct for this bias, and the favoritism is not justified by superior information about fund quality.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on conflicts of interest in retirement plans by providing empirical evidence of affiliation bias in 401(k) plan fund selection decisions, using hand-collected data on investment menus to demonstrate how service providers favor their own funds regardless of performance.

author: Clemens Sialm
title: How Global Is Your Mutual Fund? International Diversification from Multinationals
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We show that mutual funds worldwide provide substantial international exposure through their domestic holdings of multinationals. The international exposure of domestic funds increases, on average, by 32 percentage points when we consider international corporate diversification. We find that funds with higher indirect international exposure perform better in both the cross-section and the time series. This effect is primarily driven by the fund managers’ ability to invest in multinationals, rather than the performance of those multinationals. Our findings support the hypothesis that international diversification from multinationals reduces the transaction and information costs of investing abroad.</jats:p>
               <jats:p>Authors have furnished an Internet Appendix, which is available on the Oxford University Press Web site next to the link to the final published paper online.</jats:p>
research_question: How much international exposure do mutual funds obtain through their domestic holdings of multinational corporations, and does this indirect international diversification affect fund performance?
answer: Mutual funds worldwide provide substantial international exposure through domestic multinationals, with international exposure increasing by an average of 32 percentage points when considering corporate diversification. Funds with higher indirect international exposure perform better, primarily due to fund managers' ability to select multinationals rather than the inherent performance of those companies.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by demonstrating that international diversification through multinationals reduces transaction and information costs of investing abroad, providing a new perspective on how domestic mutual funds can achieve international exposure without directly investing in foreign markets.

author: Constantine Yannelis
title: Does Climate Change Affect Real Estate Prices? Only If You Believe In It
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>This paper studies whether house prices reflect belief differences about climate change. We show that in an equilibrium model of housing choice in which agents derive utility from ownership in a neighborhood of similar agents, prices exhibit different elasticities to climate risk. We use comprehensive transaction data to relate prices to inundation projections of individual homes and measures of beliefs about climate change. We find that houses projected to be underwater in believer neighborhoods sell at a discount compared to houses in denier neighborhoods. Our results suggest that house prices reflect heterogeneity in beliefs about long-run climate change risks.</jats:p>
research_question: Does climate change affect real estate prices, and if so, how do belief differences about climate change influence this relationship?
answer: House prices reflect heterogeneity in beliefs about climate change - homes projected to be underwater sell at a discount in neighborhoods where residents believe in climate change compared to neighborhoods where residents are climate change deniers.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by introducing belief heterogeneity as a key factor in how climate risk is priced in real estate markets, using an equilibrium model where agents prefer neighborhoods of similar believers and empirically testing this with comprehensive transaction data linked to inundation projections and climate belief measures.

author: Constantine Yannelis
title: Financial Inclusion, Human Capital, and Wealth Accumulation: Evidence from the Freedman’s Savings Bank
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>This paper studies how access to financial services among a previously unbanked group affects human capital, labor market, and wealth outcomes. We use novel data from the Freedman’s Savings Bank—created following the American Civil War to serve free Blacks—employing an instrumental variables strategy exploiting the staggered rollout of bank branches. Families with accounts are more likely to have children in school, be literate, work, and have higher occupational income, business ownership, and real estate wealth. Placebo effects are not present using planned but unbuilt branches, or for Whites, suggesting significant positive effects of financial inclusion.</jats:p>
research_question: How does access to financial services among a previously unbanked group affect human capital, labor market, and wealth outcomes?
answer: Access to financial services through the Freedman's Savings Bank led to significant positive effects: families with accounts were more likely to have children in school, be literate, work, and have higher occupational income, business ownership, and real estate wealth.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the financial inclusion literature by providing novel historical evidence from the Freedman's Savings Bank, using an instrumental variables strategy with staggered branch rollout to identify causal effects, and demonstrating robustness through placebo tests with planned but unbuilt branches and effects on Whites.

author: Constantine Yannelis
title: When Investor Incentives and Consumer Interests Diverge: Private Equity in Higher Education
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We study how private equity buyouts create value in higher education, a sector with opaque product quality and intense government subsidy. With novel data on 88 private equity deals involving 994 schools, we show that buyouts lead to higher tuition and per-student debt. Exploiting loan limit increases, we find that private equity-owned schools better capture government aid. After buyouts, we observe lower education inputs, graduation rates, loan repayment rates, and earnings among graduates. Neither school selection nor student body changes fully explain the results. The results indicate that in a subsidized industry, maximizing value may not improve consumer outcomes.</jats:p><jats:p>Authors have furnished an Internet Appendix, which is available on the Oxford University Press Web site next to the link to the final published paper online.</jats:p>
research_question: How do private equity buyouts create value in higher education, and what are the effects on student outcomes in this subsidized sector with opaque product quality?
answer: Private equity buyouts in higher education create value by increasing tuition and capturing more government aid, but this comes at the expense of student outcomes - leading to lower education inputs, graduation rates, loan repayment rates, and graduate earnings.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by examining private equity in a unique context where maximizing investor value may not align with consumer welfare, specifically in a government-subsidized industry with opaque product quality, demonstrating that value creation mechanisms differ from traditional private equity settings.

author: Constantine Yannelis
title: Loan guarantees and credit supply

author: Constantine Yannelis
title: Tuition, Debt, and Human Capital
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>This paper investigates the effects of college tuition on student debt and human capital accumulation. We exploit data from a random sample of undergraduate students in the United States and implement a research design that instruments for realized tuition with relatively large changes to the advertised tuition of students who enrolled at the same school in different cohorts. We find that $5,000 in higher tuition causally reduces the probability of graduating with a graduate degree by 3.1 percentage points and increases student debt by $1,480. Higher tuition also leads to a decline in mortgage balances and an increase in credit card delinquencies.</jats:p><jats:p>Authors have furnished an Internet Appendix, which is available on the Oxford University Press Web site next to the link to the final published paper online.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the effects of college tuition on student debt and human capital accumulation?
answer: $5,000 in higher tuition causally reduces the probability of graduating with a graduate degree by 3.1 percentage points, increases student debt by $1,480, leads to a decline in mortgage balances, and increases credit card delinquencies.
positioning_statement: This paper uses a novel instrumental variables approach that exploits relatively large changes to advertised tuition across different cohorts at the same school to establish causal effects of tuition on educational and financial outcomes, addressing endogeneity concerns in the existing literature on college costs and human capital.

author: Constantine Yannelis
title: Owner Incentives and Performance in Healthcare: Private Equity Investment in Nursing Homes
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Amid an aging population and a growing role for private equity (PE) in the care of older adults, this paper studies how PE ownership affects U.S. nursing homes using patient-level Medicare data. We show that PE ownership leads to a patient cohort with lower health risk. However, after instrumenting for the patient-nursing home match, we find that PE ownership increases mortality by 11%. Declines in measures of patient well-being, nurse staffing, and compliance with care standards help to explain the mortality effect. Overall, we conclude that PE has nuanced effects with adverse outcomes for a subset of patients.</jats:p>
research_question: How does private equity ownership affect the performance and patient outcomes of U.S. nursing homes?
answer: Private equity ownership leads to nursing homes selecting lower health risk patients, but when controlling for patient-nursing home matching, PE ownership increases patient mortality by 11% due to declines in patient well-being, nurse staffing, and compliance with care standards.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on private equity investment in healthcare by providing empirical evidence on the effects of PE ownership in nursing homes, addressing the growing concern about PE's role in elder care amid an aging population.

author: Daniel Garrett
title: Conflicts of Interest in Municipal Bond Advising and Underwriting
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>When can financial advisor conflicts of interest generate worse outcomes for clients? A regulation following from Dodd-Frank prohibits municipal advisors from simultaneously acting as bond underwriters. Using a difference-in-differences approach and 20,051 bond auctions, I test whether limited advisor privileges affect financial advice and borrower outcomes. Financing costs of bonds with potential dual advisor-underwriters fall by 11.4 basis points after the advisor is no longer allowed to underwrite. The decline follows from increases in standardization, third-party certification, and auction participation, all of which are consistent with limiting the adverse selection that arises from advisors withholding information from the market. (JEL D44, D53, G12, G14, G28, H74)</jats:p>
research_question: When can financial advisor conflicts of interest generate worse outcomes for clients, specifically examining whether municipal advisors simultaneously acting as bond underwriters affects financial advice and borrower outcomes?
answer: Conflicts of interest generate worse outcomes for clients when advisors have dual roles. Financing costs of bonds with potential dual advisor-underwriters fall by 11.4 basis points after the advisor is no longer allowed to underwrite, indicating that prohibiting dual roles improves outcomes for municipal borrowers.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on conflicts of interest in financial advising by examining a specific regulatory intervention (Dodd-Frank prohibition on dual advisor-underwriter roles) and providing empirical evidence on how limiting advisor privileges affects market outcomes through reduced adverse selection from information withholding.

author: Daniel Gottlieb
title: How Should Performance Signals Affect Contracts?
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>The informativeness principle states that a contract should depend on informative signals. This paper studies how it should do so. Signals indicating that the output distribution has shifted to the left (e.g., weak industry performance) reduce the threshold for the manager to be paid; those indicating that output is a precise measure of effort (e.g., low volatility) decrease high thresholds and increase low thresholds. Surprisingly, “good” signals of performance need not reduce the threshold. Applying our model to performance-based vesting, we show that performance measures should affect the strike price, rather than the number of vesting options, contrary to practice.</jats:p>
research_question: How should performance signals affect the design of contracts, specifically how should informative signals be incorporated into contract terms?
answer: Signals indicating leftward shifts in output distribution should reduce payment thresholds, signals indicating output precision should decrease high thresholds and increase low thresholds, and surprisingly, 'good' performance signals need not reduce thresholds. For performance-based vesting, performance measures should affect strike prices rather than the number of vesting options.
positioning_statement: This paper builds on the established informativeness principle (that contracts should depend on informative signals) but goes beyond it to specify exactly how contracts should incorporate these signals, and challenges current practice in performance-based vesting by showing that performance measures should affect strike prices rather than vesting quantities.

author: David Musto
title: How Investors Interpret Past Fund Returns
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The literature documents a convex relation between past returns and fund flows of mutual funds. We show this to be consistent with fund incentives, because funds discard exactly those strategies which underperform. Past returns tell less about the future performance of funds which discard, so flows are less sensitive to them when they are poor. Our model predicts that strategy changes only occur after bad performance, and that bad performers who change strategy have dollar flow and future performance that are less sensitive to current performance than those that do not. Empirical tests support both predictions.</jats:p>
research_question: Why do mutual funds exhibit a convex relation between past returns and fund flows, where flows are less sensitive to poor performance than to good performance?
answer: The convex flow-performance relation exists because funds strategically discard underperforming strategies after bad performance, making past returns less informative about future performance for poorly performing funds that change strategies, thus reducing investor flow sensitivity to poor returns.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a new theoretical explanation for the well-documented convex flow-performance relation in mutual funds by focusing on strategic behavior of fund managers who discard poor strategies, offering a fund incentive-based perspective that complements existing literature on this empirical phenomenon.

author: David Musto
title: Leaning for the Tape: Evidence of Gaming Behavior in Equity Mutual Funds
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We present evidence that fund managers inflate quarter‐end portfolio prices with last‐minute purchases of stocks already held. The magnitude of price inflation ranges from 0.5 percent per year for large‐cap funds to well over 2 percent for small‐cap funds. We find that the cross section of inflation matches the cross section of incentives from the flow/performance relation, that a surge of trading in the quarter's last minutes coincides with a surge in equity prices, and that the inflation is greatest for the stocks held by funds with the most incentive to inflate, controlling for the stocks' size and performance.</jats:p>
research_question: Do equity mutual fund managers engage in gaming behavior by inflating quarter-end portfolio prices through last-minute purchases of stocks they already hold?
answer: Yes, fund managers do inflate quarter-end portfolio prices with last-minute purchases of stocks already held, with price inflation ranging from 0.5 percent per year for large-cap funds to over 2 percent for small-cap funds, and this behavior is driven by incentives from the flow/performance relationship.
positioning_statement: This paper provides new empirical evidence of a specific type of gaming behavior in mutual funds - quarter-end price inflation through strategic trading - and demonstrates that this behavior is systematically related to fund managers' incentives from the documented flow/performance relationship in the mutual fund literature.

author: David Musto
title: Vote Trading and Information Aggregation
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>The standard analysis of corporate governance assumes that shareholders vote in ratios that firms choose, such as one share‐one vote. However, if the cost of unbundling and trading votes is sufficiently low, then shareholders choose the ratios. We document an active market for votes within the U.S. equity loan market, where the average vote sells for zero. We hypothesize that asymmetric information motivates the vote trade and find support in the cross section. More trading occurs for higher‐spread and worse‐performing firms, especially when voting is close. Vote trading corresponds to support for shareholder proposals and opposition to management proposals.</jats:p>
research_question: How does vote trading in equity markets affect information aggregation and corporate governance outcomes when shareholders can choose voting ratios rather than being constrained by firm-determined ratios like one share-one vote?
answer: An active market for votes exists within the U.S. equity loan market where votes trade at near-zero prices on average, with asymmetric information driving vote trading. More trading occurs for higher-spread and worse-performing firms, especially during close votes, and this trading corresponds to increased support for shareholder proposals and opposition to management proposals.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the standard corporate governance analysis that assumes shareholders vote in firm-chosen ratios (such as one share-one vote) by demonstrating that when unbundling and trading costs are sufficiently low, shareholders actually choose the voting ratios themselves through an active vote trading market.

author: David Musto
title: What Do Consumers’ Fund Flows Maximize? Evidence from Their Brokers’ Incentives
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We ask whether mutual funds’ flows reflect the incentives of the brokers intermediating them. The incentives we address are those revealed in statutory filings: the brokers’ shares of sales loads and other revenue, and their affiliation with the fund family. We find significant effects of these payments to brokers on funds’ inflows, particularly when the brokers are not affiliated. Tracking these investments forward, we find load sharing, but not revenue sharing, to predict poor performance, consistent with the different incentives these payments impart. We identify one benefit of captive brokerage, which is the recapture of redemptions elsewhere in the family.</jats:p>
research_question: Do mutual funds' flows reflect the incentives of the brokers intermediating them, specifically their shares of sales loads and other revenue, and their affiliation with the fund family?
answer: Yes, broker incentives significantly affect fund inflows, particularly for non-affiliated brokers. Load sharing (but not revenue sharing) predicts poor performance, and captive brokerage provides the benefit of recapturing redemptions within the fund family.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by examining the previously understudied role of broker incentives in driving mutual fund flows, using statutory filings to reveal how different types of broker compensation (load sharing vs. revenue sharing) and broker affiliation affect fund performance and flow patterns.

author: David Sraer
title: The Banking View of Bond Risk Premia
abstract:
<jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>
Banks' balance sheet exposure to fluctuations in interest rates strongly forecasts excess Treasury bond returns. This result is consistent with optimal risk management, a banking counterpart to the household Euler equation. In equilibrium, the bond risk premium compensates banks for bearing fluctuations in interest rates. When banks' exposure to interest rate risk increases, the price of this risk simultaneously rises. We present a collection of empirical observations that support this view, but also discuss several challenges to this interpretation.</jats:p>
research_question: How do banks' balance sheet exposures to interest rate fluctuations relate to Treasury bond risk premia?
answer: Banks' balance sheet exposure to interest rate fluctuations strongly forecasts excess Treasury bond returns, with bond risk premia compensating banks for bearing interest rate risk - when banks' exposure increases, the price of this risk simultaneously rises.
positioning_statement: This paper presents a 'banking view' that serves as a banking counterpart to the household Euler equation from traditional asset pricing theory, positioning banks' optimal risk management as a key driver of bond risk premia in equilibrium.

author: David Sraer
title: Speculative Betas
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>The risk and return trade‐off, the cornerstone of modern asset pricing theory, is often of the wrong sign. Our explanation is that high‐beta assets are prone to speculative overpricing. When investors disagree about the stock market's prospects, high‐beta assets are more sensitive to this aggregate disagreement, experience greater divergence of opinion about their payoffs, and are overpriced due to short‐sales constraints. When aggregate disagreement is low, the Security Market Line is upward‐sloping due to risk‐sharing. When it is high, expected returns can actually decrease with beta. We confirm our theory using a measure of disagreement about stock market earnings.</jats:p>
research_question: Why is the risk and return trade-off, which is fundamental to modern asset pricing theory, often of the wrong sign?
answer: High-beta assets are prone to speculative overpricing because they are more sensitive to aggregate disagreement among investors, leading to greater divergence of opinion and overpricing due to short-sales constraints. When aggregate disagreement is high, expected returns can actually decrease with beta, contrary to traditional theory.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a fundamental anomaly in modern asset pricing theory - the cornerstone risk-return trade-off being of the wrong sign - by providing a novel explanation based on speculative overpricing of high-beta assets driven by investor disagreement and short-sales constraints.

author: David Sraer
title: Individual Investors and Volatility
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We show that retail trading activity has a positive effect on the volatility of stock returns, which suggests that retail investors behave as noise traders. To identify this effect, we use a reform of the French stock market that raises the relative cost of speculative trading for retail investors. The daily return volatility of the stocks affected by the reform falls by 20 basis points (a quarter of the sample standard deviation of the return volatility) relative to other stocks. For affected stocks, we also find a significant decrease in the magnitude of return reversals and the price impact of trades.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the effect of retail trading activity on stock return volatility?
answer: Retail trading activity has a positive effect on stock return volatility, with daily return volatility falling by 20 basis points (a quarter of the sample standard deviation) when the relative cost of speculative trading for retail investors increases, suggesting that retail investors behave as noise traders.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on individual investors and market volatility by using a natural experiment (French stock market reform) to identify the causal effect of retail trading on volatility, providing empirical evidence that retail investors act as noise traders who increase market volatility.

author: David Sraer
title: Can Unemployment Insurance Spur Entrepreneurial Activity? Evidence from France
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We evaluate the effect of downside insurance on self‐employment. We exploit a large‐scale reform of French unemployment benefits that insured unemployed workers starting businesses. The reform significantly increased firm creation without decreasing the quality of new entrants. Firms started postreform were initially smaller, but their employment growth, productivity, and survival rates are similar to those prereform. New entrepreneurs' characteristics and expectations are also similar. Finally, jobs created by new entrants crowd out employment in incumbent firms almost one‐for‐one, but have a higher productivity than incumbents. These results highlight the benefits of encouraging experimentation by lowering barriers to entry.</jats:p>
research_question: Can unemployment insurance spur entrepreneurial activity, and what are the effects on firm quality and market dynamics?
answer: Unemployment insurance significantly increases firm creation without decreasing quality of new entrants. New firms have similar employment growth, productivity, and survival rates to pre-reform firms, though they start smaller. Job creation by new entrants crowds out incumbent employment nearly one-for-one but with higher productivity.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on barriers to entrepreneurship by providing large-scale empirical evidence on how downside insurance affects self-employment decisions, highlighting the benefits of encouraging business experimentation through policy interventions that lower entry barriers.

author: David Sraer
title: Housing Collateral and Entrepreneurship
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We show that collateral constraints restrict firm entry and postentry growth, using French administrative data and cross‐sectional variation in local house‐price appreciation as shocks to collateral values. We control for local demand shocks by comparing treated homeowners to controls in the same region that do not experience collateral shocks: renters and homeowners with an outstanding mortgage, who (in France) cannot take out a second mortgage. In both comparisons, an increase in collateral value leads to a higher probability of becoming an entrepreneur. Conditional on entry, treated entrepreneurs use more debt, start larger firms, and remain larger in the long run.</jats:p>
research_question: How do collateral constraints affect firm entry and post-entry growth, specifically examining whether increases in housing collateral values enable entrepreneurship?
answer: Collateral constraints significantly restrict firm entry and growth - when collateral values increase due to house price appreciation, individuals are more likely to become entrepreneurs, use more debt financing, start larger firms, and maintain larger firm size over time.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on financial constraints and entrepreneurship by using a novel identification strategy that exploits cross-sectional variation in local house price appreciation as exogenous shocks to collateral values, while controlling for local demand effects by comparing homeowners to renters and mortgaged homeowners who cannot access additional collateral.

author: David Sraer
title: Quantifying Reduced‐Form Evidence on Collateral Constraints
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>This paper quantifies the aggregate effects of financing constraints. We start from a standard dynamic investment model with collateral constraints. In contrast to the existing quantitative literature, our estimation does not target the mean leverage ratio to identify the scope of financing frictions. Instead, we use a reduced‐form coefficient from the recent corporate finance literature that connects exogenous debt capacity shocks to corporate investment. Relative to a frictionless benchmark, collateral constraints induce losses of 7.1% for output and 1.4% for total factor productivity (TFP) (misallocation). We show these estimated losses tend to be more robust to misspecification than estimates obtained by targeting leverage.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the aggregate effects of financing constraints on economic output and productivity?
answer: Collateral constraints induce losses of 7.1% for output and 1.4% for total factor productivity (TFP) due to misallocation, relative to a frictionless benchmark.
positioning_statement: This paper differs from existing quantitative literature by using a reduced-form coefficient from corporate finance literature that connects exogenous debt capacity shocks to corporate investment for estimation, rather than targeting the mean leverage ratio to identify the scope of financing frictions. The authors show their estimated losses are more robust to misspecification than estimates obtained by targeting leverage.

author: David Sraer
title: Financial Advisors and Investors’ Bias
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
                  <jats:p>We study an intervention by a brokerage firm providing advisory services to high-net-worth investors. In 2018, the firm changed the information displayed on its internal platform, so that financial advisors could no longer observe which clients’ holdings were in paper gain or loss. Using data on portfolio stock transactions between 2016 and 2021, we show that, while all investors exhibit a significant disposition effect before 2018, that is, a greater propensity to realize gains than losses, highly advised investors see their bias significantly reduced afterward. Our paper shows financial firms can successfully reduce clients’ biases by appropriately manipulating advisors’ information.</jats:p>
research_question: Can financial firms reduce investors' behavioral biases by manipulating the information available to their financial advisors?
answer: Yes, financial firms can successfully reduce clients' biases by appropriately manipulating advisors' information. Specifically, when advisors could no longer see which client holdings were in paper gain or loss, highly advised investors experienced a significant reduction in the disposition effect (the tendency to sell winning investments while holding losing ones).
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on behavioral finance and investor biases by demonstrating that financial intermediaries can serve as a mechanism to reduce client biases through information design, rather than focusing solely on direct investor education or individual bias correction methods.

author: David Thesmar
title: Banking Deregulation and Industry Structure: Evidence from the French Banking Reforms of 1985
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We investigate how the deregulation of the French banking industry in the 1980s affected the real behavior of firms and the structure and dynamics of product markets. Following deregulation, banks are less willing to bail out poorly performing firms and firms in the more bank‐dependent sectors are more likely to undertake restructuring activities. At the industry level, we observe an increase in asset and job reallocation, an improvement in allocative efficiency across firms, and a decline in concentration. Overall, these findings support the view that a more efficient banking sector helps foster a Schumpeterian process of “creative destruction.”</jats:p>
research_question: How did the deregulation of the French banking industry in the 1980s affect the real behavior of firms and the structure and dynamics of product markets?
answer: Banking deregulation led to banks being less willing to bail out poorly performing firms, increased restructuring activities in bank-dependent sectors, higher asset and job reallocation at the industry level, improved allocative efficiency across firms, and reduced market concentration.
positioning_statement: This paper supports the view that a more efficient banking sector helps foster a Schumpeterian process of 'creative destruction,' contributing to the literature on how financial sector reforms impact real economic outcomes and market dynamics.

author: David Thesmar
title: Noise in Expectations: Evidence from Analyst Forecasts
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Analyst forecasts outperform econometric forecasts in the short run but underperform in the long run. We decompose these differences in forecasting accuracy into analysts’ information advantage, forecast bias, and forecast noise. We find that noise and bias strongly increase with forecast horizon, while analysts’ information advantage decays rapidly. A noise increase with horizon generates a mechanical reversal in the sign of the error-revision (Coibion-Gorodnichenko) regression coefficient at longer horizons, independently of over-/underreaction. A parsimonious model with bounded rationality and a noisy cognitive default matches the term structures of noise and bias jointly.</jats:p>
research_question: Why do analyst forecasts outperform econometric forecasts in the short run but underperform in the long run, and what drives these differences in forecasting accuracy across different time horizons?
answer: The performance reversal is driven by three key factors that vary with forecast horizon: analysts' information advantage decays rapidly over time, while forecast noise and bias strongly increase with longer horizons. The increase in noise creates a mechanical reversal in forecast error patterns at longer horizons, independent of behavioral over- or underreaction.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on forecast accuracy by providing a novel decomposition framework that separates analysts' information advantage, forecast bias, and forecast noise, and by showing that noise increases with horizon can mechanically generate reversals in error-revision regression coefficients (referencing Coibion-Gorodnichenko methodology) independent of traditional behavioral explanations of over-/underreaction.

author: David Thesmar
title: The WACC Fallacy: The Real Effects of Using a Unique Discount Rate
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>In this paper, we test whether firms properly adjust for risk in their capital budgeting decisions. If managers use a single discount rate within firms, we expect that conglomerates underinvest (overinvest) in relatively safe (risky) divisions. We measure division relative risk as the difference between the division's asset beta and a firm‐wide beta. We establish a robust and significant positive relationship between division‐level investment and division relative risk. Next, we measure the value loss due to this behavior in the context of acquisitions. When the bidder's beta is lower than that of the target, announcement returns are significantly lower.</jats:p>
research_question: Do firms properly adjust for risk in their capital budgeting decisions, and what are the real effects of using a single discount rate (WACC) across divisions with different risk profiles?
answer: Firms do not properly adjust for risk when using a single discount rate - conglomerates systematically underinvest in relatively safe divisions and overinvest in relatively risky divisions, with this misallocation creating measurable value losses as evidenced by lower announcement returns in acquisitions where bidder beta is lower than target beta.
positioning_statement: This paper provides empirical evidence for what it terms 'the WACC fallacy' - testing the real-world consequences of a theoretical prediction that using a single firm-wide discount rate leads to systematic capital misallocation across divisions with different risk profiles.

author: David Thesmar
title: Wholesale Funding Dry‐Ups
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We empirically explore the fragility of wholesale funding of banks, using transaction‐level data on short‐term, unsecured certificates of deposit in the European market. We do not observe a market‐wide freeze during the 2008 to 2014 period. Yet, many banks suddenly experience funding dry‐ups. Dry‐ups predict, but do not cause, future deterioration in bank performance. Furthermore, during periods of market stress, banks with high future performance tend to increase reliance on wholesale funding. We therefore fail to find evidence consistent with adverse selection models of funding market freezes. Our evidence is in line with theories highlighting heterogeneity between informed and uninformed lenders.</jats:p>
research_question: What causes wholesale funding dry-ups for banks and do they represent market-wide freezes driven by adverse selection or bank-specific events driven by heterogeneous lender information?
answer: Wholesale funding dry-ups are bank-specific events rather than market-wide freezes, they predict but do not cause future bank performance deterioration, and during market stress, high-performing banks actually increase wholesale funding reliance, contradicting adverse selection models.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges adverse selection models of funding market freezes by providing empirical evidence that supports theories emphasizing heterogeneity between informed and uninformed lenders, using unique transaction-level data to show that funding dry-ups are bank-specific rather than systemic phenomena.

author: David Thesmar
title: Sticky Expectations and the Profitability Anomaly
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We propose a theory of the “profitability” anomaly. In our model, investors forecast future profits using a signal and sticky belief dynamics. In this model, past profits forecast future returns (the profitability anomaly). Using analyst forecast data, we measure expectation stickiness at the firm level and find strong support for three additional model predictions: (1) analysts are on average too pessimistic regarding the future profits of high‐profit firms, (2) the profitability anomaly is stronger for stocks that are followed by stickier analysts, and (3) the profitability anomaly is stronger for stocks with more persistent profits.</jats:p>
research_question: What explains the profitability anomaly, where past profits forecast future stock returns?
answer: The profitability anomaly is explained by investors' sticky belief dynamics when forecasting future profits - investors are slow to update their expectations about firm profitability, leading to predictable patterns in stock returns based on past profits.
positioning_statement: This paper proposes a new behavioral theory based on sticky expectations to explain the well-documented profitability anomaly in finance, contributing to the literature on market anomalies and behavioral finance by providing both theoretical framework and empirical evidence using analyst forecast data.

author: David Thesmar
title: CAPM-Based Company (Mis)valuations
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>There is a discrepancy between CAPM-implied and realized returns. Using the CAPM in capital budgeting—as recommended in textbooks—should thus have real effects. For instance, low beta projects should be valued more by CAPM users than by the market. We test this hypothesis using M&A data and show that bids for low-beta private targets entail lower bidder returns. We provide further support by testing several ancillary predictions. Our analyses suggest that using the CAPM when valuing targets leads to valuation errors (relative to the market’s view) corresponding on average to 12% to 33% of the deal values.</jats:p>
research_question: Does the use of CAPM in capital budgeting lead to systematic misvaluations, particularly causing low-beta projects to be overvalued relative to market pricing?
answer: Yes, CAPM usage leads to systematic misvaluations - bidders using CAPM overpay for low-beta targets, resulting in lower bidder returns and valuation errors averaging 12% to 33% of deal values relative to market pricing.
positioning_statement: This paper bridges the gap between the well-documented theoretical discrepancy between CAPM-implied and realized returns and its real-world consequences, providing empirical evidence that textbook-recommended CAPM usage in capital budgeting creates measurable valuation errors in actual M&A transactions.

author: Dimitris Papanikolaou
title: Growth Opportunities, Technology Shocks, and Asset Prices
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We explore the impact of investment‐specific technology (IST) shocks on the cross section of stock returns. Using a structural model, we show that IST shocks have a differential effect on the value of assets in place and the value of growth opportunities. This differential sensitivity to IST shocks has two main implications. First, firm risk premia depend on the contribution of growth opportunities to firm value. Second, firms with similar levels of growth opportunities comove with each other, giving rise to the value factor in stock returns and the failure of the conditional CAPM. Our empirical tests confirm the model's predictions.</jats:p>
research_question: How do investment-specific technology (IST) shocks impact the cross section of stock returns?
answer: IST shocks have differential effects on assets in place versus growth opportunities, which causes firm risk premia to depend on the contribution of growth opportunities to firm value and creates comovement among firms with similar growth opportunities, explaining the value factor in stock returns and the failure of the conditional CAPM.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing a structural model that explains the value factor in stock returns and the failure of the conditional CAPM through the lens of investment-specific technology shocks, offering a new theoretical framework for understanding cross-sectional variation in stock returns based on the differential impact of technology shocks on assets in place versus growth opportunities.

author: Dimitris Papanikolaou
title: Organization Capital and the Cross‐Section of Expected Returns
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Organization capital is a production factor that is embodied in the firm's key talent and has an efficiency that is firm specific. Hence, both shareholders and key talent have a claim to its cash flows. We develop a model in which the outside option of the key talent determines the share of firm cash flows that accrue to shareholders. This outside option varies systematically and renders firms with high organization capital riskier from shareholders' perspective. We find that firms with more organization capital have average returns that are 4.6% higher than firms with less organization capital.</jats:p>
research_question: How does organization capital affect the cross-section of expected stock returns?
answer: Firms with more organization capital have average returns that are 4.6% higher than firms with less organization capital, because the outside options of key talent make these firms riskier from shareholders' perspective.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces organization capital as a production factor embodied in key talent with firm-specific efficiency, developing a new model where the outside options of key talent determine shareholders' cash flow claims, thereby providing a novel explanation for cross-sectional variation in expected returns.

author: Dimitris Papanikolaou
title: Investment, Idiosyncratic Risk, and Ownership
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>High‐powered incentives may induce higher managerial effort, but they also expose managers to idiosyncratic risk. If managers are risk averse, they might underinvest when firm‐specific uncertainty increases, leading to suboptimal investment decisions from the perspective of well‐diversified shareholders. We empirically document that, when idiosyncratic risk rises, firm investment falls, and more so when managers own a larger fraction of the firm. This negative effect of managerial risk aversion on investment is mitigated if executives are compensated with options rather than with shares or if institutional investors form a large part of the shareholder base.</jats:p>
research_question: How does idiosyncratic risk affect firm investment decisions, and how is this relationship moderated by managerial ownership and compensation structures?
answer: When idiosyncratic risk increases, firm investment decreases, and this effect is stronger when managers own larger fractions of the firm due to managerial risk aversion. However, this negative effect is mitigated when executives are compensated with options rather than shares or when institutional investors comprise a large portion of the shareholder base.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the tension between high-powered incentives that may increase managerial effort but also expose risk-averse managers to idiosyncratic risk, leading to suboptimal investment decisions from the perspective of well-diversified shareholders - a relationship that has not been fully explored in existing literature on managerial incentives and investment behavior.

author: Dimitris Papanikolaou
title: Missing Novelty in Drug Development
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We provide evidence that risk aversion leads pharmaceutical firms to underinvest in radical innovation. We introduce a new measure of drug novelty based on chemical similarity and show that firms face a risk-reward trade-off: novel drug candidates are less likely to obtain FDA approval but are based on more valuable patents. Consistent with a simple model of costly external finance, we show that a positive shock to firms’ net worth leads firms to develop more novel drugs. This suggests that even large firms may behave as though they are risk averse, reducing their willingness to investment in potentially valuable radical innovation.</jats:p>
research_question: Do pharmaceutical firms underinvest in radical innovation due to risk aversion, and how does firm financial capacity affect their willingness to pursue novel drug development?
answer: Risk aversion does lead pharmaceutical firms to underinvest in radical innovation. Novel drug candidates face lower FDA approval rates but are based on more valuable patents, creating a risk-reward trade-off. Positive shocks to firms' net worth increase their development of novel drugs, indicating that even large firms behave in a risk-averse manner that reduces investment in potentially valuable radical innovation.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing empirical evidence for the theoretical prediction that financial constraints and risk aversion affect innovation decisions, specifically demonstrating this relationship in pharmaceutical R&D through a novel measure of drug novelty based on chemical similarity and connecting it to models of costly external finance.

author: Dimitry Muravyev
title: Options Trading Costs Are Lower than You Think
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Conventional estimates of the costs of taking liquidity in options markets are large. Nonetheless, options trading volume is high. We resolve this puzzle by showing that options price changes are predictable at high frequency, and many traders time executions by buying (selling) when the option fair value is close to the ask (bid). Effective spreads of traders who time executions are less than 40% of the size of conventional measures, and the overall average effective spread is one-quarter smaller than conventional estimates. Price impact measures are also affected. These findings alter conclusions about the after-cost profitability of options trading strategies.</jats:p>
research_question: How can the puzzle of high options trading volume despite conventionally large estimated trading costs be resolved?
answer: Options price changes are predictable at high frequency, allowing many traders to time their executions strategically (buying when fair value is near the ask, selling when near the bid), which results in effective spreads that are less than 40% of conventional measures for timing traders and overall average effective spreads that are one-quarter smaller than conventional estimates.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges conventional estimates of options trading costs by demonstrating that existing measures overstate actual trading costs, thereby resolving the apparent contradiction between high trading costs and high trading volume in options markets.

author: Dimitry Muravyev
title: Order Flow and Expected Option Returns
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>I show that the inventory risk faced by market‐makers has a first‐order effect on option prices. I introduce a simple approach that decomposes the price impact of trades into inventory risk and asymmetric information components. While both components are large for option trades, the inventory risk component is larger. Using the full panel of daily option returns, I find that option order imbalances attributable to inventory risk have five times larger impact on option prices than previously thought. Finally, I find that past order imbalances have greater predictive power than any other commonly used predictor of option returns.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the impact of inventory risk faced by market-makers on option prices and returns, and how does this compare to the effects of asymmetric information?
answer: Inventory risk has a first-order effect on option prices that is larger than asymmetric information effects. Option order imbalances attributable to inventory risk have five times larger impact on option prices than previously estimated, and past order imbalances are the strongest predictor of option returns compared to other commonly used predictors.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges existing literature by demonstrating that inventory risk effects on option prices are much larger than previously recognized, introducing a novel decomposition method to separate inventory risk from asymmetric information components, and showing that order flow effects are significantly underestimated in current research.

author: Dimitry Muravyev
title: Informed Trading Intensity
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We train a machine learning method on a class of informed trades to develop a new measure of informed trading, informed trading intensity (ITI). ITI increases before earnings, mergers and acquisitions, and news announcements, and has implications for return reversal and asset pricing. ITI is effective because it captures nonlinearities and interactions between informed trading, volume, and volatility. This data‐driven approach can shed light on the economics of informed trading, including impatient informed trading, commonality in informed trading, and models of informed trading. Overall, learning from informed trading data can generate an effective informed trading measure.</jats:p>
research_question: How can machine learning methods be used to develop a more effective measure of informed trading by capturing nonlinearities and interactions between informed trading, volume, and volatility?
answer: The paper develops Informed Trading Intensity (ITI), a machine learning-based measure that effectively captures informed trading by learning from nonlinearities and interactions between trading variables. ITI successfully predicts informed trading around earnings, M&A, and news announcements, and has significant implications for return reversal and asset pricing.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as introducing a novel data-driven approach to measuring informed trading that improves upon existing methods by using machine learning to capture complex nonlinear relationships and interactions that traditional measures may miss, thereby advancing the understanding of informed trading economics including impatient informed trading, commonality in informed trading, and informed trading models.

author: Dimitry Muravyev
title: Anomalies and Their Short‐Sale Costs
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Short‐sale costs eliminate the abnormal returns on asset pricing anomaly portfolios. While many anomalies persist out‐of‐sample before accounting for short‐sale costs, they cannot be exploited with long‐short strategies due to stock borrow fees. Using a comprehensive sample of 162 anomalies, the average long‐short portfolio return is a significant 0.14% per month before short‐sale costs, and the returns are due to the short leg. However, the average is −0.01% once returns are adjusted for borrow fees. Moreover, anomalies are not profitable even before fees if the high‐fee observations, representing 12% of stock dates, are excluded from the analysis.</jats:p>
research_question: Do asset pricing anomalies remain profitable after accounting for short-sale costs and stock borrow fees?
answer: Short-sale costs eliminate the abnormal returns on asset pricing anomaly portfolios. While anomalies show significant returns of 0.14% per month before costs, they become unprofitable (-0.01% per month) after accounting for borrow fees, and are not profitable even before fees if high-fee observations are excluded.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a gap in the anomalies literature by comprehensively examining the impact of short-sale costs on anomaly profitability across 162 different anomalies, providing evidence that many seemingly persistent out-of-sample anomalies cannot actually be exploited due to implementation costs.

author: Dimitry Muravyev
title: Is There a Risk Premium in the Stock Lending Market? Evidence from Equity Options
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Recent research argues that uncertainty about future stock borrowing fees hinders short‐selling, and this risk explains the performance of short strategies. One possible mechanism is that borrowing fee risk carries a risk premium. Since the present value of the uncertain borrowing fee is reflected in options prices, the difference between option‐implied and realized fees estimates this premium. We find that the risk premium is small. Moreover, if the risk premium is substantial, it should be reflected in the returns to short‐selling stock after adjusting for stock borrowing fees. However, borrowing fee risk does not predict fee‐adjusted returns.</jats:p>
research_question: Is there a risk premium in the stock lending market, and does borrowing fee risk explain the performance of short-selling strategies?
answer: The risk premium in the stock lending market is small, and borrowing fee risk does not predict fee-adjusted returns from short-selling strategies.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges recent research that argues uncertainty about future stock borrowing fees hinders short-selling and that this risk explains short strategy performance, by directly testing whether borrowing fee risk carries a meaningful risk premium.

author: Dirk Jenter
title: Market Timing and Managerial Portfolio Decisions
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>This paper provides evidence that top managers have contrarian views on firm value. Managers' perceptions of fundamental value diverge systematically from market valuations, and perceived mispricing seems an important determinant of managers' decision making. Insider trading patterns shows that low valuation firms are regarded as undervalued by their own managers relative to high valuation firms. This finding is robust to controlling for noninformation motivated trading. Further evidence links managers' private portfolio decisions to changes in corporate capital structures, suggesting that managers try to actively time the market both in their private trades and in firm‐level decisions.</jats:p>
research_question: Do top managers have contrarian views on firm value, and do their perceptions of mispricing influence both their personal trading decisions and corporate decision making?
answer: Yes, managers have systematic contrarian views where they perceive low valuation firms as undervalued relative to high valuation firms, and this perceived mispricing drives both their insider trading patterns and corporate capital structure decisions as they attempt to time the market.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing evidence linking managers' private portfolio decisions to corporate decision making, demonstrating that market timing behavior extends beyond just corporate finance decisions to include coordinated personal trading strategies based on perceived mispricing.

author: Dirk Jenter
title: CEO Turnover and Relative Performance Evaluation
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>This paper shows that CEOs are fired after bad firm performance caused by factors beyond their control. Standard economic theory predicts that corporate boards filter out exogenous industry and market shocks from firm performance before deciding on CEO retention. Using a hand‐collected sample of 3,365 CEO turnovers from 1993 to 2009, we document that CEOs are significantly more likely to be dismissed from their jobs after bad industry and, to a lesser extent, after bad market performance. A decline in industry performance from the 90<jats:sup>th</jats:sup>to the 10<jats:sup>th</jats:sup>percentile doubles the probability of a forced CEO turnover.</jats:p>
research_question: Do corporate boards filter out exogenous industry and market shocks from firm performance when making CEO retention decisions, as predicted by standard economic theory?
answer: CEOs are fired after bad firm performance caused by factors beyond their control - they are significantly more likely to be dismissed after bad industry performance and, to a lesser extent, after bad market performance, with a decline in industry performance from the 90th to 10th percentile doubling the probability of forced CEO turnover.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges standard economic theory which predicts that corporate boards should filter out exogenous industry and market shocks from firm performance before deciding on CEO retention, by providing empirical evidence that boards do not actually follow this theoretical prediction.

author: Dirk Jenter
title: CEO Preferences and Acquisitions
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>This paper explores the impact of target CEOs’ retirement preferences on takeovers. Using retirement age as a proxy for CEOs’ private merger costs, we find strong evidence that target CEOs’ preferences affect merger activity. The likelihood of receiving a successful takeover bid is sharply higher when target CEOs are close to age 65. Takeover premiums and target announcement returns are similar for retirement‐age and younger CEOs, implying that retirement‐age CEOs increase firm sales without sacrificing premiums. Better corporate governance is associated with more acquisitions of firms led by young CEOs, and with a smaller increase in deals at retirement age.</jats:p>
research_question: How do target CEOs' retirement preferences impact takeover activity and merger outcomes?
answer: Target CEOs close to retirement age (65) are significantly more likely to receive successful takeover bids, with similar premiums to younger CEOs, suggesting retirement-age CEOs facilitate firm sales without sacrificing shareholder value. Better corporate governance reduces this retirement age effect.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by using retirement age as a novel proxy for CEOs' private merger costs to examine how personal preferences affect M&A activity, extending beyond traditional financial and strategic factors typically studied in takeover research.

author: Dirk Jenter
title: Performance-Induced CEO Turnover
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>This paper revisits the relationship between firm performance and CEO turnover. Instead of classifying turnovers into forced and voluntary, we introduce performance-induced turnover, defined as turnover that would not have occurred had performance been “good.” We document a close turnover-performance link and estimate that 38%–55% of turnovers are performance induced. This is significantly more than the number of forced turnovers, though the two types of turnovers are highly correlated. Compared to the predictions of Bayesian learning models, learning about CEO ability appears to be slow, and boards act as if CEO ability (or match quality) was subject to frequent shocks.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the relationship between firm performance and CEO turnover, and how much of CEO turnover can be attributed to poor performance?
answer: 38%-55% of CEO turnovers are performance-induced (would not have occurred if performance had been good), which is significantly more than the number of forced turnovers, indicating a close turnover-performance link with learning about CEO ability appearing to be slow compared to Bayesian learning model predictions.
positioning_statement: This paper revisits the existing literature on firm performance and CEO turnover by introducing a new classification of 'performance-induced turnover' instead of the traditional forced versus voluntary turnover categorization, and compares findings against predictions from Bayesian learning models to show that boards behave as if CEO ability is subject to frequent shocks.
