author: Dirk Jenter
title: Security Issue Timing: What Do Managers Know, and When Do They Know It?
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We study put option sales on company stock by large firms. An often‐cited motivation for these transactions is market timing, and managers' decision to issue puts should be sensitive to whether the stock is undervalued. We provide new evidence that large firms successfully time security sales. In the 100 days following put option issues, there is roughly a 5% abnormal stock return, with much of the abnormal return following the first earnings release date after the sale. Direct evidence on put option exercises reinforces these findings: exercise frequencies and payoffs to put holders are abnormally low.</jats:p>
research_question: Do managers of large firms have superior information about their stock's value when timing security issues, specifically put option sales, and when do they acquire this information advantage?
answer: Large firms successfully time put option sales based on superior information about their stock being undervalued, evidenced by 5% abnormal positive stock returns in the 100 days following put issues, with much of the abnormal return occurring after the first earnings release, and abnormally low exercise frequencies and payoffs for put holders.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes new evidence to the market timing literature by focusing specifically on put option sales by large firms as a test of managerial information advantages, providing direct evidence through both stock return analysis and put option exercise data to support successful security issue timing.

author: Dong Lou
title: Comomentum: Inferring Arbitrage Activity from Return Correlations
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We propose a novel measure of arbitrage activity to examine whether arbitrageurs can have a destabilizing effect on the stock market. We focus on stock price momentum, a classic example of a positive-feedback strategy that our theory predicts can be destabilizing. Our measure, dubbed comomentum, is the high-frequency abnormal return correlation among stocks on which a typical momentum strategy would speculate. When comomentum is low, momentum strategies are stabilizing, reflecting an underreaction phenomenon that arbitrageurs correct. When comomentum is high, the returns on momentum stocks strongly revert, reflecting prior overreaction from crowded momentum trading that pushes prices away from fundamentals.</jats:p>
               <jats:p>Authors have furnished an Internet Appendix, which is available on the Oxford University Press Web site next to the link to the final published paper online.</jats:p>
research_question: Can arbitrageurs have a destabilizing effect on the stock market, specifically through momentum trading strategies?
answer: Arbitrageurs can have both stabilizing and destabilizing effects depending on the level of comomentum: when comomentum is low, momentum strategies are stabilizing by correcting underreaction; when comomentum is high, momentum strategies are destabilizing due to crowded trading that pushes prices away from fundamentals and leads to subsequent return reversals.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by proposing a novel measure called 'comomentum' to examine arbitrage activity's market effects, focusing on stock price momentum as a classic positive-feedback strategy that theory predicts can be destabilizing, thereby providing new empirical evidence on the dual role of arbitrageurs in financial markets.

author: Elias Papaioannou
title: Financial Regulation, Financial Globalization, and the Synchronization of Economic Activity
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We analyze the impact of financial globalization on business cycle synchronization using a proprietary database on banks’ international exposure for industrialized countries during 1978 to 2006. Theory makes ambiguous predictions and identification has been elusive due to lack of bilateral time‐varying financial linkages data. In contrast to conventional wisdom and previous empirical studies, we identify a strong negative effect of banking integration on output synchronization, conditional on global shocks and country‐pair heterogeneity. Similarly, we show divergent economic activity due to higher integration using an exogenous de‐jure measure of integration based on financial regulations that harmonized EU markets.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the impact of financial globalization on business cycle synchronization across industrialized countries?
answer: Financial globalization, particularly banking integration, has a strong negative effect on output synchronization - meaning that greater financial integration leads to more divergent rather than synchronized economic activity across countries.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges conventional wisdom and previous empirical studies by using a proprietary database on banks' international exposure with bilateral time-varying financial linkages data to overcome identification problems that have been elusive in prior research, ultimately finding results that contradict the prevailing view in the literature.

author: Elias Papaioannou
title: Corporate Control around the World
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We study corporate control tracing controlling shareholders for thousands of listed firms from 127 countries over 2004 to 2012. Government and family control is pervasive in civil‐law countries. Blocks are commonplace, but less so in common‐law countries. These patterns apply to large, medium, and small firms. In contrast, the development‐control nexus is heterogeneous; strong for large but absent for small firms. Control correlates strongly with shareholder protection, the stringency of employment contracts and unions power. Conversely, the correlations with creditor rights, legal formalism, and entry regulation appear weak. These patterns support both legal origin and political theories of financial development.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the patterns of corporate control structures across different countries and legal systems, and what factors explain these patterns?
answer: Government and family control is pervasive in civil-law countries, while blocks are commonplace but less so in common-law countries. The development-control relationship varies by firm size (strong for large firms, absent for small firms). Corporate control correlates strongly with shareholder protection, employment contract stringency, and union power, but weakly with creditor rights, legal formalism, and entry regulation.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing comprehensive empirical evidence on corporate control patterns across 127 countries from 2004-2012, supporting both legal origin and political theories of financial development through analysis of thousands of listed firms of varying sizes.

author: Elisabeth Kempf
title: Partisan Professionals: Evidence from Credit Rating Analysts
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Partisan perception affects the actions of professionals in the financial sector. Linking credit rating analysts to party affiliations from voter records, we show that analysts not affiliated with the U.S. president's party downward‐adjust corporate credit ratings more frequently. Since we compare analysts with different party affiliations covering the same firm in the same quarter, differences in firm fundamentals cannot explain the results. We also find a sharp divergence in the rating actions of Democratic and Republican analysts around the 2016 presidential election. Our results show that analysts' partisan perception has price effects and may influence firms' investment policies.</jats:p>
research_question: Does partisan political affiliation affect the professional judgment and actions of credit rating analysts in the financial sector?
answer: Yes, partisan perception significantly affects credit rating analysts' professional decisions - analysts not affiliated with the U.S. president's party downward-adjust corporate credit ratings more frequently, with sharp divergence in rating actions between Democratic and Republican analysts around the 2016 presidential election, and these partisan effects have real price impacts and may influence firms' investment policies.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes novel evidence to the literature by directly linking credit rating analysts to their party affiliations through voter records and demonstrating that political partisanship affects professional financial decision-making, extending beyond previous work by showing that partisan perception influences not just individual investors but also professional analysts in the financial sector.

author: Emily Breza
title: Financial Contracting and Organizational Form: Evidence from the Regulation of Trade Credit
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We present evidence that restrictions to the set of feasible financial contracts affect buyer‐supplier relationships and the organizational form of the firm. We exploit a regulation that restricted the maturity of the trade credit contracts that a large retailer could sign with some of its small suppliers. Using a within‐product difference‐in‐differences identification strategy, we find that the restriction reduces the likelihood of trade by 11%. The retailer also responds by internalizing procurement to its own subsidiaries and reducing overall purchases. Finally, we find that relational contracts can mitigate the inability to extend long trade credit terms.</jats:p>
research_question: How do restrictions on feasible financial contracts affect buyer-supplier relationships and the organizational form of the firm?
answer: Financial contract restrictions significantly impact firm organization and relationships: trade credit maturity restrictions reduce the likelihood of trade by 11%, cause retailers to internalize procurement through subsidiaries, reduce overall purchases, and can be partially mitigated through relational contracts.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on financial contracting and organizational form by providing empirical evidence of how regulatory restrictions on trade credit contracts affect buyer-supplier relationships, using a natural experiment approach with difference-in-differences identification to establish causal relationships.

author: Francesco Bianchi
title: Using Social Media to Identify the Effects of Congressional Viewpoints on Asset Prices
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We use a high-frequency identification approach to document that individual politicians affect asset prices. We exploit the regular flow of viewpoints contained in Congress members’ tweets. Supportive (critical) tweets increase (decrease) the stock prices of the targeted firm and the corresponding industry in minutes around the tweet. The bulk of the stock price effects is concentrated in the tweets revealing news about future legislative action. The effects are amplified around committee meeting days, especially when the tweet originates from committee members and influential politicians. Overall, we show that Congress members’ social media accounts are an important source of political news.</jats:p>
research_question: Do individual politicians affect asset prices through their social media communications, specifically through viewpoints expressed in Congress members' tweets?
answer: Yes, individual politicians significantly affect asset prices through their tweets. Supportive tweets increase stock prices while critical tweets decrease them within minutes, with effects concentrated in tweets revealing news about future legislative action and amplified around committee meeting days, especially from committee members and influential politicians.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by using a high-frequency identification approach to demonstrate that Congress members' social media accounts are an important source of political news that affects asset prices, exploiting the regular flow of viewpoints in tweets to identify causal effects of individual political communications on financial markets.

author: Francesco Bianchi
title: Monetary Policy and Asset Valuation
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We document large, longer term, joint regime shifts in asset valuations and the real federal funds rate‐ spread. To interpret these findings, we estimate a novel macrofinance model of monetary transmission and find that the documented regimes coincide with shifts in the parameters of a policy rule, with long‐term consequences for the real interest rate. Estimates imply that two‐thirds of the decline in the real interest rate since the early 1980s is attributable to regime changes in monetary policy. The model explains how infrequent changes in the stance of monetary policy can generate persistent changes in asset valuations and the equity premium.</jats:p>
research_question: How do regime shifts in monetary policy affect asset valuations and real interest rates over the long term?
answer: Two-thirds of the decline in the real interest rate since the early 1980s is attributable to regime changes in monetary policy, and infrequent changes in monetary policy stance can generate persistent changes in asset valuations and the equity premium through shifts in policy rule parameters.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes a novel macrofinance model of monetary transmission that explains the joint regime shifts in asset valuations and real federal funds rate-spread, providing new insights into how monetary policy changes have long-term consequences for asset markets.

author: Francesco Franzoni
title: Pension Plan Funding and Stock Market Efficiency
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>The paper argues that the market significantly overvalues firms with severely underfunded pension plans. These companies earn lower stock returns than firms with healthier pension plans for at least 5 years after the first emergence of the underfunding. The low returns are not explained by risk, price momentum, earnings momentum, or accruals. Further, the evidence suggests that investors do not anticipate the impact of the pension liability on future earnings, and they are surprised when the negative implications of underfunding ultimately materialize. Finally, underfunded firms have poor operating performance, and they earn low returns, although they are value companies.</jats:p>
research_question: Does the stock market efficiently price firms with severely underfunded pension plans?
answer: The market significantly overvalues firms with severely underfunded pension plans, which subsequently earn lower stock returns than firms with healthier pension plans for at least 5 years after underfunding emerges.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges market efficiency by demonstrating that investors fail to properly anticipate the impact of pension liabilities on future earnings and are surprised when negative implications materialize, contributing to literature on market anomalies and mispricing.

author: Francesco Franzoni
title: Private Equity Performance and Liquidity Risk
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Private equity has traditionally been thought to provide diversification benefits. However, these benefits may be lower than anticipated as we find that private equity suffers from significant exposure to the same liquidity risk factor as public equity and other alternative asset classes. The unconditional liquidity risk premium is about 3% annually and, in a four‐factor model, the inclusion of this liquidity risk premium reduces alpha to zero. In addition, we provide evidence that the link between private equity returns and overall market liquidity occurs via a funding liquidity channel.</jats:p>
research_question: Does private equity provide the anticipated diversification benefits, and what is the role of liquidity risk in private equity performance?
answer: Private equity does not provide the expected diversification benefits as it suffers from significant exposure to the same liquidity risk factor as public equity and other alternative assets, with an unconditional liquidity risk premium of about 3% annually that reduces alpha to zero in a four-factor model.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the traditional view that private equity provides diversification benefits by demonstrating that private equity shares significant liquidity risk exposure with public equity and other alternative asset classes, contrary to conventional wisdom in the literature.

author: Francesco Franzoni
title: The value of intermediation in the stock market

author: Francesco Franzoni
title: Do ETFs Increase Volatility?
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Due to their low trading costs, exchange‐traded funds (ETFs) are a potential catalyst for short‐horizon liquidity traders. The liquidity shocks can propagate to the underlying securities through the arbitrage channel, and ETFs may increase the nonfundamental volatility of the securities in their baskets. We exploit exogenous changes in index membership and find that stocks with higher ETF ownership display significantly higher volatility. ETF ownership increases the negative autocorrelation in stock prices. The increase in volatility appears to introduce undiversifiable risk in prices because stocks with high ETF ownership earn a significant risk premium of up to 56 basis points monthly.</jats:p>
research_question: Do exchange-traded funds (ETFs) increase the volatility of their underlying securities?
answer: Yes, ETFs increase volatility of underlying stocks. Stocks with higher ETF ownership display significantly higher volatility, increased negative price autocorrelation, and earn a risk premium of up to 56 basis points monthly due to the undiversifiable risk introduced.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on ETF market effects by identifying a specific mechanism through which ETFs impact underlying securities - that low trading costs attract short-horizon liquidity traders whose shocks propagate to underlying securities through arbitrage channels, creating nonfundamental volatility that represents undiversifiable risk.

author: Francesco Franzoni
title: Hedge Fund Stock Trading in the Financial Crisis of 2007–2009

author: Francesco Franzoni
title: Brokers and Order Flow Leakage: Evidence from Fire Sales
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Using trade‐level data, we study whether brokers play a role in spreading order flow information in the stock market. We focus on large portfolio liquidations that result in temporary price drops, and identify the brokers who intermediate these trades. These brokers’ clients are more likely to predate on the liquidating funds than to provide liquidity. Predation leads to profits of about 25 basis points over 10 days and increases the liquidation costs of the distressed fund by 40%. This evidence suggests a role of information leakage in exacerbating fire sales.</jats:p>
research_question: Do brokers play a role in spreading order flow information in the stock market, particularly during large portfolio liquidations?
answer: Yes, brokers do spread order flow information. Brokers' clients are more likely to predate on liquidating funds rather than provide liquidity, earning profits of about 25 basis points over 10 days while increasing the distressed fund's liquidation costs by 40%.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on fire sales by providing evidence for a specific mechanism - information leakage through brokers - that exacerbates fire sale conditions, using trade-level data to identify broker intermediation patterns during large portfolio liquidations.

author: Francesco Franzoni
title: The relevance of broker networks for information diffusion in the stock market

author: Francesco Franzoni
title: Do Hedge Funds Manipulate Stock Prices?
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We provide evidence suggesting that some hedge funds manipulate stock prices on critical reporting dates. Stocks in the top quartile of hedge fund holdings exhibit abnormal returns of 0.30% on the last day of the quarter and a reversal of 0.25% on the following day. A significant part of the return is earned during the last minutes of trading. Analysis of intraday volume and order imbalance provides further evidence consistent with manipulation. These patterns are stronger for funds that have higher incentives to improve their ranking relative to their peers.</jats:p>
research_question: Do hedge funds manipulate stock prices on critical reporting dates?
answer: Yes, the evidence suggests that some hedge funds manipulate stock prices on critical reporting dates. Stocks with high hedge fund holdings show abnormal positive returns of 0.30% on the last day of quarters followed by reversals of 0.25% the next day, with significant returns occurring in the final minutes of trading.
positioning_statement: This paper provides new empirical evidence of hedge fund market manipulation behavior, particularly focusing on end-of-quarter reporting periods and examining intraday trading patterns and volume data to demonstrate manipulation tactics that were not previously documented in the existing literature.

author: Francesco Trebbi
title: Foreclosures, House Prices, and the Real Economy
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>From 2007 to 2009, states without a judicial requirement for foreclosures were <jats:italic>twice</jats:italic> as likely to foreclose on delinquent homeowners. Analysis of borders of states with differing foreclosure laws reveals a discrete jump in foreclosure propensity as one enters nonjudicial states. Using state judicial requirement as an instrument for foreclosures, we show that foreclosures led to a large decline in house prices, residential investment, and consumer demand from 2007 to 2009. As foreclosures subsided from 2011 to 2013, the foreclosure rates in nonjudicial and judicial requirement states converged and we find some evidence of a stronger recovery in nonjudicial states.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the causal impact of foreclosures on house prices, residential investment, and consumer demand during the 2007-2009 financial crisis and subsequent recovery?
answer: Foreclosures caused large declines in house prices, residential investment, and consumer demand from 2007 to 2009, with nonjudicial states experiencing twice the foreclosure rate of judicial states, and some evidence of stronger recovery in nonjudicial states from 2011 to 2013 as foreclosure rates converged.
positioning_statement: This paper uses variation in state foreclosure laws (judicial vs. nonjudicial requirements) as an instrumental variable to identify the causal effects of foreclosures on real economic outcomes, exploiting discrete differences in foreclosure propensity at state borders to address endogeneity concerns in measuring foreclosure impacts.

author: Francisco Gomes
title: Optimal Life‐Cycle Asset Allocation: Understanding the Empirical Evidence
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We show that a life‐cycle model with realistically calibrated uninsurable labor income risk and moderate risk aversion can simultaneously match stock market participation rates and asset allocation decisions conditional on participation. The key ingredients of the model are Epstein–Zin preferences, a fixed stock market entry cost, and moderate heterogeneity in risk aversion. Households with low risk aversion smooth earnings shocks with a small buffer stock of assets, and consequently most of them (optimally) never invest in equities. Therefore, the marginal stockholders are (endogenously) more risk averse, and as a result they do not invest their portfolios fully in stocks.</jats:p>
research_question: How can a life-cycle model explain both observed stock market participation rates and asset allocation decisions conditional on participation?
answer: A life-cycle model with realistically calibrated uninsurable labor income risk, moderate risk aversion, Epstein-Zin preferences, fixed stock market entry costs, and moderate heterogeneity in risk aversion can simultaneously match both stock market participation rates and conditional asset allocation decisions. Low risk aversion households optimally avoid equity investment and use small asset buffers to smooth earnings shocks, while marginal stockholders are endogenously more risk averse and therefore don't invest fully in stocks.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the challenge of simultaneously explaining two key empirical patterns in household finance - stock market participation rates and asset allocation conditional on participation - which existing life-cycle models have struggled to match together.

author: Francisco Gomes
title: Asset Pricing with Limited Risk Sharing and Heterogeneous Agents

author: Francesco Franzoni
title: Competition for Attention in the ETF Space
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The interplay between investors’ demand and providers’ incentives has shaped the evolution of exchange-traded funds (ETFs). While early ETFs invested in broad-based indexes and therefore offered diversification at low cost, more recent products track niche portfolios and charge high fees. Strikingly, over their first 5 years, specialized ETFs lose about 30$\%$ (risk-adjusted). This underperformance cannot be explained by high fees or hedging demand. Rather, it is driven by the overvaluation of the underlying stocks at the time of the launch. Our results are consistent with providers catering to investors’ extrapolative beliefs by issuing specialized ETFs that track attention-grabbing themes.</jats:p>
research_question: How has the interplay between investors' demand and providers' incentives shaped the evolution of exchange-traded funds (ETFs), particularly regarding the performance and characteristics of specialized versus broad-based ETFs?
answer: Specialized ETFs underperform significantly, losing about 30% (risk-adjusted) over their first 5 years, which is driven by overvaluation of underlying stocks at launch time rather than high fees or hedging demand. This underperformance occurs because providers cater to investors' extrapolative beliefs by issuing specialized ETFs that track attention-grabbing themes.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by explaining the evolution from early broad-based, low-cost ETFs offering diversification to more recent specialized, high-fee ETFs tracking niche portfolios, providing empirical evidence that this shift is driven by providers exploiting investor behavioral biases rather than fundamental economic factors.

author: Francisco Gomes
title: Unconventional monetary policy in the Euro area: Impacts on loans, employment, and investment
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Using a dataset of bank‐ and regional‐level data, we study the effectiveness and heterogeneity of the transmission mechanism of the ECB's large scale asset purchases (LSAPs) to the real economy. Our results indicate that banks more exposed to government debt securities had higher growth of loans and loans relative to total assets than less exposed banks after the asset purchase programme (APP), but not after the pandemic emergency purchase programme (PEPP). Furthermore, our results demonstrate that regions where banks are more exposed to government securities exhibit more favorable outcomes after the APP in GDP, fixed capital formation, unemployment, and compensation of employees than regions with less exposed banks, via the bank lending channel. We argue that banks' exposure to LSAPs targeted assets and their geographical location is an important factor determining the magnitude and heterogeneity of the portfolio rebalancing transmission mechanism to the real economy.</jats:p>
research_question: How effective is the transmission mechanism of the ECB's large scale asset purchases (LSAPs) to the real economy, and what factors determine the heterogeneity of these effects across banks and regions?
answer: Banks more exposed to government debt securities had higher loan growth after the asset purchase programme (APP) but not after the pandemic emergency purchase programme (PEPP). Regions with more exposed banks experienced better outcomes in GDP, fixed capital formation, unemployment, and employee compensation after the APP through the bank lending channel. Banks' exposure to LSAP-targeted assets and their geographical location are key factors determining the magnitude and heterogeneity of the portfolio rebalancing transmission mechanism.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on unconventional monetary policy transmission by using bank- and regional-level data to examine the heterogeneous effects of ECB's large scale asset purchases, specifically focusing on how banks' exposure to government securities and their geographical location affect the portfolio rebalancing transmission mechanism to the real economy through the bank lending channel.

author: Francisco Gomes
title: Do Robots Increase Wealth Dispersion?
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We document significant negative effects of exposure to increased automation at work on household wealth accumulation. Beyond the income and savings channels, we uncover a novel mechanism contributing to the negative wealth effects of automation that arises through the endogenous optimal portfolio decisions of households. We show that households rebalance their financial wealth away from the stock market in response to increased human capital risk induced by pervasive automation, thereby attaining lower wealth levels and relative positions in the wealth distribution. Our evidence suggests that the portfolio channel amplifies the inequality-enhancing effects of increased automation.</jats:p>
               <jats:p>Authors have furnished an Internet Appendix, which is available on the Oxford University Press Web site next to the link to the final published paper online.</jats:p>
research_question: Do robots increase wealth dispersion, and what are the mechanisms through which automation affects household wealth accumulation and inequality?
answer: Yes, robots increase wealth dispersion. Automation has significant negative effects on household wealth accumulation through multiple channels: direct income and savings effects, and a novel portfolio rebalancing mechanism where households shift away from stock market investments due to increased human capital risk from automation, resulting in lower wealth levels and amplified inequality.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the automation and inequality literature by uncovering a previously undocumented mechanism - the portfolio channel - through which automation affects wealth distribution, beyond the commonly studied income and savings channels, showing that this portfolio rebalancing amplifies the inequality-enhancing effects of increased automation.

author: Francisco Gomes
title: Asset Pricing and Risk‐Sharing Implications of Alternative Pension Plan Systems
abstract:
<jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title>
                  <jats:p>We show that incorporating defined benefit pension funds in an incomplete markets asset pricing model improves its ability to match the historical equity premium and riskless rate and has important risk‐sharing implications. We document the importance of the pension fund's size and asset demands, and a new risk channel arising from fluctuations in the fund's returns. We use our calibrated model to study the implications of a shift to an economy with defined contribution plans. The new steady state is characterized by a higher riskless rate and a lower equity premium. Consumption volatility increases for retirees but decreases for workers.</jats:p>
research_question: How do defined benefit pension funds affect asset pricing and risk-sharing, and what are the implications of shifting from defined benefit to defined contribution pension plans?
answer: Incorporating defined benefit pension funds in asset pricing models improves their ability to match historical equity premiums and riskless rates. A shift to defined contribution plans results in a higher riskless rate, lower equity premium, increased consumption volatility for retirees, and decreased consumption volatility for workers.
positioning_statement: This paper extends existing incomplete markets asset pricing models by incorporating defined benefit pension funds, documenting their importance through fund size, asset demands, and a new risk channel from fund return fluctuations that has not been previously analyzed in the literature.

author: Frederico Belo
title: What Drives Firms’ Hiring Decisions? An Asset Pricing Perspective
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We document that the aggregate hiring rate of publicly traded firms in the U.S. economy negatively predicts stock market returns and long-term cash flows, and positively predicts short-term cash flows. In addition, through a variance decomposition, we show that the time-series variation in the aggregate hiring rate is mainly driven by changes in discount rates and short-term expected cash flows, with no contribution from variation in long-term expected cash flows. We estimate a neoclassical dynamic model with labor market frictions and show that labor adjustment costs and time-varying risk are essential for the model to replicate the empirical patterns.</jats:p>
               <jats:p>Authors have furnished an Internet Appendix, which is available on the Oxford University Press Web site next to the link to the final published paper online.</jats:p>
research_question: What drives firms' hiring decisions and how do aggregate hiring patterns relate to stock market returns and cash flows from an asset pricing perspective?
answer: The aggregate hiring rate of publicly traded firms negatively predicts stock market returns and long-term cash flows, while positively predicting short-term cash flows. The variation in aggregate hiring rates is primarily driven by changes in discount rates and short-term expected cash flows, with labor adjustment costs and time-varying risk being essential factors.
positioning_statement: This paper bridges labor economics and asset pricing by examining hiring decisions through an asset pricing lens, using a neoclassical dynamic model with labor market frictions to explain the relationship between aggregate hiring patterns and financial market outcomes.

author: Frederico Belo
title: Dividend Dynamics and the Term Structure of Dividend Strips
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Many leading asset pricing models are specified so that the term structure of dividend volatility is either flat or upward sloping. These models predict that the term structures of expected returns and volatilities on dividend strips (i.e., claims to dividends paid over a prespecified interval) are also upward sloping. However, the empirical evidence suggests otherwise. This discrepancy can be reconciled if these models replace their proposed dividend dynamics with processes that generate stationary leverage ratios. Under such policies, shareholders are forced to divest (invest) when leverage is low (high), which shifts risk from long‐ to short‐horizon dividend strips.</jats:p>
research_question: Why do leading asset pricing models predict upward sloping term structures of expected returns and volatilities on dividend strips when empirical evidence suggests otherwise?
answer: The discrepancy can be reconciled if asset pricing models replace their proposed dividend dynamics with processes that generate stationary leverage ratios, which shifts risk from long- to short-horizon dividend strips through forced divestment when leverage is low and forced investment when leverage is high.
positioning_statement: This paper identifies a fundamental inconsistency between many leading asset pricing models (which specify flat or upward sloping dividend volatility term structures) and empirical evidence, proposing an alternative dividend dynamics specification to resolve this discrepancy.

author: Frederico Belo
title: External Equity Financing Shocks, Financial Flows, and Asset Prices
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We develop a dynamic model with time variation in external equity financing costs and show that variation in these costs is important for the model to quantitatively capture the joint dynamics of firms’ asset prices, real quantities, and financial flows in the U.S. economy. Growth firms and high investment firms are less risky in equilibrium, because they can substitute more easily debt financing for equity financing when it becomes more costly to raise external equity, which are high marginal utility states. Using a model-implied proxy of aggregate equity issuance cost shocks, we provide empirical support for the model’s economic mechanism.</jats:p><jats:p>Received August 7, 2017; editorial decision September 24, 2018 by Editor Stijn Van Nieuwerburgh. Authors have furnished an Internet Appendix, which is available on the Oxford University Press Web site next to the link to the final published paper online</jats:p>
research_question: How does time variation in external equity financing costs affect the joint dynamics of firms' asset prices, real quantities, and financial flows in the U.S. economy?
answer: Variation in external equity financing costs is quantitatively important for capturing the joint dynamics of asset prices, real quantities, and financial flows. Growth firms and high investment firms are less risky in equilibrium because they can more easily substitute debt financing for equity financing when external equity becomes more costly to raise during high marginal utility states.
positioning_statement: The paper develops a dynamic model that incorporates time-varying external equity financing costs as a key mechanism, providing both theoretical modeling and empirical validation using a model-implied proxy of aggregate equity issuance cost shocks to support the proposed economic mechanism.

author: Gabriel Chodorow-Reich
title: The Loan Covenant Channel: How Bank Health Transmits to the Real Economy
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We document the importance of covenant violations in transmitting bank health to nonfinancial firms. Roughly one‐third of loans in our supervisory data breach a covenant during the 2008 to 2009 period, allowing lenders to force a renegotiation of loan terms or to accelerate repayment of otherwise long‐term credit. Lenders in worse health are more likely to force a reduction in the loan commitment following a violation. The reduction in credit to borrowers who violate a covenant can account for the majority of the cross‐sectional variation in credit supply during the 2008 to 2009 crisis.</jats:p>
research_question: How does bank health transmit to the real economy through loan covenant violations?
answer: Covenant violations serve as a key transmission mechanism where banks in worse health are more likely to reduce loan commitments following violations, with this reduction in credit to covenant-violating borrowers accounting for the majority of cross-sectional variation in credit supply during the 2008-2009 crisis.
positioning_statement: This paper identifies and documents a specific transmission channel (the loan covenant channel) through which bank health affects the real economy, contributing new empirical evidence on how financial sector stress propagates to nonfinancial firms through contractual mechanisms in lending relationships.

author: George Aragon
title: Investor Protection and Capital Fragility: Evidence from Hedge Funds around the World
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We find that capital flows to hedge funds in different countries are influenced by the strength and the enforcement of investor protection laws. Hedge funds located in weak investor protection countries exhibit greater sensitivity of investor outflow to poor performance, relative to funds in countries with strong protection. Furthermore, weak investor protection is associated with fund managers engaging in greater returns management. Our findings suggest that in countries with weaker investor protection, poor fund performance exposes investors to a greater risk of fraud and legal jeopardy, thus triggering a larger outflow of capital.</jats:p>
research_question: How does the strength and enforcement of investor protection laws influence capital flows to hedge funds across different countries?
answer: Hedge funds in countries with weak investor protection laws exhibit greater sensitivity of investor outflows to poor performance and engage in more returns management, as poor performance exposes investors to greater fraud risk and legal jeopardy, triggering larger capital outflows.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by examining the relationship between country-level investor protection laws and hedge fund capital flows, specifically focusing on how weak investor protection creates capital fragility through increased outflow sensitivity to performance and greater returns management by fund managers.

author: Gabriel Chodorow-Reich
title: Asset Insulators
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We construct a new data set tracking the daily value of life insurers’ assets at the security level. Outside of the 2008–2009 crisis, a ${\$}$ 1 drop in the market value of assets reduces an insurer’s market equity by ${\$}$ 0.10. During the ?nancial crisis, this pass-through rises to ${\$}$ 1. We explain this pattern by viewing insurance companies as asset insulators, institutions with stable, long-term liabilities that can ride out transitory dislocations in market prices. Illustrating the macroeconomic importance of insulation, insurers’ market equity declined by ${\$}$50 billion less than the duration-adjusted value of their securities during the crisis.</jats:p>
research_question: How do changes in asset values affect life insurers' market equity, and does this relationship vary during financial crises versus normal times?
answer: Outside of crises, a $1 drop in asset market value reduces insurer market equity by only $0.10, but during the 2008-2009 financial crisis this pass-through increased to $1. This demonstrates that insurance companies normally act as 'asset insulators' but lose this capacity during severe market stress.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces the novel concept of insurance companies as 'asset insulators' - institutions with stable, long-term liabilities that can ride out transitory market price dislocations, contributing new empirical evidence on the macroeconomic role of insurers during financial crises.

author: George Aragon
title: Anticipatory Trading Against Distressed Mega Hedge Funds
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
                  <jats:p>Stocks expected to be sold by distressed mega hedge funds (MHFs) face anticipatory institutional selling and increased short interest. However, no evidence of anticipatory trading is found in stocks held by nondistressed MHFs, distressed non-MHFs, or stocks confidentially held by distressed MHFs, suggesting that public portfolio disclosure by large and closely followed distressed investors, and not common investment signals, drives anticipatory trading. Distressed MHFs with greater exposure to such anticipatory trading suffer 2.21% lower style-adjusted returns. Stocks subject to anticipatory trading experience negative abnormal returns followed by reversals, indicating the price destabilizing effect of anticipatory trading.</jats:p>
research_question: Do other institutional investors engage in anticipatory trading against distressed mega hedge funds, and what are the effects of such trading on both the distressed funds and stock prices?
answer: Stocks expected to be sold by distressed mega hedge funds face significant anticipatory institutional selling and increased short interest, which reduces the distressed funds' style-adjusted returns by 2.21% and causes temporary price destabilization with subsequent reversals.
positioning_statement: This paper identifies a new mechanism of anticipatory trading specifically targeting distressed mega hedge funds, demonstrating that public portfolio disclosure by large, closely followed distressed investors (rather than common investment signals) drives this behavior, as evidenced by the absence of such trading against nondistressed mega hedge funds, distressed non-mega hedge funds, or confidentially held positions.

author: Giorgia Piacentino
title: Venture Capital and Capital Allocation
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>I show that venture capitalists' motivation to build reputation can have beneficial effects in the primary market, mitigating information frictions and helping firms go public. Because uninformed reputation‐motivated venture capitalists want to appear informed, they are biased against backing firms—by not backing firms, they avoid taking low‐value firms to market, which would ultimately reveal their lack of information. In equilibrium, reputation‐motivated venture capitalists back relatively few bad firms, creating a certification effect that mitigates information frictions. However, they also back relatively few good firms, and thus, reputation motivation decreases welfare when good firms are abundant or profitable.</jats:p>
research_question: How does venture capitalists' motivation to build reputation affect capital allocation and welfare in the primary market?
answer: Reputation-motivated venture capitalists create a certification effect that mitigates information frictions by being biased against backing firms (to avoid revealing lack of information), but this decreases welfare when good firms are abundant or profitable because they also back relatively few good firms.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on venture capital and information frictions by showing that reputation motivation has both beneficial effects (certification and mitigation of information frictions) and welfare costs (reduced backing of good firms), providing a nuanced view of how reputation incentives affect capital allocation in venture capital markets.

author: Giorgia Piacentino
title: The Wall Street Walk when Blockholders Compete for Flows
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Effective monitoring by equity blockholders is important for good corporate governance. A prominent theoretical literature argues that the threat of block sale (“exit”) can be an effective governance mechanism. Many blockholders are money managers. We show that, when money managers compete for investor capital, the threat of exit loses credibility, weakening its governance role. Money managers with more skin in the game will govern more successfully using exit. Allowing funds to engage in activist measures (“voice”) does not alter our qualitative results. Our results link widely prevalent incentives in the ever‐expanding money management industry to the nature of corporate governance.</jats:p>
research_question: How does competition for investor capital among money managers affect the credibility and effectiveness of the 'Wall Street Walk' (threat of block sale) as a corporate governance mechanism?
answer: When money managers compete for investor capital, the threat of exit loses credibility and weakens its governance role, but money managers with more skin in the game can govern more successfully using exit threats.
positioning_statement: This paper builds on the prominent theoretical literature that argues block sale threats can be effective governance mechanisms, but extends it by examining how competition for flows in the money management industry undermines this mechanism, thereby linking prevalent industry incentives to corporate governance outcomes.

author: Giorgia Piacentino
title: Deadlock on the Board
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We develop a dynamic model of board decision-making akin to dynamic voting models in the political economy literature. We show a board could retain a policy all directors agree is worse than an available alternative. Thus, directors may retain a CEO they agree is bad—deadlocked boards lead to entrenched CEOs. We explore how to compose boards and appoint directors to mitigate deadlock. We find board diversity and long director tenure can exacerbate deadlock. We rationalize why CEOs and incumbent directors have power to appoint new directors: to avoid deadlock. Our model speaks to short-termism, staggered boards, and proxy access.</jats:p>
research_question: How can board decision-making processes lead to suboptimal outcomes where directors retain policies or CEOs they agree are inferior to available alternatives?
answer: Boards can become deadlocked and retain policies all directors agree are worse than available alternatives, leading to CEO entrenchment even when all directors agree the CEO is bad. Board diversity and long director tenure can exacerbate this deadlock problem.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a dynamic model of board decision-making that draws from dynamic voting models in the political economy literature, extending these concepts to corporate governance to explain board deadlock and CEO entrenchment phenomena.

author: Giorgia Piacentino
title: Intermediation Variety
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We explain why banks and nonbank intermediaries coexist in a model based only on differences in their funding costs. Banks enjoy a low cost of capital due to safety nets and money‐like liabilities. We show that this can actually be a disadvantage: it generates a soft‐budget‐constraint problem that makes it difficult for banks to credibly threaten to withhold additional funding to failed projects. Nonbanks emerge to solve this problem. Their high cost of capital is an advantage: it allows them to commit to terminate funding. Still, nonbanks never take over the entire market, but other coexist with banks in equilibrium.</jats:p>
research_question: Why do banks and nonbank intermediaries coexist in financial markets?
answer: Banks and nonbank intermediaries coexist because their different funding costs create complementary advantages: banks' low cost of capital (due to safety nets and money-like liabilities) creates a soft-budget-constraint problem that makes it difficult for them to credibly threaten to withhold funding from failed projects, while nonbanks' high cost of capital allows them to commit to terminate funding, solving this credibility problem.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a novel explanation for the coexistence of banks and nonbank intermediaries based solely on differences in their funding costs, offering a new theoretical framework that shows how banks' traditional funding advantage can actually be a disadvantage in certain contexts.

author: Giorgia Piacentino
title: Conflicting Priorities: A Theory of Covenants and Collateral
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We develop a theory of secured debt, unsecured debt, and debt with anti‐dilution covenants. We assume that, as in practice, covenants convey the right to accelerate if violated, but the new secured debt retains its priority even if issued in violation of covenants. We find that such covenants are nonetheless useful: They provide state‐contingent financing flexibility, balancing over‐ and underinvestment incentives. The optimal debt structure is multilayered, combining secured and unsecured debt with and without covenants. Our results are consistent with observations about debt structure, covenant violations, and waivers. They speak to a policy debate about debt priority.</jats:p>
research_question: How do anti-dilution covenants interact with secured and unsecured debt to create optimal debt structures, given that covenants allow acceleration when violated but new secured debt retains priority even when issued in violation of covenants?
answer: Anti-dilution covenants are useful because they provide state-contingent financing flexibility that balances over- and underinvestment incentives, and the optimal debt structure is multilayered, combining secured and unsecured debt both with and without covenants.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a new theory that explains the coexistence and interaction of secured debt, unsecured debt, and debt with anti-dilution covenants, addressing observations about debt structure, covenant violations, and waivers while contributing to policy debates about debt priority.

author: Giorgia Piacentino
title: Household Debt Overhang and Unemployment
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We use a labor‐search model to explain why the worst employment slumps often follow expansions of household debt. We find that households protected by limited liability suffer from a household‐debt‐overhang problem that leads them to require high wages to work. Firms respond by posting high wages but few vacancies. This <jats:italic>vacancy posting effect</jats:italic> implies that high household debt leads to high unemployment. Even though households borrow from banks via bilaterally optimal contracts, the equilibrium level of household debt is inefficiently high due to a <jats:italic>household‐debt externality</jats:italic>. We analyze the role that a financial regulator can play in mitigating this externality.</jats:p>
research_question: Why do the worst employment slumps often follow expansions of household debt?
answer: Households protected by limited liability suffer from a debt-overhang problem that leads them to require high wages to work, causing firms to post high wages but few vacancies (vacancy posting effect), which results in high unemployment. The equilibrium level of household debt is inefficiently high due to a household-debt externality.
positioning_statement: This paper uses a labor-search model to provide a novel theoretical explanation for the empirical observation that severe employment downturns follow household debt expansions, identifying a previously unrecognized household-debt externality that makes equilibrium debt levels inefficiently high despite bilaterally optimal contracts between households and banks.

author: Greg Nini
title: Is the Corporate Loan Market Globally Integrated? A Pricing Puzzle
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We offer evidence that interest rate spreads on syndicated loans to corporate borrowers are economically significantly smaller in Europe than in the United States, other things equal. Differences in borrower, loan, and lender characteristics do not appear to explain this phenomenon. Borrowers overwhelmingly issue in their natural home market and bank portfolios display home bias. This may explain why pricing discrepancies are not competed away, though their causes remain a puzzle. Thus, important determinants of loan origination market outcomes remain to be identified, home bias appears to be material for pricing, and corporate financing costs differ across Europe and the United States.</jats:p>
research_question: Is the corporate loan market globally integrated, and specifically, do loan pricing differences exist between Europe and the United States that suggest market segmentation?
answer: The corporate loan market is not globally integrated - interest rate spreads on syndicated loans are economically significantly smaller in Europe than in the United States, even after controlling for borrower, loan, and lender characteristics. This pricing discrepancy persists due to home bias in both borrower issuance patterns and bank lending portfolios.
positioning_statement: This paper identifies a previously unexplained pricing puzzle in global corporate loan markets, revealing that important determinants of loan origination market outcomes remain unidentified in existing literature and demonstrating that home bias has material pricing effects that contradict assumptions of perfect market integration.

author: Greg Nini
title: Creditor Control of Corporate Acquisitions
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We examine the impact of creditor control rights on corporate acquisitions. Nearly 75$\%$ of loan agreements include restrictions that limit borrower acquisition decisions throughout the life of the contract. Following a financial covenant violation, creditors use their bargaining power to tighten these restrictions and limit acquisition activity, particularly deals expected to earn negative announcement returns. Firms that do announce an acquisition after violating a financial covenant earn 1.8$\%$ higher stock returns, on average, and do not pursue less risky deals. We conclude that creditors use contractual rights and the renegotiation process to limit value-destroying acquisitions driven by managerial agency problems.</jats:p>
research_question: How do creditor control rights impact corporate acquisition decisions?
answer: Creditors use contractual rights and the renegotiation process following financial covenant violations to limit value-destroying acquisitions driven by managerial agency problems, resulting in firms earning 1.8% higher stock returns on average when they do announce acquisitions after covenant violations.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on creditor control and corporate governance by examining how loan agreement restrictions and covenant violations specifically affect acquisition decisions, demonstrating that creditors actively use their bargaining power to mitigate managerial agency problems in M&A activities.

author: Greg Nini
title: Securitization and Capital Structure in Nonfinancial Firms: An Empirical Investigation
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Contrary to recent accounts of off‐balance‐sheet securitization by financial firms, we show that asset securitization by nonfinancial firms provides a valuable form of financing for shareholders without harming debtholders. Using data from firms’ SEC filings, we find that securitization is attractive to firms in the middle of the credit quality distribution, which are the firms with the most to gain. Upon initiation, firms experience positive abnormal stock returns and zero abnormal bond returns, and largely use the securitization proceeds to repay existing debt. Securitization minimizes financing costs by reducing expected bankruptcy costs and providing access to segmented credit markets.</jats:p>
research_question: How does asset securitization affect the capital structure and financing outcomes of nonfinancial firms, particularly in terms of its impact on shareholders and debtholders?
answer: Asset securitization by nonfinancial firms provides valuable financing for shareholders without harming debtholders, is most attractive to firms in the middle of the credit quality distribution, generates positive abnormal stock returns with zero abnormal bond returns upon initiation, and minimizes financing costs by reducing expected bankruptcy costs and providing access to segmented credit markets.
positioning_statement: This paper contrasts with recent accounts of off-balance-sheet securitization by financial firms by focusing specifically on nonfinancial firms and demonstrating that securitization can be beneficial rather than harmful in this context.

author: Gregor Matvos
title: Selling Failed Banks
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>The average FDIC loss from selling a failed bank is 28% of assets. We document that failed banks are predominantly sold to bidders within the same county, with similar assets business lines, when these bidders are well capitalized. Otherwise, they are acquired by less similar banks located further away. We interpret these facts within a model of auctions with budget constraints, in which poor capitalization of some potential acquirers drives a wedge between their willingness and ability to pay for failed banks. We document that this wedge drives misallocation, and partially explains the FDIC losses from failed bank sales.</jats:p>
research_question: What factors determine who acquires failed banks and how do these factors contribute to FDIC losses from failed bank sales?
answer: Failed banks are predominantly sold to well-capitalized bidders within the same county with similar business lines, but when such bidders are not available, they are acquired by less similar banks located further away. This creates misallocation due to budget constraints of potential acquirers, which partially explains the average 28% FDIC loss from failed bank sales.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by interpreting failed bank acquisition patterns through a model of auctions with budget constraints, specifically focusing on how poor capitalization of potential acquirers creates a wedge between willingness and ability to pay, leading to misallocation and FDIC losses.

author: Gregor Matvos
title: Advertising Expensive Mortgages
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Using information on advertising and mortgages originated by subprime lenders, we study whether advertising helped consumers find cheaper mortgages. Lenders that advertise more within a region sell more expensive mortgages, measured as the excess rate of a mortgage after accounting for borrower, contract, and regional characteristics. These effects are stronger for mortgages sold to less sophisticated consumers. We exploit regional variation in mortgage advertising induced by the entry of Craigslist and other tests to demonstrate that these findings are not spurious. Analyzing advertising content reveals that initial/introductory rates are frequently advertised in a salient fashion, where reset rates are not.</jats:p>
research_question: Does advertising help consumers find cheaper mortgages in the subprime lending market?
answer: No, advertising does not help consumers find cheaper mortgages. Lenders that advertise more within a region actually sell more expensive mortgages (measured as excess rates after accounting for borrower, contract, and regional characteristics), with these effects being stronger for less sophisticated consumers.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on advertising in financial markets by providing empirical evidence that contradicts the assumption that advertising helps consumers find better deals, specifically focusing on the subprime mortgage market and using regional variation in advertising exposure (induced by Craigslist entry) to establish causal relationships.

author: Gregory Duffee
title: Macroeconomic News in Asset Pricing and Reality
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Revisions in successive Greenbook forecasts of quarterly real GDP growth proxy for news of current and expected future economic growth. In the sample 1975 through 2015, news of future growth is slightly negatively related to contemporaneous changes in Treasury bond yields, while news of current growth is strongly positively related to changes in these yields. Both results are difficult to reconcile with a representative agent's bondholding first‐order condition. A continuous‐time dynamic model of output attributes almost all of the covariation with yields to martingale innovations in log output and a minimal amount to innovations in the conditional drift of log output.</jats:p>
research_question: How do macroeconomic news about current and future economic growth relate to Treasury bond yield changes, and can these relationships be explained by standard asset pricing theory?
answer: News of future growth is slightly negatively related to Treasury bond yield changes, while news of current growth is strongly positively related to yield changes. These relationships are difficult to reconcile with standard representative agent asset pricing models, and a continuous-time dynamic model shows that most covariation with yields comes from martingale innovations in log output rather than changes in expected future growth.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the ability of standard representative agent asset pricing models to explain the observed relationships between macroeconomic news and bond yields, contributing to the literature on asset pricing puzzles and the disconnect between theoretical models and empirical evidence in bond markets.

author: Gregory Duffee
title: Term Premia and Interest Rate Forecasts in Affine Models
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>The standard class of affine models produces poor forecasts of future Treasury yields. Better forecasts are generated by assuming that yields follow random walks. The failure of these models is driven by one of their key features: Compensation for risk is a multiple of the variance of the risk. Thus risk compensation cannot vary independently of interest rate volatility. I also describe a broader class of models. These aessentially affine‐ models retain the tractability of standard models, but allow compensation for interest rate risk to vary independently of interest rate volatility. This additional flexibility proves useful in forecasting future yields.</jats:p>
research_question: Why do standard affine models produce poor forecasts of future Treasury yields, and can a modified class of models improve forecasting performance?
answer: Standard affine models fail at forecasting because they constrain risk compensation to be a multiple of risk variance, preventing independent variation of risk compensation and interest rate volatility. 'Essentially affine' models that allow risk compensation to vary independently of volatility provide better yield forecasts while maintaining tractability.
positioning_statement: This paper identifies a fundamental limitation in the standard class of affine models used in fixed income research and proposes a broader 'essentially affine' class that maintains the computational advantages of standard models while addressing their forecasting deficiencies.

author: Gregory Duffee
title: Time Variation in the Covariance between Stock Returns and Consumption Growth
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>The conditional covariance between aggregate stock returns and aggregate consumption growth varies substantially over time. When stock market wealth is high relative to consumption, both the conditional covariance and correlation are high. This pattern is consistent with the “composition effect,” where agents' consumption growth is more closely tied to stock returns when stock wealth is a larger share of total wealth. This variation can be used to test asset‐pricing models in which the price of consumption risk varies. After accounting for variations in this price, the relation between expected excess stock returns and the conditional covariance is negative.</jats:p>
research_question: How does the conditional covariance between aggregate stock returns and aggregate consumption growth vary over time, and what are the implications for asset pricing models?
answer: The conditional covariance between stock returns and consumption growth varies substantially over time and is high when stock market wealth is high relative to consumption, consistent with a 'composition effect.' After accounting for variations in the price of consumption risk, there is a negative relation between expected excess stock returns and the conditional covariance.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the asset pricing literature by providing empirical evidence for time-varying covariance patterns that can be used to test asset pricing models where the price of consumption risk varies, offering a new perspective on the relationship between stock returns and consumption growth.

author: Gregory Duffee
title: Expected Inflation and Other Determinants of Treasury Yields
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Shocks to nominal bond yields consist of news about expected future inflation, expected future real short rates, and expected excess returns—all over the bond's life. I estimate the magnitude of the first component for short‐ and long‐maturity Treasury bonds. At a quarterly frequency, variances of news about expected inflation account for between 10% to 20% of variances of yield shocks. Standard dynamic models with long‐run risk imply variance ratios close to 1. Habit formation models fare somewhat better. The magnitudes of shocks to real rates and expected excess returns cannot be determined reliably.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the magnitude of expected future inflation shocks as a component of nominal Treasury bond yield shocks, and how does this compare to predictions from standard dynamic models?
answer: Expected inflation news accounts for only 10-20% of the variance in Treasury yield shocks at quarterly frequency, which is much lower than the near 100% variance ratios predicted by standard dynamic models with long-run risk, while habit formation models perform somewhat better in matching this empirical finding.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges standard dynamic models with long-run risk by showing they dramatically overpredict the role of inflation expectations in bond yield movements, while finding that habit formation models provide a better fit to the empirical evidence of limited inflation influence on yield volatility.

author: Holger Mueller
title: Increasing Enrollment in Income‐Driven Student Loan Repayment Plans: Evidence from the Navient Field Experiment
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We report evidence from a randomized field experiment conducted by a major student loan servicer, Navient, in which student loan borrowers received prepopulated applications for income‐driven repayment (IDR) plans. Treatment increased IDR enrollment by 34 percentage points relative to the control group. Using the random treatment assignment as an instrument for IDR enrollment, we furthermore provide local average treatment effect (LATE) estimates of the effects of IDR enrollment on new delinquencies, monthly student loan payments, and consumer spending. Our study is the first field‐experimental evaluation of a U.S. government program designed to address the soaring debt burdens of U.S. households.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the effect of providing prepopulated applications for income-driven repayment (IDR) plans on student loan borrower enrollment and subsequent financial outcomes?
answer: Providing prepopulated IDR applications increased enrollment by 34 percentage points, and the study provides causal estimates of IDR enrollment effects on delinquencies, monthly payments, and consumer spending using the randomized treatment as an instrument.
positioning_statement: This is the first field-experimental evaluation of a U.S. government program designed to address the soaring debt burdens of U.S. households, positioning it as a pioneering empirical study in evaluating debt relief policy interventions.

author: Holger Mueller
title: Capital and Labor Reallocation within Firms
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We document how a positive shock to investment opportunities at one plant (“treated plant”) spills over to other plants within the same firm, but only if the firm is financially constrained. To provide the treated plant with resources, the firm's headquarters withdraws capital and labor from other plants, especially plants that are relatively less productive, not part of the firm's core industries, and located far away from headquarters. As a result of the resource reallocation, aggregate firm‐wide productivity increases. We do not find evidence of capital or labor spillovers among plants of financially unconstrained firms.</jats:p>
research_question: How do positive investment opportunity shocks at one plant within a firm affect resource allocation to other plants within the same firm, and does this effect vary by the firm's financial constraints?
answer: Positive investment shocks at one plant cause financially constrained firms to reallocate capital and labor from other plants (especially less productive, non-core, and geographically distant plants) to the treated plant, resulting in increased aggregate firm-wide productivity. This reallocation effect does not occur in financially unconstrained firms.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by documenting within-firm resource reallocation effects that occur specifically under financial constraints, showing how firms internally manage resource allocation across plants in response to investment opportunities when external financing is limited.

author: Gregory Duffee
title: Estimation of Dynamic Term Structure Models
abstract: <jats:p>We study the finite-sample properties of some of the standard techniques used to estimate modern term structure models. For sample sizes and models similar to those used in most empirical work, we reach three surprising conclusions. First, while maximum likelihood works well for simple models, it produces strongly biased parameter estimates when the model includes a flexible specification of the dynamics of interest rate risk. Second, despite having the same asymptotic efficiency as maximum likelihood, the small-sample performance of Efficient Method of Moments (a commonly used method for estimating complicated models) is unacceptable even in the simplest term structure settings. Third, the linearized Kalman filter is a tractable and reasonably accurate estimation technique, which we recommend in settings where maximum likelihood is impractical.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the finite-sample properties of standard estimation techniques used for modern term structure models?
answer: Maximum likelihood works well for simple models but produces strongly biased estimates for complex models with flexible interest rate risk dynamics; Efficient Method of Moments performs unacceptably even in simple settings despite asymptotic efficiency; the linearized Kalman filter provides tractable and reasonably accurate estimation when maximum likelihood is impractical.
positioning_statement: This paper evaluates the practical performance of existing standard estimation techniques for term structure models, revealing surprising limitations in commonly used methods and recommending an alternative approach for complex model estimation.

author: Holger Mueller
title: Informed Lending and Security Design
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We examine the role of security design when lenders make inefficient accept or reject decisions after screening projects. Lenders may be either “too conservative,” in which case they reject positive‐NPV projects, or “too aggressive,” in which case they accept negative‐NPV projects. In the first case, the uniquely optimal security is debt. In the second case, it is levered equity. In equilibrium, profitable projects that are relatively likely to break even are financed with debt, while less profitable projects are financed with equity. Highly profitable projects are financed by uninformed arm's‐length lenders.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the optimal security design when lenders make inefficient accept or reject decisions after screening projects?
answer: The optimal security design depends on the type of lender inefficiency: debt is uniquely optimal when lenders are 'too conservative' (rejecting positive-NPV projects), while levered equity is optimal when lenders are 'too aggressive' (accepting negative-NPV projects). In equilibrium, profitable projects likely to break even use debt financing, less profitable projects use equity financing, and highly profitable projects are financed by uninformed arm's-length lenders.
positioning_statement: This paper examines security design in the context of informed lenders who make inefficient screening decisions, contributing to the literature by identifying how different types of lender bias (conservative vs. aggressive) lead to different optimal security structures.

author: Holger Mueller
title: Corporate Governance, Product Market Competition, and Equity Prices
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>This paper examines whether firms in noncompetitive industries benefit more from good governance than do firms in competitive industries. We find that weak governance firms have lower equity returns, worse operating performance, and lower firm value, but only in noncompetitive industries. When exploring the causes of the inefficiency, we find that weak governance firms have lower labor productivity and higher input costs, and make more value‐destroying acquisitions, but, again, only in noncompetitive industries. We also find that weak governance firms in noncompetitive industries are more likely to be targeted by activist hedge funds, suggesting that investors take actions to mitigate the inefficiency.</jats:p>
research_question: Do firms in noncompetitive industries benefit more from good governance than firms in competitive industries?
answer: Yes, weak governance firms have lower equity returns, worse operating performance, and lower firm value, but only in noncompetitive industries. The governance-performance relationship is significantly stronger for firms operating in less competitive product markets.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by examining the interaction between corporate governance and product market competition, showing that the benefits of good governance are conditional on the competitive environment rather than uniform across all firms.
