author: Holger Mueller
title: COVID-19 and Its Impact on Financial Markets and the Real Economy
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The COVID-19 pandemic severely disrupted financial markets and the real economy worldwide. These extraordinary events prompted large monetary and fiscal policy interventions. Recognizing the unusual nature of the shock, the academic community has produced an impressive amount of research during the last year. Macro-finance models have been extended to analyze the impact of epidemics. Empirical papers study the origins and consequences of the disruptions and the impact of policy interventions. New research evaluates the ongoing financial fragility and its relation to previous episodes and regulations. This special issue contains early contributions to this important and rapidly developing literature.1</jats:p>
research_question: What is the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on financial markets and the real economy?
answer: The COVID-19 pandemic severely disrupted financial markets and the real economy worldwide, prompting large monetary and fiscal policy interventions and creating ongoing financial fragility.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as contributing to a rapidly developing literature that has emerged in response to the extraordinary nature of the COVID-19 shock, building on macro-finance models extended to analyze epidemic impacts, empirical studies of disruptions and policy interventions, and research evaluating financial fragility in relation to previous episodes and regulations.

author: Holger Mueller
title: Legal Investor Protection and Takeovers
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>This paper examines the role of legal investor protection for the efficiency of the market for corporate control when bidders are financially constrained. In the model, stronger legal investor protection increases bidders' outside funding capacity. However, absent effective bidding competition, this does not improve efficiency, as the bid price, and thus bidders' need for funds, increases one‐for‐one with the pledgeable income. In contrast, under effective competition for the target, the increased outside funding capacity improves efficiency by making it less likely that more efficient but less wealthy bidders are outbid by less efficient but wealthier rivals.</jats:p>
research_question: How does legal investor protection affect the efficiency of the market for corporate control when bidders are financially constrained?
answer: Stronger legal investor protection improves takeover efficiency only when there is effective bidding competition, as it enables more efficient but less wealthy bidders to compete against wealthier but less efficient rivals; without competition, stronger protection does not improve efficiency because bid prices increase proportionally with pledgeable income.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by examining the interaction between legal investor protection and takeover efficiency specifically in the context of financially constrained bidders, showing that the benefits of stronger legal protection are conditional on the presence of effective bidding competition.

author: Hülya Eraslan
title: Invoicing currency, exchange rate pass‐through, and value‐added trade: The case of Turkey
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We explore the role of invoicing currency and global production integration in the effect of exchange rate pass‐through on import and export prices. We use 3‐digit product‐level data classified by end use and 2‐digit sector‐level data displaying varying integration with global value chains from an emerging country, Turkey. Overall, pass‐through rate significantly affects both export and import prices. Contrary to the literature, pass‐through is significantly higher for local currency‐priced goods. The relative rate of pass‐through to the U.S. dollar and euro‐priced goods is determined by the type of products and value‐added trade. Stronger integration with global value chains and the use of a vehicle currency tend to smooth out the response of domestic prices to changes in exchange rates.</jats:p>
research_question: How do invoicing currency and global production integration affect exchange rate pass-through on import and export prices?
answer: Pass-through rates significantly affect both export and import prices, with surprisingly higher pass-through for local currency-priced goods (contrary to existing literature). The relative pass-through rates to U.S. dollar and euro-priced goods depend on product type and value-added trade, while stronger global value chain integration and vehicle currency use tend to smooth domestic price responses to exchange rate changes.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges existing literature by finding that pass-through is significantly higher for local currency-priced goods, contrary to conventional findings, and extends the analysis by examining the role of global value chain integration in exchange rate pass-through effects.

author: Igor Makarov
title: Informational Black Holes in Financial Markets
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We show that information aggregation in primary financial markets fails precisely when investors hold socially useful information for screening projects. Being wary of the Winner's Curse, less optimistic investors refrain from making financing offers, since their offers would be accepted only when a project is unviable. Their information is therefore lost. The Winner's Curse and associated information loss grow with the number of informed market participants, so that larger markets can lead to worse financing decisions and higher cost of capital for firms seeking financing. Precommitment to ration fundraising allocations, collusive club bidding, and shorting markets can mitigate the inefficiency.</jats:p>
research_question: How does information aggregation work in primary financial markets when investors hold socially useful information for screening projects?
answer: Information aggregation in primary financial markets fails when investors hold socially useful information for screening projects because less optimistic investors refrain from making financing offers due to the Winner's Curse, causing their information to be lost and leading to worse financing decisions and higher cost of capital in larger markets.
positioning_statement: This paper identifies a fundamental failure in information aggregation in primary financial markets, showing that contrary to conventional wisdom, larger markets with more informed participants can lead to worse outcomes due to the Winner's Curse effect, and proposes specific mechanisms to mitigate this inefficiency.

author: Igor Makarov
title: Equilibrium Subprime Lending
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>This paper develops an equilibrium model of a subprime mortgage market. Our goal is to offer a benchmark with which the recent subprime boom and bust can be compared. The model is tractable and delivers plausible orders of magnitude for borrowing capacities, as well as default and trading intensities. We offer simple explanations for several phenomena in the subprime market, such as the prevalence of teaser rates and the clustering of defaults. In our model, both nondiversifiable and diversifiable income risks reduce debt capacities. Thus, debt capacities need not be higher when a larger fraction of income risk is diversifiable.</jats:p>
research_question: How can we develop an equilibrium model to understand the functioning of subprime mortgage markets and provide a benchmark for analyzing the recent subprime boom and bust?
answer: The paper develops a tractable equilibrium model that delivers plausible magnitudes for borrowing capacities, default rates, and trading intensities, and provides simple explanations for key subprime market phenomena like teaser rates and clustered defaults. A key finding is that both nondiversifiable and diversifiable income risks reduce debt capacities, meaning that debt capacities are not necessarily higher when more income risk is diversifiable.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as providing a foundational benchmark model for understanding subprime mortgage markets, offering a theoretical framework to compare against the observed subprime boom and bust cycle that had occurred.

author: Itamar Drechsler
title: Uncertainty, Time‐Varying Fear, and Asset Prices
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>I construct an equilibrium model that captures salient properties of index option prices, equity returns, variance, and the risk‐free rate. A representative investor makes consumption and portfolio choice decisions that are robust to his uncertainty about the true economic model. He pays a large premium for index options because they hedge important model misspecification concerns, particularly concerning jump shocks to cash flow growth and volatility. A calibration shows that empirically consistent fundamentals and reasonable model uncertainty explain option prices and the variance premium. Time variation in uncertainty generates variance premium fluctuations, helping explain their power to predict stock returns.</jats:p>
research_question: How can uncertainty and time-varying fear explain the salient properties of index option prices, equity returns, variance, and the risk-free rate?
answer: A representative investor who makes decisions robust to model uncertainty pays large premiums for index options because they hedge against model misspecification concerns, particularly regarding jump shocks to cash flow growth and volatility. Time variation in uncertainty generates variance premium fluctuations that help explain their power to predict stock returns.
positioning_statement: This paper constructs an equilibrium model that incorporates model uncertainty and robust decision-making to explain option pricing anomalies and variance premium puzzles that existing literature has struggled to address comprehensively.

author: Itamar Drechsler
title: Banking on Deposits: Maturity Transformation without Interest Rate Risk
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We show that maturity transformation does not expose banks to interest rate risk—it hedges it. The reason is the deposit franchise, which allows banks to pay deposit rates that are low and insensitive to market interest rates. Hedging the deposit franchise requires banks to earn income that is also insensitive, that is, to lend long term at fixed rates. As predicted by this theory, we show that banks closely match the interest rate sensitivities of their interest income and expense, and that this insulates their equity from interest rate shocks. Our results explain why banks supply long‐term credit.</jats:p>
research_question: Why do banks engage in maturity transformation and how does it affect their exposure to interest rate risk?
answer: Maturity transformation does not expose banks to interest rate risk but actually hedges it, because banks use their deposit franchise (which provides low, interest-rate-insensitive funding) to match the interest rate sensitivities of their income and expenses, thereby insulating their equity from interest rate shocks.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the conventional view that maturity transformation exposes banks to interest rate risk, instead arguing that it serves as a hedging mechanism due to the unique properties of the deposit franchise that allows banks to pay rates that are low and insensitive to market rates.

author: Igor Makarov
title: Rewarding Trading Skills without Inducing Gambling
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>This paper develops a model of active asset management in which fund managers may forgo alpha‐generating strategies, preferring instead to make negative‐alpha trades that enable them to temporarily manipulate investors' perceptions of their skills. We show that such trades are optimally generated by taking on hidden tail risk, and are more likely to occur when fund managers are impatient and when their trading skills are scalable, and generate a high profit per unit of risk. We propose long‐term contracts that deter this behavior by dynamically adjusting the dates on which the manager is compensated in response to her cumulative performance.</jats:p>
research_question: How can compensation contracts for fund managers be designed to reward genuine trading skills while preventing them from engaging in negative-alpha trades that manipulate investor perceptions through hidden tail risk?
answer: Long-term contracts that dynamically adjust compensation dates based on the manager's cumulative performance can effectively deter skill manipulation behavior, particularly when managers are impatient or have scalable trading skills that generate high profit per unit of risk.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the active asset management literature by developing a novel model that explains why fund managers may rationally choose negative-alpha trades to manipulate skill perceptions, and proposes a contractual solution to align manager incentives with genuine alpha generation rather than gambling behavior.

author: Itamar Drechsler
title: Who Borrows from the Lender of Last Resort?
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We analyze lender of last resort (LOLR) lending during the European sovereign debt crisis. Using a novel data set on all central bank lending and collateral, we show that weakly capitalized banks took out more LOLR loans and used riskier collateral than strongly capitalized banks. We also find that weakly capitalized banks used LOLR loans to buy risky assets such as distressed sovereign debt. This resulted in a reallocation of risky assets from strongly to weakly capitalized banks. Our findings cannot be explained by classical LOLR theory. Rather, they point to risk taking by banks, both independently and with the encouragement of governments, and highlight the benefit of unifying LOLR lending and bank supervision.</jats:p>
research_question: Who borrows from the lender of last resort and how do they use these loans?
answer: Weakly capitalized banks borrowed more from the lender of last resort, used riskier collateral, and used these loans to purchase risky assets like distressed sovereign debt, resulting in a reallocation of risky assets from strongly to weakly capitalized banks.
positioning_statement: The findings cannot be explained by classical lender of last resort theory, instead revealing risk-taking behavior by banks that challenges existing theoretical frameworks and highlights the need for unifying LOLR lending with bank supervision.

author: Itamar Drechsler
title: A Pyrrhic Victory? Bank Bailouts and Sovereign Credit Risk
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We model a loop between sovereign and bank credit risk. A distressed financial sector induces government bailouts, whose cost increases sovereign credit risk. Increased sovereign credit risk in turn weakens the financial sector by eroding the value of its government guarantees and bond holdings. Using credit default swap (CDS) rates on European sovereigns and banks, we show that bailouts triggered the rise of sovereign credit risk in 2008. We document that post‐bailout changes in sovereign CDS explain changes in bank CDS even after controlling for aggregate and bank‐level determinants of credit spreads, confirming the sovereign‐bank loop.</jats:p>
research_question: How do bank bailouts affect sovereign credit risk, and is there a feedback loop between sovereign and bank credit risk?
answer: Bank bailouts triggered the rise of sovereign credit risk in 2008, creating a feedback loop where increased sovereign credit risk weakens the financial sector by eroding the value of government guarantees and bond holdings, with post-bailout changes in sovereign CDS explaining changes in bank CDS.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by modeling and empirically documenting the bidirectional feedback loop between sovereign and bank credit risk, specifically showing how government bailouts of distressed financial sectors can increase sovereign credit risk, which then feeds back to weaken the banking sector.

author: Itamar Drechsler
title: A Model of Monetary Policy and Risk Premia
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We develop a dynamic asset pricing model in which monetary policy affects the risk premium component of the cost of capital. Risk‐tolerant agents (banks) borrow from risk‐averse agents (i.e., take deposits) to fund levered investments. Leverage exposes banks to funding risk, which they insure by holding liquidity buffers. By changing the nominal rate the central bank influences the liquidity premium, and hence the cost of taking leverage. Lower nominal rates make liquidity cheaper and raise leverage, resulting in lower risk premia and higher asset prices, volatility, investment, and growth. We analyze forward guidance, a “Greenspan put,” and the yield curve.</jats:p>
research_question: How does monetary policy affect the risk premium component of the cost of capital through its impact on bank leverage and liquidity decisions?
answer: Lower nominal interest rates reduce the cost of liquidity, which encourages banks to increase leverage, resulting in lower risk premia and higher asset prices, volatility, investment, and growth. The central bank influences risk premia by changing the liquidity premium through the nominal rate, which affects banks' cost of taking leverage.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a new dynamic asset pricing model that explicitly links monetary policy to risk premia through a banking sector mechanism involving leverage and liquidity buffers, extending beyond traditional models to analyze specific monetary policy tools like forward guidance and the 'Greenspan put.'

author: Jack Bao
title: The Illiquidity of Corporate Bonds
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>This paper examines the illiquidity of corporate bonds and its asset‐pricing implications. Using transactions data from 2003 to 2009, we show that the illiquidity in corporate bonds is substantial, significantly greater than what can be explained by bid–ask spreads. We establish a strong link between bond illiquidity and bond prices. In aggregate, changes in market‐level illiquidity explain a substantial part of the time variation in yield spreads of high‐rated (AAA through A) bonds, overshadowing the credit risk component. In the cross‐section, the bond‐level illiquidity measure explains individual bond yield spreads with large economic significance.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the extent of illiquidity in corporate bonds and how does it affect bond pricing?
answer: Corporate bond illiquidity is substantial and significantly greater than what bid-ask spreads can explain. Bond illiquidity has a strong link to bond prices, with market-level illiquidity changes explaining a substantial part of yield spread time variation in high-rated bonds (overshadowing credit risk), and bond-level illiquidity explaining individual bond yield spreads with large economic significance.
positioning_statement: This paper provides empirical evidence using transactions data from 2003 to 2009 to quantify corporate bond illiquidity and establish its asset-pricing implications, demonstrating that illiquidity effects are more substantial than previously captured by traditional bid-ask spread measures and showing that illiquidity can overshadow credit risk in explaining yield spreads for high-rated bonds.

author: Jacob Sagi
title: Asset-Level Risk and Return in Real Estate Investments
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>In stark contrast with liquid asset returns, commercial real estate idiosyncratic return means and variances do not scale with the holding period, even after accounting for all cash flow-relevant events. This puzzling phenomenon survives controlling for vintage effects, systematic risk heterogeneity, and a host of other explanations. To explain the findings, I derive an equilibrium search-based asset-pricing model that, when calibrated, provides an excellent fit to transactions data. A structural model of transaction risk seems crucial to understanding real estate price dynamics. These insights extend to other highly illiquid asset classes, such as private equity and residential real estate.</jats:p>
research_question: Why do commercial real estate idiosyncratic return means and variances not scale with holding period, unlike liquid asset returns?
answer: A structural model of transaction risk based on equilibrium search-based asset pricing explains this phenomenon - the illiquid nature of real estate markets creates pricing dynamics that differ fundamentally from liquid assets.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a puzzling phenomenon in real estate returns that contrasts starkly with liquid asset behavior, and extends insights to other highly illiquid asset classes like private equity and residential real estate, filling a gap in understanding illiquid asset pricing dynamics.

author: Jacob Sagi
title: Estimating Oil Risk Factors Using Information from Equity and Derivatives Markets
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We introduce a novel approach to estimating latent oil risk factors and establish their significance in pricing nonoil securities. Our model, which features four factors with simple economic interpretations, is estimated using both derivative prices and oil‐related equity returns. The fit is excellent in and out of sample. The extracted oil factors carry significant risk premia, and are significantly related to macroeconomic variables as well as portfolio returns sorted on characteristics and industry. The average nonoil portfolio exhibits a sensitivity to the oil factors amounting to a sixth (in magnitude) of that of the oil industry itself.</jats:p>
research_question: How can latent oil risk factors be estimated and what is their significance in pricing nonoil securities?
answer: The paper develops a four-factor model with simple economic interpretations that successfully estimates oil risk factors using derivative prices and oil-related equity returns, finding that these factors carry significant risk premia and affect nonoil securities with sensitivity averaging one-sixth that of the oil industry itself.
positioning_statement: The paper introduces a novel approach to estimating latent oil risk factors by combining information from both equity and derivatives markets, establishing the broader significance of oil factors beyond just oil-related securities to include nonoil portfolio pricing.

author: James Choi
title: What Matters to Individual Investors? Evidence from the Horse's Mouth
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We survey a representative sample of U.S. individuals about how well leading academic theories describe their financial beliefs and decisions. We find substantial support for many factors hypothesized to affect portfolio equity share, particularly background risk, investment horizon, rare disasters, transactional factors, and fixed costs of stock market participation. Individuals tend to believe that past mutual fund performance is a good signal of stock‐picking skill, actively managed funds do not suffer from diseconomies of scale, value stocks are safer and do not have higher expected returns, and high‐momentum stocks are riskier and do have higher expected returns.</jats:p>
research_question: How well do leading academic theories describe individual investors' financial beliefs and decisions?
answer: Individual investors show substantial support for many academic theories affecting portfolio equity share (background risk, investment horizon, rare disasters, transactional factors, and fixed costs), but hold beliefs that contradict some academic findings - they believe past mutual fund performance predicts skill, actively managed funds don't suffer from diseconomies of scale, value stocks are safer without higher expected returns, and high-momentum stocks are riskier but have higher expected returns.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as directly testing academic theories by surveying individual investors themselves ('from the horse's mouth'), providing empirical evidence of which theoretical factors resonate with actual investor beliefs and decision-making processes.

author: James Choi
title: Reinforcement Learning and Savings Behavior
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We show that individual investors over‐extrapolate from their personal experience when making savings decisions. Investors who experience particularly rewarding outcomes from 401(k) saving—a high average and/or low variance return—increase their 401(k) savings rate more than investors who have less rewarding experiences. This finding is not driven by aggregate time‐series shocks, income effects, rational learning about investing skill, investor fixed effects, or time‐varying investor‐level heterogeneity that is correlated with portfolio allocations to stock, bond, and cash asset classes. We discuss implications for the equity premium puzzle and interventions aimed at improving household financial outcomes.</jats:p>
research_question: Do individual investors over-extrapolate from their personal experience when making savings decisions, specifically regarding how rewarding outcomes from 401(k) saving affect future savings behavior?
answer: Yes, individual investors over-extrapolate from personal experience - those who experience particularly rewarding outcomes from 401(k) saving (high average and/or low variance returns) increase their 401(k) savings rate more than investors with less rewarding experiences, and this effect persists after controlling for various alternative explanations.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on behavioral finance and household savings by providing evidence of reinforcement learning in savings decisions, with implications for understanding the equity premium puzzle and designing interventions to improve household financial outcomes.

author: James Choi
title: Why Does the Law of One Price Fail? An Experiment on Index Mutual Funds
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We evaluate why individuals invest in high-fee index funds. In our experiments, subjects each allocate $10,000 across four S&P 500 index funds and are rewarded for their portfolio's subsequent return. Subjects overwhelmingly fail to minimize fees. We reject the hypothesis that subjects buy high-fee index funds because of bundled nonportfolio services. Search costs for fees matter, but even when we eliminate these costs, fees are not minimized. Instead, subjects place high weight on annualized returns since inception. Fees paid decrease with financial literacy. Interestingly, subjects who choose high-fee funds sense they are making a mistake.</jats:p>
research_question: Why do individuals invest in high-fee index funds when economically rational behavior would suggest minimizing fees?
answer: Individuals fail to minimize fees primarily because they place high weight on annualized returns since inception rather than focusing on fees, even when search costs are eliminated. Financial literacy reduces fees paid, and those choosing high-fee funds often sense they are making a mistake.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the puzzle of why the law of one price fails in index mutual funds by conducting controlled experiments to test specific hypotheses about investor behavior, rejecting explanations based on bundled services and search costs while identifying the role of return salience and financial literacy.

author: Janet Gao
title: Credit and Punishment: Are Corporate Bankers Disciplined for Risk-Taking?
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We examine whether bankers face disciplining consequences for structuring poorly performing corporate loans. We construct a novel data set containing the employment histories and loan portfolios of a large sample of corporate bankers and find that corporate credit events (i.e., downgrades, defaults, bankruptcies) increase banker turnover. The effect is pronounced when bankers issue loans with loose terms or experience severe losses. Credit events prompt bankers to adopt stricter future risk management practices, such as offering restrictive covenant packages. Overall, our findings are consistent with banks disciplining employees as a means to manage their own risk exposure.</jats:p>
research_question: Do corporate bankers face disciplining consequences for structuring poorly performing corporate loans?
answer: Yes, corporate bankers are disciplined for risk-taking - credit events (downgrades, defaults, bankruptcies) increase banker turnover, especially when bankers issue loans with loose terms or experience severe losses, and surviving bankers adopt stricter future risk management practices.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes novel empirical evidence on banker-level discipline by constructing a unique dataset of employment histories and loan portfolios to examine how banks manage risk exposure through employee discipline, addressing a gap in understanding individual banker accountability for loan performance.

author: Janet Gao
title: Human Capital Portability and Careers in Finance
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>How does firm-specific human capital shape careers in the finance industry? We build a dynamic model where workers accumulate portable and nonportable (firm-specific) human capital and learn about their match quality with employers. Estimating the model using granular data on M&A advisory bankers, we show that a large fraction of bankers’ human capital is nonportable, ranging from 12% to 46% across different firm types. Bankers make a dynamic trade-off between portability and returns on human capital, leading to time-varying job preferences over their life cycle. Our results have broad implications for careers in finance and the provision of financial services.</jats:p>
research_question: How does firm-specific human capital shape careers in the finance industry?
answer: A large fraction of bankers' human capital is nonportable (ranging from 12% to 46% across different firm types), and bankers make a dynamic trade-off between portability and returns on human capital, leading to time-varying job preferences over their life cycle.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on human capital and careers in finance by building a dynamic model that distinguishes between portable and nonportable human capital and examining how workers learn about their match quality with employers, using granular data on M&A advisory bankers to provide empirical evidence on the extent and implications of firm-specific human capital in finance careers.

author: Jason Donaldson
title: Conflicting Priorities: A Theory of Covenants and Collateral
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We develop a theory of secured debt, unsecured debt, and debt with anti‐dilution covenants. We assume that, as in practice, covenants convey the right to accelerate if violated, but the new secured debt retains its priority even if issued in violation of covenants. We find that such covenants are nonetheless useful: They provide state‐contingent financing flexibility, balancing over‐ and underinvestment incentives. The optimal debt structure is multilayered, combining secured and unsecured debt with and without covenants. Our results are consistent with observations about debt structure, covenant violations, and waivers. They speak to a policy debate about debt priority.</jats:p>
research_question: How do anti-dilution covenants interact with secured and unsecured debt to create optimal debt structures, given that covenants allow acceleration when violated but new secured debt retains priority even when issued in violation of covenants?
answer: Anti-dilution covenants are useful because they provide state-contingent financing flexibility that balances over- and underinvestment incentives, and the optimal debt structure is multilayered, combining secured and unsecured debt both with and without covenants.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a new theory that explains the coexistence and interaction of secured debt, unsecured debt, and debt with anti-dilution covenants, addressing observations about debt structure, covenant violations, and waivers while contributing to policy debates about debt priority.

author: Jason Donaldson
title: Household Debt Overhang and Unemployment
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We use a labor‐search model to explain why the worst employment slumps often follow expansions of household debt. We find that households protected by limited liability suffer from a household‐debt‐overhang problem that leads them to require high wages to work. Firms respond by posting high wages but few vacancies. This <jats:italic>vacancy posting effect</jats:italic> implies that high household debt leads to high unemployment. Even though households borrow from banks via bilaterally optimal contracts, the equilibrium level of household debt is inefficiently high due to a <jats:italic>household‐debt externality</jats:italic>. We analyze the role that a financial regulator can play in mitigating this externality.</jats:p>
research_question: Why do the worst employment slumps often follow expansions of household debt?
answer: Households protected by limited liability suffer from a debt-overhang problem that leads them to require high wages to work, causing firms to post high wages but few vacancies (vacancy posting effect), which results in high unemployment. The equilibrium level of household debt is inefficiently high due to a household-debt externality.
positioning_statement: This paper uses a labor-search model to provide a novel theoretical explanation for the empirical observation that severe employment downturns follow household debt expansions, identifying a previously unrecognized household-debt externality that makes equilibrium debt levels inefficiently high despite bilaterally optimal contracts between households and banks.

author: Janet Gao
title: Sustainability or Greenwashing: Evidence from the Asset Market for Industrial Pollution
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We study the asset market for pollutive plants. Firms divest pollutive plants in response to environmental pressures. Buyers are firms facing weaker environmental pressures that have supply chain relationships or joint ventures with the sellers. While pollution levels do not decline following divestitures, sellers highlight their sustainable policies in subsequent conference calls, earn higher returns as they sell more pollutive plants, and benefit from higher Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) ratings and lower compliance costs. Overall, the asset market allows firms to redraw their boundaries in a manner perceived as environmentally friendly without real consequences for pollution but with substantial gains from trade.</jats:p>
research_question: How does the asset market for pollutive plants function, and does the divestiture of these plants by firms lead to actual environmental improvements or merely create an appearance of sustainability?
answer: The asset market allows firms to divest pollutive plants to buyers with weaker environmental pressures (often supply chain partners), creating substantial gains from trade and improved ESG perceptions for sellers, but without actually reducing pollution levels - constituting greenwashing rather than genuine sustainability.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on corporate environmental responsibility and greenwashing by providing novel evidence on how asset markets facilitate the appearance of sustainability without environmental substance, revealing a previously understudied mechanism through which firms can gain ESG benefits while pollution persists through strategic plant ownership transfers.

author: Jason Donaldson
title: Deadlock on the Board
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We develop a dynamic model of board decision-making akin to dynamic voting models in the political economy literature. We show a board could retain a policy all directors agree is worse than an available alternative. Thus, directors may retain a CEO they agree is bad—deadlocked boards lead to entrenched CEOs. We explore how to compose boards and appoint directors to mitigate deadlock. We find board diversity and long director tenure can exacerbate deadlock. We rationalize why CEOs and incumbent directors have power to appoint new directors: to avoid deadlock. Our model speaks to short-termism, staggered boards, and proxy access.</jats:p>
research_question: How can board decision-making processes lead to suboptimal outcomes where directors retain policies or CEOs they agree are inferior to available alternatives?
answer: Boards can become deadlocked and retain policies all directors agree are worse than available alternatives, leading to CEO entrenchment even when all directors agree the CEO is bad. Board diversity and long director tenure can exacerbate this deadlock problem.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a dynamic model of board decision-making that draws from dynamic voting models in the political economy literature, extending these concepts to corporate governance to explain board deadlock and CEO entrenchment phenomena.

author: Jason Donaldson
title: The paradox of pledgeability

author: Jason Donaldson
title: Intermediation Variety
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We explain why banks and nonbank intermediaries coexist in a model based only on differences in their funding costs. Banks enjoy a low cost of capital due to safety nets and money‐like liabilities. We show that this can actually be a disadvantage: it generates a soft‐budget‐constraint problem that makes it difficult for banks to credibly threaten to withhold additional funding to failed projects. Nonbanks emerge to solve this problem. Their high cost of capital is an advantage: it allows them to commit to terminate funding. Still, nonbanks never take over the entire market, but other coexist with banks in equilibrium.</jats:p>
research_question: Why do banks and nonbank intermediaries coexist in financial markets?
answer: Banks and nonbank intermediaries coexist because their different funding costs create complementary advantages: banks' low cost of capital (due to safety nets and money-like liabilities) creates a soft-budget-constraint problem that makes it difficult for them to credibly threaten to withhold funding from failed projects, while nonbanks' high cost of capital allows them to commit to terminate funding, solving this credibility problem.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a novel explanation for the coexistence of banks and nonbank intermediaries based solely on differences in their funding costs, offering a new theoretical framework that shows how banks' traditional funding advantage can actually be a disadvantage in certain contexts.

author: Jessica Wachter
title: Can Time‐Varying Risk of Rare Disasters Explain Aggregate Stock Market Volatility?
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Why is the equity premium so high, and why are stocks so volatile? Why are stock returns in excess of government bill rates predictable? This paper proposes an answer to these questions based on a time‐varying probability of a consumption disaster. In the model, aggregate consumption follows a normal distribution with low volatility most of the time, but with some probability of a consumption realization far out in the left tail. The possibility of this poor outcome substantially increases the equity premium, while time‐variation in the probability of this outcome drives high stock market volatility and excess return predictability.</jats:p>
research_question: Why is the equity premium so high, why are stocks so volatile, and why are stock returns in excess of government bill rates predictable?
answer: A time-varying probability of a consumption disaster can explain these phenomena - the possibility of rare but severe consumption outcomes substantially increases the equity premium, while time-variation in the probability of these disasters drives high stock market volatility and excess return predictability.
positioning_statement: This paper proposes a novel explanation for well-known financial market puzzles (high equity premium, stock volatility, and return predictability) by introducing a model based on time-varying disaster risk, offering an alternative to existing theories that struggle to simultaneously explain these empirical regularities.

author: Jean-François Houde
title: The Role of Intermediaries in Selection Markets: Evidence from Mortgage Lending
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We study the role of brokers in selection markets. We find broker-clients in the Canadian mortgage market are observationally different from branch-clients. They finance larger loans with more leverage and longer amortization. We build and estimate a model of mortgage demand to disentangle three possible explanations for these riskier product choices: (1) selection on observables, (2) unobserved borrower preferences for riskier loans, and (3) a causal effect of brokers. Although we find that brokers influence product choices, the main reason borrowers choose high-leverage products is unobserved preferences. Borrowers prefer larger loans and brokers facilitate qualification for them.</jats:p>
research_question: What role do brokers play in selection markets, specifically in explaining why broker-clients choose riskier mortgage products compared to branch-clients?
answer: While brokers do causally influence product choices, the main driver of borrowers choosing high-leverage mortgage products is unobserved borrower preferences for riskier loans. Brokers primarily facilitate qualification for the larger loans that borrowers already prefer.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on selection markets by developing a structural model to disentangle three competing explanations (selection on observables, unobserved preferences, and causal broker effects) for observed differences in mortgage product choices between broker-clients and branch-clients.

author: Jessica Wachter
title: Does the Failure of the Expectations Hypothesis Matter for Long‐Term Investors?
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We solve the portfolio problem of a long‐run investor when the term structure is Gaussian and when the investor has access to nominal bonds and stock. We apply our method to a three‐factor model that captures the failure of the expectations hypothesis. We extend this model to account for time‐varying expected inflation, and estimate the model with both inflation and term structure data. The estimates imply that the bond portfolio of a long‐run investor looks very different from the portfolio of a mean‐variance optimizer. In particular, time‐varying term premia generate large hedging demands for long‐term bonds.</jats:p>
research_question: Does the failure of the expectations hypothesis matter for the portfolio decisions of long-term investors?
answer: Yes, the failure of the expectations hypothesis significantly matters for long-term investors. The bond portfolio of a long-run investor looks very different from a mean-variance optimizer's portfolio, with time-varying term premia generating large hedging demands for long-term bonds.
positioning_statement: This paper extends existing literature by solving the portfolio problem for long-run investors using a three-factor model that captures the failure of the expectations hypothesis, and further extends this model to account for time-varying expected inflation, estimated with both inflation and term structure data.

author: Jessica Wachter
title: Do Rare Events Explain CDX Tranche Spreads?
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We investigate whether a model with time‐varying probability of economic disaster can explain prices of collateralized debt obligations. We focus on senior tranches of the CDX, an index of credit default swaps on investment grade firms. These assets do not incur losses until a large fraction of previously stable firms default, and thus are deep out‐of‐the money put options on the overall economy. When calibrated to consumption data and to the equity premium, the model explains the spreads on CDX tranches prior to and during the 2008 to 2009 crisis.</jats:p>
research_question: Can a model with time-varying probability of economic disaster explain prices of collateralized debt obligations, specifically senior tranches of the CDX index?
answer: Yes, when calibrated to consumption data and the equity premium, the rare events model successfully explains CDX tranche spreads both prior to and during the 2008-2009 financial crisis.
positioning_statement: This paper applies rare events/disaster risk modeling to credit derivatives pricing, specifically focusing on senior CDX tranches as deep out-of-the-money put options on the overall economy that only incur losses when a large fraction of previously stable firms default.

author: Jessica Wachter
title: A Model of Two Days: Discrete News and Asset Prices
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Empirical studies demonstrate striking patterns in stock returns related to scheduled macroeconomic announcements. A large proportion of the total equity premium is realized on days with macroeconomic announcements. The relation between market betas and expected returns is far stronger on announcement days as compared with nonannouncement days. Finally, these results hold for fixed-income investments as well as for stocks. We present a model in which agents learn the probability of an adverse economic state on announcement days. We show that the model quantitatively accounts for the empirical findings. Evidence from options data provides support for the model’s mechanism.</jats:p>
research_question: How can we explain the striking empirical patterns in stock returns related to scheduled macroeconomic announcements, including the concentration of equity premium on announcement days and the stronger relationship between market betas and expected returns on these days?
answer: A model where agents learn about the probability of adverse economic states on announcement days can quantitatively account for the observed empirical patterns in asset returns around macroeconomic announcements.
positioning_statement: This paper builds on existing empirical studies that have documented striking patterns in stock returns around scheduled macroeconomic announcements, and provides a theoretical model to explain these previously observed but unexplained phenomena, with the model's mechanism supported by options data evidence.

author: Jessica Wachter
title: Maximum likelihood estimation of the equity premium

author: Jessica Wachter
title: Why Is Long‐Horizon Equity Less Risky? A Duration‐Based Explanation of the Value Premium
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We propose a dynamic risk‐based model that captures the value premium. Firms are modeled as long‐lived assets distinguished by the timing of cash flows. The stochastic discount factor is specified so that shocks to aggregate dividends are priced, but shocks to the discount rate are not. The model implies that growth firms covary more with the discount rate than do value firms, which covary more with cash flows. When calibrated to explain aggregate stock market behavior, the model accounts for the observed value premium, the high Sharpe ratios on value firms, and the poor performance of the CAPM.</jats:p>
research_question: Why do value stocks outperform growth stocks (the value premium) and why is long-horizon equity less risky?
answer: The value premium exists because growth firms covary more with discount rate shocks (which are not priced) while value firms covary more with cash flow shocks (which are priced), making value firms appear less risky despite their higher returns when viewed through a duration-based lens.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a new risk-based explanation for the value premium using a dynamic model that distinguishes firms by cash flow timing, offering an alternative to existing explanations and addressing the CAPM's poor performance in explaining cross-sectional return differences.

author: Jessica Wachter
title: Should Investors Avoid All Actively Managed Mutual Funds? A Study in Bayesian Performance Evaluation
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>This paper analyzes mutual‐fund performance from an investor's perspective. We study the portfolio‐choice problem for a mean‐variance investor choosing among a risk‐free asset, index funds, and actively managed mutual funds. To solve this problem, we employ a Bayesian method of performance evaluation; a key innovation in our approach is the development of a flexible set of prior beliefs about managerial skill. We then apply our methodology to a sample of 1,437 mutual funds. We find that some extremely skeptical prior beliefs nevertheless lead to economically significant allocations to active managers.</jats:p>
research_question: Should investors avoid all actively managed mutual funds, and how should investors optimally allocate their portfolios among risk-free assets, index funds, and actively managed mutual funds?
answer: No, investors should not avoid all actively managed mutual funds. Even with extremely skeptical prior beliefs about managerial skill, the Bayesian analysis shows that economically significant allocations to active managers can be justified.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as providing a novel investor-centric perspective on mutual fund performance evaluation by developing a Bayesian methodology with flexible prior beliefs about managerial skill, contrasting with traditional performance evaluation approaches that may not adequately account for investor decision-making under uncertainty.

title: The Declining Equity Premium: What Role Does Macroeconomic Risk Play?

author: Jessica Wachter
title: Is the United States a Lucky Survivor? A Hierarchical Bayesian Approach
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Using international data, we quantify the magnitude of survivorship bias in U.S. equity market performance, finding that it explains about one‐third of the equity risk premium in the past century. We model the subjective crash belief of an investor who infers the crash risk in the United States by cross‐learning from other countries. The U.S. crash probability shows a persistent and widening divergence from the implied global average. We attribute the upward bias in the measured equity premium to crashes that did not occur in‐sample and to shocks to valuations resulting from learning about the probability.</jats:p>
research_question: How much of the U.S. equity risk premium can be attributed to survivorship bias, and what is the magnitude of this bias when accounting for crashes that occurred in other countries but not in the United States?
answer: Survivorship bias explains about one-third of the U.S. equity risk premium over the past century, with the upward bias in the measured equity premium attributed to crashes that did not occur in the U.S. sample and to valuation shocks from learning about crash probabilities through cross-country evidence.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by using a hierarchical Bayesian approach with international data to quantify survivorship bias in U.S. equity markets, modeling how investors update their crash beliefs by learning from other countries' experiences, and showing a persistent divergence between U.S. crash probability and the global average.

author: Jianfeng Yu
title: Technological Growth and Asset Pricing
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We study the asset‐pricing implications of technological growth in a model with “small,” disembodied productivity shocks and “large,” infrequent technological innovations, which are embodied into new capital vintages. The technological‐adoption process leads to endogenous cycles in output and asset valuations. This process can help explain stylized asset‐valuation patterns around major technological innovations. More importantly, it can help provide a unified, investment‐based theory for numerous well‐documented facts related to excess‐return predictability. To illustrate the distinguishing features of our theory, we highlight novel implications pertaining to the joint time‐series properties of consumption and excess returns.</jats:p>
research_question: How do technological innovations, particularly large and infrequent technological advances embodied in new capital vintages, affect asset pricing and excess return predictability?
answer: The technological adoption process creates endogenous cycles in output and asset valuations that can explain stylized asset-valuation patterns around major technological innovations and provide a unified, investment-based theory for well-documented excess-return predictability facts.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a unified, investment-based theory that can explain numerous well-documented facts related to excess-return predictability, distinguishing itself by focusing on the joint time-series properties of consumption and excess returns in the context of technological growth cycles.

author: Jianfeng Yu
title: Arbitrage Asymmetry and the Idiosyncratic Volatility Puzzle
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Buying is easier than shorting for many equity investors. Combining this arbitrage asymmetry with the arbitrage risk represented by idiosyncratic volatility (IVOL) explains the negative relation between IVOL and average return. The IVOL‐return relation is negative among overpriced stocks but positive among underpriced stocks, with mispricing determined by combining 11 return anomalies. Consistent with arbitrage asymmetry, the negative relation among overpriced stocks is stronger, especially for stocks less easily shorted, so the overall IVOL‐return relation is negative. Further supporting our explanation, high investor sentiment weakens the positive relation among underpriced stocks and, especially, strengthens the negative relation among overpriced stocks.</jats:p>
research_question: Why is there a negative relation between idiosyncratic volatility (IVOL) and average stock returns?
answer: The negative IVOL-return relation is explained by arbitrage asymmetry (buying is easier than shorting) combined with arbitrage risk from idiosyncratic volatility. The relation is negative among overpriced stocks but positive among underpriced stocks, with the negative relation being stronger, resulting in an overall negative IVOL-return relationship.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a new explanation for the established 'idiosyncratic volatility puzzle' by introducing the concept of arbitrage asymmetry and demonstrating how it interacts with mispricing and investor sentiment to explain the previously puzzling negative relationship between idiosyncratic volatility and returns.

author: Jianfeng Yu
title: Impediments to Financial Trade: Theory and Applications
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We propose a tractable model of an informationally inefficient market featuring nonrevealing prices, general preferences and payoff distributions, but not noise traders. We show the equivalence between our model and a substantially simpler one in which investors face distortionary investment taxes depending on both their identity and the asset class. This equivalence allows us to account for such phenomena as underdiversification. We further employ the model to assess approaches to performance evaluation and find that it provides a theoretical basis for some intuitive practices, such as style analysis, that have been adopted by finance professionals.</jats:p>
               <jats:p>Authors have furnished an Internet Appendix, which is available on the Oxford University Press Web site next to the link to the final published paper online.</jats:p>
research_question: How can we model informationally inefficient markets with nonrevealing prices without relying on noise traders, and what are the implications for financial phenomena and performance evaluation?
answer: The paper develops a tractable model of informationally inefficient markets that is equivalent to a simpler model where investors face distortionary investment taxes based on their identity and asset class. This model can explain underdiversification and provides theoretical justification for performance evaluation practices like style analysis.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on informationally inefficient markets by proposing an alternative modeling approach that does not require noise traders while maintaining tractability and generality in preferences and payoff distributions, and by connecting this theoretical framework to practical performance evaluation methods used by finance professionals.

author: Jianfeng Yu
title: Reference-dependent preferences and the risk–return trade-off

author: Jianfeng Yu
title: Attention Spillover in Asset Pricing
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Exploiting a screen display feature whereby the order of stock display is determined by the stock's listing code, we lever a novel identification strategy and study how the interaction between overconfidence and limited attention affect asset pricing. We find that stocks displayed next to those with higher returns in the past two weeks are associated with higher returns in the future week, which are reverted in the long run. This is consistent with our conjectures that investors tend to trade more after positive investment experience and are more likely to pay attention to neighboring stocks, both confirmed using trading data.</jats:p>
research_question: How does the interaction between overconfidence and limited attention affect asset pricing?
answer: Stocks displayed next to those with higher returns in the past two weeks are associated with higher returns in the future week, which are reverted in the long run, demonstrating that attention spillover effects from neighboring stocks create temporary price distortions.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the asset pricing literature by providing a novel identification strategy using screen display features and stock listing codes to study the combined effects of overconfidence and limited attention, offering new empirical evidence on how investor behavior affects stock prices through attention spillover mechanisms.

author: Joachim Freyberger
title: Missing Data in Asset Pricing Panels
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We propose a simple and computationally attractive method to deal with missing data in in cross-sectional asset pricing using conditional mean imputations and weighted least squares, cast in a generalized method of moments (GMM) framework. This method allows us to use all observations with observed returns; it results in valid inference; and it can be applied in nonlinear and high-dimensional settings. In simulations, we find it performs almost as well as the efficient but computationally costly GMM estimator. We apply our procedure to a large panel of return predictors and find that it leads to improved out-of-sample predictability.</jats:p>
research_question: How can missing data in cross-sectional asset pricing panels be handled effectively while maintaining computational efficiency and valid statistical inference?
answer: A simple and computationally attractive method using conditional mean imputations and weighted least squares within a GMM framework can effectively handle missing data, allowing use of all observations with observed returns while maintaining valid inference and applicability to nonlinear and high-dimensional settings.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a practical problem in asset pricing by proposing a method that performs almost as well as the efficient but computationally costly GMM estimator, offering a more accessible alternative that maintains statistical validity while being computationally tractable for nonlinear and high-dimensional applications.

author: Joan Llull
title: Improvements in NYSE Trading and Information Technology: 1878-1984
abstract: <jats:p>Improvements in the technology of information flow and execution/clearing at the New York Stock Exchange between 1878 and 1984 were examined for their effects on price volatility and trading volume. Overall, price volatility was found to decrease after an improvement in trading technology, while both volume and intra-day volatility increased after an improvement in information flow. Noise traders may be attracted by faster information flow, even in the absence of new information, and bring additional volatility to the market. Solutions to the problem of such noise traders might involve increasing the ease of trading, and thus liquidity, to dampen price volatility.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the effects of improvements in information flow technology and execution/clearing technology on price volatility and trading volume at the New York Stock Exchange between 1878 and 1984?
answer: Improvements in trading technology decreased price volatility, while improvements in information flow technology increased both trading volume and intra-day volatility, with noise traders being attracted by faster information flow even without new information.
positioning_statement: This paper examines the historical relationship between technological improvements and market behavior over a century-long period, contributing to the literature on how trading technology and information flow affect market dynamics, and proposes that increasing trading ease and liquidity could be solutions to volatility problems caused by noise traders.

author: Joachim Freyberger
title: Dissecting Characteristics Nonparametrically
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We propose a nonparametric method to study which characteristics provide incremental information for the cross-section of expected returns. We use the adaptive group LASSO to select characteristics and to estimate how selected characteristics affect expected returns nonparametrically. Our method can handle a large number of characteristics and allows for a flexible functional form. Our implementation is insensitive to outliers. Many of the previously identified return predictors don’t provide incremental information for expected returns, and nonlinearities are important. We study our method’s properties in simulations and find large improvements in both model selection and prediction compared to alternative selection methods.</jats:p>
               <jats:p>Authors have furnished an Internet Appendix, which is available on the Oxford University Press Web site next to the link to the final published paper online.</jats:p>
research_question: Which characteristics provide incremental information for the cross-section of expected returns, and how do these characteristics affect expected returns in a flexible, nonparametric framework?
answer: Many previously identified return predictors don't provide incremental information for expected returns when analyzed nonparametrically, and nonlinearities are important in understanding how characteristics affect expected returns. The proposed adaptive group LASSO method shows large improvements in both model selection and prediction compared to alternative selection methods.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as advancing beyond existing literature by proposing a nonparametric method using adaptive group LASSO that can handle a large number of characteristics with flexible functional forms and robustness to outliers, offering improvements over alternative selection methods in studying cross-sectional expected returns.

author: Johannes Stroebel
title: Climate Change and Long-Run Discount Rates: Evidence from Real Estate
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We show that housing markets provide information about the appropriate discount rates for valuing investments in climate change abatement. Real estate is exposed to both consumption and climate risk and its term structure of discount rates is downward sloping, reaching 2.6% for payoffs beyond 100 years. We use a tractable asset pricing model that incorporates features of climate change to show that the term structure of discount rates for climate-hedging investments is thus upward sloping but bounded above by the risk-free rate. At horizons at which risk-free rates are unavailable, the estimated housing discount rates provide an upper bound.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the appropriate discount rates for valuing investments in climate change abatement, particularly at long horizons?
answer: Housing markets reveal that discount rates for climate-hedging investments have an upward sloping term structure bounded above by the risk-free rate, with real estate discount rates reaching 2.6% for payoffs beyond 100 years providing an upper bound when risk-free rates are unavailable at long horizons.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by using real estate markets as a novel source of information about long-run discount rates for climate investments, employing a tractable asset pricing model that incorporates climate change features to derive the term structure of discount rates for climate-hedging investments.

author: Johannes Stroebel
title: What do you think about climate finance?

title: Testing for Information Asymmetries in Real Estate Markets

author: Johannes Stroebel
title: Asymmetric Information about Collateral Values
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>I empirically analyze credit market outcomes when competing lenders are differentially informed about the expected return from making a loan. I study the residential mortgage market, where property developers often cooperate with vertically integrated mortgage lenders to offer financing to buyers of new homes. I show that these integrated lenders have superior information about the construction quality of individual homes and exploit this information to lend against higher quality collateral, decreasing foreclosures by up to 40%. To compensate for this adverse selection on collateral quality, nonintegrated lenders charge higher interest rates when competing against a better‐informed integrated lender.</jats:p>
research_question: How do credit market outcomes differ when competing lenders have asymmetric information about the expected return from making a loan, specifically regarding collateral values?
answer: Vertically integrated mortgage lenders exploit their superior information about construction quality to selectively lend against higher quality collateral, reducing their foreclosures by up to 40%, while nonintegrated lenders respond to this adverse selection by charging higher interest rates when competing against better-informed integrated lenders.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on asymmetric information in credit markets by empirically examining a specific setting where lenders have differential information about collateral quality, focusing on the residential mortgage market with vertically integrated lenders rather than the more commonly studied borrower-lender information asymmetries.

author: Johannes Stroebel
title: Social Proximity to Capital: Implications for Investors and Firms
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We show that institutional investors are more likely to invest in firms from regions to which they have stronger social ties but find no evidence that these investments earn a differential return. Firms in regions with stronger social ties to locations with many institutional investors have higher valuations and liquidity. These effects are largest for small firms with little analyst coverage, suggesting that the investors’ behavior is explained by their increased awareness of firms in socially proximate locations. Our results highlight that the social structure of regions affects firms’ access to capital and contributes to geographic differences in economic outcomes.</jats:p>
               <jats:p>Authors have furnished an Internet Appendix, which is available on the Oxford University Press Web site next to the link to the final published paper online.</jats:p>
research_question: How does social proximity between regions affect institutional investors' investment decisions and what are the implications for firms' access to capital?
answer: Institutional investors are more likely to invest in firms from regions with stronger social ties, but these investments do not earn differential returns. Firms in regions with stronger social ties to locations with many institutional investors have higher valuations and liquidity, with effects being largest for small firms with little analyst coverage due to increased investor awareness.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by demonstrating that regional social structure affects firms' access to capital and helps explain geographic differences in economic outcomes, focusing specifically on how social proximity influences institutional investor behavior and firm outcomes.

author: Johannes Stroebel
title: Hedging Climate Change News
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We propose and implement a procedure to dynamically hedge climate change risk. We extract innovations from climate news series that we construct through textual analysis of newspapers. We then use a mimicking portfolio approach to build climate change hedge portfolios. We discipline the exercise by using third-party ESG scores of firms to model their climate risk exposures. We show that this approach yields parsimonious and industry-balanced portfolios that perform well in hedging innovations in climate news both in sample and out of sample. We discuss multiple directions for future research on financial approaches to managing climate risk.</jats:p>
research_question: How can investors dynamically hedge climate change risk using financial instruments?
answer: The paper demonstrates that climate change risk can be effectively hedged by constructing portfolios based on innovations in climate news (extracted through textual analysis) and firms' ESG scores, yielding parsimonious, industry-balanced portfolios that perform well both in-sample and out-of-sample.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the emerging literature on financial approaches to managing climate risk by proposing a novel dynamic hedging procedure that combines textual analysis of climate news with ESG-based firm exposure modeling, opening multiple directions for future research in this area.

author: Johannes Stroebel
title: Lender Automation and Racial Disparities in Credit Access
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Process automation reduces racial disparities in credit access by enabling smaller loans, broadening banks' geographic reach, and removing human biases from decision making. We document these findings in the context of the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP), where private lenders faced no credit risk but decided which firms to serve. Black‐owned firms obtained PPP loans primarily from automated fintech lenders, especially in areas with high racial animus. After traditional banks automated their loan processing procedures, their PPP lending to Black‐owned firms increased. Our findings cannot be fully explained by racial differences in loan application behaviors, preexisting banking relationships, firm performance, or fraud rates.</jats:p>
research_question: How does process automation in lending affect racial disparities in credit access?
answer: Process automation reduces racial disparities in credit access by enabling smaller loans, broadening banks' geographic reach, and removing human biases from decision making, as evidenced by Black-owned firms obtaining more loans from automated fintech lenders and increased lending from traditional banks after they automated their processes.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on racial disparities in lending by demonstrating that automation can mitigate discrimination, using the unique context of the Paycheck Protection Program where lenders faced no credit risk, thus isolating the effects of automation from traditional risk-based explanations for lending disparities.
