author: John List
title: Do Professional Traders Exhibit Myopic Loss Aversion? An Experimental Analysis
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Two behavioral concepts, loss aversion and mental accounting, have been combined to provide a theoretical explanation of the equity premium puzzle. Recent experimental evidence supports the theory, as students' behavior has been found to be consistent with myopic loss aversion (MLA). Yet, much like certain anomalies in the realm of riskless decision‐making, these behavioral tendencies may be attenuated among professionals. Using traders recruited from the CBOT, we do indeed find behavioral differences between professionals and students, but rather than discovering that the anomaly is muted, we find that traders exhibit behavior consistent with MLA to a <jats:italic>greater</jats:italic> extent than students.</jats:p>
research_question: Do professional traders exhibit myopic loss aversion, and if so, how does their behavior compare to that of students?
answer: Professional traders exhibit behavior consistent with myopic loss aversion to a greater extent than students, contrary to expectations that professionals would show attenuated behavioral biases.
positioning_statement: This paper builds on existing experimental evidence showing that students exhibit myopic loss aversion (which helps explain the equity premium puzzle), but challenges the assumption that behavioral anomalies are reduced among professionals by testing actual traders from the Chicago Board of Trade.

author: Jonathan Karpoff
title: Short Sellers and Financial Misconduct
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We examine whether short sellers detect firms that misrepresent their financial statements, and whether their trading conveys external costs or benefits to other investors. Abnormal short interest increases steadily in the 19 months before the misrepresentation is publicly revealed, particularly when the misconduct is severe. Short selling is associated with a faster time‐to‐discovery, and it dampens the share price inflation that occurs when firms misstate their earnings. These results indicate that short sellers anticipate the eventual discovery and severity of financial misconduct. They also convey external benefits, helping to uncover misconduct and keeping prices closer to fundamental values.</jats:p>
research_question: Do short sellers detect firms that misrepresent their financial statements, and does their trading convey external costs or benefits to other investors?
answer: Short sellers do detect financial misconduct, with abnormal short interest increasing steadily in the 19 months before public revelation, particularly for severe misconduct. Their trading provides external benefits by accelerating discovery time and reducing share price inflation during earnings misstatements.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by demonstrating that short sellers serve a beneficial market function in detecting and exposing financial misconduct, challenging views that characterize short selling as purely detrimental and instead positioning it as a mechanism that enhances market efficiency and price discovery.

author: Jonathan Karpoff
title: Shareholder Perks and Firm Value
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Shareholder perks are in-kind gifts or purchase discounts that disproportionately reward small shareholders. Data from Japanese firms indicate that firms initiating perk programs attract individual retail shareholders and experience increases in share values. We find support for three channels by which perks increase firm value: an increase in share liquidity, a decrease in the equity cost of capital, and signaling to investors. A fourth channel, by which perks help to market the firm’s products to consumers, receives mixed support. We do not find evidence that perk programs work to entrench managers.</jats:p>
research_question: How do shareholder perks (in-kind gifts or purchase discounts that disproportionately reward small shareholders) affect firm value?
answer: Shareholder perks increase firm value through three main channels: increasing share liquidity, decreasing the equity cost of capital, and signaling to investors. Firms initiating perk programs attract individual retail shareholders and experience increases in share values.
positioning_statement: This paper investigates shareholder perks as a corporate policy tool, testing multiple theoretical channels for value creation while explicitly examining and rejecting the managerial entrenchment hypothesis, and providing mixed evidence for the product marketing channel.

author: Jonathan Karpoff
title: Takeover Defenses of IPO Firms
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Many firms deploy takeover defenses when they go public. IPO managers tend to deploy defenses when their compensation is high, shareholdings are small, and oversight from nonmanagerial shareholders is weak. The presence of a defense is negatively related to subsequent acquisition likelihood, yet has no impact on takeover premiums for firms that are acquired. These results do not support arguments that takeover defenses facilitate the eventual sale of IPO firms at high takeover premiums. Rather, they suggest that managers shift the cost of takeover protection onto nonmanagerial shareholders. Thus, agency problems are important even for firms at the IPO stage.</jats:p>
research_question: Why do many firms deploy takeover defenses when they go public, and what are the effects of these defenses on acquisition likelihood and takeover premiums?
answer: IPO managers deploy takeover defenses primarily when their compensation is high, shareholdings are small, and oversight is weak. These defenses reduce acquisition likelihood but do not increase takeover premiums, suggesting managers shift the cost of takeover protection onto nonmanagerial shareholders rather than facilitating high-premium sales.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges existing arguments that takeover defenses facilitate eventual high-premium sales of IPO firms, instead providing evidence that agency problems are important even at the IPO stage and that managers use defenses to benefit themselves at the expense of other shareholders.

author: Jonathan Karpoff
title: Institutional and Legal Context in Natural Experiments: The Case of State Antitakeover Laws
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We argue and demonstrate empirically that a firm's institutional and legal context has first‐order effects in tests that use state antitakeover laws for identification. A priori, the size and direction of a law's effect on a firm's takeover protection depends on (i) other state antitakeover laws, (ii) preexisting firm‐level takeover defenses, and (iii) the legal regime as reflected by important court decisions. In addition, (iv) state antitakeover laws are not exogenous for many easily identifiable firms. We show that the inferences from nine prior studies related to nine different outcome variables change substantially when we include controls for these considerations.</jats:p>
research_question: How does a firm's institutional and legal context affect the validity and interpretation of empirical tests that use state antitakeover laws for identification in natural experiments?
answer: A firm's institutional and legal context has first-order effects on tests using state antitakeover laws for identification. The size and direction of a law's effect depends on other state antitakeover laws, preexisting firm-level takeover defenses, the legal regime from court decisions, and the fact that these laws are not exogenous for many identifiable firms. When controlling for these factors, inferences from nine prior studies across nine different outcome variables change substantially.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the existing literature that uses state antitakeover laws as natural experiments by demonstrating that prior studies have failed to adequately account for crucial institutional and legal context factors, leading to potentially flawed inferences across multiple outcome variables and research questions.

author: Jonathan Karpoff
title: Short Selling and Earnings Management: A Controlled Experiment
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>During 2005 to 2007, the SEC ordered a pilot program in which one‐third of the Russell 3000 index were arbitrarily chosen as pilot stocks and exempted from short‐sale price tests. Pilot firms’ discretionary accruals and likelihood of marginally beating earnings targets decrease during this period, and revert to pre‐experiment levels when the program ends. After the program starts, pilot firms are more likely to be caught for fraud initiated before the program, and their stock returns better incorporate earnings information. These results indicate that short selling, or its prospect, curbs earnings management, helps detect fraud, and improves price efficiency.</jats:p>
research_question: Does short selling activity curb earnings management and improve market efficiency?
answer: Short selling, or its prospect, curbs earnings management (as evidenced by decreased discretionary accruals and reduced likelihood of marginally beating earnings targets), helps detect fraud, and improves price efficiency through better incorporation of earnings information into stock prices.
positioning_statement: This paper uses a unique natural experiment (the SEC's 2005-2007 pilot program that randomly exempted one-third of Russell 3000 stocks from short-sale price tests) to provide causal evidence on the relationship between short selling and earnings management, contributing to the literature on market efficiency and corporate governance mechanisms.

title: The Life Cycle Effects of Corporate Takeover Defenses
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We document that the relation between firm value and the use of takeover defenses is positive for young firms but becomes negative as firms age. This value reversal pattern reflects specific changes in the costs and benefits of takeover defenses as firms age and arises because defenses are sticky and rarely removed. Firms can attenuate the value reversal by removing defenses, but do so only when the defenses become very costly and adjustment costs are low. The value reversal explains previous mixed evidence about takeover defenses and implies that firm age proxies for takeover defenses’ heterogeneous impacts on firm value.</jats:p><jats:p>Authors have furnished an Internet Appendix, which is available on the Oxford University Press Web site next to the link to the final published paper online.</jats:p>
research_question: How does the relationship between firm value and takeover defenses change over a firm's life cycle?
answer: The relation between firm value and takeover defenses is positive for young firms but becomes negative as firms age, creating a value reversal pattern that occurs because defenses are sticky and rarely removed despite changing costs and benefits over time.
positioning_statement: This paper explains previous mixed evidence about takeover defenses by showing that firm age proxies for the heterogeneous impacts of takeover defenses on firm value, resolving inconsistencies in prior literature through a life cycle perspective.

title: Institutional Investors and Corporate Governance: The Incentive to Be Engaged
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>This paper studies institutional investors’ incentives to be engaged shareholders. In 2017, the average institution gains an extra $129,000 in annual management fees if a stockholding increases 1% in value, considering both the direct effect on assets under management and the indirect effect on subsequent fund flows. The estimates range from $19,600 for investments in small firms to $307,600 for investments in large firms. Institutional shareholders in one firm often gain when the firm's competitors do well, by virtue of institutions’ holdings in those firms, but the impact of common ownership is modest in the most concentrated industries.</jats:p>
research_question: What are institutional investors' financial incentives to be engaged shareholders in corporate governance?
answer: The average institution gains an extra $129,000 in annual management fees if a stockholding increases 1% in value, with estimates ranging from $19,600 for small firms to $307,600 for large firms, considering both direct effects on assets under management and indirect effects on fund flows.
positioning_statement: This paper quantifies the specific financial incentives that drive institutional investor engagement in corporate governance, providing empirical evidence on how management fee structures create monetary motivations for shareholder activism, while also examining the modest impact of common ownership effects in concentrated industries.

author: Jonathan Lewellen
title: Learning, Asset‐Pricing Tests, and Market Efficiency
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>This paper studies the asset‐pricing implications of parameter uncertainty. We show that, when investors must learn about expected cash flows, empirical tests can find patterns in the data that differ from those perceived by rational investors. Returns might appear predictable to an econometrician, or appear to deviate from the Capital Asset Pricing Model, but investors can neither perceive nor exploit this predictability. Returns may also appear excessively volatile even though prices react efficiently to cash‐flow news. We conclude that parameter uncertainty can be important for characterizing and testing market efficiency.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the asset-pricing implications of parameter uncertainty when investors must learn about expected cash flows?
answer: Parameter uncertainty can cause empirical tests to find patterns (predictability, CAPM deviations, excess volatility) that differ from what rational investors actually perceive, meaning returns can appear inefficient to econometricians while markets remain efficient from investors' perspectives.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the market efficiency literature by showing that parameter uncertainty can reconcile the apparent contradiction between empirical findings of market anomalies and the theoretical expectation of market efficiency, suggesting that existing asset-pricing tests may be misinterpreting efficient market behavior as inefficiency.

author: Jonathan Lewellen
title: Women in Charge: Evidence from Hospitals
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>The paper examines the decision‐making, compensation, and turnover of female CEOs in U.S. hospitals. Contrary to the literature on lower‐ranked executives and directors in public firms, there is no evidence that gender differences in preferences for risk or altruism affect decision‐making of hospital CEOs: corporate policies do not shift when women take (or leave) office, and male and female CEOs respond similarly to a major financial shock. However, female CEOs earn lower salaries, face flatter pay‐for‐performance incentives, and exhibit greater turnover after poor performance. Hospital boards behave as though they perceive female CEOs as less productive.</jats:p>
research_question: Do gender differences affect the decision-making, compensation, and turnover patterns of female CEOs compared to male CEOs in U.S. hospitals?
answer: Female hospital CEOs do not differ from male CEOs in decision-making or risk preferences, but they face significant disadvantages in compensation (lower salaries, flatter pay-for-performance incentives) and higher turnover after poor performance, suggesting hospital boards perceive them as less productive despite similar actual performance.
positioning_statement: This paper contrasts with existing literature on lower-ranked executives and directors in public firms by finding no evidence of gender differences in risk preferences or altruism affecting CEO decision-making, while documenting compensation and treatment disparities that suggest board bias rather than actual performance differences.

author: Jonathan Lewellen
title: Risk, Reputation, and IPO Price Support
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Immediately following an initial public offering, underwriters often repurchase shares of poorly performing offerings in an apparent attempt to stabilize the price. Using proprietary Nasdaq data, I study the price effects and determinants of price support. Some of the key findings are (1) Stabilization is substantial, inducing price rigidity at and below the offer price; (2) I find no evidence that stocks with larger information asymmetries are stabilized more strongly; (3) Larger underwriters stabilize more, perhaps to protect their reputations with investors; and (4) Investment banks with retail brokerage operations stabilize much more than other banks, inconsistent with the view that stabilization benefits primarily institutional investors.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the price effects and determinants of underwriter price support activities (stabilization) following initial public offerings?
answer: Stabilization creates substantial price rigidity at and below the offer price, with larger underwriters and those with retail brokerage operations engaging in more stabilization activity, likely to protect their reputations, and the practice appears to benefit retail rather than institutional investors.
positioning_statement: This paper provides new empirical evidence on IPO price support using proprietary Nasdaq data, challenging the existing view that stabilization primarily benefits institutional investors and instead showing it benefits retail investors, while also documenting the role of underwriter reputation and size in stabilization decisions.

author: Jonathan Lewellen
title: The Cross-Section of Bank Value
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We study the determinants of value creation in U.S. commercial banks. We develop novel measures of individual banks’ productivities at collecting deposits and making loans that we relate to bank market values. We find that deposit productivity is responsible for two-thirds of the value of the median bank and most variation in value across banks. Variation in productivity is driven by differences across banks in technology, customer demographics, and market power. We also find evidence of synergies between deposit-taking and lending. Our findings suggest that there is significant heterogeneity in banks’ ability to capture value by manufacturing safe assets.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the determinants of value creation in U.S. commercial banks?
answer: Deposit productivity is responsible for two-thirds of the value of the median bank and most variation in value across banks, with variation driven by differences in technology, customer demographics, and market power, plus evidence of synergies between deposit-taking and lending.
positioning_statement: The paper develops novel measures of individual banks' productivities at collecting deposits and making loans to study bank value creation, suggesting significant heterogeneity in banks' ability to capture value by manufacturing safe assets.

author: Jonathan Lewellen
title: CEO Preferences and Acquisitions
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>This paper explores the impact of target CEOs’ retirement preferences on takeovers. Using retirement age as a proxy for CEOs’ private merger costs, we find strong evidence that target CEOs’ preferences affect merger activity. The likelihood of receiving a successful takeover bid is sharply higher when target CEOs are close to age 65. Takeover premiums and target announcement returns are similar for retirement‐age and younger CEOs, implying that retirement‐age CEOs increase firm sales without sacrificing premiums. Better corporate governance is associated with more acquisitions of firms led by young CEOs, and with a smaller increase in deals at retirement age.</jats:p>
research_question: How do target CEOs' retirement preferences impact takeover activity and merger outcomes?
answer: Target CEOs close to retirement age (65) are significantly more likely to receive successful takeover bids, with similar premiums to younger CEOs, suggesting retirement-age CEOs facilitate firm sales without sacrificing shareholder value. Better corporate governance reduces this retirement age effect.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by using retirement age as a novel proxy for CEOs' private merger costs to examine how personal preferences affect M&A activity, extending beyond traditional financial and strategic factors typically studied in takeover research.

title: Investment Decisions of Nonprofit Firms: Evidence from Hospitals
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>This paper examines investment choices of nonprofit hospitals. It tests how shocks to cash flows caused by the performance of the hospitals’ financial assets affect hospital expenditures. Capital expenditures increase, on average, by 10 to 28 cents for every dollar received from financial assets. The sensitivity is similar to that found earlier for shareholder‐owned corporations. Executive compensation, other salaries, and perks do not respond significantly to cash flow shocks. Hospitals with an apparent tendency to overspend on medical procedures do not exhibit higher investment‐cash flow sensitivities. The sensitivities are higher for hospitals that appear financially constrained.</jats:p>
research_question: How do shocks to cash flows from financial assets affect the investment decisions and expenditures of nonprofit hospitals?
answer: Capital expenditures of nonprofit hospitals increase by 10 to 28 cents for every dollar received from financial assets, with sensitivity similar to shareholder-owned corporations and higher for financially constrained hospitals, while executive compensation and other non-capital expenditures do not respond significantly to cash flow shocks.
positioning_statement: This paper extends existing research on investment-cash flow sensitivity from shareholder-owned corporations to nonprofit hospitals, finding similar sensitivities and contributing to understanding of how financial constraints affect nonprofit firm investment behavior.

author: Jonathan Lewellen
title: Performance-Induced CEO Turnover
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>This paper revisits the relationship between firm performance and CEO turnover. Instead of classifying turnovers into forced and voluntary, we introduce performance-induced turnover, defined as turnover that would not have occurred had performance been “good.” We document a close turnover-performance link and estimate that 38%–55% of turnovers are performance induced. This is significantly more than the number of forced turnovers, though the two types of turnovers are highly correlated. Compared to the predictions of Bayesian learning models, learning about CEO ability appears to be slow, and boards act as if CEO ability (or match quality) was subject to frequent shocks.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the relationship between firm performance and CEO turnover, and how much of CEO turnover can be attributed to poor performance?
answer: 38%-55% of CEO turnovers are performance-induced (would not have occurred if performance had been good), which is significantly more than the number of forced turnovers, indicating a close turnover-performance link with learning about CEO ability appearing to be slow compared to Bayesian learning model predictions.
positioning_statement: This paper revisits the existing literature on firm performance and CEO turnover by introducing a new classification of 'performance-induced turnover' instead of the traditional forced versus voluntary turnover categorization, and compares findings against predictions from Bayesian learning models to show that boards behave as if CEO ability is subject to frequent shocks.

author: Jonathan Lewellen
title: Security Issue Timing: What Do Managers Know, and When Do They Know It?
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We study put option sales on company stock by large firms. An often‐cited motivation for these transactions is market timing, and managers' decision to issue puts should be sensitive to whether the stock is undervalued. We provide new evidence that large firms successfully time security sales. In the 100 days following put option issues, there is roughly a 5% abnormal stock return, with much of the abnormal return following the first earnings release date after the sale. Direct evidence on put option exercises reinforces these findings: exercise frequencies and payoffs to put holders are abnormally low.</jats:p>
research_question: Do managers of large firms have superior information about their stock's value when timing security issues, specifically put option sales, and when do they acquire this information advantage?
answer: Large firms successfully time put option sales based on superior information about their stock being undervalued, evidenced by 5% abnormal positive stock returns in the 100 days following put issues, with much of the abnormal return occurring after the first earnings release, and abnormally low exercise frequencies and payoffs for put holders.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes new evidence to the market timing literature by focusing specifically on put option sales by large firms as a test of managerial information advantages, providing direct evidence through both stock return analysis and put option exercise data to support successful security issue timing.

author: Joshua R. Schwartzstein
title: Operational Efficiency and Financial Performance of Manufacturing and Allied Firms Listed at the Nairobi Securities Exchange, Kenya
abstract:
<jats:p>Purpose: A company's financial performance indicates how well it combines policies, operations, and characteristics to gain a competitive edge. It also indicates the percentage of a company's revenue that is distributed to investors. The objective was to establish the effect of operational efficiency on the financial performance of manufacturing firms listed at the Nairobi Securities Exchange. Kenya.
Methodology: The study was supported by efficient market hypothesis theory. The study employed a descriptive research design. The study targeted a population of 9 manufacturing firms listed at the Nairobi Securities Exchange in Kenya as of 31st December 2024.A census of all the 9 manufacturing firms listed on the Nairobi Securities Exchange was used as a unit of analysis. Data was gathered from secondary sources through a secondary data collection sheet. Data was sourced from financial and statistical reports released by the NSE and the KMA. Data was analyzed using descriptive and inferential statistics.
Findings: The findings of the panel regression model indicated a positive and significant effect between operational efficiency and the financial performance of manufacturing firms listed at the NSE, Kenya.
Unique Contribution to Theory, Practice and Policy: The study recommends that manufacturing firms listed at the NSE should develop strategies to establish a firm-specific optimization framework designed to enhance the financial performance of NSE-listed manufacturing firms by integrating and addressing key internal characteristics that influence profitability and sustainability. By adopting a targeted and evidence-based approach through the firm-specific optimization framework, Kenya can empower its manufacturing firms to thrive within their unique structural contexts. Such alignment is not only beneficial to individual firms but is also essential to achieving national development goals under Vision 2030 and the Bottom-Up Economic Transformation Agenda.</jats:p>
venue: International Journal of Finance and Accounting
research_question: What is the effect of operational efficiency on the financial performance of manufacturing firms listed at the Nairobi Securities Exchange, Kenya?
answer: There is a positive and significant effect between operational efficiency and the financial performance of manufacturing firms listed at the NSE, Kenya.
positioning_statement: The study is supported by efficient market hypothesis theory and contributes to theory, practice and policy by recommending that manufacturing firms develop firm-specific optimization frameworks to enhance financial performance, aligning with Kenya's Vision 2030 and Bottom-Up Economic Transformation Agenda.

author: Jonathan Reuter
title: Are IPO Allocations for Sale? Evidence from Mutual Funds
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Combining data on brokerage commissions that mutual fund families paid for trade execution between 1996 and 1999 with data on mutual fund holdings of initial public offerings (IPOs), I document a robust, positive correlation between commissions paid to lead underwriters and reported holdings of the IPOs they underwrite. Moreover, I find that the correlation is limited to IPOs with nonnegative first‐day returns and strongest for IPOs that occur shortly before mutual funds report their holdings, when the noise introduced by flipping is smallest. Overall, the evidence suggests that business relationships with lead underwriters increase investor access to underpriced IPOs.</jats:p>
research_question: Do business relationships between mutual funds and investment banks, specifically through brokerage commissions paid, influence mutual fund access to initial public offering (IPO) allocations?
answer: Yes, there is a robust positive correlation between brokerage commissions that mutual fund families pay to lead underwriters and their holdings of IPOs underwritten by those same firms, particularly for underpriced IPOs with nonnegative first-day returns, suggesting that business relationships increase access to profitable IPO allocations.
positioning_statement: This paper provides empirical evidence for the existence of quid pro quo arrangements in IPO allocation practices by directly linking brokerage commission payments to IPO holdings, contributing to the literature on IPO allocation mechanisms and potential conflicts of interest in investment banking relationships.

author: Joshua R. Schwartzstein
title: FINANCIAL RISK AND FINANCIAL PERFORMANCE OF COMMERCIAL BANKS LISTED IN THE NAIROBI SECURITIES EXCHANGE IN KENYA
abstract:
<jats:p>Purpose: The objective was to determine the relationship between financial risk and financial performance of listed commercial banks in Kenya.
Methodology: Descriptive research design was adopted in the study. The target population of the study was formed by all the twelve listed commercial banks as at December 2021. Secondary data was utilized in the study. This secondary data was acquired from published financial statements of the listed commercial banks in Kenya for the period 2015 – 2020.  Data obtained was analysed using descriptive and inferential statistics. Further, data analysis was conducted using STATA software. The results obtained were then summarized using tables and charts.
Findings: The study found that credit risk, liquidity risk, market risk and operational risk explain 31.42% of financial performance of the listed commercial banks. Credit risk has a positive significant effect on financial performance of the listed commercial banks, while market risk and operation risk have negative and significant effect on financial performance of the listed commercial banks. Liquidity risk was found have positive insignificant effect on financial performance of the listed commercial banks.
Unique contribution to Theory, Practice and Policy: The study recommends that the banks should increase their secured loans portfolio, manage the liabilities of the company and ensure sustainable growth of the company assets and finally, the listed commercial banks should manage their expenses to a level that is sustainable. The credit risk theory and liquidity preference theory may be used to anchor future studies in the listed commercial banks.</jats:p>
venue: International Journal of Finance and Accounting
research_question: What is the relationship between financial risk and financial performance of listed commercial banks in Kenya?
answer: Credit risk, liquidity risk, market risk and operational risk explain 31.42% of financial performance of listed commercial banks. Credit risk has a positive significant effect on financial performance, while market risk and operational risk have negative significant effects. Liquidity risk has a positive but insignificant effect on financial performance.
positioning_statement: The study contributes to theory by recommending the use of credit risk theory and liquidity preference theory to anchor future studies in listed commercial banks, and provides practical recommendations for banks to manage their risk portfolios and expenses sustainably.

author: Jonathan Reuter
title: Mutual Fund Performance and the Incentive to Generate Alpha
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>To rationalize the well‐known underperformance of the average actively managed mutual fund, we exploit the fact that retail funds in different market segments compete for different types of investors. Within the segment of funds marketed directly to retail investors, we show that flows chase risk‐adjusted returns, and that funds respond by investing more in active management. Importantly, within this direct‐sold segment, we find no evidence that actively managed funds underperform index funds. In contrast, we show that actively managed funds sold through brokers face a weaker incentive to generate alpha and significantly underperform index funds.</jats:p>
research_question: Why do actively managed mutual funds typically underperform, and how do different distribution channels and investor types affect fund performance incentives?
answer: The underperformance of actively managed funds is explained by distribution channel differences: direct-sold funds face stronger incentives to generate alpha (as flows chase risk-adjusted returns) and do not underperform index funds, while broker-sold funds face weaker alpha-generation incentives and significantly underperform index funds.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a new explanation for the well-known puzzle of mutual fund underperformance by exploiting previously underexplored differences in market segments and distribution channels, showing that the average underperformance masks important heterogeneity based on how funds compete for different types of investors.

author: Joshua R. Schwartzstein
title: EFFECT OF MACRO-ECONOMIC FACTORS ON FINANCIAL PERFORMANCE IN KENYA OF REGISTERED REAL ESTATE INVESTMENTS TRUSTS
abstract:
<jats:p>Purpose: The purpose of the study was to determine the macroeconomic effect on Registered Real Estate Investments Trusts (REITs) financial performance in Kenya.
Materials and Methods: Causal research design was used to describe the REITs financial performance. This study used the population comprising of thirteen REITs firms in Kenya. The entire population (census) was used for the study. This study utilized secondary sources of data to get the information required to satisfy the research objectives. Time series data on REITs financial performance was computed for a four-year period as at 1st January 2016 to 31stDecember 2019, thus making use of 4 data points. The process of data analysis entailed preparation of the collected data through cleaning, editing and coding so that statistics could be keyed in the SPSS (statistical package for social sciences) package. The data was presented through tables and figures
Results:  The regression model results without the moderating variable showed that R = 0.792, R² = 0.627 indicating that 62.7% of the variance in the REITs financial performance can be accounted for by the independent variables (macroeconomic variables). On the other hand, the regression model results with the moderating variable showed that R = 0.838, R² = 0.703 indicating that 70.3% of the variance in the REITs financial performance can be accounted for by the independent variables (macroeconomic variables) and the moderating variable considered in this study. 
Unique contribution to theory, practice and policy: The study recommended that the government and REITs stakeholders should focus on policies and strategies that encourage favorable balance of payment in Kenya. REITs develop and design their products to suit consumers tastes and preferences to ensure their increased as consumption increases. Lastly, the government should expand the money supply to lower the inflation rates through tight fiscal and economic policies.</jats:p>
venue: International Journal of Finance and Accounting
research_question: What is the effect of macroeconomic factors on the financial performance of Registered Real Estate Investments Trusts (REITs) in Kenya?
answer: Macroeconomic factors significantly affect REITs financial performance in Kenya, explaining 62.7% of the variance in performance, which increases to 70.3% when a moderating variable is included in the model.
positioning_statement: This study contributes to theory, practice and policy by providing unique insights into the macroeconomic determinants of REITs performance specifically in the Kenyan context, filling a gap in understanding how macroeconomic variables affect real estate investment trusts in emerging markets.

author: Joshua Rauh
title: The Return Expectations of Public Pension Funds
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>The return expectations of public pension funds are positively related to cross-sectional differences in past performance. This positive relation operates through the expected risk premium, rather than the expected risk-free rate or inflation rate. Pension funds act on their beliefs and adjust their portfolio composition accordingly. Persistent investment skills, risk taking, efforts to reduce costly rebalancing, and fiscal incentives from unfunded liabilities cannot fully explain the reliance of expectations on past performance. The results are consistent with extrapolative expectations, since the dependence on past returns is greater when executives have personally experienced longer performance histories with the fund.</jats:p>
               <jats:p>Authors have furnished an Internet Appendix, which is available on the Oxford University Press Web site next to the link to the final published paper online.</jats:p>
research_question: How do public pension funds form their return expectations, and what factors influence these expectations?
answer: Public pension funds' return expectations are positively related to their past performance, operating through expected risk premiums rather than risk-free rates or inflation. This relationship is consistent with extrapolative expectations, where funds project past performance into future expectations, especially when executives have longer personal experience with the fund's performance history.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on institutional investor behavior by demonstrating that public pension funds exhibit extrapolative expectations based on past performance, which cannot be fully explained by existing theories such as persistent investment skills, risk taking, rebalancing costs, or fiscal incentives from unfunded liabilities.

author: Joshua Rauh
title: Public Pension Promises: How Big Are They and What Are They Worth?
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We calculate the present value of state employee pension liabilities using discount rates that reflect the risk of the payments from a taxpayer perspective. If benefits have the same default and recovery characteristics as state general obligation debt, the national total of promised liabilities based on current salary and service is $3.20 trillion. If pensions have higher priority than state debt, the value of liabilities is much larger. Using zero‐coupon Treasury yields, which are default‐free but contain other priced risks, promised liabilities are $4.43 trillion. Liabilities are even larger under broader concepts that account for salary growth and future service.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the present value of state employee pension liabilities when calculated using discount rates that reflect the risk of the payments from a taxpayer perspective?
answer: The present value of state employee pension liabilities ranges from $3.20 trillion (if benefits have the same default and recovery characteristics as state general obligation debt) to $4.43 trillion (using zero-coupon Treasury yields), with even larger liabilities when accounting for salary growth and future service.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by applying risk-adjusted discount rates that reflect the taxpayer perspective when valuing pension liabilities, rather than using traditional actuarial methods, and by considering different risk scenarios including comparison to state general obligation debt and default-free Treasury yields.

author: Joshua Rauh
title: Investment and Financing Constraints: Evidence from the Funding of Corporate Pension Plans
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>I exploit sharply nonlinear funding rules for defined benefit pension plans in order to identify the dependence of corporate investment on internal financial resources in a large sample. Capital expenditures decline with mandatory contributions to DB pension plans, even when controlling for correlations between the pension funding status itself and the firm's unobserved investment opportunities. The effect is particularly evident among firms that face financing constraints based on observable variables such as credit ratings. Investment also displays strong negative correlations with the part of mandatory contributions resulting solely from unexpected asset market movements.</jats:p>
research_question: How do mandatory contributions to defined benefit pension plans affect corporate investment decisions, and does this relationship vary based on firms' financing constraints?
answer: Capital expenditures decline with mandatory contributions to DB pension plans, with the effect being particularly strong among financing-constrained firms and when contributions result from unexpected asset market movements, providing evidence that corporate investment depends on internal financial resources.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on financing constraints and corporate investment by exploiting sharply nonlinear funding rules for defined benefit pension plans as a novel identification strategy to isolate the causal effect of internal financial resources on investment, while controlling for correlations between pension funding status and unobserved investment opportunities.

author: Joshua Rauh
title: Institutional Investors and Infrastructure Investing
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Institutional investors expect infrastructure to deliver long-term stable returns but gain exposure to infrastructure predominantly through finite-horizon closed private funds. The cash flows delivered by infrastructure funds display similar volatility and cyclicality as other private equity investments, and their performance similarly depends on quick deal exits. Despite weak risk-adjusted performance and failure to match the supposed characteristics of infrastructure assets, closed funds have received more commitments over time, particularly from public investors. Public institutional investors perform worse than private institutional investors. ESG preferences and regulations explain 25$\%$–40$\%$ of their increased allocation to infrastructure and 30$\%$ of their underperformance.</jats:p>
research_question: How do institutional investors gain exposure to infrastructure investments and do these investments deliver the expected long-term stable returns that match the characteristics of infrastructure assets?
answer: Infrastructure funds fail to deliver the expected stable, long-term returns that institutional investors seek. Instead, they display similar volatility and cyclicality as other private equity investments, exhibit weak risk-adjusted performance, and depend on quick deal exits rather than long-term stable cash flows.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the conventional wisdom about infrastructure investing by documenting that despite poor performance and misaligned characteristics, infrastructure funds continue to attract increasing commitments from institutional investors, particularly public ones, with ESG preferences and regulations partially explaining this seemingly irrational behavior.

author: Joshua Schwartzstein
title: Operational Efficiency and Financial Performance of Manufacturing and Allied Firms Listed at the Nairobi Securities Exchange, Kenya
abstract:
<jats:p>Purpose: A company's financial performance indicates how well it combines policies, operations, and characteristics to gain a competitive edge. It also indicates the percentage of a company's revenue that is distributed to investors. The objective was to establish the effect of operational efficiency on the financial performance of manufacturing firms listed at the Nairobi Securities Exchange. Kenya.
Methodology: The study was supported by efficient market hypothesis theory. The study employed a descriptive research design. The study targeted a population of 9 manufacturing firms listed at the Nairobi Securities Exchange in Kenya as of 31st December 2024.A census of all the 9 manufacturing firms listed on the Nairobi Securities Exchange was used as a unit of analysis. Data was gathered from secondary sources through a secondary data collection sheet. Data was sourced from financial and statistical reports released by the NSE and the KMA. Data was analyzed using descriptive and inferential statistics.
Findings: The findings of the panel regression model indicated a positive and significant effect between operational efficiency and the financial performance of manufacturing firms listed at the NSE, Kenya.
Unique Contribution to Theory, Practice and Policy: The study recommends that manufacturing firms listed at the NSE should develop strategies to establish a firm-specific optimization framework designed to enhance the financial performance of NSE-listed manufacturing firms by integrating and addressing key internal characteristics that influence profitability and sustainability. By adopting a targeted and evidence-based approach through the firm-specific optimization framework, Kenya can empower its manufacturing firms to thrive within their unique structural contexts. Such alignment is not only beneficial to individual firms but is also essential to achieving national development goals under Vision 2030 and the Bottom-Up Economic Transformation Agenda.</jats:p>
venue: International Journal of Finance and Accounting
research_question: What is the effect of operational efficiency on the financial performance of manufacturing firms listed at the Nairobi Securities Exchange, Kenya?
answer: There is a positive and significant effect between operational efficiency and the financial performance of manufacturing firms listed at the NSE, Kenya.
positioning_statement: The study is supported by efficient market hypothesis theory and contributes to theory, practice and policy by recommending that manufacturing firms develop firm-specific optimization frameworks to enhance financial performance, aligning with Kenya's Vision 2030 and Bottom-Up Economic Transformation Agenda.

author: Joshua Schwartzstein
title: EFFECT OF MACRO-ECONOMIC FACTORS ON FINANCIAL PERFORMANCE IN KENYA OF REGISTERED REAL ESTATE INVESTMENTS TRUSTS
abstract:
<jats:p>Purpose: The purpose of the study was to determine the macroeconomic effect on Registered Real Estate Investments Trusts (REITs) financial performance in Kenya.
Materials and Methods: Causal research design was used to describe the REITs financial performance. This study used the population comprising of thirteen REITs firms in Kenya. The entire population (census) was used for the study. This study utilized secondary sources of data to get the information required to satisfy the research objectives. Time series data on REITs financial performance was computed for a four-year period as at 1st January 2016 to 31stDecember 2019, thus making use of 4 data points. The process of data analysis entailed preparation of the collected data through cleaning, editing and coding so that statistics could be keyed in the SPSS (statistical package for social sciences) package. The data was presented through tables and figures
Results:  The regression model results without the moderating variable showed that R = 0.792, R² = 0.627 indicating that 62.7% of the variance in the REITs financial performance can be accounted for by the independent variables (macroeconomic variables). On the other hand, the regression model results with the moderating variable showed that R = 0.838, R² = 0.703 indicating that 70.3% of the variance in the REITs financial performance can be accounted for by the independent variables (macroeconomic variables) and the moderating variable considered in this study. 
Unique contribution to theory, practice and policy: The study recommended that the government and REITs stakeholders should focus on policies and strategies that encourage favorable balance of payment in Kenya. REITs develop and design their products to suit consumers tastes and preferences to ensure their increased as consumption increases. Lastly, the government should expand the money supply to lower the inflation rates through tight fiscal and economic policies.</jats:p>
venue: International Journal of Finance and Accounting
research_question: What is the effect of macroeconomic factors on the financial performance of Registered Real Estate Investments Trusts (REITs) in Kenya?
answer: Macroeconomic factors significantly affect REITs financial performance in Kenya, explaining 62.7% of the variance in performance, which increases to 70.3% when a moderating variable is included in the model.
positioning_statement: This study contributes to theory, practice and policy by providing unique insights into the macroeconomic determinants of REITs performance specifically in the Kenyan context, filling a gap in understanding how macroeconomic variables affect real estate investment trusts in emerging markets.

author: Joshua Rauh
title: Political Representation and Governance: Evidence from the Investment Decisions of Public Pension Funds
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Representation on pension fund boards by state officials—often determined by statute decades past—is negatively related to the performance of private equity investments made by the pension fund, despite state officials’ relatively strong financial education and experience. Their underperformance appears to be partly driven by poor investment decisions consistent with political expediency, and is also positively related to political contributions from the finance industry. Boards dominated by elected rank‐and‐file plan participants also underperform, but to a smaller extent and due to these trustees’ lesser financial experience.</jats:p>
research_question: How does political representation on public pension fund boards affect investment performance, particularly in private equity investments?
answer: State officials' representation on pension fund boards is negatively related to private equity investment performance, with underperformance driven by politically expedient investment decisions and influenced by political contributions from the finance industry, while boards dominated by elected rank-and-file participants also underperform but to a lesser extent due to limited financial experience.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on political governance and institutional investment by examining how different types of board representation (state officials vs. rank-and-file participants) affect investment outcomes, focusing specifically on the mechanisms through which political considerations influence financial decision-making in public pension funds.

author: Joël Peress
title: Product Market Competition, Insider Trading, and Stock Market Efficiency
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>How does competition in firms' product markets influence their behavior in equity markets? Do product market imperfections spread to equity markets? We examine these questions in a noisy rational expectations model in which firms operate under monopolistic competition while their shares trade in perfectly competitive markets. Firms use their monopoly power to pass on shocks to customers, thereby insulating their profits. This encourages stock trading, expedites the capitalization of private information into stock prices and improves the allocation of capital. Several implications are derived and tested.</jats:p>
research_question: How does competition in firms' product markets influence their behavior in equity markets, and do product market imperfections spread to equity markets?
answer: Firms with monopoly power use it to pass on shocks to customers, insulating their profits, which encourages stock trading, expedites the capitalization of private information into stock prices, and improves capital allocation.
positioning_statement: This paper examines the intersection of product market competition and equity market efficiency using a noisy rational expectations model, investigating how monopolistic competition in product markets affects stock market behavior and information incorporation.

author: Joël Peress
title: The Media and the Diffusion of Information in Financial Markets: Evidence from Newspaper Strikes
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>The media are increasingly recognized as key players in financial markets. I investigate their causal impact on trading and price formation by examining national newspaper strikes in several countries. Trading volume falls 12% on strike days. The dispersion of stock returns and their intraday volatility are reduced by 7%, while aggregate returns are unaffected. Moreover, analysis of return predictability indicates that newspapers propagate news from the previous day. These findings demonstrate that the media contribute to the efficiency of the stock market by improving the dissemination of information among investors and its incorporation into stock prices.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the causal impact of media on trading and price formation in financial markets?
answer: The media contribute to stock market efficiency by improving information dissemination among investors and its incorporation into stock prices, as evidenced by 12% lower trading volume, 7% reduced return dispersion and intraday volatility during newspaper strikes, and evidence that newspapers propagate news from the previous day.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the increasingly recognized role of media as key players in financial markets by providing causal evidence of their impact, using the natural experiment of newspaper strikes to overcome endogeneity issues that likely plagued previous research on media effects in finance.

author: Jules van Binsbergen
title: Real Anomalies
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We examine the importance of cross‐sectional asset pricing anomalies (alphas) for the real economy. To this end, we develop a novel quantitative model of the cross‐section of firms that features lumpy investment and informational inefficiencies, while yielding distributions in closed form. Our findings indicate that anomalies can cause material real inefficiencies, which raises the possibility that agents who help eliminate them add significant value to the economy. The model shows that the magnitude of alphas alone is a poor indicator of real outcomes, and highlights the importance of the alpha persistence, the amount of mispriced capital, and the Tobin's <jats:italic>q</jats:italic> of firms affected.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the importance of cross-sectional asset pricing anomalies (alphas) for the real economy?
answer: Anomalies can cause material real inefficiencies, suggesting that agents who help eliminate them add significant value to the economy. The magnitude of alphas alone is a poor indicator of real outcomes - what matters more is alpha persistence, the amount of mispriced capital, and the Tobin's q of affected firms.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a novel quantitative model of the cross-section of firms that features lumpy investment and informational inefficiencies while yielding distributions in closed form, bridging asset pricing anomalies research with real economic outcomes.

author: Joël Peress
title: Media Coverage and the Cross‐section of Stock Returns
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>By reaching a broad population of investors, mass media can alleviate informational frictions and affect security pricing even if it does not supply genuine news. We investigate this hypothesis by studying the cross‐sectional relation between media coverage and expected stock returns. We find that stocks with no media coverage earn higher returns than stocks with high media coverage even after controlling for well‐known risk factors. These results are more pronounced among small stocks and stocks with high individual ownership, low analyst following, and high idiosyncratic volatility. Our findings suggest that the breadth of information dissemination affects stock returns.</jats:p>
research_question: How does media coverage affect the cross-sectional relation with expected stock returns, and can mass media alleviate informational frictions to affect security pricing even without supplying genuine news?
answer: Stocks with no media coverage earn higher returns than stocks with high media coverage, even after controlling for well-known risk factors, with effects being more pronounced among small stocks and stocks with high individual ownership, low analyst following, and high idiosyncratic volatility.
positioning_statement: This paper investigates the hypothesis that mass media can alleviate informational frictions and affect security pricing by reaching a broad population of investors, even if it does not supply genuine news, contributing to understanding how the breadth of information dissemination affects stock returns.

author: Joël Peress
title: Glued to the TV: Distracted Noise Traders and Stock Market Liquidity
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>In this paper, we study the impact of noise traders’ limited attention on financial markets. Specifically, we exploit episodes of sensational news (exogenous to the market) that distract noise traders. We find that on “distraction days,” trading activity, liquidity, and volatility decrease, and prices reverse less among stocks owned predominantly by noise traders. These outcomes contrast sharply with those due to the inattention of informed speculators and market makers, and are consistent with noise traders mitigating adverse selection risk. We discuss the evolution of these outcomes over time and the role of technological changes.</jats:p>
research_question: How does noise traders' limited attention affect financial market outcomes such as trading activity, liquidity, volatility, and price behavior?
answer: When noise traders are distracted by sensational news, trading activity, liquidity, and volatility decrease, and prices reverse less among stocks owned predominantly by noise traders, which is consistent with noise traders mitigating adverse selection risk.
positioning_statement: This paper contrasts its findings with existing literature on inattention by showing that noise trader distraction produces outcomes that are sharply different from those caused by inattention of informed speculators and market makers, and examines how these effects have evolved over time with technological changes.

author: Jules van Binsbergen
title: Good‐Specific Habit Formation and the Cross‐Section of Expected Returns
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>I study asset prices in a general equilibrium framework in which agents form habits over individual varieties of goods rather than over an aggregate consumption bundle. Goods are produced by monopolistically competitive firms whose elasticities of demand depend on consumers' habit formation. Firms that produce goods with a high habit level relative to consumption have low demand elasticities, set high prices for their product, have low expected returns on their stock, and have low asset pricing betas and stock return volatilities. I find supportive evidence for these predictions in the data.</jats:p>
research_question: How does good-specific habit formation (where agents form habits over individual varieties of goods rather than aggregate consumption) affect asset prices and the cross-section of expected returns?
answer: Firms that produce goods with high habit levels relative to consumption have low demand elasticities, set high prices, and consequently have low expected stock returns, low asset pricing betas, and low stock return volatilities.
positioning_statement: This paper extends existing habit formation models in asset pricing by moving from aggregate consumption habit formation to good-specific habit formation, incorporating monopolistic competition and examining how individual product habits affect firm-level asset pricing through demand elasticity channels.

author: Joël Peress
title: Fast and Slow Arbitrage: The Predictive Power of (Persistent) Capital Flows for Factor Returns
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We document that persistent aggregate capital flows to hedge and mutual funds predict monthly factor returns with an out-of-sample R2 reaching 6.6%. Transient flows display no such power despite being more predictable. We show—both empirically and theoretically—that persistent flows’ predictive power stems from active fund managers’ capital constraints. As a result, managers invest persistent, but not transient, capital flows into factor trading strategies, leading to factor-return predictability and factor momentum, yet greater price efficiency. Our key insight is that capital-constrained managers account for both current and anticipated future flows in the arbitrage sector, thereby incorporating the dynamics of capital into their strategies.</jats:p>
research_question: Do capital flows to hedge and mutual funds predict factor returns, and if so, what explains this predictive power?
answer: Persistent aggregate capital flows to hedge and mutual funds predict monthly factor returns with an out-of-sample R² reaching 6.6%, while transient flows show no predictive power. This predictive ability stems from active fund managers' capital constraints, which cause them to invest persistent (but not transient) flows into factor trading strategies.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by identifying a novel source of factor return predictability through persistent capital flows, and provides both empirical evidence and theoretical explanation for how capital-constrained managers incorporate flow dynamics into their arbitrage strategies, connecting capital flow literature with factor investing and market efficiency research.

author: Jules van Binsbergen
title: Regulation of Charlatans in High‐Skill Professions
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We model a market for a skill in short supply and high demand, where the presence of charlatans (professionals who sell a service they do not deliver on) is an equilibrium outcome. In the model, reducing the number of charlatans through regulation lowers consumer surplus because of the resulting reduction in competition among producers. Producers can benefit from this reduction, potentially explaining the regulation we observe. The effect on total surplus depends on the type of regulation. We derive the factors that drive the cross‐sectional variation in charlatans (regulation) across professions.</jats:p>
research_question: How does regulation of charlatans (professionals who sell services they do not deliver) in high-skill professions affect market outcomes and welfare?
answer: Reducing charlatans through regulation lowers consumer surplus due to reduced competition among producers, while producers benefit from this reduction, which explains observed regulation patterns across professions.
positioning_statement: This paper models charlatan presence as an equilibrium outcome in markets with skill shortages and high demand, providing a novel explanation for professional regulation that focuses on competition effects rather than traditional quality concerns.

author: Jules van Binsbergen
title: Predictive Regressions: A Present‐Value Approach
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We propose a latent variables approach within a present‐value model to estimate the expected returns and expected dividend growth rates of the aggregate stock market. This approach aggregates information contained in the history of price‐dividend ratios and dividend growth rates to predict future returns and dividend growth rates. We find that returns and dividend growth rates are predictable with  values ranging from 8.2% to 8.9% for returns and 13.9% to 31.6% for dividend growth rates. Both expected returns and expected dividend growth rates have a persistent component, but expected returns are more persistent than expected dividend growth rates.</jats:p>
research_question: How can expected returns and expected dividend growth rates of the aggregate stock market be estimated and predicted using information from price-dividend ratios and dividend growth rates?
answer: Returns and dividend growth rates are predictable using a latent variables approach within a present-value model, with R² values of 8.2%-8.9% for returns and 13.9%-31.6% for dividend growth rates. Both expected returns and expected dividend growth rates have persistent components, but expected returns are more persistent than expected dividend growth rates.
positioning_statement: The paper proposes a latent variables approach within a present-value model as a new method to aggregate information from the history of price-dividend ratios and dividend growth rates for predicting future market returns and dividend growth rates.

author: Jules van Binsbergen
title: Duration-Based Valuation of Corporate Bonds
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We decompose corporate bond and equity index returns into duration-matched government bond returns and the excess returns over this duration-matched counterfactual, which we term duration-adjusted returns. Compared with previously used excess return definitions (ie, returns in excess of Treasury bills), our decomposition leads to markedly different return patterns and asset pricing implications. In particular, we find that investment-grade bonds earn a small credit risk premium, comparable in magnitude to the convenience yield, and that duration adjustment resolves the CAPM’s failure to price corporate bonds. These findings highlight the importance of adjusting for nonstationary interest rate environments in asset pricing tests.</jats:p>
research_question: How does decomposing corporate bond returns using duration-matched government bonds as a benchmark (rather than Treasury bills) affect our understanding of corporate bond pricing and risk premiums?
answer: Investment-grade corporate bonds earn only a small credit risk premium comparable to the convenience yield when properly adjusted for duration, and this duration adjustment resolves the CAPM's previous failure to price corporate bonds effectively.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the conventional approach of using Treasury bills as the risk-free benchmark for corporate bond excess returns, arguing that previous asset pricing studies have failed to account for nonstationary interest rate environments, and demonstrates that duration-matching provides a superior framework for understanding corporate bond pricing relative to existing literature.

author: Jules van Binsbergen
title: Matching Capital and Labor
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We establish an important role for the firm by studying capital reallocation decisions of mutual fund firms. The firm's decision to reallocate capital among its mutual fund managers adds at least $474,000 a month, which amounts to over 30% of the total value added of the industry. We provide evidence that this additional value added results from the firm's private information about the skill of its managers. The firm captures this value because investors reward the firm following a capital reallocation decision by allocating additional capital to the firm's funds.</jats:p>
research_question: What role do mutual fund firms play in creating value through capital reallocation decisions among their managers?
answer: Mutual fund firms create substantial value by reallocating capital among their managers, adding at least $474,000 per month (over 30% of total industry value added) through their private information about manager skill, with investors rewarding these decisions by allocating additional capital to the firm's funds.
positioning_statement: This paper establishes an important and previously understudied role for the firm in mutual fund value creation, focusing on internal capital reallocation decisions rather than just individual manager performance.

author: Jules van Binsbergen
title: Man versus Machine Learning: The Term Structure of Earnings Expectations and Conditional Biases
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We introduce a real-time measure of conditional biases to firms’ earnings forecasts. The measure is defined as the difference between analysts’ expectations and a statistically optimal unbiased machine-learning benchmark. Analysts’ conditional expectations are, on average, biased upward, a bias that increases in the forecast horizon. These biases are associated with negative cross-sectional return predictability, and the short legs of many anomalies contain firms with excessively optimistic earnings forecasts. Further, managers of companies with the greatest upward-biased earnings forecasts are more likely to issue stocks. Commonly used linear earnings models do not work out-of-sample and are inferior to those analysts provide.</jats:p>
               <jats:p>Authors have furnished an Internet Appendix, which is available on the Oxford University Press Web site next to the link to the final published paper online.</jats:p>
research_question: How do analysts' earnings forecasts compare to statistically optimal unbiased machine-learning benchmarks, and what are the implications of any systematic biases for stock returns and corporate behavior?
answer: Analysts' conditional earnings expectations are systematically biased upward on average, with bias increasing over longer forecast horizons. These biases are associated with negative cross-sectional return predictability, appear in the short legs of many market anomalies, and influence managerial decisions such as stock issuance timing.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces a novel real-time measure of conditional biases by comparing human analyst forecasts to machine-learning benchmarks, demonstrating that commonly used linear earnings models are inferior to analyst forecasts out-of-sample, while also revealing systematic biases that existing literature has not adequately captured through conditional analysis.

author: Jules van Binsbergen
title: A Horizon‐Based Decomposition of Mutual Fund Value Added Using Transactions
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We decompose mutual fund value added by the length of funds' holdings using transaction‐level data. We motivate our decomposition with a model featuring horizon‐specific investment ideas, where short‐term ideas are less scalable because the associated trades cannot be spread over time. Fund turnover correlates negatively with the horizon over which value is added and positively with price impact costs. As predicted, holdings of high‐turnover funds add a substantial amount of value in the first two weeks, of which more than 80% is earned on Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) and earnings announcement days. Holdings of low‐turnover funds add value only over longer horizons.</jats:p>
research_question: How does mutual fund value added vary by the length of time funds hold their positions, and how does this relate to fund turnover and trading costs?
answer: High-turnover funds add substantial value in the short term (first two weeks), with over 80% earned on FOMC and earnings announcement days, while low-turnover funds only add value over longer horizons. Fund turnover correlates negatively with the investment horizon over which value is added and positively with price impact costs.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces a novel horizon-based decomposition of mutual fund performance using transaction-level data and develops a model featuring horizon-specific investment ideas, where short-term ideas are less scalable due to the inability to spread trades over time.

author: Jules van Binsbergen
title: Is the United States a Lucky Survivor? A Hierarchical Bayesian Approach
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Using international data, we quantify the magnitude of survivorship bias in U.S. equity market performance, finding that it explains about one‐third of the equity risk premium in the past century. We model the subjective crash belief of an investor who infers the crash risk in the United States by cross‐learning from other countries. The U.S. crash probability shows a persistent and widening divergence from the implied global average. We attribute the upward bias in the measured equity premium to crashes that did not occur in‐sample and to shocks to valuations resulting from learning about the probability.</jats:p>
research_question: How much of the U.S. equity risk premium can be attributed to survivorship bias, and what is the magnitude of this bias when accounting for crashes that occurred in other countries but not in the United States?
answer: Survivorship bias explains about one-third of the U.S. equity risk premium over the past century, with the upward bias in the measured equity premium attributed to crashes that did not occur in the U.S. sample and to valuation shocks from learning about crash probabilities through cross-country evidence.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by using a hierarchical Bayesian approach with international data to quantify survivorship bias in U.S. equity markets, modeling how investors update their crash beliefs by learning from other countries' experiences, and showing a persistent divergence between U.S. crash probability and the global average.

author: Jules van Binsbergen
title: The Cost of Debt
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We use exogenous variation in tax benefit functions to estimate firm‐specific cost of debt functions that are conditional on company characteristics such as collateral, size, and book‐to‐market. By integrating the area between the benefit and cost functions, we estimate that the equilibrium net benefit of debt is 3.5% of asset value, resulting from an estimated gross benefit (cost) of debt equal to 10.4% (6.9%) of asset value. We find that the cost of being overlevered is asymmetrically higher than the cost of being underlevered and that expected default costs constitute only half of the total ex ante costs of debt.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the firm-specific costs and benefits of debt, and how do they determine the equilibrium net benefit of debt for companies?
answer: The equilibrium net benefit of debt is 3.5% of asset value, resulting from a gross benefit of 10.4% minus costs of 6.9% of asset value. The cost of being overlevered is asymmetrically higher than being underlevered, and expected default costs represent only half of the total ex ante costs of debt.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by using exogenous variation in tax benefit functions to estimate firm-specific cost of debt functions conditional on company characteristics, providing a novel empirical approach to quantify the trade-offs in capital structure decisions.

author: Juliane Begenau
title: Fee Variation in Private Equity
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We study how investment fees vary within private equity funds. Net‐of‐fee return clustering suggests that most funds have two tiers of fees, and we decompose differences across tiers into both management‐ and performance‐based fees. Managers of venture capital funds and those in high demand are less likely to use multiple fee schedules. Some investors consistently pay lower fees relative to others within their funds. Investor size, experience, and past performance explain some but not all of this effect, suggesting that unobserved traits like negotiation skill or bargaining power materially impact the fees that investors pay to access private markets.</jats:p>
research_question: How do investment fees vary within private equity funds and what factors explain differences in fees paid by different investors in the same fund?
answer: Most private equity funds have two tiers of fees with differences in both management and performance-based components. Some investors consistently pay lower fees than others within the same fund, with investor size, experience, and past performance explaining only part of this variation - suggesting that unobserved traits like negotiation skill or bargaining power significantly impact the fees investors pay.
positioning_statement: This paper appears to be among the first to systematically examine fee variation within private equity funds (rather than across funds), using net-of-fee return clustering as a novel method to identify multiple fee tiers and highlighting the previously understudied role of investor-specific characteristics and bargaining power in fee determination.
