author: Jules van Binsbergen
title: Optimal Decentralized Investment Management
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We study an institutional investment problem in which a centralized decision maker, the Chief Investment Officer (CIO), for example, employs multiple asset managers to implement investment strategies in separate asset classes. The CIO allocates capital to the managers who, in turn, allocate these funds to the assets in their asset class. This two‐step investment process causes several misalignments of objectives between the CIO and his managers and can lead to large utility costs for the CIO. We focus on (1) loss of diversification, (2) unobservable managerial appetite for risk, and (3) different investment horizons. We derive an optimal unconditional linear performance benchmark and show that this benchmark can be used to better align incentives within the firm. We find that the CIO's uncertainty about the managers' risk appetites increases both the costs of decentralized investment management and the value of an optimally designed benchmark.</jats:p>
research_question: How can a Chief Investment Officer optimally design performance benchmarks to align incentives with multiple asset managers in a decentralized investment management structure, given misalignments in objectives such as loss of diversification, unobservable managerial risk appetite, and different investment horizons?
answer: An optimal unconditional linear performance benchmark can be derived and used to better align incentives between the CIO and managers, with the value of this optimally designed benchmark increasing when there is greater uncertainty about managers' risk appetites.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the institutional investment problem of decentralized management by focusing on three specific sources of misalignment between CIOs and asset managers: loss of diversification, unobservable managerial risk appetite, and different investment horizons, providing a framework for optimal benchmark design to mitigate the utility costs arising from these agency problems.

author: Jun Pan
title: Dynamic Asset Allocation with Event Risk
abstract: <jats:p>Major events often trigger abrupt changes in stock prices and volatility. We study the implications of jumps in prices and volatility on investment strategies. Using the event‐risk framework of <jats:ext-link xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="#jofi523-bib-0019">Duffie, Pan, and Singleton (2000)</jats:ext-link>, we provide analytical solutions to the optimal portfolio problem. Event risk dramatically affects the optimal strategy. An investor facing event risk is less willing to take leveraged or short positions. The investor acts as if some portion of his wealth may become illiquid and the optimal strategy blends both dynamic and buy‐and‐hold strategies. Jumps in prices and volatility both have important effects.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the implications of jumps in prices and volatility (event risk) on optimal investment strategies?
answer: Event risk dramatically affects optimal investment strategies by making investors less willing to take leveraged or short positions. Investors behave as if some portion of their wealth may become illiquid, leading to optimal strategies that blend both dynamic and buy-and-hold approaches, with both price jumps and volatility jumps having important effects.
positioning_statement: This paper builds on the event-risk framework of Duffie, Pan, and Singleton (2000) by providing analytical solutions to the optimal portfolio problem under event risk, specifically focusing on how major events that trigger abrupt changes in stock prices and volatility affect dynamic asset allocation decisions.

author: Jun Pan
title: The SOE Premium and Government Support in China's Credit Market
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Studying China's credit market using a structural default model that integrates credit risk, liquidity, and bailout, we document improved price discovery and a deepening divide between state‐owned enterprises (SOEs) and non‐SOEs. Amidst liquidity deterioration, the presence of government bailout helps alleviate the heightened liquidity‐driven default, making SOE bonds more valuable and widening the SOE premium. Meanwhile, the increased importance of government support makes SOEs more sensitive to bailout, while the heightened default risk increases non‐SOEs' sensitivity to credit quality. Examining the real impact, we find severe performance deteriorations of non‐SOEs relative to SOEs, reversing the long‐standing trend of non‐SOEs outperforming SOEs.</jats:p>
research_question: How do credit risk, liquidity conditions, and government bailout expectations interact to affect the pricing and performance differences between state-owned enterprises (SOEs) and non-SOEs in China's credit market?
answer: The study finds that government bailout expectations help SOEs during liquidity deterioration by alleviating liquidity-driven default risk, making SOE bonds more valuable and widening the SOE premium. This has led to improved price discovery, a deepening divide between SOEs and non-SOEs, with non-SOEs experiencing severe performance deteriorations that reverse the historical trend of non-SOEs outperforming SOEs.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by developing a structural default model that uniquely integrates three key factors - credit risk, liquidity, and bailout expectations - to explain pricing dynamics in China's credit market, providing new insights into how government support mechanisms affect the relative performance and valuation of SOEs versus non-SOEs.

author: Justin Murfin
title: Is the Risk of Sea Level Rise Capitalized in Residential Real Estate?
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Using a comprehensive database of coastal home sales merged with data on elevation relative to local tides, we compare prices for houses based on their inundation threshold under projections of sea level rise. The analysis separates the sensitivity of housing to rising seas from other confounding characteristics by exploiting cross-sectional differences in relative sea level rise due to vertical land motion. This provides variation in the expected time to inundation for properties of similar elevation and distance from the coast. In a variety of specifications and test settings, we find precisely estimated null results suggesting limited price effects.</jats:p>
research_question: Is the risk of sea level rise capitalized in residential real estate prices?
answer: The study finds precisely estimated null results suggesting limited price effects, indicating that sea level rise risk is not significantly capitalized in residential real estate prices.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by using a novel approach that exploits cross-sectional differences in relative sea level rise due to vertical land motion to separate the sensitivity of housing to rising seas from other confounding characteristics, providing cleaner identification than previous studies.

author: Justin Murfin
title: The Supply‐Side Determinants of Loan Contract Strictness
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Using a measure of contract strictness based on the probability of a covenant violation, I investigate how lender‐specific shocks impact the strictness of the loan contract that a borrower receives. Banks write tighter contracts than their peers after suffering payment defaults to their own loan portfolios, even when defaulting borrowers are in different industries and geographic regions from the current borrower. The effects persist after controlling for bank capitalization, although bank equity compression is also associated with tighter contracts. The evidence suggests that recent defaults inform the lender's perception of its own screening ability, thereby impacting its contracting behavior.</jats:p>
research_question: How do lender-specific shocks impact the strictness of loan contracts that borrowers receive?
answer: Banks write tighter contracts than their peers after suffering payment defaults to their own loan portfolios, even when defaulting borrowers are in different industries and geographic regions from the current borrower, suggesting that recent defaults inform the lender's perception of its own screening ability and impact contracting behavior.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by focusing on supply-side (lender-specific) determinants of loan contract strictness, using a novel measure based on covenant violation probability, and demonstrating that lenders' recent default experiences affect their contracting behavior beyond traditional factors like bank capitalization.

author: Jun Pan
title: Default and Recovery Implicit in the Term Structure of Sovereign CDS Spreads
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>This paper explores the nature of default arrival and recovery implicit in the term structures of sovereign <jats:italic>CDS</jats:italic> spreads. We argue that term structures of spreads reveal not only the arrival rates of credit events , but also the loss rates given credit events. Applying our framework to Mexico, Turkey, and Korea, we show that a single‐factor model with  following a lognormal process captures most of the variation in the term structures of spreads. The risk premiums associated with unpredictable variation in  are found to be economically significant and co‐vary importantly with several economic measures of global event risk, financial market volatility, and macroeconomic policy.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the nature of default arrival and recovery rates implicit in the term structures of sovereign CDS spreads?
answer: Term structures of sovereign CDS spreads reveal both arrival rates of credit events and loss rates given credit events, with a single-factor model using a lognormal process capturing most variation in spread term structures, and associated risk premiums being economically significant and correlated with global event risk, financial market volatility, and macroeconomic policy measures.
positioning_statement: This paper argues that term structures of spreads reveal not only the arrival rates of credit events but also the loss rates given credit events, extending beyond existing literature that may focus on only one of these components.

author: Jun Pan
title: The Illiquidity of Corporate Bonds
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>This paper examines the illiquidity of corporate bonds and its asset‐pricing implications. Using transactions data from 2003 to 2009, we show that the illiquidity in corporate bonds is substantial, significantly greater than what can be explained by bid–ask spreads. We establish a strong link between bond illiquidity and bond prices. In aggregate, changes in market‐level illiquidity explain a substantial part of the time variation in yield spreads of high‐rated (AAA through A) bonds, overshadowing the credit risk component. In the cross‐section, the bond‐level illiquidity measure explains individual bond yield spreads with large economic significance.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the extent of illiquidity in corporate bonds and how does it affect bond pricing?
answer: Corporate bond illiquidity is substantial and significantly greater than what bid-ask spreads can explain. Bond illiquidity has a strong link to bond prices, with market-level illiquidity changes explaining a substantial part of yield spread time variation in high-rated bonds (overshadowing credit risk), and bond-level illiquidity explaining individual bond yield spreads with large economic significance.
positioning_statement: This paper provides empirical evidence using transactions data from 2003 to 2009 to quantify corporate bond illiquidity and establish its asset-pricing implications, demonstrating that illiquidity effects are more substantial than previously captured by traditional bid-ask spread measures and showing that illiquidity can overshadow credit risk in explaining yield spreads for high-rated bonds.

author: Justin Murfin
title: Who Finances Durable Goods and Why It Matters: Captive Finance and the Coase Conjecture
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We propose that, by financing their own product sales through captive finance subsidiaries, durable goods manufacturers commit to higher resale values for their products in future periods. Using data on captive financing by the manufacturers of heavy equipment, we find that captive‐backed models have lower price depreciation. The evidence is consistent with captive finance helping manufacturers commit to ex‐post actions that support used machine prices. This, in turn, conveys higher pledgeability for captive‐backed products, even for individual machines financed by banks. Although motivated as a rent‐seeking device, captive financing generates positive spillovers by relaxing credit constraints.</jats:p>
research_question: How does captive financing by durable goods manufacturers affect product resale values and credit constraints?
answer: Captive finance subsidiaries help manufacturers commit to higher resale values for their products in future periods, leading to lower price depreciation and higher pledgeability that relaxes credit constraints, even generating positive spillovers for products financed by banks.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the Coase Conjecture by proposing that captive financing serves as a commitment mechanism for manufacturers to support used product prices, offering a new perspective on why manufacturers establish captive finance subsidiaries beyond traditional rent-seeking motivations.

author: Kelly Shue
title: Can the Market Multiply and Divide? Non‐Proportional Thinking in Financial Markets
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We hypothesize that investors partially think about stock price changes in dollar rather than percentage units, leading to more extreme return responses to news for lower‐priced stocks. Consistent with such non‐proportional thinking, we find a doubling in price is associated with a 20% to 30% decline in volatility and beta (controlling for size/liquidity). To identify a causal price effect, we show that volatility jumps following stock splits and drops following reverse splits. Lower‐priced stocks also respond more strongly to firm‐specific news. Non‐proportional thinking helps explain asset pricing patterns such as the size‐volatility/beta relation, the leverage effect puzzle, and return drift and reversals.</jats:p>
research_question: Do investors think about stock price changes in dollar rather than percentage units, and does this lead to more extreme return responses to news for lower-priced stocks?
answer: Yes, investors exhibit non-proportional thinking by partially considering stock price changes in dollar units rather than percentage units, which causes lower-priced stocks to have higher volatility and beta - specifically, a doubling in price is associated with a 20% to 30% decline in volatility and beta.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces the concept of non-proportional thinking as a behavioral explanation for several existing asset pricing puzzles, including the size-volatility/beta relation, the leverage effect puzzle, and return drift and reversals, providing a unifying framework for understanding these previously unexplained market patterns.

author: Kelly Shue
title: How Do Quasi‐Random Option Grants Affect CEO Risk‐Taking?
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We examine how an increase in stock option grants affects CEO risk‐taking. The overall net effect of option grants is theoretically ambiguous for risk‐averse CEOs. To overcome the endogeneity of option grants, we exploit institutional features of multiyear compensation plans, which generate two distinct types of variation in the timing of when large increases in new at‐the‐money options are granted. We find that, given average grant levels during our sample period, a 10% increase in new options granted leads to a 2.8% to 4.2% increase in equity volatility. This increase in risk is driven largely by increased leverage.</jats:p>
research_question: How does an increase in stock option grants affect CEO risk-taking behavior?
answer: A 10% increase in new options granted leads to a 2.8% to 4.2% increase in equity volatility, with this increased risk driven largely by increased leverage.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the theoretical ambiguity regarding the net effect of option grants on risk-averse CEOs' behavior by using quasi-random variation from multiyear compensation plans to overcome endogeneity issues that have limited previous research.

author: Justin Murfin
title: Equity Price Discovery with Informed Private Debt
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Equity markets fail to account for the value-relevant nonpublic information enjoyed by syndicated loan participants and reflected in publicly posted loan prices. A long-short strategy that buys (sells) the equities of firms with recently appreciated (depreciated) loans earns large risk-adjusted returns, suggesting a surprising and economically important level of segmentation across the same firm’s capital structure. The information lag captured by trading strategy returns is not affected by drivers of firm-specific attention, including the publication of loan returns in the Wall Street Journal. Instead, returns to the strategy are eliminated among equities held by mutual funds also trading in syndicated loans.</jats:p><jats:p>Authors have furnished an Internet Appendix, which is available on the Oxford University Press Web site next to the link to the final published paper online.</jats:p>
research_question: Do equity markets efficiently incorporate value-relevant nonpublic information that is available to syndicated loan participants and reflected in loan prices?
answer: Equity markets fail to account for information from syndicated loan markets, as evidenced by large risk-adjusted returns from a trading strategy that buys equities of firms with recently appreciated loans and sells equities of firms with recently depreciated loans, indicating significant segmentation across the same firm's capital structure.
positioning_statement: This paper identifies a surprising and economically important level of market segmentation within the same firm's capital structure, showing that equity price discovery fails to incorporate information already reflected in loan markets, with this inefficiency only eliminated when mutual funds trade in both markets simultaneously.

author: Kelly Shue
title: Growth through rigidity: An explanation for the rise in CEO pay

author: Kelly Shue
title: A Tough Act to Follow: Contrast Effects in Financial Markets
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>A contrast effect occurs when the value of a previously observed signal inversely biases perception of the next signal. We present the first evidence that contrast effects can distort prices in sophisticated and liquid markets. Investors mistakenly perceive earnings news today as more impressive if yesterday's earnings surprise was bad and less impressive if yesterday's surprise was good. A unique advantage of our financial setting is that we can identify contrast effects as an error in perceptions rather than expectations. Finally, we show that our results cannot be explained by an alternative explanation involving information transmission from previous earnings announcements.</jats:p>
research_question: Do contrast effects occur in financial markets, where investors' perception of current earnings news is inversely biased by previously observed earnings signals?
answer: Yes, contrast effects distort prices in sophisticated and liquid financial markets - investors mistakenly perceive today's earnings news as more impressive following bad yesterday's earnings surprises and less impressive following good yesterday's surprises.
positioning_statement: This paper presents the first evidence that contrast effects can distort prices in sophisticated and liquid markets, with the unique advantage of identifying contrast effects as errors in perceptions rather than expectations, distinguishing it from alternative explanations involving information transmission from previous earnings announcements.

author: Kelly Shue
title: The Gender Gap in Housing Returns
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Using detailed transactions data across the United States, we find that single women earn 1.5 percentage points lower annualized returns on housing relative to single men. Forty‐five percent of the gap is explained by transaction timing and location. The remaining gap arises from a 2% gender difference in execution prices at purchase and sale. Consistent with a negotiation channel, women list for less and experience worse negotiated discounts. The gender gap shrinks in tight markets, where negotiation is replaced by quasi‐auctions. Overall, gender differences in housing explain 30% of the gender gap in wealth accumulation for the median household.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the gender gap in housing returns between single women and single men, and what factors explain this gap?
answer: Single women earn 1.5 percentage points lower annualized returns on housing relative to single men, with 45% of the gap explained by transaction timing and location, and the remaining gap arising from a 2% gender difference in execution prices at purchase and sale due to negotiation differences.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on gender differences in wealth accumulation by identifying housing returns as a significant factor, showing that gender differences in housing explain 30% of the gender gap in wealth accumulation for the median household, with the mechanism operating through negotiation differences rather than just timing and location choices.

author: Kenneth Ahern
title: Who Writes the News? Corporate Press Releases during Merger Negotiations
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Firms have an incentive to manage media coverage to influence their stock prices during important corporate events. Using comprehensive data on media coverage and merger negotiations, we find that bidders in stock mergers originate substantially more news stories after the start of merger negotiations, but before the public announcement. This strategy generates a short‐lived run‐up in bidders' stock prices during the period when the stock exchange ratio is determined, which substantially impacts the takeover price. Our results demonstrate that the timing and content of financial media coverage may be biased by firms seeking to manipulate their stock price.</jats:p>
research_question: Do firms strategically manage media coverage to influence their stock prices during merger negotiations, particularly before public announcements?
answer: Yes, bidders in stock mergers originate substantially more news stories after merger negotiations begin but before public announcement, creating short-lived stock price run-ups during the period when exchange ratios are determined, which significantly impacts takeover prices.
positioning_statement: This paper demonstrates that financial media coverage timing and content may be biased by firms seeking stock price manipulation, contributing to the literature on corporate information management and media influence on financial markets during merger events.

author: Kenneth Ahern
title: The Importance of Industry Links in Merger Waves
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We represent the economy as a network of industries connected through customer and supplier trade flows. Using this network topology, we find that stronger product market connections lead to a greater incidence of cross‐industry mergers. Furthermore, mergers propagate in waves across the network through customer‐supplier links. Merger activity transmits to close industries quickly and to distant industries with a delay. Finally, economy‐wide merger waves are driven by merger activity in industries that are centrally located in the product market network. Overall, we show that the network of real economic transactions helps to explain the formation and propagation of merger waves.</jats:p>
research_question: How do industry connections through customer-supplier relationships affect the formation and propagation of merger waves across the economy?
answer: Stronger product market connections lead to greater cross-industry merger activity, mergers propagate in waves through customer-supplier networks (quickly to close industries, with delay to distant ones), and economy-wide merger waves are driven by merger activity in centrally located industries within the product market network.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to merger wave literature by introducing a network-based approach that uses the topology of real economic transactions through customer-supplier trade flows to explain merger wave formation and propagation, rather than relying solely on traditional explanations.

author: Kerry Back
title: Working Orders in Limit Order Markets and Floor Exchanges
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We analyze limit order markets and floor exchanges, assuming an informed trader and discretionary liquidity traders use market orders and can either submit block orders or work their demands as a series of small orders. By working their demands, large market order traders pool with small traders. We show that every equilibrium on a floor exchange must involve at least partial pooling. Moreover, there is always a fully pooling (worked order) equilibrium on a floor exchange that is equivalent to a block order equilibrium in a limit order market.</jats:p>
research_question: How do trading strategies differ between limit order markets and floor exchanges when traders can choose between submitting block orders versus working their demands as a series of small orders?
answer: Every equilibrium on a floor exchange must involve at least partial pooling of large and small traders, and there always exists a fully pooling (worked order) equilibrium on a floor exchange that is equivalent to a block order equilibrium in a limit order market.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on market microstructure by comparing limit order markets and floor exchanges, specifically analyzing the strategic choice between block orders and worked orders when informed and discretionary liquidity traders can pool together through order fragmentation.

author: Kim Peijnenburg
title: Household Portfolio Underdiversification and Probability Weighting: Evidence from the Field
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We test whether probability weighting affects household portfolio choice in a representative survey. On average, people display inverse-S-shaped probability weighting, overweighting low probability events. As theory predicts, probability weighting is positively associated with portfolio underdiversification and significant Sharpe ratio losses. Analyzing respondents’ individual stock holdings, we find higher probability weighting is associated with owning lottery-type stocks and positively skewed equity portfolios. People with higher probability weighting are less likely to own mutual funds and more likely to either avoid equities or hold individual stocks. We are the first to empirically link individuals’ elicited probability weighting and real-world decisions under risk.</jats:p>
research_question: Does probability weighting affect household portfolio choice and diversification decisions?
answer: Yes, probability weighting significantly affects portfolio choice. People with inverse-S-shaped probability weighting (who overweight low probability events) exhibit greater portfolio underdiversification, experience significant Sharpe ratio losses, are more likely to own lottery-type stocks and positively skewed equity portfolios, and are less likely to own mutual funds.
positioning_statement: This paper is the first to empirically link individuals' elicited probability weighting to real-world decisions under risk, testing theoretical predictions about probability weighting and portfolio choice using representative survey data from actual household investment decisions.

author: Kerry Back
title: Imperfect Competition among Informed Traders
abstract: <jats:p>We analyze competition among informed traders in the continuous‐time Kyle(1985) model, as Foster and Viswanathan (1996) do in discrete time. We explicitly describe the unique linear equilibrium when signals are imperfectly correlated and confirm the conjecture of Holden and Subrahmanyam (1992) that there is no linear equilibrium when signals are perfectly correlated. One result is that at some date, and at all dates thereafter, the market would have been more informationally efficient had there been a monopolist informed trader instead of competing traders. The relatively large amount of private information remaining near the end of trading causes the market to approach complete illiquidity.</jats:p>
research_question: How does competition among informed traders affect market efficiency and liquidity in a continuous-time trading model?
answer: Competition among informed traders can actually reduce market efficiency compared to a monopolist trader, particularly near the end of trading when large amounts of private information remain, causing the market to approach complete illiquidity.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the discrete-time analysis of Foster and Viswanathan (1996) to continuous time using the Kyle (1985) model framework, and provides explicit confirmation of Holden and Subrahmanyam's (1992) conjecture about the non-existence of linear equilibrium when signals are perfectly correlated.

author: Kristoph Kleiner
title: Competing for Talent: Firms, Managers, and Social Networks
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Do social networks help firms recruit talented managers? In our setting, firms are randomly connected to prospective young managers through former employees. Under a discrete choice model, we find networks increase the likelihood firms hire high-ability managers, while having no effect on the hiring rate of low-ability managers. Effects are greatest for nonlocal firms, strong ties, and peers living in the same neighborhood. Survey evidence suggests social networks promote recruitment by providing information about firm fundamentals to potential applicants. Our results help rationalize why the majority of managers hold prior connections to the firm.</jats:p>
research_question: Do social networks help firms recruit talented managers?
answer: Yes, social networks increase the likelihood that firms hire high-ability managers while having no effect on the hiring rate of low-ability managers, with the strongest effects occurring for nonlocal firms, strong ties, and peers living in the same neighborhood.
positioning_statement: This paper provides empirical evidence to help rationalize the observed phenomenon that the majority of managers hold prior connections to their firms, contributing to the literature on social networks in labor markets by demonstrating their specific role in talent recruitment.

author: Kristoph Kleiner
title: Forced Entrepreneurs
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Conventional wisdom suggests that labor market distress drives workers into temporary self‐employment, lowering entrepreneurial quality. Analyzing employment histories for 640,000 U.S. workers, we document that graduating college during a period of high unemployment does increase entry to entrepreneurship. However, compared to voluntary entrepreneurs, firms founded by <jats:italic>forced</jats:italic> entrepreneurs are more likely to survive, innovate, and receive venture backing. Explaining these results, we confirm that labor shocks disproportionately impact high earners, with these workers starting more successful firms. Overall, we document untapped entrepreneurial potential across the top of the income distribution and the role of recessions in reversing this missing entrepreneurship.</jats:p>
research_question: How does labor market distress affect entrepreneurial entry and the quality of firms founded by workers who become entrepreneurs due to employment difficulties?
answer: While labor market distress (graduating during high unemployment) does increase entry to entrepreneurship, firms founded by 'forced' entrepreneurs are actually more likely to survive, innovate, and receive venture backing compared to voluntary entrepreneurs, because labor shocks disproportionately impact high earners who start more successful firms.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the conventional wisdom that labor market distress drives workers into temporary self-employment and lowers entrepreneurial quality, instead documenting that there is untapped entrepreneurial potential across the top of the income distribution and that recessions can reverse this missing entrepreneurship.

author: Kristoph Kleiner
title: Credit and Punishment: Are Corporate Bankers Disciplined for Risk-Taking?
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We examine whether bankers face disciplining consequences for structuring poorly performing corporate loans. We construct a novel data set containing the employment histories and loan portfolios of a large sample of corporate bankers and find that corporate credit events (i.e., downgrades, defaults, bankruptcies) increase banker turnover. The effect is pronounced when bankers issue loans with loose terms or experience severe losses. Credit events prompt bankers to adopt stricter future risk management practices, such as offering restrictive covenant packages. Overall, our findings are consistent with banks disciplining employees as a means to manage their own risk exposure.</jats:p>
research_question: Do corporate bankers face disciplining consequences for structuring poorly performing corporate loans?
answer: Yes, corporate bankers are disciplined for risk-taking - credit events (downgrades, defaults, bankruptcies) increase banker turnover, especially when bankers issue loans with loose terms or experience severe losses, and surviving bankers adopt stricter future risk management practices.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes novel empirical evidence on banker-level discipline by constructing a unique dataset of employment histories and loan portfolios to examine how banks manage risk exposure through employee discipline, addressing a gap in understanding individual banker accountability for loan performance.

author: Kim Peijnenburg
title: Noncognitive Abilities and Financial Distress: Evidence from a Representative Household Panel
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>This paper provides evidence of how noncognitive abilities affect financial distress. In a representative panel of households, we find that people in the bottom quintile of noncognitive abilities are 10 times more likely to experience financial distress than those in the top quintile. We provide evidence that this relation largely arises from worse financial choices and lack of financial insight by low-ability individuals and reflects differential exposure to income shocks only to a lesser degree. We mitigate endogeneity concerns using an IV approach and an extensive set of controls. Implications for policy and finance research are discussed.</jats:p><jats:p>Received September 24, 2017; editorial decision September 26, 2018 by Editor Stijn Van Nieuwerburgh. Authors have furnished an Internet Appendix, which is available on the Oxford University Press Web site next to the link to the final published paper online.</jats:p>
research_question: How do noncognitive abilities affect financial distress?
answer: People in the bottom quintile of noncognitive abilities are 10 times more likely to experience financial distress than those in the top quintile, and this relation largely arises from worse financial choices and lack of financial insight by low-ability individuals rather than differential exposure to income shocks.
positioning_statement: This paper provides new evidence on the relationship between noncognitive abilities and financial distress using a representative household panel, addressing endogeneity concerns through instrumental variable approaches and extensive controls, with implications for both policy and finance research.

author: Kristoph Kleiner
title: Friends with bankruptcy protection benefits

author: Lars-Alexander Kuehn
title: Consumption Volatility Risk
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We show that time variation in macroeconomic uncertainty affects asset prices. Consumption volatility is a negatively priced source of risk for a wide variety of test portfolios. At the firm level, exposure to consumption volatility risk predicts future returns, generating a spread across quintile portfolios in excess of 7% annually. This premium is explained by cross‐sectional differences in the sensitivity of dividend volatility to consumption volatility. Stocks with volatile cash flows in uncertain aggregate times require higher expected returns.</jats:p>
research_question: How does time variation in macroeconomic uncertainty affect asset prices?
answer: Consumption volatility is a negatively priced source of risk that affects asset prices, with exposure to consumption volatility risk predicting future returns and generating a spread of over 7% annually across quintile portfolios, explained by differences in dividend volatility sensitivity to consumption volatility.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by demonstrating that macroeconomic uncertainty, specifically consumption volatility, is a systematic risk factor that affects asset pricing across various portfolios and at the firm level, with stocks having volatile cash flows during uncertain times requiring higher expected returns.

author: Lars-Alexander Kuehn
title: Investment‐Based Corporate Bond Pricing
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>A standard assumption of structural models of default is that firms' assets evolve exogenously. In this paper, we examine the importance of accounting for investment options in models of credit risk. In the presence of financing and investment frictions, firm‐level variables that proxy for asset composition are significant determinants of credit spreads beyond leverage and asset volatility, because they capture the systematic risk of firms' assets. Cross‐sectional studies of credit spreads that fail to control for the interdependence of leverage and investment decisions are unlikely to be very informative. Such frictions also give rise to a realistic term structure of credit spreads in a production economy.</jats:p>
research_question: How important is it to account for investment options and the interdependence of leverage and investment decisions in structural models of credit risk and corporate bond pricing?
answer: Investment options are crucial for credit risk models - firm-level variables that proxy for asset composition are significant determinants of credit spreads beyond traditional factors like leverage and asset volatility, because they capture the systematic risk of firms' assets, and accounting for financing and investment frictions produces a realistic term structure of credit spreads.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the standard assumption in structural models of default that firms' assets evolve exogenously, and argues that cross-sectional studies of credit spreads that fail to control for the interdependence of leverage and investment decisions are unlikely to be very informative.

author: Lars-Alexander Kuehn
title: Learning about the consumption risk exposure of firms

author: Lars-Alexander Kuehn
title: A Labor Capital Asset Pricing Model
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We show that labor search frictions are an important determinant of the cross‐section of equity returns. Empirically, we find that firms with low loadings on labor market tightness outperform firms with high loadings by 6% annually. We propose a partial equilibrium labor market model in which heterogeneous firms make dynamic employment decisions under labor search frictions. In the model, loadings on labor market tightness proxy for priced time‐variation in the efficiency of the aggregate matching technology. Firms with low loadings are more exposed to adverse matching efficiency shocks and require higher expected stock returns.</jats:p>
research_question: How do labor search frictions affect the cross-section of equity returns?
answer: Firms with low loadings on labor market tightness outperform firms with high loadings by 6% annually, as low-loading firms are more exposed to adverse matching efficiency shocks and require higher expected stock returns as compensation.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces labor search frictions as an important but previously underexplored determinant of cross-sectional equity return variation, proposing a partial equilibrium labor market model that connects firm-level employment decisions to asset pricing through the efficiency of aggregate matching technology.

author: Lars-Alexander Kuehn
title: Persistent Crises and Levered Asset Prices
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>This paper shows that standard disaster risk models are inconsistent with movements in stock market volatility and credit spreads during disasters. We resolve this shortcoming by incorporating persistent macroeconomic crises into a structural credit risk model. The model successfully captures the joint dynamics of aggregate consumption, financial leverage, and asset market risks, both unconditionally and during crises. Leverage strongly amplifies fundamental shocks by continuing to rise while crises endure. We structurally estimate the model and show that it replicates the firm-level implied volatility curve and its cross-sectional relation with observable proxies of default risk.</jats:p>
research_question: How can disaster risk models be made consistent with observed movements in stock market volatility and credit spreads during financial crises?
answer: Incorporating persistent macroeconomic crises into a structural credit risk model resolves the inconsistency, with leverage strongly amplifying fundamental shocks by continuing to rise while crises endure, successfully capturing the joint dynamics of aggregate consumption, financial leverage, and asset market risks.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a shortcoming in standard disaster risk models by showing they are inconsistent with volatility and credit spread movements during disasters, and proposes a solution that extends existing structural credit risk models to incorporate persistent macroeconomic crises.

author: Laura Veldkamp
title: The Changing Economics of Knowledge Production
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Big data technologies change the way in which data and labor combine to create knowledge. Is this a modest innovation or a data revolution? Using hiring and wage data, we estimate firms’ data stocks and their knowledge production functions. Quantifying changes in production functions informs us about the likely long-run changes in output, in factor shares, and in the distribution of income, due to big data technologies. For the investment management industry, our structural estimates predict a 5% decline in the labor share of income; that change is comparable to similar estimates for the industrial revolution.</jats:p>
               <jats:p>Authors have furnished an Internet Appendix, which is available on the Oxford University Press Web site next to the link to the final published paper online</jats:p>
research_question: Is the impact of big data technologies on knowledge production a modest innovation or a data revolution, and what are the quantifiable effects on output, factor shares, and income distribution?
answer: Big data technologies represent a significant transformation comparable to the industrial revolution, with structural estimates predicting a 5% decline in the labor share of income in the investment management industry, indicating substantial long-run changes in how data and labor combine to create knowledge.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as providing the first structural estimation approach to quantify the economic impact of big data technologies on knowledge production functions, comparing the magnitude of this technological shift to historical precedents like the industrial revolution.

author: Laura Veldkamp
title: Information Immobility and the Home Bias Puzzle
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Many argue that home bias arises because home investors can predict home asset payoffs more accurately than foreigners can. But why does global information access not eliminate this asymmetry? We model investors, endowed with a small home information advantage, who choose what information to learn before they invest. Surprisingly, even when home investors can learn what foreigners know, they choose not to: Investors profit more from knowing information others do not know. Learning amplifies information asymmetry. The model matches patterns of local and industry bias, foreign investments, portfolio outperformance, and asset prices. Finally, we propose new avenues for empirical research.</jats:p>
research_question: Why does global information access not eliminate the home information advantage that is believed to cause home bias in investment portfolios?
answer: Even when home investors can learn what foreigners know, they choose not to because investors profit more from knowing information that others do not know, and learning amplifies information asymmetry rather than reducing it.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a gap in the existing literature that argues home bias arises from home investors' superior ability to predict home asset payoffs, by explaining why information asymmetries persist despite global information access and providing a model that matches empirical patterns of investment behavior.

author: Laura Veldkamp
title: Valuing Financial Data
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>How should an investor value financial data? The answer is complicated because it depends on the characteristics of all investors. We develop a sufficient statistics approach that uses equilibrium asset return moments to summarize all relevant information about others’ characteristics. Our approach values public or private data, data about one or many assets, and data relevant for dividends or sentiment. While different data types, of course, have different valuations, heterogeneous investors also value the same data very differently. This finding suggests a low price elasticity for data demand. Heterogeneous investors’ data valuations are also affected very differentially by market illiquidity.</jats:p>
research_question: How should an investor value financial data?
answer: The value of financial data depends on the characteristics of all investors and can be determined using a sufficient statistics approach that uses equilibrium asset return moments to summarize all relevant information about others' characteristics. The approach shows that heterogeneous investors value the same data very differently, suggesting low price elasticity for data demand, and their valuations are differentially affected by market illiquidity.
positioning_statement: The paper develops a novel sufficient statistics approach to data valuation that addresses the complexity of valuing financial data in markets with heterogeneous investors, providing a comprehensive framework that can handle various data types (public/private, single/multiple assets, dividend/sentiment-relevant) and accounts for how investor heterogeneity affects data valuations.

author: Laura Veldkamp
title: Where Has All the Data Gone?
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Since the finance industry is transforming into a data industry, measuring the quantity of data investors have about various assets is important. Informed by a structural model, we develop such a cross-sectional measure. We show how our measure differs from price informativeness and use it to document a new fact: data about large high-growth firms is becoming increasingly abundant, relative to data about other firms. Our structural model offers an explanation for this data divergence: large high-growth firms’ data became more valuable, as big firms got bigger and growth magnified the effect of these changes in size.</jats:p>
research_question: How can we measure the quantity of data investors have about various assets, and what patterns exist in data availability across different types of firms?
answer: Data about large high-growth firms is becoming increasingly abundant relative to data about other firms, because these firms' data became more valuable as big firms got bigger and growth magnified the effect of size changes.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a new cross-sectional measure of data quantity that differs from existing price informativeness measures, addressing the gap in measuring data availability as the finance industry transforms into a data industry.

author: Leonid Kogan
title: Growth Opportunities, Technology Shocks, and Asset Prices
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We explore the impact of investment‐specific technology (IST) shocks on the cross section of stock returns. Using a structural model, we show that IST shocks have a differential effect on the value of assets in place and the value of growth opportunities. This differential sensitivity to IST shocks has two main implications. First, firm risk premia depend on the contribution of growth opportunities to firm value. Second, firms with similar levels of growth opportunities comove with each other, giving rise to the value factor in stock returns and the failure of the conditional CAPM. Our empirical tests confirm the model's predictions.</jats:p>
research_question: How do investment-specific technology (IST) shocks impact the cross section of stock returns?
answer: IST shocks have differential effects on assets in place versus growth opportunities, which causes firm risk premia to depend on the contribution of growth opportunities to firm value and creates comovement among firms with similar growth opportunities, explaining the value factor in stock returns and the failure of the conditional CAPM.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing a structural model that explains the value factor in stock returns and the failure of the conditional CAPM through the lens of investment-specific technology shocks, offering a new theoretical framework for understanding cross-sectional variation in stock returns based on the differential impact of technology shocks on assets in place versus growth opportunities.

author: Laura Veldkamp
title: Time‐Varying Fund Manager Skill
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We propose a new definition of skill as general cognitive ability to pick stocks or time the market. We find evidence for stock picking in booms and market timing in recessions. Moreover, the <jats:italic>same</jats:italic> fund managers that pick stocks well in expansions also time the market well in recessions. These fund managers significantly outperform other funds and passive benchmarks. Our results suggest a new measure of managerial ability that weighs a fund's market timing more in recessions and stock picking more in booms. The measure displays more persistence than either market timing or stock picking alone and predicts fund performance.</jats:p>
research_question: How does fund manager skill vary across different market conditions, and can a unified measure of skill that accounts for time-varying abilities better predict fund performance?
answer: Fund managers demonstrate stock picking skill during booms and market timing skill during recessions, with the same managers excelling at both abilities in their respective optimal periods. A new measure that weighs market timing more heavily in recessions and stock picking more heavily in booms shows greater persistence and better predicts fund performance than traditional single-skill measures.
positioning_statement: This paper proposes a new definition of skill as general cognitive ability that manifests differently across market conditions, contrasting with existing literature that typically treats stock picking and market timing as separate, static abilities, and introduces a time-varying composite measure that demonstrates superior persistence and predictive power compared to traditional skill measures.

author: Leonid Kogan
title: Near-Rational Equilibria in Heterogeneous-Agent Models: A Verification Method
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We propose a general simulation-based procedure for estimating the quality of approximate policies in heterogeneous-agent equilibrium models, which allows us to verify that such approximate solutions describe a near-rational equilibrium. Our procedure endows agents with superior knowledge of the future path of the economy, while imposing a suitable penalty for such foresight. The relaxed problem is more tractable than the original, and results in an upper bound on agents’ welfare. Our method applies to various solution algorithms. We illustrate our approach in two applications: the incomplete-markets model of Krusell and Smith (1998) and the heterogeneous firm model of Khan and Thomas (2008).</jats:p>
research_question: How can we verify that approximate solutions in heterogeneous-agent equilibrium models describe a near-rational equilibrium and estimate the quality of these approximate policies?
answer: The authors develop a general simulation-based procedure that provides agents with superior knowledge of the future path of the economy while imposing a penalty for such foresight, creating a more tractable relaxed problem that yields an upper bound on agents' welfare and allows verification of near-rational equilibria.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a methodological gap in the heterogeneous-agent modeling literature by providing a general verification method that can be applied to various solution algorithms, demonstrated through applications to established models by Krusell and Smith (1998) and Khan and Thomas (2008).

author: Leonid Kogan
title: Mutual Fund Trading Pressure: Firm‐Level Stock Price Impact and Timing of SEOs
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We use price pressure resulting from purchases by mutual funds with large capital inflows to identify overvalued equity. This is a relatively exogenous overvaluation indicator as it is associated with who is buying—buyers with excess liquidity—rather than what is being purchased. We document substantial stock price impact associated with purchases by high‐inflow mutual funds, and find the probability of a seasoned equity offering (SEO), insider sales, and the probability of a stock‐based acquisition increase significantly in the four quarters following the mutual fund buying pressure. These results provide new evidence that firm managers are able to identify and exploit overvalued equity.</jats:p>
research_question: Can mutual fund trading pressure from large capital inflows serve as an indicator of equity overvaluation, and do firm managers exploit such overvaluation through corporate actions like SEOs, insider sales, and stock-based acquisitions?
answer: Yes, purchases by high-inflow mutual funds create substantial stock price impact that serves as a relatively exogenous overvaluation indicator, and firm managers do exploit this overvaluation - the probability of SEOs, insider sales, and stock-based acquisitions increases significantly in the four quarters following mutual fund buying pressure.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a novel approach to identifying overvalued equity by using mutual fund trading pressure as a relatively exogenous indicator based on who is buying (buyers with excess liquidity) rather than what is being purchased, offering new evidence on managers' ability to identify and exploit overvaluation.

author: Leonid Kogan
title: Oil Futures Prices in a Production Economy with Investment Constraints
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We document a new stylized fact, that the relationship between the volatility of oil futures prices and the slope of the forward curve is nonmonotone and has a V‐shape. This pattern cannot be generated by standard models that emphasize storage. We develop an equilibrium model of oil production in which investment is irreversible and capacity constrained. Investment constraints affect firms' investment decisions and imply that the supply elasticity changes over time. Since demand shocks must be absorbed by changes in prices or changes in supply, time‐varying supply elasticity results in time‐varying volatility of futures prices. Estimating this model, we show it is quantitatively consistent with the V‐shape relationship between the volatility of futures prices and the slope of the forward curve.</jats:p>
research_question: Why does the relationship between oil futures price volatility and the slope of the forward curve exhibit a V-shaped pattern, and what economic mechanisms can explain this stylized fact?
answer: The V-shaped relationship between oil futures price volatility and forward curve slope is explained by time-varying supply elasticity caused by investment constraints in oil production. When firms face irreversible and capacity-constrained investment decisions, supply elasticity changes over time, and since demand shocks must be absorbed by either price or supply changes, this results in time-varying volatility of futures prices that creates the observed V-shape pattern.
positioning_statement: This paper identifies a new stylized fact that cannot be explained by standard storage-based models in the existing literature, and fills this gap by developing a novel equilibrium model of oil production that incorporates investment irreversibility and capacity constraints to explain the previously unexplained V-shaped volatility pattern.

author: Leonid Kogan
title: Operating Hedge and Gross Profitability Premium
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We show theoretically that variable production costs reduce systematic risk of firms' cash flows if capital and variable inputs are complementary in firms' production and input prices are procyclical. In our dynamic model, this operating hedge effect is weaker for more profitable firms, giving rise to a gross profitability premium. Moreover, gross profitability and value factors are distinct and negatively correlated, and their premia are not captured by the capital asset pricing model (CAPM). We estimate the model by simulated method of moments, and find that its main implications for stock returns and cash flow dynamics are quantitatively consistent with the data.</jats:p>
research_question: How do variable production costs affect systematic risk of firms' cash flows and what is the relationship between operating hedging effects and the gross profitability premium?
answer: Variable production costs reduce systematic risk of firms' cash flows when capital and variable inputs are complementary and input prices are procyclical, and this operating hedge effect is weaker for more profitable firms, which explains the gross profitability premium.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a theoretical explanation for the gross profitability premium through an operating hedge mechanism, showing that gross profitability and value factors are distinct and negatively correlated, with their premia not captured by the traditional CAPM model.

author: Leonid Kogan
title: Measuring “Dark Matter” in Asset Pricing Models
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We formalize the concept of “dark matter” in asset pricing models by quantifying the additional informativeness of cross‐equation restrictions about fundamental dynamics. The dark‐matter measure captures the degree of fragility for models that are potentially misspecified and unstable: a large dark‐matter measure indicates that the model lacks internal refutability (weak power of optimal specification tests) and external validity (high overfitting tendency and poor out‐of‐sample fit). The measure can be computed at low cost even for complex dynamic structural models. To illustrate its applications, we provide quantitative examples applying the measure to (time‐varying) rare‐disaster risk and long‐run risk models.</jats:p>
research_question: How can we quantify the degree of fragility and misspecification in asset pricing models by measuring the additional informativeness of cross-equation restrictions about fundamental dynamics?
answer: The paper develops a 'dark matter' measure that captures model fragility - models with large dark matter measures lack internal refutability (weak specification test power) and external validity (high overfitting and poor out-of-sample performance), while the measure can be computed efficiently even for complex dynamic structural models.
positioning_statement: This paper formalizes and operationalizes the concept of 'dark matter' in asset pricing models, providing a new methodological tool to assess model fragility that complements existing specification testing approaches by focusing on the informativeness of cross-equation restrictions.

author: Lu Zhang
title: The Value Premium
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>The value anomaly arises naturally in the neoclassical framework with rational expectations. Costly reversibility and countercyclical price of risk cause assets in place to be harder to reduce, and hence are riskier than growth options especially in bad times when the price of risk is high. By linking risk and expected returns to economic primitives, such as tastes and technology, my model generates many empirical regularities in the cross‐section of returns; it also yields an array of new refutable hypotheses providing fresh directions for future empirical research.</jats:p>
research_question: How can the value premium anomaly be explained within a neoclassical framework with rational expectations?
answer: The value premium arises naturally due to costly reversibility and countercyclical price of risk, which make assets in place riskier than growth options, especially during bad economic times when the price of risk is high.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as providing a neoclassical rational expectations explanation for the value anomaly, linking risk and expected returns to fundamental economic primitives (tastes and technology) rather than relying on behavioral or market inefficiency explanations.

author: Leonid Kogan
title: The Price Impact and Survival of Irrational Traders
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Milton Friedman argued that irrational traders will consistently lose money, will not survive, and, therefore, cannot influence long‐run asset prices. Since his work, survival and price impact have been assumed to be the same. In this paper, we demonstrate that survival and price impact are two independent concepts. The price impact of irrational traders does not rely on their long‐run survival, and they can have a significant impact on asset prices even when their wealth becomes negligible. We also show that irrational traders' portfolio policies can deviate from their limits long after the price process approaches its long‐run limit.</jats:p>
research_question: Can irrational traders influence long-run asset prices even if they do not survive in the market, challenging Milton Friedman's argument that survival and price impact are linked?
answer: Survival and price impact are two independent concepts - irrational traders can have significant impact on asset prices even when their wealth becomes negligible and they do not survive in the long run.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the conventional wisdom established by Milton Friedman and subsequent literature that has assumed survival and price impact are equivalent concepts, demonstrating instead that these are independent phenomena.

author: Loukas Karabarbounis
title: Beyond the three lines of defense: The five lines of defense model for financial institutions
abstract: <jats:p>he purpose of this study is to provide an updated version of the widely accepted three lines of defense model (3LoD) to better apply for regulated financial institutions. The author proposes the five lines of defense model (5LoD) which consists of the existing three lines along with external audit and regulators (comprising the fourth and fifth line of defense respectively). In spite of the fact that the bodies forming the two additional lines of defense constitute the external lines of defense, there should be active in supervising and monitoring control issues within the organization, in strong cooperation with the internal lines. This calls for closer interaction among the internal auditors, external auditors and regulators in the design and implementation of an efficient and effective internal control system, aiming to strengthen the existing framework regarding the governance of modern financial institutions, which operate in a highly demanding regulated environment.</jats:p>
venue: ACRN Journal of Finance and Risk Perspectives
research_question: How can the widely accepted three lines of defense model be updated to better apply for regulated financial institutions?
answer: The author proposes a five lines of defense model (5LoD) that extends the existing three lines by adding external audit as the fourth line and regulators as the fifth line of defense, with these external lines actively supervising and monitoring control issues in cooperation with internal lines.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as providing an updated version of the widely accepted three lines of defense model, specifically tailored for the highly demanding regulated environment in which modern financial institutions operate, calling for closer interaction among internal auditors, external auditors and regulators to strengthen existing governance frameworks.

author: Lucian Taylor
title: Why Are CEOs Rarely Fired? Evidence from Structural Estimation
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>I evaluate the forced CEO turnover rate and quantify effects on shareholder value by estimating a dynamic model. The model features learning about CEO ability and costly turnover. To fit the observed forced turnover rate, the model needs the average board of directors to behave as if replacing the CEO costs shareholders at least $200 million. This cost mainly reflects CEO entrenchment rather than a real cost to shareholders. The model predicts that shareholder value would rise 3% if we eliminated this perceived turnover cost, all else equal. The model also helps explain the relation between CEO firings, tenure, and profitability.</jats:p>
research_question: Why are CEOs rarely fired, and what are the effects of this low forced turnover rate on shareholder value?
answer: CEOs are rarely fired because boards behave as if replacing a CEO costs at least $200 million, which mainly reflects CEO entrenchment rather than real costs. Eliminating this perceived cost would increase shareholder value by 3%.
positioning_statement: This paper uses structural estimation of a dynamic model featuring learning about CEO ability and costly turnover to quantify the effects of CEO firing decisions on shareholder value, providing a novel approach to understanding the relationship between CEO firings, tenure, and profitability.

author: Lucian Taylor
title: Do Funds Make More When They Trade More?
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We model fund turnover in the presence of time‐varying profit opportunities. Our model predicts a positive relation between an active fund's turnover and its subsequent benchmark‐adjusted return. We find such a relation for equity mutual funds. This time‐series relation between turnover and performance is stronger than the cross‐sectional relation, as the model predicts. Also as predicted, the turnover‐performance relation is stronger for funds trading less‐liquid stocks and funds likely to possess greater skill. Turnover is correlated across funds. The common component of turnover is positively correlated with proxies for stock mispricing. Turnover of similar funds helps predict a fund's performance.</jats:p>
research_question: Do funds make more when they trade more? Specifically, is there a positive relation between an active fund's turnover and its subsequent benchmark-adjusted return?
answer: Yes, there is a positive relation between an active fund's turnover and its subsequent benchmark-adjusted return. This time-series relation is stronger than the cross-sectional relation, and is particularly pronounced for funds trading less-liquid stocks and funds with greater skill.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by modeling fund turnover in the presence of time-varying profit opportunities, distinguishing between time-series and cross-sectional relations between turnover and performance, and showing that the common component of turnover across funds is correlated with stock mispricing proxies.

author: Luigi Pistaferri
title: Trusting the Stock Market
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We study the effect that a general lack of trust can have on stock market participation. In deciding whether to buy stocks, investors factor in the risk of being cheated. The perception of this risk is a function of the objective characteristics of the stocks and the subjective characteristics of the investor. Less trusting individuals are less likely to buy stock and, conditional on buying stock, they will buy less. In Dutch and Italian micro data, as well as in cross‐country data, we find evidence consistent with lack of trust being an important factor in explaining the limited participation puzzle.</jats:p>
research_question: What effect does a general lack of trust have on stock market participation?
answer: Less trusting individuals are less likely to buy stock and, conditional on buying stock, they will buy less. Trust is an important factor in explaining the limited participation puzzle in stock markets.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as providing an explanation for the limited participation puzzle in stock markets by introducing trust as a key behavioral factor, using empirical evidence from Dutch and Italian micro data as well as cross-country data to support this novel explanation.
