author: Mikhail Chernov
title: The PPP View of Multihorizon Currency Risk Premiums
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Exposures of expected future nominal depreciation rates to the current interest rate differential violate the UIP hypothesis in a pattern that is a nonmonotonic function of horizon. Forward expected nominal depreciation rates are monotonic. We explain the two patterns by simultaneously incorporating the weak form of PPP into a joint model of the stochastic discount factor, the nominal exchange rate, and domestic and foreign yield curves. Departures from PPP generate the first pattern. The risk premiums for these departures generate the second pattern. Thus, the variance of the stochastic discount factor is related to the real exchange rate.</jats:p>
research_question: How can the nonmonotonic pattern of currency risk premiums across different horizons and the violation of uncovered interest parity (UIP) be explained?
answer: The nonmonotonic pattern of currency risk premiums and UIP violations can be explained by incorporating the weak form of purchasing power parity (PPP) into a joint model of the stochastic discount factor, nominal exchange rate, and yield curves. Departures from PPP generate the nonmonotonic exposure pattern, while risk premiums for these departures create the monotonic forward depreciation pattern, with the variance of the stochastic discount factor being related to the real exchange rate.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing a unified explanation for two previously unexplained empirical patterns in currency markets - the nonmonotonic violation of UIP across horizons and the monotonic nature of forward expected depreciation rates - through a novel integration of PPP considerations into exchange rate modeling.

author: Mikhail Chernov
title: A study towards a unified approach to the joint estimation of objective and risk neutral measures for the purpose of options valuation

author: Mikhail Chernov
title: A Macrofinance View of U.S. Sovereign CDS Premiums
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Premiums on U.S. sovereign credit default swaps (CDS) have risen to persistently elevated levels since the financial crisis. We examine whether these premiums reflect the probability of a fiscal default—a state in which a balanced budget can no longer be restored by raising taxes or eroding the real value of debt by increasing inflation. We develop an equilibrium macrofinance model in which the fiscal and monetary policy stances jointly endogenously determine nominal debt, taxes, inflation, and growth. We show that the CDS premiums reflect the endogenous risk‐adjusted probabilities of fiscal default. The calibrated model is consistent with elevated levels of CDS premiums but leaves dynamic implications quantitatively unresolved.</jats:p>
research_question: Do elevated U.S. sovereign CDS premiums since the financial crisis reflect the probability of a fiscal default—a state in which a balanced budget can no longer be restored by raising taxes or eroding the real value of debt by increasing inflation?
answer: Yes, CDS premiums reflect the endogenous risk-adjusted probabilities of fiscal default. The calibrated model is consistent with elevated levels of CDS premiums observed since the financial crisis.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by developing an equilibrium macrofinance model that jointly considers fiscal and monetary policy stances to endogenously determine nominal debt, taxes, inflation, and growth, providing a framework to understand U.S. sovereign CDS premiums through the lens of fiscal default probability rather than traditional credit risk models.

author: Mikhail Chernov
title: The term structure of inflation expectations

author: Mikhail Chernov
title: International Yield Curves and Currency Puzzles
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>The currency depreciation rate is often computed as the ratio of foreign to domestic pricing kernels. Using bond prices alone to estimate these kernels leads to currency puzzles: the inability of models to match violations of uncovered interest parity and the volatility of exchange rates. This happens because of the <jats:italic>FX bond disconnect</jats:italic>, the inability of bonds to span exchange rates. Incorporating innovations to the pricing kernel that affect exchange rates but not bonds helps resolve the puzzles. This approach also allows one to relate news about cross‐country differences between international yields to news about currency risk premiums.</jats:p>
research_question: Why do models using bond prices alone fail to explain currency puzzles such as violations of uncovered interest parity and exchange rate volatility?
answer: The failure occurs due to the 'FX bond disconnect' - the inability of bonds to span exchange rates. Incorporating innovations to the pricing kernel that affect exchange rates but not bonds helps resolve these currency puzzles.
positioning_statement: This paper identifies a fundamental limitation in existing approaches that use bond prices alone to estimate pricing kernels for currency analysis, and proposes a solution by incorporating exchange rate-specific pricing kernel innovations that are not captured by bonds.

author: Mikhail Chernov
title: Interest Rate Skewness and Biased Beliefs
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Conditional skewness of Treasury yields is an important indicator of the risks to the macroeconomic outlook. Positive skewness signals upside risk to interest rates during periods of accommodative monetary policy and an upward‐sloping yield curve, and vice versa. Skewness has substantial predictive power for future bond excess returns, high‐frequency interest rate changes around Federal Open Market Committee announcements, and survey forecast errors for interest rates. The estimated expectational errors, or biases in beliefs, are quantitatively important for statistical bond risk premia. These findings are consistent with a heterogeneous‐beliefs model in which one of the agents is wrong about consumption growth.</jats:p>
research_question: How does conditional skewness of Treasury yields relate to macroeconomic risks and what role do biased beliefs play in bond risk premia?
answer: Conditional skewness of Treasury yields is an important indicator of macroeconomic risks, with positive skewness signaling upside risk to interest rates during accommodative monetary policy periods. Skewness has substantial predictive power for bond excess returns, high-frequency interest rate changes around FOMC announcements, and survey forecast errors. The estimated expectational errors or biased beliefs are quantitatively important for statistical bond risk premia.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by demonstrating that interest rate skewness serves as a key risk indicator and by showing how biased beliefs affect bond risk premia, consistent with a heterogeneous-beliefs model where agents have incorrect beliefs about consumption growth.

author: Mikhail Chernov
title: Disasters Implied by Equity Index Options
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We use equity index options to quantify the distribution of consumption growth disasters. The challenge lies in connecting the risk‐neutral distribution of equity returns implied by options to the true distribution of consumption growth. First, we compare pricing kernels constructed from macro‐finance and option‐pricing models. Second, we compare option prices derived from a macro‐finance model to those we observe. Third, we compare the distribution of consumption growth derived from option prices using a macro‐finance model to estimates based on macroeconomic data. All three perspectives suggest that options imply smaller probabilities of extreme outcomes than have been estimated from macroeconomic data.</jats:p>
research_question: How can equity index options be used to quantify the distribution of consumption growth disasters, and what does this reveal about the probability of extreme economic outcomes?
answer: Options imply smaller probabilities of extreme consumption growth disasters than have been estimated from macroeconomic data, suggesting that financial markets price lower disaster risk than what historical macroeconomic evidence suggests.
positioning_statement: This paper bridges macro-finance and option-pricing literature by using three complementary approaches to connect risk-neutral equity return distributions from options to true consumption growth distributions, providing a novel financial markets-based perspective on disaster risk estimation that can be compared against traditional macroeconomic approaches.

author: Mikhail Chernov
title: Pricing Currency Risks
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>The currency market features a small cross‐section, and conditional expected returns can be characterized by few signals: interest differential, trend, and mean reversion. We exploit these properties to construct the ex ante mean‐variance efficient portfolio of individual currencies. The portfolio is updated in real time and prices all prominent currency trading strategies, conditionally and unconditionally. The fraction of risk in these assets that does not affect their risk premiums is at least 85%. Extant explanations of carry strategies based on intermediary capital or global volatility are related to these unpriced components, while consumption growth is related to the priced component of returns.</jats:p>
research_question: What fraction of currency risk is priced versus unpriced, and what factors explain the risk premiums in currency markets?
answer: At least 85% of currency risk is unpriced (does not affect risk premiums), while consumption growth is related to the priced component of returns, and intermediary capital/global volatility explanations relate to unpriced components.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as providing a comprehensive framework that can price all prominent currency trading strategies by exploiting the small cross-section nature of currency markets and characterizing expected returns through few key signals, while reconciling existing explanations by distinguishing between priced and unpriced risk components.

author: Mikhail Chernov
title: Term structures of asset prices and returns

author: Mikhail Chernov
title: Sources of Entropy in Representative Agent Models
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We propose two data‐based performance measures for asset pricing models and apply them to models with recursive utility and habits. Excess returns on risky securities are reflected in the pricing kernel's dispersion and riskless bond yields are reflected in its dynamics. We measure dispersion with entropy and dynamics with horizon dependence, the difference between entropy over several periods and one. We compare their magnitudes to estimates derived from asset returns. This exercise reveals tension between a model's ability to generate one‐period entropy, which should be large, and horizon dependence, which should be small.</jats:p>
research_question: How well do representative agent models with recursive utility and habits perform in explaining asset pricing patterns, specifically in terms of generating appropriate pricing kernel dispersion and dynamics?
answer: There is a fundamental tension in these models between their ability to generate sufficient one-period entropy (which should be large to match observed excess returns) and appropriate horizon dependence (which should be small to match observed bond yields), suggesting these models struggle to simultaneously explain both equity and bond market phenomena.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the asset pricing literature by proposing novel data-based performance measures (entropy for dispersion and horizon dependence for dynamics) to evaluate representative agent models, providing a new framework for assessing how well these models match empirical asset return patterns.

author: Mikhail Chernov
title: Model Specification and Risk Premia: Evidence from Futures Options
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>This paper examines model specification issues and estimates diffusive and jump risk premia using S&P futures option prices from 1987 to 2003. We first develop a time series test to detect the presence of jumps in volatility, and find strong evidence in support of their presence. Next, using the cross section of option prices, we find strong evidence for jumps in prices and modest evidence for jumps in volatility based on model fit. The evidence points toward economically and statistically significant jump risk premia, which are important for understanding option returns.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the model specification issues and risk premia associated with diffusive and jump components in S&P futures options, particularly regarding jumps in both prices and volatility?
answer: The study finds strong evidence for jumps in volatility using time series tests and strong evidence for jumps in prices with modest evidence for jumps in volatility based on cross-sectional option pricing model fit. Most importantly, they discover economically and statistically significant jump risk premia that are crucial for understanding option returns.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the options pricing literature by developing new time series tests for detecting volatility jumps and providing comprehensive empirical evidence on jump risk premia using a large dataset of S&P futures options from 1987 to 2003, addressing important model specification issues in option pricing models.

author: Mikhail Chernov
title: Understanding Index Option Returns

author: Mikhail Chernov
title: The Term Structure of Covered Interest Rate Parity Violations
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We quantify the impact of risk‐based and nonrisk‐based intermediary constraints (IC) on the term structure of covered interest rate parity (CIP) violations. Using a stochastic discount factor (SDF) inferred from interest rate swaps, we value currency derivatives. The wedge between model‐implied and observed derivative prices reflects the impact of nonrisk‐based IC because our SDF incorporates risk‐based IC. There is no wedge at short horizons, while the wedge accounts for 40% of long‐term CIP violations. Consistent with IC theory, the wedge correlates with the shadow cost of intermediary capital, and the SDF‐implied interest rate is a weighted average of collateralized and uncollateralized interest rates.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the impact of risk-based versus nonrisk-based intermediary constraints on covered interest rate parity violations across different time horizons?
answer: Nonrisk-based intermediary constraints have no impact on short-term CIP violations but account for 40% of long-term CIP violations, while risk-based constraints affect CIP violations across all horizons through the stochastic discount factor.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on covered interest rate parity violations by providing a novel decomposition method that separates risk-based from nonrisk-based intermediary constraints using a stochastic discount factor approach, offering new insights into the term structure of these violations that previous studies have not distinguished.

author: Mikhail Chernov
title: Sovereign credit risk and exchange rates: Evidence from CDS quanto spreads

author: Mikhail Chernov
title: Conditional Dynamics and the Multihorizon Risk-Return Trade-Off
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We propose testing asset pricing models using multihorizon returns (MHRs). MHRs effectively generate a new set of test assets that is endogenous to the model and that identifies a broad set of possible conditional misspecifications. We apply MHR-based testing to prominent linear factor models and show that these models typically do a poor job of pricing longer-horizon returns, with pricing errors that are similar in magnitude to the risk premiums they were designed to explain. We trace the errors to the conditional factor dynamics. Explicitly incorporating factor timing into the models often makes mispricing worse, thereby posing a challenge for future research.</jats:p>
research_question: How well do prominent linear factor models perform when tested using multihorizon returns, and what drives any observed pricing errors?
answer: Linear factor models typically perform poorly at pricing longer-horizon returns, with pricing errors similar in magnitude to the risk premiums they were designed to explain. These errors are traced to conditional factor dynamics, and incorporating factor timing into the models often worsens the mispricing.
positioning_statement: This paper proposes a new testing methodology using multihorizon returns (MHRs) that generates endogenous test assets and identifies conditional misspecifications in asset pricing models, providing a novel approach to evaluate existing prominent linear factor models.

author: Mikhail Chernov
title: Optimal Debt and Equity Values in the Presence of Chapter 7 and Chapter 11
abstract: <jats:p>Explicit presence of reorganization in addition to liquidation leads to conflicts of interest between borrowers and lenders. In the first–best outcome, reorganization adds value to both parties via higher debt capacity, lower credit spreads, and improved overall firm value. If control of the ex ante reorganization timing and the ex post decision to liquidate is given to borrowers, most of the benefits are appropriated by borrowers ex post. Lenders can restore the first–best outcome by seizing this control or by the ex post transfer of control rights. Reorganization is more likely and liquidation is less likely relative to the benchmark case with liquidation only.</jats:p>
research_question: How do the presence of both Chapter 7 (liquidation) and Chapter 11 (reorganization) bankruptcy options affect optimal debt and equity values, and what are the implications of control allocation between borrowers and lenders?
answer: Reorganization adds value through higher debt capacity, lower credit spreads, and improved firm value in the first-best outcome, but when borrowers control reorganization timing and liquidation decisions, they appropriate most benefits ex post. Lenders can restore first-best outcomes by seizing control or through ex post transfer of control rights, leading to more frequent reorganization and less frequent liquidation compared to liquidation-only scenarios.
positioning_statement: This paper extends existing bankruptcy literature by explicitly modeling both liquidation and reorganization options simultaneously, focusing on the conflicts of interest and control allocation between borrowers and lenders, rather than examining these bankruptcy procedures in isolation.

author: Mikhail Chernov
title: Monetary Policy Risk: Rules versus Discretion
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Long-run asset pricing restrictions in a macro term structure model identify discretionary monetary policy separately from a policy rule. We find that policy discretion is an important contributor to aggregate risk. In addition, discretionary easing coincides with good news about the macroeconomy in the form of lower inflation, higher output growth, and lower risk premiums on short-term nominal bonds. However, it also coincides with bad news about long-term financial conditions in the form of higher risk premiums on long-term nominal bonds. Shocks to the rule correlate with changes in the yield curve’s level. Shocks to discretion correlate with changes in its slope.</jats:p>
research_question: How does discretionary monetary policy differ from rule-based monetary policy in terms of their contributions to aggregate risk and their effects on asset pricing and macroeconomic conditions?
answer: Policy discretion is an important contributor to aggregate risk. Discretionary easing has mixed effects: it coincides with positive short-term macroeconomic news (lower inflation, higher output growth, lower short-term bond risk premiums) but negative long-term financial news (higher long-term bond risk premiums). Additionally, rule shocks correlate with yield curve level changes while discretionary shocks correlate with slope changes.
positioning_statement: This paper uses long-run asset pricing restrictions in a macro term structure model to separately identify discretionary monetary policy from policy rules, providing a novel empirical approach to distinguish between these two components of monetary policy that have been theoretically discussed but difficult to measure empirically.

author: Moses Shayo
title: Micro Finance Institutions (MFIs) Practices and Povery Alleviation in Tanzania
abstract: Tanzania's Poverty Reduction Strategy (PRS) focuses among other efforts at reducing income poverty, improving human capabilities, survival and social well being and containing extreme vulnerability among the poor. In this context access of households and firms to physical and financial resources is extremely crucial. For the majority of Tanzanians who are poor, without access to formal financial institutions, access to micro finance services is a viable alternative in an attempt to reduce poverty. Micro finance institutions (MFIs) offer the poor, the possibility of managing scarce resources more efficiently and taking advantage of investment opportunities for economic returns. Access to finance services may contribute to increased income generation and thus achievement of higher standards of living at household levels while at enterprise levels it can facilitate the pursuit of income and firms growth. The operations of MFIs need therefore to have greater outreach particulars where the poor are concentrated, i.e. in the rural settings. At the same time services ought to be sustainable in order to have impact on poverty alleviation.
venue: African Journal of Finance and Management

author: Motohiro Yogo
title: A Consumption‐Based Explanation of Expected Stock Returns
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>When utility is nonseparable in nondurable and durable consumption and the elasticity of substitution between the two consumption goods is sufficiently high, marginal utility rises when durable consumption falls. The model explains both the cross‐sectional variation in expected stock returns and the time variation in the equity premium. Small stocks and value stocks deliver relatively low returns during recessions, when durable consumption falls, which explains their high average returns relative to big stocks and growth stocks. Stock returns are unexpectedly low at business cycle troughs, when durable consumption falls sharply, which explains the countercyclical variation in the equity premium.</jats:p>
research_question: Can a consumption-based model with nonseparable utility in nondurable and durable consumption explain both the cross-sectional variation in expected stock returns and the time variation in the equity premium?
answer: Yes, when utility is nonseparable in nondurable and durable consumption with sufficiently high elasticity of substitution, marginal utility rises when durable consumption falls, which explains why small stocks and value stocks have high average returns (due to low returns during recessions when durable consumption falls) and why the equity premium varies countercyclically (due to unexpectedly low stock returns at business cycle troughs when durable consumption falls sharply).
positioning_statement: This paper provides a consumption-based explanation for well-known asset pricing puzzles by extending traditional consumption-based models to include both nondurable and durable consumption with nonseparable utility, offering a unified framework that can simultaneously explain cross-sectional return differences and time-varying equity premiums.

author: Motohiro Yogo
title: What does futures market interest tell us about the macroeconomy and asset prices?

title: Does firm value move too much to be justified by subsequent changes in cash flow?

author: Motohiro Yogo
title: New Perspectives on Insurance
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>This special issue originates from a dual submission conference with the NBER Insurance Working Group and the Corporate Finance Program in 2020. It brings a broader perspective on important frictions in insurance markets, including trust between insurers and policyholders, conflicts of interest among brokers, suboptimal policyholder behavior, and risk-based capital regulation. Several developments in the economy and the academic literature have provided an impetus for new perspectives, including the growth of savings products with minimum return guarantees, the global financial crisis, and intermediary asset pricing. We conclude with an overview of research questions that are promising for further exploration.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the important frictions in insurance markets and how do recent economic developments and academic literature provide new perspectives on these frictions?
answer: The key frictions in insurance markets include trust between insurers and policyholders, conflicts of interest among brokers, suboptimal policyholder behavior, and risk-based capital regulation, with new perspectives emerging from developments such as growth of savings products with minimum return guarantees, the global financial crisis, and intermediary asset pricing.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as providing a 'broader perspective' on insurance market frictions by incorporating insights from recent economic developments (global financial crisis, growth of guaranteed savings products) and advances in academic literature (particularly intermediary asset pricing), building upon work from the NBER Insurance Working Group and Corporate Finance Program.

author: Motohiro Yogo
title: Why Do Household Portfolio Shares Rise in Wealth?

author: Motohiro Yogo
title: Financial Inclusion Across the United States

author: Motohiro Yogo
title: The Fragility of Market Risk Insurance
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Variable annuities, which package mutual funds with minimum return guarantees over long horizons, accounted for $1.5 trillion or 35% of U.S. life insurer liabilities in 2015. Sales decreased and fees increased during the global financial crisis, and insurers made guarantees less generous or stopped offering guarantees to reduce risk exposure. These effects persist in the low‐interest rate environment after the global financial crisis, and variable annuity insurers suffered large equity drawdowns during the COVID‐19 crisis. We develop and estimate a model of insurance markets in which financial frictions and market power determine pricing, contract characteristics, and the degree of market completeness.</jats:p>
research_question: How do financial frictions and market power affect pricing, contract characteristics, and market completeness in variable annuity insurance markets, particularly during periods of financial stress?
answer: Variable annuity markets exhibit significant fragility during financial crises - sales decrease, fees increase, guarantees become less generous, and insurers reduce or eliminate guarantee offerings. These effects persist in low-interest rate environments, and insurers continue to suffer large equity drawdowns during market stress events like COVID-19.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by developing and estimating a comprehensive model that explains how financial frictions and market power jointly determine insurance market outcomes, providing a framework to understand the observed fragility and market incompleteness in variable annuity markets during crisis periods.

author: Motohiro Yogo
title: Health and Mortality Delta: Assessing the Welfare Cost of Household Insurance Choice
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We develop a pair of risk measures, health and mortality delta, for the universe of life and health insurance products. A life‐cycle model of insurance choice simplifies to replicating the optimal health and mortality delta through a portfolio of insurance products. We estimate the model to explain the observed variation in health and mortality delta implied by the ownership of life insurance, annuities including private pensions, and long‐term care insurance in the Health and Retirement Study. For the median household aged 51 to 57, the lifetime welfare cost of market incompleteness and suboptimal choice is 3.2% of total wealth.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the welfare cost of household insurance choice, specifically examining how market incompleteness and suboptimal insurance decisions affect household welfare?
answer: For the median household aged 51 to 57, the lifetime welfare cost of market incompleteness and suboptimal choice is 3.2% of total wealth.
positioning_statement: This paper develops novel risk measures (health and mortality delta) for the universe of life and health insurance products and creates a life-cycle model that simplifies insurance choice to replicating optimal risk exposure through insurance portfolios, providing a new framework for quantifying welfare costs in insurance markets.

author: Motohiro Yogo
title: Luxury Goods and the Equity Premium
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>This paper evaluates the equity premium using novel data on the consumption of luxury goods. Specifying utility as a nonhomothetic function of both luxury and basic consumption goods, we derive pricing equations and evaluate the risk of holding equity. Household survey and national accounts data mostly reflect basic consumption, and therefore overstate the risk aversion necessary to match the observed equity premium. The risk aversion implied by the consumption of luxury goods is more than an order of magnitude less than that implied by national accounts data. For the very rich, the equity premium is much less of a puzzle.</jats:p>
research_question: Can the equity premium puzzle be resolved by examining the consumption patterns of luxury goods rather than relying solely on aggregate consumption data?
answer: Yes, when utility is modeled as a nonhomothetic function that includes luxury goods consumption, the implied risk aversion is more than an order of magnitude lower than that derived from national accounts data, making the equity premium much less puzzling for wealthy investors.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the traditional approach to the equity premium puzzle by arguing that existing literature relies too heavily on household survey and national accounts data that primarily capture basic consumption, leading to overstated risk aversion estimates, and proposes that incorporating luxury goods consumption provides a more accurate assessment of investor behavior.

title: Inspecting the mechanism of quantitative easing in the euro area

author: Nadya Malenko
title: Creating Controversy in Proxy Voting Advice
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We analyze how a profit‐maximizing proxy advisor designs vote recommendations and research reports. The advisor benefits from producing informative, unbiased reports, but only partially informative recommendations, biased against the a priori likely alternative. Such recommendations induce close votes, increasing controversy and thereby the relevance and value of proxy advice. Our results suggest shifting from an exclusive emphasis on recommendations, highlighting the importance of both reports and recommendations in proxy advisors' information provision. They rationalize the one‐size‐fits‐all approach and help reinterpret empirical patterns of voting behavior, suggesting that proxy advisors' recommendations may not be a suitable benchmark for evaluating shareholders' votes.</jats:p>
research_question: How does a profit-maximizing proxy advisor design vote recommendations and research reports?
answer: A profit-maximizing proxy advisor produces informative, unbiased reports but only partially informative recommendations that are biased against the a priori likely alternative, creating close votes that increase controversy and thereby the relevance and value of proxy advice.
positioning_statement: This paper shifts from the existing literature's exclusive emphasis on recommendations to highlighting the importance of both reports and recommendations in proxy advisors' information provision, rationalizes the one-size-fits-all approach, and suggests that proxy advisors' recommendations may not be a suitable benchmark for evaluating shareholders' votes as commonly assumed in empirical studies.

author: Nadya Malenko
title: Communication and Decision-Making in Corporate Boards

author: Nadya Malenko
title: The Labor Market for Directors and Externalities in Corporate Governance
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>This paper studies how directors' reputational concerns affect board structure, corporate governance, and firm value. In our setting, directors affect their firms' governance, and governance in turn affects firms' demand for new directors. Whether the labor market rewards a shareholder‐friendly or management‐friendly reputation is determined in equilibrium and depends on aggregate governance. We show that directors' desire to be invited to other boards creates strategic complementarity of corporate governance across firms. Directors' reputational concerns amplify the governance system: strong systems become stronger and weak systems become weaker. We derive implications for multiple directorships, board size, transparency, and board independence.</jats:p>
research_question: How do directors' reputational concerns in the labor market affect board structure, corporate governance, and firm value?
answer: Directors' desire to be invited to other boards creates strategic complementarity of corporate governance across firms, where reputational concerns amplify the governance system - making strong governance systems stronger and weak governance systems weaker.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the corporate governance literature by introducing a novel equilibrium framework that endogenizes the relationship between directors' labor market incentives and governance outcomes, showing how reputational concerns create externalities across firms that amplify existing governance systems.

author: Nadya Malenko
title: Nonbinding Voting for Shareholder Proposals
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Shareholder proposals are a common form of shareholder activism. Voting for shareholder proposals, however, is nonbinding since management has the authority to reject the proposal even if it received majority support from shareholders. We analyze whether nonbinding voting is an effective mechanism for conveying shareholder expectations. We show that, unlike binding voting, nonbinding voting generally fails to convey shareholder views when manager and shareholder interests are not aligned. Surprisingly, the presence of an activist investor who can discipline the manager may enhance the advisory role of nonbinding voting only if conflicts of interest between shareholders and the activist are substantial.</jats:p>
research_question: Is nonbinding voting an effective mechanism for conveying shareholder expectations in the context of shareholder proposals?
answer: Nonbinding voting generally fails to convey shareholder views when manager and shareholder interests are not aligned, unlike binding voting. However, the presence of an activist investor who can discipline the manager may enhance the advisory role of nonbinding voting, but only if conflicts of interest between shareholders and the activist are substantial.
positioning_statement: This paper analyzes the effectiveness of nonbinding voting mechanisms in shareholder activism, specifically examining how the nonbinding nature of shareholder proposal voting affects the communication of shareholder expectations to management, with particular attention to the role of activist investors in this process.

author: Nadya Malenko
title: Proxy Advisory Firms: The Economics of Selling Information to Voters
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We analyze how proxy advisors, which sell voting recommendations to shareholders, affect corporate decision‐making. If the quality of the advisor's information is low, there is overreliance on its recommendations and insufficient private information production. In contrast, if the advisor's information is precise, it may be underused because the advisor rations its recommendations to maximize profits. Overall, the advisor's presence leads to more informative voting only if its information is sufficiently precise. We evaluate several proposals on regulating proxy advisors and show that some suggested policies, such as reducing proxy advisors' market power or decreasing litigation pressure, can have negative effects.</jats:p>
research_question: How do proxy advisory firms, which sell voting recommendations to shareholders, affect corporate decision-making?
answer: The effect of proxy advisors on corporate decision-making depends on the quality of their information: low-quality information leads to overreliance and insufficient private information production, while high-quality information may be underused due to profit-maximizing rationing. Proxy advisors only improve voting informativeness when their information is sufficiently precise.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on proxy advisory firms by providing a theoretical framework that analyzes the economics of information selling to voters, and evaluates existing regulatory proposals, showing that some commonly suggested policies may have unintended negative consequences.

author: Nadya Malenko
title: The Role of Proxy Advisory Firms: Evidence from a Regression-Discontinuity Design

author: Nadya Malenko
title: Advising the Management: A Theory of Shareholder Engagement
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We study the effectiveness of shareholder engagement, that is, shareholders communicating their views to management. When shareholders and management have different beliefs, each shareholder engages more effectively when other shareholders engage as well. A limited shareholder base can thus prevent effective engagement. However, a limited shareholder base naturally arises under heterogeneous beliefs because investors who most disagree with management do not become shareholders. Passive funds, which own the firm regardless of their beliefs, can counteract these effects and improve engagement. When shareholders’ and management’s preferences are strongly misaligned, shareholders’ engagement decisions become substitutes and the role of ownership structure declines.</jats:p><jats:p>Authors have furnished an Internet Appendix, which is available on the Oxford University Press Web site next to the link to the final published paper online.</jats:p>
research_question: What determines the effectiveness of shareholder engagement when shareholders communicate their views to management?
answer: Shareholder engagement is more effective when multiple shareholders engage simultaneously, but heterogeneous beliefs naturally limit the shareholder base as investors who disagree with management avoid becoming shareholders. Passive funds can improve engagement effectiveness by owning firms regardless of their beliefs, though when preferences are strongly misaligned, engagement decisions become substitutes and ownership structure matters less.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a theoretical framework to analyze shareholder engagement effectiveness, contributing to the literature by examining how belief heterogeneity and ownership structure (particularly passive funds) affect the coordination and substitutability of shareholders' engagement decisions.

author: Nadya Malenko
title: Trading and Shareholder Democracy
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We study shareholder voting in a model in which trading affects the composition of the shareholder base. Trading and voting are complementary, which gives rise to self‐fulfilling expectations about proposal acceptance and multiple equilibria. Prices and shareholder welfare can move in opposite directions, so the former may be an invalid proxy for the latter. Relaxing trading frictions can reduce welfare because it allows extreme shareholders to gain more weight in voting. Delegating decision‐making to the board can help overcome collective action problems at the voting stage. We also analyze the role of index investors and social concerns of shareholders.</jats:p>
research_question: How does trading affect the composition of the shareholder base and what are the implications for shareholder voting outcomes and welfare?
answer: Trading and voting are complementary activities that create self-fulfilling expectations about proposal acceptance and lead to multiple equilibria. Prices can move in opposite directions from shareholder welfare, making prices an invalid proxy for welfare. Reducing trading frictions can actually harm welfare by allowing extreme shareholders to gain disproportionate voting influence.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by modeling the interaction between trading and voting decisions, showing that the traditional assumption of prices as welfare proxies may be flawed, and demonstrating that reduced trading frictions can have counterintuitive negative welfare effects through their impact on shareholder composition and voting outcomes.

author: Nadya Malenko
title: Strategic and Financial Bidders in Takeover Auctions
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Using data on auctions of companies, we estimate valuations (maximum willingness to pay) of strategic and financial bidders from their bids. We find that a typical target is valued higher by strategic bidders. However, 22.4% of targets in our sample are valued higher by financial bidders. These are mature, poorly performing companies. We also find that (i) valuations of different strategic bidders are more dispersed and (ii) valuations of financial bidders are correlated with aggregate economic conditions. Our results suggest that different targets appeal to different types of bidders, rather than that strategic bidders always value targets more because of synergies.</jats:p>
research_question: How do valuations differ between strategic and financial bidders in takeover auctions, and what factors determine which type of bidder values a target company more highly?
answer: While strategic bidders typically value targets higher, 22.4% of targets (specifically mature, poorly performing companies) are valued higher by financial bidders. Strategic bidders show more dispersed valuations, while financial bidders' valuations correlate with aggregate economic conditions.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the conventional wisdom that strategic bidders always value targets more due to synergies, instead demonstrating that different types of targets appeal to different types of bidders based on company characteristics and market conditions.

author: Nadya Malenko
title: Real Options Signaling Games with Applications to Corporate Finance

author: Nadya Malenko
title: Deadlock on the Board
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We develop a dynamic model of board decision-making akin to dynamic voting models in the political economy literature. We show a board could retain a policy all directors agree is worse than an available alternative. Thus, directors may retain a CEO they agree is bad—deadlocked boards lead to entrenched CEOs. We explore how to compose boards and appoint directors to mitigate deadlock. We find board diversity and long director tenure can exacerbate deadlock. We rationalize why CEOs and incumbent directors have power to appoint new directors: to avoid deadlock. Our model speaks to short-termism, staggered boards, and proxy access.</jats:p>
research_question: How can board decision-making processes lead to suboptimal outcomes where directors retain policies or CEOs they agree are inferior to available alternatives?
answer: Boards can become deadlocked and retain policies all directors agree are worse than available alternatives, leading to CEO entrenchment even when all directors agree the CEO is bad. Board diversity and long director tenure can exacerbate this deadlock problem.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a dynamic model of board decision-making that draws from dynamic voting models in the political economy literature, extending these concepts to corporate governance to explain board deadlock and CEO entrenchment phenomena.

author: Nadya Malenko
title: A Bayesian Approach to Real Options: The Case of Distinguishing between Temporary and Permanent Shocks
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Traditional real options models demonstrate the importance of the “option to wait” due to uncertainty over future shocks to project cash flows. However, there is often another important source of uncertainty: uncertainty over the permanence of past shocks. Adding Bayesian uncertainty over the permanence of past shocks augments the traditional option to wait with an additional “option to learn.” The implied investment behavior differs significantly from that in standard models. For example, investment may occur at a time of stable or decreasing cash flows, respond sluggishly to cash flow shocks, and depend on the timing of project cash flows.</jats:p>
research_question: How does uncertainty over the permanence of past shocks affect real options investment decisions, beyond the traditional uncertainty over future shocks?
answer: Adding Bayesian uncertainty over whether past shocks are temporary or permanent creates an additional 'option to learn' that significantly changes investment behavior - causing investment to occur during stable or decreasing cash flows, respond sluggishly to shocks, and depend on timing of cash flows.
positioning_statement: This paper extends traditional real options models that focus on the 'option to wait' due to uncertainty over future shocks by incorporating a previously understudied dimension - uncertainty over the permanence of past shocks - which adds an 'option to learn' component to investment decisions.

author: Nicholas Barberis
title: Mental Accounting, Loss Aversion, and Individual Stock Returns
abstract: <jats:p>We study equilibrium firm‐level stock returns in two economies: one in which investors are loss averse over the fluctuations of their stock portfolio, and another in which they are loss averse over the fluctuations of individual stocks that they own. Both approaches can shed light on empirical phenomena, but we find the second approach to be more successful: In that economy, the typical individual stock return has a high mean and excess volatility, and there is a large value premium in the cross section which can, to some extent, be captured by a commonly used multifactor model.</jats:p>
research_question: How do different forms of mental accounting and loss aversion (portfolio-level vs. individual stock-level) affect equilibrium firm-level stock returns?
answer: Loss aversion applied at the individual stock level (rather than portfolio level) better explains empirical phenomena, generating high mean returns, excess volatility, and a large value premium that can be captured by multifactor models.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the behavioral finance literature by comparing two different applications of loss aversion and mental accounting to stock returns, building on existing work but specifically examining which level of mental accounting (portfolio vs. individual stock) better explains observed market phenomena.

author: Nicholas Barberis
title: Investing for the Long Run when Returns Are Predictable
abstract: <jats:p>We examine how the evidence of predictability in asset returns affects optimal portfolio choice for investors with long horizons. Particular attention is paid to estimation risk, or uncertainty about the true values of model parameters. We find that even after incorporating parameter uncertainty, there is enough predictability in returns to make investors allocate substantially more to stocks, the longer their horizon. Moreover, the weak statistical significance of the evidence for predictability makes it important to take estimation risk into account; a long‐horizon investor who ignores it may overallocate to stocks by a sizeable amount.</jats:p>
research_question: How does the evidence of predictability in asset returns affect optimal portfolio choice for investors with long horizons, particularly when accounting for estimation risk or uncertainty about model parameters?
answer: Even after incorporating parameter uncertainty, there is sufficient predictability in returns to justify long-horizon investors allocating substantially more to stocks as their investment horizon increases. However, ignoring estimation risk can lead to significant overallocation to stocks.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on long-horizon portfolio choice by explicitly incorporating estimation risk into the analysis of return predictability, addressing a gap where previous work may have overlooked the importance of parameter uncertainty in portfolio allocation decisions for long-term investors.

author: Nadya Malenko
title: Auctions with Endogenous Initiation
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We study initiation of takeover auctions by potential buyers and the seller. A bidder's indication of interest reveals that she is optimistic about the target. If bidders' values have a substantial common component, as in takeover battles between financial bidders, this effect disincentivizes bidders from indicating interest, and auctions are seller‐initiated. Conversely, in private‐value auctions, such as battles between strategic bidders, equilibria can feature both seller‐ and bidder‐initiated auctions, with the likelihood of the latter decreasing in commonality of values and the probability of a forced sale by the seller. We also relate initiation to bids and auction outcomes.</jats:p>
research_question: How do potential buyers and sellers decide whether to initiate takeover auctions, and what factors determine who initiates these auctions?
answer: Auction initiation depends on the degree of common versus private value components in bidders' valuations. When values have substantial common components (as with financial bidders), bidders avoid indicating interest because it reveals optimism to competitors, leading to seller-initiated auctions. In private-value settings (strategic bidders), both seller- and bidder-initiated auctions can occur in equilibrium, with bidder initiation becoming less likely as value commonality increases or when forced sales are more probable.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a gap in auction theory by endogenizing the initiation decision in takeover auctions, distinguishing between different types of bidders (financial vs. strategic) and examining how the common versus private value nature of bidder valuations affects who initiates auctions - a question not previously addressed in the takeover auction literature.

author: Nicholas Barberis
title: What Drives the Disposition Effect? An Analysis of a Long‐Standing Preference‐Based Explanation
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We investigate whether prospect theory preferences can predict a disposition effect. We consider two implementations of prospect theory: in one case, preferences are defined over <jats:italic>annual</jats:italic> gains and losses; in the other, they are defined over <jats:italic>realized</jats:italic> gains and losses. Surprisingly, the annual gain/loss model often fails to predict a disposition effect. The realized gain/loss model, however, predicts a disposition effect more reliably. Utility from realized gains and losses may therefore be a useful way of thinking about certain aspects of individual investor trading.</jats:p>
research_question: Can prospect theory preferences predict the disposition effect, and which implementation of prospect theory better explains this behavioral bias?
answer: The realized gain/loss model of prospect theory reliably predicts a disposition effect, while the annual gain/loss model often fails to do so, suggesting that utility from realized gains and losses better explains individual investor trading behavior.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the existing literature by testing a long-standing preference-based explanation for the disposition effect, specifically examining different implementations of prospect theory to determine which better accounts for this well-documented behavioral phenomenon in investor trading.

author: Nicholas Barberis
title: Prospect Theory and Stock Market Anomalies
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We present a new model of asset prices in which investors evaluate risk according to prospect theory and examine its ability to explain 23 prominent stock market anomalies. The model incorporates all of the elements of prospect theory, accounts for investors' prior gains and losses, and makes quantitative predictions about an asset's average return based on empirical estimates of the asset's return volatility, return skewness, and past capital gain. We find that the model can help explain a majority of the 23 anomalies.</jats:p>
research_question: Can a model incorporating prospect theory explain prominent stock market anomalies?
answer: The prospect theory-based model can help explain a majority of the 23 examined stock market anomalies by making quantitative predictions about average returns based on return volatility, skewness, and past capital gains.
positioning_statement: This paper presents a new asset pricing model that incorporates all elements of prospect theory and accounts for investors' prior gains and losses, offering a behavioral finance approach to explaining stock market anomalies that traditional models cannot adequately address.

author: Nicholas Barberis
title: Using Neural Data to Test a Theory of Investor Behavior: An Application to Realization Utility
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We conduct a study in which subjects trade stocks in an experimental market while we measure their brain activity using functional magnetic resonance imaging. All of the subjects trade in a suboptimal way. We use the neural data to test a “realization utility” explanation for their behavior. We find that activity in two areas of the brain that are important for economic decision‐making exhibit activity consistent with the predictions of realization utility. These results provide support for the realization utility model. More generally, they demonstrate that neural data can be helpful in testing models of investor behavior.</jats:p>
research_question: Can neural data be used to test the realization utility theory as an explanation for suboptimal investor trading behavior?
answer: Yes, brain activity in two key economic decision-making areas exhibits patterns consistent with realization utility predictions, providing neural evidence supporting the realization utility model for explaining suboptimal trading behavior.
positioning_statement: This paper demonstrates a novel methodological approach by using neural data (fMRI) to test existing theories of investor behavior, specifically applying neuroscience techniques to validate the realization utility model and establishing neural evidence as a useful tool for testing models of investor behavior.

author: Nicolae Gârleanu
title: Technological Growth and Asset Pricing
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We study the asset‐pricing implications of technological growth in a model with “small,” disembodied productivity shocks and “large,” infrequent technological innovations, which are embodied into new capital vintages. The technological‐adoption process leads to endogenous cycles in output and asset valuations. This process can help explain stylized asset‐valuation patterns around major technological innovations. More importantly, it can help provide a unified, investment‐based theory for numerous well‐documented facts related to excess‐return predictability. To illustrate the distinguishing features of our theory, we highlight novel implications pertaining to the joint time‐series properties of consumption and excess returns.</jats:p>
research_question: How do technological innovations, particularly large and infrequent technological advances embodied in new capital vintages, affect asset pricing and excess return predictability?
answer: The technological adoption process creates endogenous cycles in output and asset valuations that can explain stylized asset-valuation patterns around major technological innovations and provide a unified, investment-based theory for well-documented excess-return predictability facts.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a unified, investment-based theory that can explain numerous well-documented facts related to excess-return predictability, distinguishing itself by focusing on the joint time-series properties of consumption and excess returns in the context of technological growth cycles.

author: Nicolae Gârleanu
title: Efficiently Inefficient Markets for Assets and Asset Management
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We consider a model where investors can invest directly or search for an asset manager, information about assets is costly, and managers charge an endogenous fee. The efficiency of asset prices is linked to the efficiency of the asset management market: if investors can find managers more easily, more money is allocated to active management, fees are lower, and asset prices are more efficient. Informed managers outperform after fees, uninformed managers underperform, while the average manager's performance depends on the number of “noise allocators.” Small investors should remain uninformed, but large and sophisticated investors benefit from searching for informed active managers since their search cost is low relative to capital. Hence, managers with larger and more sophisticated investors are expected to outperform.</jats:p>
research_question: How does the efficiency of the asset management market relate to asset price efficiency, and what determines investor decisions between direct investment and searching for asset managers?
answer: Asset price efficiency is directly linked to asset management market efficiency - when investors can find managers more easily, more capital flows to active management, fees decrease, and prices become more efficient. Informed managers outperform after fees while uninformed managers underperform, and large/sophisticated investors benefit from searching for informed managers due to their lower relative search costs.
positioning_statement: This paper bridges asset pricing and asset management literature by modeling the endogenous relationship between asset management market efficiency and asset price efficiency, incorporating costly information acquisition, endogenous fees, and heterogeneous investor search costs in a unified framework.

author: Nicolae Gârleanu
title: Dynamic Trading with Predictable Returns and Transaction Costs
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We derive a closed‐form optimal dynamic portfolio policy when trading is costly and security returns are predictable by signals with different mean‐reversion speeds. The optimal strategy is characterized by two principles: (1) aim in front of the target, and (2) trade partially toward the current aim. Specifically, the optimal updated portfolio is a linear combination of the existing portfolio and an “aim portfolio,” which is a weighted average of the current Markowitz portfolio (the moving target) and the expected Markowitz portfolios on all future dates (where the target is moving). Intuitively, predictors with slower mean‐reversion (alpha decay) get more weight in the aim portfolio. We implement the optimal strategy for commodity futures and find superior net returns relative to more naive benchmarks.</jats:p>
research_question: How should investors optimally trade when security returns are predictable by signals with different mean-reversion speeds and trading involves transaction costs?
answer: The optimal dynamic portfolio policy follows two principles: (1) aim in front of the target, and (2) trade partially toward the current aim. The optimal portfolio is a linear combination of the existing portfolio and an 'aim portfolio' that weights predictors with slower mean-reversion more heavily, accounting for where the target is moving rather than just current conditions.
positioning_statement: This paper extends existing dynamic portfolio theory by providing a closed-form solution that incorporates both transaction costs and predictable returns with varying mean-reversion speeds, offering a more sophisticated approach than naive benchmarks that don't account for these realistic market features.

author: Nikhil Agarwal
title: The Future of the Finance Workforce: How Microsoft Copilot May Reshape Roles and Skillsets
abstract:
<jats:p>Purpose: Artificial intelligence (AI) is rapidly advancing, with tools like Microsoft Copilot poised to significantly change the workplace. This paper examines the potential impact of Copilot adoption on the finance workforce.
Methodology: It analyzes which financial tasks may be susceptible to automation through Copilot's capabilities and identifies the emerging skills that will be crucial for finance professionals to remain competitive in an AI-driven landscape.
Findings: This research provides insights for educators, policymakers, and finance professionals seeking to prepare for the future of work in the finance sector.
Unique contribution to theory, policy and practice: In essence, the future of the finance workforce will be characterized by a dynamic interplay between automation, skill evolution, and ethical considerations. By embracing the transformative potential of Microsoft Copilot and cultivating the necessary skillsets, finance professionals can seize opportunities for innovation, drive value creation, and navigate the evolving landscape of finance with confidence and resilience.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the potential impact of Microsoft Copilot adoption on the finance workforce, specifically which financial tasks may be automated and what emerging skills will be crucial for finance professionals?
answer: The future of the finance workforce will be characterized by a dynamic interplay between automation, skill evolution, and ethical considerations, where finance professionals can seize opportunities for innovation and drive value creation by embracing Microsoft Copilot's transformative potential and cultivating necessary skillsets.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as providing insights for educators, policymakers, and finance professionals seeking to prepare for the future of work in the finance sector, with a unique contribution examining the specific impact of Microsoft Copilot on financial task automation and required skill evolution.

author: Nicolas Crouzet
title: On the Effects of Restricting Short-Term Investment
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We study the effects of policies proposed to address “short-termism” in financial markets. We examine a noisy rational expectations model in which investors’ exposures and information about fundamentals endogenously vary across horizons. In this environment, taxing or outlawing short-term investment doesn’t negatively affect the information in prices about long-term fundamentals. However, such a policy reduces short- and long-term investors’ profits and utility. Changing policies about the release of short-term information can help long-term investors—an objective of some policy makers—at the expense of short-term investors. Doing so also makes prices less informative and increases costs of speculation.</jats:p><jats:p>Received June 24, 2018; editorial decision February 19, 2019 by Editor Stijn Van Nieuwerburgh. Authors have furnished an Internet Appendix, which is available on the Oxford University Press Web site next to the link to the final published paper online.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the effects of policies designed to address 'short-termism' in financial markets, specifically examining how restricting short-term investment affects price informativeness, investor profits, and market outcomes?
answer: Taxing or outlawing short-term investment does not negatively affect the information content of prices about long-term fundamentals, but it reduces both short-term and long-term investors' profits and utility. Policies that change the release of short-term information can benefit long-term investors at the expense of short-term investors, but make prices less informative and increase speculation costs.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on short-termism in financial markets by developing a noisy rational expectations model where investors' exposures and information about fundamentals endogenously vary across investment horizons, providing a theoretical framework to evaluate proposed policy interventions.

author: Nicolae Gârleanu
title: Impediments to Financial Trade: Theory and Applications
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We propose a tractable model of an informationally inefficient market featuring nonrevealing prices, general preferences and payoff distributions, but not noise traders. We show the equivalence between our model and a substantially simpler one in which investors face distortionary investment taxes depending on both their identity and the asset class. This equivalence allows us to account for such phenomena as underdiversification. We further employ the model to assess approaches to performance evaluation and find that it provides a theoretical basis for some intuitive practices, such as style analysis, that have been adopted by finance professionals.</jats:p>
               <jats:p>Authors have furnished an Internet Appendix, which is available on the Oxford University Press Web site next to the link to the final published paper online.</jats:p>
research_question: How can we model informationally inefficient markets with nonrevealing prices without relying on noise traders, and what are the implications for financial phenomena and performance evaluation?
answer: The paper develops a tractable model of informationally inefficient markets that is equivalent to a simpler model where investors face distortionary investment taxes based on their identity and asset class. This model can explain underdiversification and provides theoretical justification for performance evaluation practices like style analysis.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on informationally inefficient markets by proposing an alternative approach that does not require noise traders while maintaining tractability and generality in preferences and payoff distributions, and by connecting this theoretical framework to practical performance evaluation methods used by finance professionals.

author: Nicolas Crouzet
title: Rents and Intangible Capital: A Q+ Framework
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>In recent years, U.S. investment has been lackluster, despite rising valuations. Key explanations include growing rents and growing intangibles. We propose and estimate a framework to quantify their roles. The gap between valuations—reflected in average <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic>—and investment—reflected in marginal <jats:italic>q</jats:italic>—can be decomposed into three terms: the value of installed intangibles; rents generated by physical capital; and an interaction term, measuring rents generated by intangibles. The intangible related terms contribute significantly to the gap, particularly in fast‐growing sectors. Our findings suggest care in a pure‐rents interpretation, given the rising role of intangibles.</jats:p>
research_question: What explains the gap between rising U.S. stock market valuations and lackluster investment, specifically quantifying the roles of growing rents and growing intangible capital?
answer: The gap between valuations (average Q) and investment (marginal q) can be decomposed into three components: the value of installed intangibles, rents generated by physical capital, and rents generated by intangibles. The intangible-related terms contribute significantly to this gap, particularly in fast-growing sectors.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by developing a Q+ framework that can quantify and separate the effects of both rents and intangible capital on the valuation-investment gap, cautioning against pure-rents interpretations given the rising importance of intangibles in the economy.

author: Nikolai Roussanov
title: Diversification and Its Discontents: Idiosyncratic and Entrepreneurial Risk in the Quest for Social Status
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Social status concerns influence investors' decisions by driving a wedge in attitudes toward aggregate and idiosyncratic risks. I model such concerns by emphasizing the desire to “get ahead of the Joneses,” which implies that aversion to idiosyncratic risk is lower than aversion to aggregate risk. The model predicts that investors hold concentrated portfolios in equilibrium, which helps rationalize the small premium for undiversified entrepreneurial risk. In the model, status concerns are more important for wealthier households. Consequently, these households own a disproportionate share of risky assets, particularly private equity, and experience greater volatility of consumption, consistent with empirical evidence.</jats:p>
research_question: How do social status concerns influence investors' portfolio diversification decisions and risk attitudes, particularly regarding the relationship between aggregate and idiosyncratic risks?
answer: Social status concerns drive investors to hold concentrated portfolios because the desire to 'get ahead of the Joneses' makes them less averse to idiosyncratic risk than to aggregate risk, which helps explain the small premium for undiversified entrepreneurial risk and why wealthier households hold disproportionate shares of risky assets like private equity.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing a novel explanation for observed portfolio concentration and entrepreneurial risk premiums through a model that distinguishes between attitudes toward aggregate versus idiosyncratic risk based on social status motivations, offering an alternative to traditional diversification theories.

author: Nikolai Roussanov
title: Managing Mental Accounts: Payment Cards and Consumption Expenditures
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Does mental accounting matter for total consumption expenditures? We exploit a unique setting in which individuals exogenously receive a new payment card, without requesting one. Using random variation in the time of receipt, we show that individuals temporarily increase total consumption expenditure by making purchases with the new card without reducing spending on the others. We do not observe a corresponding increase in indebtedness. Total consumption expenditure rises even for the least liquidity-constrained individuals. The evidence is consistent with consumers treating methods of payment as nonfungible budget categories, as suggested by models of mental accounting and narrow bracketing.</jats:p>
research_question: Does mental accounting matter for total consumption expenditures?
answer: Yes, mental accounting matters for total consumption expenditures. Individuals temporarily increase total consumption expenditure when they receive a new payment card by making purchases with the new card without reducing spending on other cards, even without increasing indebtedness and even among the least liquidity-constrained individuals.
positioning_statement: The evidence is consistent with consumers treating methods of payment as nonfungible budget categories, as suggested by models of mental accounting and narrow bracketing, contributing to this theoretical literature by providing empirical evidence of mental accounting effects on consumption behavior.

author: Nikolai Roussanov
title: Getting to the Core: Inflation Risks Within and Across Asset Classes
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Do real assets protect against inflation? Stocks’ core inflation betas are negative, while their energy betas are positive. Currencies, commodities, and real estate mostly hedge against energy inflation, but not core inflation. These hedging properties are reflected in the prices of inflation risks: only core inflation carries a negative risk premium, and its magnitude is consistent within and across asset classes, uniquely among macroeconomic risk factors. Energy inflation has become more procyclical and volatile since the 1990s, which helps explain the time-varying correlation between stock and bond returns. A two-sector New Keynesian asset pricing model accounts for these facts quantitatively.</jats:p>
research_question: Do real assets protect against inflation, and how do different types of inflation risks affect asset prices across various asset classes?
answer: Real assets provide limited inflation protection - stocks have negative core inflation betas but positive energy betas, while currencies, commodities, and real estate hedge against energy inflation but not core inflation. Only core inflation carries a negative risk premium that is consistent within and across asset classes, and energy inflation has become more procyclical and volatile since the 1990s.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by distinguishing between core and energy inflation components and showing that core inflation uniquely carries a consistent negative risk premium across asset classes among macroeconomic risk factors, while providing a theoretical framework through a two-sector New Keynesian asset pricing model that quantitatively accounts for these empirical findings.
