author: Nikolai Roussanov
title: Commodity Trade and the Carry Trade: A Tale of Two Countries
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Persistent interest rate differentials account for much of the currency carry trade profitability. “Commodity currencies” offer high interest rates on average, while countries that export finished goods tend to have low interest rates. We develop a general equilibrium model of international trade and currency pricing where countries have an advantage in producing either basic inputs or final goods. In the model, domestic production insulates commodity‐producing countries from global productivity shocks, forcing final‐good producers to absorb them. Commodity‐currency exchange rates and risk premia increase with productivity differentials and trade frictions. These predictions are strongly supported in the data.</jats:p>
research_question: Why do commodity currencies persistently offer high interest rates while countries that export finished goods tend to have low interest rates, and how does this relate to carry trade profitability?
answer: Domestic production insulates commodity-producing countries from global productivity shocks, forcing final-good producers to absorb them, which leads to commodity-currency exchange rates and risk premia increasing with productivity differentials and trade frictions.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a new general equilibrium model of international trade and currency pricing that explains the persistent interest rate differentials underlying carry trade profitability by linking countries' comparative advantages in production (basic inputs vs. final goods) to their currency risk characteristics.

author: Nikolai Roussanov
title: Marketing Mutual Funds
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Marketing and distribution expenses are responsible for about one-third of the cost of active management in the mutual fund industry. Estimating a structural model with costly investor search and learning about fund skill, we find that marketing is nearly as important as performance and fees in determining fund size. Eliminating marketing substantially improves welfare: capital shifts toward cheaper funds and competition decreases fees; active funds shrink and capital allocation becomes more closely aligned with skill. Declining investor search costs imply a reduction in marketing expenses and management fees as well as a shift toward passive investing, as observed empirically.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the role and impact of marketing and distribution expenses in the mutual fund industry, particularly on fund size, investor welfare, and capital allocation?
answer: Marketing is nearly as important as performance and fees in determining fund size, accounting for about one-third of active management costs. Eliminating marketing would substantially improve welfare by shifting capital toward cheaper funds, reducing fees through increased competition, shrinking active funds, and better aligning capital allocation with fund skill.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the mutual fund literature by developing a structural model that incorporates costly investor search and learning about fund skill to quantify the specific role of marketing expenses, which represents a significant but previously under-analyzed component of fund costs.

author: Nina Boyarchenko
title: The Overnight Drift
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>This paper documents that U.S. equity returns are large and positive during the opening hours of European markets. These returns are pervasive and highly economically and statistically significant. Consistent with models of inventory risk, we demonstrate a strong relationship with order imbalances at the close of the preceding U.S. trading day. Rationalizing unconditionally positive “overnight drift” returns, we uncover an asymmetric reaction to demand shocks: market sell-offs generate robust positive overnight reversals, while reversals following market rallies are much more modest. We argue that demand shock asymmetry can arise in inventory management models with time-varying market maker risk-bearing capacity.</jats:p>
               <jats:p>Authors have furnished an Internet Appendix, which is available on the Oxford University Press Web site next to the link to the final published paper online.</jats:p>
research_question: Why do U.S. equity returns exhibit large and positive returns during the opening hours of European markets, and what drives this 'overnight drift' phenomenon?
answer: The overnight drift is driven by inventory risk and asymmetric reactions to demand shocks - market sell-offs generate robust positive overnight reversals while reversals following market rallies are much more modest, with this asymmetry arising from time-varying market maker risk-bearing capacity.
positioning_statement: This paper extends inventory risk models by documenting and explaining the asymmetric nature of overnight returns, contributing to the literature on market microstructure and inventory management models with time-varying risk-bearing capacity.

author: Nikolai Roussanov
title: Houses as ATMs: Mortgage Refinancing and Macroeconomic Uncertainty
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Mortgage refinancing activity associated with extraction of home equity contains a strongly countercyclical component consistent with household demand for liquidity. We estimate a structural model of liquidity management featuring countercyclical idiosyncratic labor income uncertainty, long‐ and short‐term mortgages, and realistic borrowing constraints. We empirically evaluate its predictions for households' choices of leverage, liquid assets, and mortgage refinancing using microlevel data. Taking the observed historical paths of house prices, aggregate income, and interest rates as given, the model accounts for many salient features in the evolution of balance sheets and consumption in the cross‐section of households over 2001 to 2012.</jats:p>
research_question: How does macroeconomic uncertainty affect household mortgage refinancing behavior, particularly the extraction of home equity for liquidity management purposes?
answer: Mortgage refinancing activity with home equity extraction has a strongly countercyclical component driven by household demand for liquidity during periods of increased macroeconomic uncertainty, and a structural model incorporating countercyclical idiosyncratic labor income uncertainty can successfully explain household choices regarding leverage, liquid assets, and refinancing behavior from 2001-2012.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by developing a structural model of liquidity management that incorporates countercyclical idiosyncratic labor income uncertainty, long- and short-term mortgages, and realistic borrowing constraints, then empirically evaluating its predictions using microlevel data to explain the evolution of household balance sheets and consumption across different household types during a critical period of macroeconomic volatility.

author: Nina Boyarchenko
title: Understanding Mortgage Spreads
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Because most mortgages in the United States are securitized in agency mortgage-backed securities (MBS), yield spreads on MBS are a key determinant of homeowners’ funding costs. We study variation in MBS spreads in the time series and across securities and document that MBS spreads show a pronounced cross-sectional smile with respect to the securities’ coupon rates. We present a new pricing model that uses “stripped” MBS prices to identify the contribution of non-interest-rate prepayment risk to spreads and find that this risk explains the smile, whereas the time-series spread variation is mostly accounted for by nonprepayment risk factors.</jats:p>
               <jats:p>Received March 30, 2015; editorial decision November 21, 2018 by Editor Leonid Kogan. Authors have furnished an Internet Appendix, which is available on the Oxford University Press Web site next to the link to the final published paper online.</jats:p>
research_question: What factors explain the variation in mortgage-backed securities (MBS) yield spreads both across different securities and over time?
answer: Non-interest-rate prepayment risk explains the cross-sectional smile pattern in MBS spreads with respect to coupon rates, while nonprepayment risk factors primarily account for time-series variation in spreads.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes a new pricing model that uses 'stripped' MBS prices to separately identify the contribution of non-interest-rate prepayment risk to spreads, providing a novel approach to decompose the sources of MBS spread variation that was not previously available in the literature.

author: Pablo Kurlat
title: Liquidity as Social Expertise
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>This paper proposes a theory of liquidity dynamics. Illiquidity results from asymmetric information. Observing the historical track record teaches agents how to interpret public information and helps overcome information asymmetry. However, an illiquidity trap can arise: too much asymmetric information leads to the breakdown of trade, which interrupts learning and perpetuates illiquidity. Liquidity falls in response to unexpected events that lead agents to question their valuation models (especially in newer markets) may be slow to recover after a crisis, and is higher in periods of stability.</jats:p>
research_question: What drives liquidity dynamics in financial markets and how does learning from historical information affect market liquidity over time?
answer: Liquidity dynamics are driven by asymmetric information and learning processes, where observing historical track records helps agents interpret public information and overcome information asymmetries, but illiquidity traps can occur when excessive asymmetric information breaks down trade and interrupts learning, perpetuating illiquidity.
positioning_statement: This paper proposes a new theory of liquidity dynamics that emphasizes the role of social learning and expertise development through historical observation, offering an explanation for why liquidity may be slow to recover after crises and why newer markets are particularly vulnerable to liquidity breakdowns.

author: Philipp Schnabl
title: Efficient Recapitalization
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We analyze government interventions to recapitalize a banking sector that restricts lending to firms because of debt overhang. We find that the efficient recapitalization program injects capital against preferred stock plus warrants and conditions implementation on sufficient bank participation. Preferred stock plus warrants reduces opportunistic participation by banks that do not require recapitalization, although conditional implementation limits free riding by banks that benefit from lower credit risk because of other banks’ participation. Efficient recapitalization is profitable if the benefits of lower aggregate credit risk exceed the cost of implicit transfers to bank debt holders.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the optimal design for government interventions to recapitalize a banking sector that restricts lending to firms due to debt overhang?
answer: The efficient recapitalization program should inject capital against preferred stock plus warrants and condition implementation on sufficient bank participation, as this design reduces opportunistic participation by healthy banks while limiting free riding by banks that benefit from others' participation.
positioning_statement: This paper analyzes the design of government bank recapitalization programs by examining the trade-offs between preventing opportunistic participation by banks that don't need capital and limiting free riding by banks that benefit from systemic risk reduction without participating themselves.

author: Philipp Schnabl
title: The International Transmission of Bank Liquidity Shocks: Evidence from an Emerging Market
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>I exploit the 1998 Russian default as a negative liquidity shock to international banks and analyze its transmission to Peru. I find that after the shock international banks reduce bank‐to‐bank lending to Peruvian banks and Peruvian banks reduce lending to Peruvian firms. The effect is strongest for domestically owned banks that borrow internationally, intermediate for foreign‐owned banks, and weakest for locally funded banks. I control for credit demand by examining firms that borrow from several banks. These results suggest that international banks transmit liquidity shocks across countries and that negative liquidity shocks reduce bank lending in affected countries.</jats:p>
research_question: How do liquidity shocks to international banks transmit across countries and affect bank lending in emerging markets?
answer: International banks transmit liquidity shocks across countries by reducing bank-to-bank lending, which causes domestic banks to reduce lending to firms. The transmission effect varies by bank ownership structure, with domestically owned banks that borrow internationally being most affected, foreign-owned banks experiencing intermediate effects, and locally funded banks being least affected.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on international financial transmission by providing empirical evidence of how liquidity shocks propagate through the international banking system to emerging markets, using the 1998 Russian default as a natural experiment and controlling for credit demand effects by examining multi-bank borrowing relationships.

author: Parag Pathak
title: The Leadership Conundrum and the Critical Dimension
abstract: <jats:p>The Leadership debate is perhaps one issue that still remains inconclusive even after ages of discussion. There have been diverse views  between the American and British schools of thought on the issue of leadership and management. However, the Indian text Manusmriti mentions that effective leadership is not always about winning but about rightful conduct. It is the quality of decisions rather than the outcome that makes the crucial difference in leadership. Furthermore, a true leader should becompassionate because the fact is that it works in all societies and at all times. A leader has to know his people and not get carried away by others’ opinions without careful analysis. Hence it is equally important to understand that leaders should also know when to break the rules and for whom. </jats:p>
venue: International Journal of Finance, Entrepreneurship & Sustainability
research_question: What constitutes effective leadership and how should leadership be understood beyond traditional Western perspectives?
answer: Effective leadership is not about winning but about rightful conduct, with the quality of decisions being more important than outcomes. True leadership requires compassion, understanding one's people, independent analysis, and knowing when to break rules appropriately.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as offering an alternative perspective to the ongoing inconclusive debate between American and British schools of thought on leadership and management by drawing on ancient Indian wisdom from Manusmriti to provide timeless principles that work across all societies and times.

author: Philipp Schnabl
title: The Rise of Finance Companies and FinTech Lenders in Small Business Lending
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We document that finance companies and FinTech lenders increased lending to small businesses after the 2008 financial crisis. We show that most of the increase substituted for a reduction in bank lending. In counties in which banks had a larger market share before the crisis, finance companies and FinTech lenders increased their lending more. We find no effect of reduced bank lending on employment, wages, and new business creation by 2016. Our results suggest that finance companies and FinTech lenders are major suppliers of credit to small businesses and played an important role in the recovery from the 2008 financial crisis.</jats:p>
               <jats:p>Authors have furnished an Internet Appendix, which is available on the Oxford University Press Web site next to the link to the final published paper online</jats:p>
research_question: How did finance companies and FinTech lenders respond to changes in bank lending to small businesses after the 2008 financial crisis, and what was the impact on economic outcomes?
answer: Finance companies and FinTech lenders increased lending to small businesses after the 2008 financial crisis, mostly substituting for reduced bank lending, with greater increases in counties where banks previously had larger market shares. This substitution was effective enough that there was no negative effect on employment, wages, and new business creation by 2016.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by documenting the important role of finance companies and FinTech lenders as major suppliers of credit to small businesses and their significant contribution to economic recovery from the 2008 financial crisis, positioning these non-bank lenders as effective substitutes for traditional bank lending.

author: Philipp Schnabl
title: Banking on Deposits: Maturity Transformation without Interest Rate Risk
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We show that maturity transformation does not expose banks to interest rate risk—it hedges it. The reason is the deposit franchise, which allows banks to pay deposit rates that are low and insensitive to market interest rates. Hedging the deposit franchise requires banks to earn income that is also insensitive, that is, to lend long term at fixed rates. As predicted by this theory, we show that banks closely match the interest rate sensitivities of their interest income and expense, and that this insulates their equity from interest rate shocks. Our results explain why banks supply long‐term credit.</jats:p>
research_question: Why do banks engage in maturity transformation and how does it affect their exposure to interest rate risk?
answer: Maturity transformation does not expose banks to interest rate risk but actually hedges it, because banks use their deposit franchise (which provides low, interest-rate-insensitive funding) to match the interest rate sensitivities of their income and expenses, thereby insulating their equity from interest rate shocks.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the conventional view that maturity transformation exposes banks to interest rate risk, instead arguing that it serves as a hedging mechanism due to the unique properties of the deposit franchise that allows banks to pay rates that are low and insensitive to market rates.

author: Philipp Schnabl
title: A Pyrrhic Victory? Bank Bailouts and Sovereign Credit Risk
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We model a loop between sovereign and bank credit risk. A distressed financial sector induces government bailouts, whose cost increases sovereign credit risk. Increased sovereign credit risk in turn weakens the financial sector by eroding the value of its government guarantees and bond holdings. Using credit default swap (CDS) rates on European sovereigns and banks, we show that bailouts triggered the rise of sovereign credit risk in 2008. We document that post‐bailout changes in sovereign CDS explain changes in bank CDS even after controlling for aggregate and bank‐level determinants of credit spreads, confirming the sovereign‐bank loop.</jats:p>
research_question: How do bank bailouts affect sovereign credit risk, and is there a feedback loop between sovereign and bank credit risk?
answer: Bank bailouts triggered the rise of sovereign credit risk in 2008, creating a feedback loop where increased sovereign credit risk weakens the financial sector by eroding the value of government guarantees and bond holdings, with post-bailout changes in sovereign CDS explaining changes in bank CDS.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by modeling and empirically documenting the bidirectional feedback loop between sovereign and bank credit risk, specifically showing how government bailouts of distressed financial sectors can increase sovereign credit risk, which then feeds back to weaken the banking sector.

author: Philipp Schnabl
title: A Model of Monetary Policy and Risk Premia
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We develop a dynamic asset pricing model in which monetary policy affects the risk premium component of the cost of capital. Risk‐tolerant agents (banks) borrow from risk‐averse agents (i.e., take deposits) to fund levered investments. Leverage exposes banks to funding risk, which they insure by holding liquidity buffers. By changing the nominal rate the central bank influences the liquidity premium, and hence the cost of taking leverage. Lower nominal rates make liquidity cheaper and raise leverage, resulting in lower risk premia and higher asset prices, volatility, investment, and growth. We analyze forward guidance, a “Greenspan put,” and the yield curve.</jats:p>
research_question: How does monetary policy affect the risk premium component of the cost of capital through its impact on bank leverage and liquidity decisions?
answer: Lower nominal interest rates reduce the cost of liquidity, which encourages banks to increase leverage, resulting in lower risk premia and higher asset prices, volatility, investment, and growth. The central bank influences risk premia by changing the liquidity premium through the nominal rate, which affects banks' cost of taking leverage.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a new dynamic asset pricing model that explicitly links monetary policy to risk premia through a banking sector mechanism involving leverage and liquidity buffers, extending beyond traditional models to analyze specific monetary policy tools like forward guidance and the 'Greenspan put.'

author: Philipp Schnabl
title: Who Borrows from the Lender of Last Resort?
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We analyze lender of last resort (LOLR) lending during the European sovereign debt crisis. Using a novel data set on all central bank lending and collateral, we show that weakly capitalized banks took out more LOLR loans and used riskier collateral than strongly capitalized banks. We also find that weakly capitalized banks used LOLR loans to buy risky assets such as distressed sovereign debt. This resulted in a reallocation of risky assets from strongly to weakly capitalized banks. Our findings cannot be explained by classical LOLR theory. Rather, they point to risk taking by banks, both independently and with the encouragement of governments, and highlight the benefit of unifying LOLR lending and bank supervision.</jats:p>
research_question: Who borrows from the lender of last resort and how do they use these loans?
answer: Weakly capitalized banks borrowed more from the lender of last resort, used riskier collateral, and used these loans to purchase risky assets like distressed sovereign debt, resulting in a reallocation of risky assets from strongly to weakly capitalized banks.
positioning_statement: The findings cannot be explained by classical lender of last resort theory, instead revealing risk-taking behavior by banks that challenges existing theoretical frameworks and highlights the need for unifying LOLR lending with bank supervision.

author: Philipp Schnabl
title: Specialization in Bank Lending: Evidence from Exporting Firms
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We develop a novel approach for measuring bank specialization using granular data on borrower activities and apply it to Peruvian exporters and their banks. We find that borrowers seek credit from banks that specialize in their export destinations, both when expanding exports and when exporting to new countries. Firms experiencing country‐specific export demand shocks adjust borrowing disproportionately from specialized banks. Specialized bank credit supply shocks affect exports disproportionately to countries of specialization. Our results demonstrate that firm credit demand is bank‐ and activity‐specific, which reduces banking competition and affects the transmission and amplification of shocks through the banking sector.</jats:p>
research_question: How does bank specialization in specific export destinations affect firm borrowing patterns and the transmission of shocks through the banking sector?
answer: Borrowers systematically seek credit from banks that specialize in their export destinations, both when expanding exports and entering new countries. This specialization creates bank- and activity-specific credit demand that reduces banking competition and amplifies the transmission of shocks through the banking sector.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a novel approach for measuring bank specialization using granular data on borrower activities, contributing new evidence on how firm credit demand is bank- and activity-specific, which has implications for understanding banking competition and shock transmission mechanisms.

author: Piotr Dworczak
title: Robust benchmark design

author: Piotr Dworczak
title: Benchmarks in Search Markets
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We characterize the role of benchmarks in price transparency of over‐the‐counter markets. A benchmark can raise social surplus by increasing the volume of beneficial trade, facilitating more efficient matching between dealers and customers, and reducing search costs. Although the market transparency promoted by benchmarks reduces dealers' profit margins, dealers may nonetheless introduce a benchmark to encourage greater market participation by investors. Low‐cost dealers may also introduce a benchmark to increase their market share relative to high‐cost dealers. We construct a revelation mechanism that maximizes welfare subject to search frictions, and show conditions under which it coincides with announcing the benchmark.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the role of benchmarks in price transparency of over-the-counter markets and how do they affect social welfare, trading efficiency, and market participation?
answer: Benchmarks can raise social surplus by increasing beneficial trade volume, facilitating more efficient dealer-customer matching, and reducing search costs. Despite reducing dealers' profit margins through increased transparency, dealers may still introduce benchmarks to encourage greater investor participation, and low-cost dealers may use them to gain market share over high-cost competitors.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on over-the-counter market transparency and search frictions by analyzing the welfare effects of benchmarks and constructing a revelation mechanism that maximizes welfare subject to search constraints, showing conditions under which optimal welfare coincides with benchmark announcement.

author: Richard Evans
title: Mutual Fund Incubation
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Incubation is a strategy for initiating new funds, where multiple funds are started privately, and, at the end of an evaluation period, some are opened to the public. Consistent with incubation being used by fund families to increase performance and attract flows, funds in incubation outperform nonincubated funds by 3.5% risk‐adjusted, and when they are opened to the public they attract higher flows. Postincubation, however, this outperformance disappears. This performance reversal imparts an upward bias to returns that is not removed by a fund size filter. Fund age and ticker creation date filters, however, eliminate the bias.</jats:p>
research_question: How does the mutual fund incubation strategy affect fund performance and investor flows, and what biases does this create in performance measurement?
answer: Incubated funds outperform non-incubated funds by 3.5% risk-adjusted during incubation and attract higher flows when opened to the public, but this outperformance disappears post-incubation, creating an upward bias in returns that can be eliminated by fund age and ticker creation date filters but not by fund size filters.
positioning_statement: This paper identifies and addresses a previously unrecognized source of bias in mutual fund performance measurement, showing that while fund size filters have been used to address performance biases, they are insufficient for eliminating the bias created by incubation strategies, requiring alternative filtering approaches based on fund age and ticker creation dates.

author: Robert Ready
title: Order Flows and Financial Investor Impacts in Commodity Futures Markets
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Using intraday data, we document statistically strong, but temporary, impacts of commodity index trade flows on commodity futures prices. We also examine the previously documented positive returns around the issuance of commodity-linked notes and find that these returns are an order of magnitude too large to be caused by the small trades necessary to hedge the notes. We provide new evidence that they are instead the result of endogenous issuance. Our results provide novel support for commodity financialization but highlight the importance of measuring the magnitude of financial investment, since even large financial flows have economically modest impacts on prices.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the impacts of financial investor order flows, particularly commodity index trade flows and commodity-linked note issuance, on commodity futures prices?
answer: Commodity index trade flows have statistically strong but temporary impacts on commodity futures prices, while positive returns around commodity-linked note issuance are caused by endogenous issuance rather than hedging trades, and overall financial flows have economically modest price impacts despite being large.
positioning_statement: This paper provides novel support for commodity financialization literature while emphasizing the critical importance of measuring the actual magnitude of financial investment impacts, challenging previous assumptions about the scale of price effects from financial investor activity in commodity markets.

author: Robert Ready
title: Commodity Trade and the Carry Trade: A Tale of Two Countries
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Persistent interest rate differentials account for much of the currency carry trade profitability. “Commodity currencies” offer high interest rates on average, while countries that export finished goods tend to have low interest rates. We develop a general equilibrium model of international trade and currency pricing where countries have an advantage in producing either basic inputs or final goods. In the model, domestic production insulates commodity‐producing countries from global productivity shocks, forcing final‐good producers to absorb them. Commodity‐currency exchange rates and risk premia increase with productivity differentials and trade frictions. These predictions are strongly supported in the data.</jats:p>
research_question: Why do commodity currencies persistently offer high interest rates while countries that export finished goods tend to have low interest rates, and how does this relate to carry trade profitability?
answer: Domestic production insulates commodity-producing countries from global productivity shocks, forcing final-good producers to absorb them, which leads to commodity-currency exchange rates and risk premia increasing with productivity differentials and trade frictions.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a new general equilibrium model of international trade and currency pricing that explains the persistent interest rate differentials underlying carry trade profitability by linking countries' comparative advantages in production (basic inputs vs. final goods) to their currency risk characteristics.

author: Robert Ready
title: Currency Risk Factors in a Recursive Multicountry Economy
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Focusing on the 10 most traded currencies, we provide empirical evidence regarding a significant heterogeneous exposure to global growth news shocks. We incorporate this empirical fact in a frictionless risk‐sharing model with recursive preferences, multiple countries, and multiple consumption goods whose supply features both global and local short‐ and long‐run shocks. Since news shocks are priced, heterogeneous exposure to long‐lasting global growth shocks results in a relevant reallocation of international resources and currency adjustments. Our unified framework replicates the properties of the HML‐FX and HML‐NFA carry‐trade strategies studied by Lustig, Roussanov, and Verdelhan and Della Corte, Riddiough, and Sarno.</jats:p>
research_question: How does heterogeneous exposure to global growth news shocks across currencies affect international resource allocation and currency adjustments in a multicountry economy with recursive preferences?
answer: Heterogeneous exposure to long-lasting global growth shocks results in significant reallocation of international resources and currency adjustments, as news shocks are priced in the market, which can explain the properties of established carry-trade strategies.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a unified theoretical framework that incorporates empirically observed heterogeneous exposure to global growth news shocks into a frictionless risk-sharing model, successfully replicating the properties of existing carry-trade strategies (HML-FX and HML-NFA) studied by Lustig, Roussanov, and Verdelhan and Della Corte, Riddiough, and Sarno.

author: Rustom Irani
title: Can Strong Creditors Inhibit Entrepreneurial Activity?
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We examine entrepreneurial activity following the staggered adoption of modern-day fraudulent transfer laws in the United States. These laws strengthen unsecured creditors’ rights and are particularly important for entrepreneurs whose personal assets commingle with the firm’s. Using administrative data from the U.S. Census Bureau, we document declines in startup entry—particularly among riskier entrants—and closures of existing firms after these laws pass. Firm financial data shows that entrepreneurs lower leverage by reducing demand for unsecured credit. Our results suggest that strong creditor protections can limit entrepreneurs’ appetite for risk, which may reduce churning along the extensive margin among the smallest firms in the economy.</jats:p>
research_question: How does the strengthening of unsecured creditors' rights through fraudulent transfer laws affect entrepreneurial activity and firm behavior?
answer: Strong creditor protections reduce entrepreneurial activity by decreasing startup entry (particularly among riskier entrants), increasing firm closures, and causing entrepreneurs to lower leverage by reducing demand for unsecured credit, ultimately limiting entrepreneurs' appetite for risk.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on creditor rights and entrepreneurship by examining the unintended consequences of strong creditor protections, specifically showing how laws designed to protect creditors can actually inhibit entrepreneurial risk-taking and reduce business churning among the smallest firms in the economy.

author: Rustom Irani
title: Does a Larger Menu Increase Appetite? Collateral Eligibility and Credit Supply

author: Rustom Irani
title: How Do Short-Term Incentives Affect Long-Term Productivity?
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Previous research shows that incentives to meet short-term earnings targets can cause firms to increase share buybacks, leading to cuts in investments and employment. Using plant-level census data, we find that incentives to engage in earnings-per-share-motivated buybacks result in lower productivity at both the plant and firm level. We attribute this productivity drop to two mechanisms: reduced investment in productivity-augmenting technology, and inefficient allocation of resources across a firm’s plants. We identify multiple frictions—including labor unions, financial constraints, agency problems, and adjustment costs—that can constrain efficient reallocations across plants and thus exacerbate the consequences of firms’ short-term incentives.</jats:p>
research_question: How do short-term incentives to meet earnings targets affect long-term productivity?
answer: Short-term incentives that motivate earnings-per-share-driven buybacks result in lower productivity at both plant and firm levels through two main mechanisms: reduced investment in productivity-augmenting technology and inefficient allocation of resources across a firm's plants.
positioning_statement: This paper builds on previous research showing that short-term earnings incentives lead to increased share buybacks and cuts in investments and employment, but extends this work by using plant-level census data to examine the specific productivity consequences and identifying the underlying mechanisms and frictions that exacerbate these effects.

author: Rustom Irani
title: The Rise of Shadow Banking: Evidence from Capital Regulation
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We investigate the connections between bank capital regulation and the prevalence of lightly regulated nonbanks (shadow banks) in the U.S. corporate loan market. For identification, we exploit a supervisory credit register of syndicated loans, loan-time fixed effects, and shocks to capital requirements arising from surprise features of the U.S. implementation of Basel III. We find that less-capitalized banks reduce loan retention, particularly among loans with higher capital requirements and at times when capital is scarce, and nonbanks step in. This reallocation is associated with important adverse effects during the 2008 crisis: loans funded by nonbanks with fragile liabilities are less likely to be rolled over and experience greater price volatility.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the connections between bank capital regulation and the prevalence of lightly regulated nonbanks (shadow banks) in the U.S. corporate loan market?
answer: Less-capitalized banks reduce loan retention when facing higher capital requirements and capital scarcity, leading nonbanks to step in and fill this gap. This reallocation creates adverse effects during crises, as loans funded by nonbanks with fragile liabilities are less likely to be rolled over and experience greater price volatility.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing empirical evidence on how bank capital regulation drives the growth of shadow banking, using a supervisory credit register and exploiting shocks from Basel III implementation for identification, while also documenting the crisis-time consequences of this regulatory arbitrage.

author: Sabrina T. Howell
title: Reducing information frictions in venture capital: The role of new venture competitions

author: Sabrina T. Howell
title: Do Cash Windfalls Affect Wages? Evidence from R&D Grants to Small Firms
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>This paper examines how employee earnings respond to a one-time cash flow shock in the form of a government R&D grant. In a regression discontinuity design, we find that the grant immediately increases average annual employee-level earnings by 2.9$\%$. This benefit accrues only to incumbent employees and rises with job tenure. The grant also affects firm growth, but the initial wage patterns do not appear to reflect growth or productivity. Instead, the evidence supports implicit equity financing within the firm, where employees initially accept lower wages from financially constrained firms and earn more when the firm has ability to pay.</jats:p>
               <jats:p>Authors have furnished an Internet Appendix, which is available on the Oxford University Press Web site next to the link to the final published paper online.</jats:p>
research_question: How do employee earnings respond to a one-time cash flow shock in the form of a government R&D grant?
answer: The grant immediately increases average annual employee-level earnings by 2.9%, with benefits accruing only to incumbent employees and rising with job tenure. The evidence supports implicit equity financing within the firm, where employees initially accept lower wages from financially constrained firms and earn more when the firm has ability to pay.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on wage determination and financial constraints by providing evidence that wage patterns reflect implicit equity financing arrangements between employees and financially constrained firms, rather than simply reflecting productivity or growth effects.

author: Sabrina T. Howell
title: Initial Coin Offerings: Financing Growth with Cryptocurrency Token Sales
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Initial coin offerings (ICOs) have emerged as a new mechanism for entrepreneurial finance, with parallels to initial public offerings, venture capital, and presale crowdfunding. In a sample of more than 1,500 ICOs that collectively raise ${\$}$12.9 billion, we examine which issuer and ICO characteristics predict successful real outcomes (increasing issuer employment and avoiding enterprise failure). Success is associated with disclosure, credible commitment to the project, and quality signals. An instrumental variables analysis finds that ICO token exchange listing causes higher future employment, indicating that access to token liquidity has important real consequences for the enterprise.</jats:p>
               <jats:p>Authors have furnished an Internet Appendix, which is available on the Oxford University Press Web site next to the link to the final published paper online.</jats:p>
research_question: Which issuer and ICO characteristics predict successful real outcomes (increasing issuer employment and avoiding enterprise failure) in initial coin offerings?
answer: Success in ICOs is associated with disclosure, credible commitment to the project, and quality signals. Additionally, ICO token exchange listing causes higher future employment, indicating that access to token liquidity has important real consequences for the enterprise.
positioning_statement: This paper positions ICOs as a new mechanism for entrepreneurial finance with parallels to initial public offerings, venture capital, and presale crowdfunding, examining this emerging financing method through the lens of established corporate finance frameworks.

author: Sabrina T. Howell
title: When Investor Incentives and Consumer Interests Diverge: Private Equity in Higher Education
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We study how private equity buyouts create value in higher education, a sector with opaque product quality and intense government subsidy. With novel data on 88 private equity deals involving 994 schools, we show that buyouts lead to higher tuition and per-student debt. Exploiting loan limit increases, we find that private equity-owned schools better capture government aid. After buyouts, we observe lower education inputs, graduation rates, loan repayment rates, and earnings among graduates. Neither school selection nor student body changes fully explain the results. The results indicate that in a subsidized industry, maximizing value may not improve consumer outcomes.</jats:p><jats:p>Authors have furnished an Internet Appendix, which is available on the Oxford University Press Web site next to the link to the final published paper online.</jats:p>
research_question: How do private equity buyouts create value in higher education, and what are the effects on student outcomes in this subsidized sector with opaque product quality?
answer: Private equity buyouts in higher education create value by increasing tuition and capturing more government aid, but this comes at the expense of student outcomes - leading to lower education inputs, graduation rates, loan repayment rates, and graduate earnings.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by examining private equity in a unique context where maximizing investor value may not align with consumer welfare, specifically in a government-subsidized industry with opaque product quality, demonstrating that value creation mechanisms differ from traditional private equity settings.

author: Sabrina T. Howell
title: Owner Incentives and Performance in Healthcare: Private Equity Investment in Nursing Homes
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Amid an aging population and a growing role for private equity (PE) in the care of older adults, this paper studies how PE ownership affects U.S. nursing homes using patient-level Medicare data. We show that PE ownership leads to a patient cohort with lower health risk. However, after instrumenting for the patient-nursing home match, we find that PE ownership increases mortality by 11%. Declines in measures of patient well-being, nurse staffing, and compliance with care standards help to explain the mortality effect. Overall, we conclude that PE has nuanced effects with adverse outcomes for a subset of patients.</jats:p>
research_question: How does private equity ownership affect the performance and patient outcomes of U.S. nursing homes?
answer: Private equity ownership leads to nursing homes selecting lower health risk patients, but when controlling for patient-nursing home matching, PE ownership increases patient mortality by 11% due to declines in patient well-being, nurse staffing, and compliance with care standards.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on private equity investment in healthcare by providing empirical evidence on the effects of PE ownership in nursing homes, addressing the growing concern about PE's role in elder care amid an aging population.

title: Regulatory arbitrage or random errors? Implications of race prediction algorithms in fair lending analysis

author: Sabrina T. Howell
title: Investor Tax Credits and Entrepreneurship: Evidence from U.S. States
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Angel investor tax credits are used globally to spur high‐growth entrepreneurship. Exploiting their staggered implementation in 31 U.S. states, we find that they increase angel investment yet have no significant impact on entrepreneurial activity. Two mechanisms explain these results: crowding out of alternative financing and low sensitivity of professional investors to tax credits. With a large‐scale survey and a stylized model, we show that low responsiveness among professional angels may reflect the fat‐tailed return distributions that characterize high‐growth startups. The results contrast with evidence that direct subsidies to firms have positive effects, raising concerns about promoting entrepreneurship with investor subsidies.</jats:p>
research_question: Do angel investor tax credits effectively spur high-growth entrepreneurship and entrepreneurial activity?
answer: Angel investor tax credits increase angel investment but have no significant impact on entrepreneurial activity due to crowding out of alternative financing and low sensitivity of professional investors to tax credits, particularly because of the fat-tailed return distributions characteristic of high-growth startups.
positioning_statement: This paper contrasts with existing evidence that direct subsidies to firms have positive effects, raising concerns about the effectiveness of promoting entrepreneurship through investor subsidies rather than direct firm subsidies.

author: Sabrina T. Howell
title: Lender Automation and Racial Disparities in Credit Access
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Process automation reduces racial disparities in credit access by enabling smaller loans, broadening banks' geographic reach, and removing human biases from decision making. We document these findings in the context of the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP), where private lenders faced no credit risk but decided which firms to serve. Black‐owned firms obtained PPP loans primarily from automated fintech lenders, especially in areas with high racial animus. After traditional banks automated their loan processing procedures, their PPP lending to Black‐owned firms increased. Our findings cannot be fully explained by racial differences in loan application behaviors, preexisting banking relationships, firm performance, or fraud rates.</jats:p>
research_question: How does process automation in lending affect racial disparities in credit access?
answer: Process automation reduces racial disparities in credit access by enabling smaller loans, broadening banks' geographic reach, and removing human biases from decision making, as evidenced by Black-owned firms obtaining more loans from automated fintech lenders and increased lending from traditional banks after they automated their processes.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on racial disparities in lending by demonstrating that automation can mitigate discrimination, using the unique context of the Paycheck Protection Program where lenders faced no credit risk, thus isolating the effects of automation from traditional risk-based explanations for lending disparities.

author: Samual Hartzmark
title: A Tough Act to Follow: Contrast Effects in Financial Markets
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>A contrast effect occurs when the value of a previously observed signal inversely biases perception of the next signal. We present the first evidence that contrast effects can distort prices in sophisticated and liquid markets. Investors mistakenly perceive earnings news today as more impressive if yesterday's earnings surprise was bad and less impressive if yesterday's surprise was good. A unique advantage of our financial setting is that we can identify contrast effects as an error in perceptions rather than expectations. Finally, we show that our results cannot be explained by an alternative explanation involving information transmission from previous earnings announcements.</jats:p>
research_question: Do contrast effects occur in financial markets, where investors' perception of current earnings news is inversely biased by previously observed earnings signals?
answer: Yes, contrast effects distort prices in sophisticated and liquid financial markets - investors mistakenly perceive today's earnings news as more impressive following bad yesterday's earnings surprises and less impressive following good yesterday's surprises.
positioning_statement: This paper presents the first evidence that contrast effects can distort prices in sophisticated and liquid markets, with the unique advantage of identifying contrast effects as errors in perceptions rather than expectations, distinguishing it from alternative explanations involving information transmission from previous earnings announcements.

author: Samual Hartzmark
title: The Dividend Disconnect
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Many individual investors, mutual funds, and institutions trade as if dividends and capital gains are disconnected attributes, not fully appreciating that dividends result in price decreases. Behavioral trading patterns (e.g., the disposition effect) are driven by price changes instead of total returns. Investors rarely reinvest dividends, and trade as if dividends are a separate, stable income stream. Analysts fail to account for the effect of dividends on price, leading to optimistic price forecasts for dividend‐paying stocks. Demand for dividends is systematically higher in periods of low interest rates and poor market performance, leading to lower returns for dividend‐paying stocks.</jats:p>
research_question: Do investors properly understand the relationship between dividends and capital gains, specifically that dividends result in corresponding price decreases?
answer: Many individual investors, mutual funds, and institutions treat dividends and capital gains as disconnected attributes, failing to fully appreciate that dividends cause price decreases, leading to suboptimal trading behaviors and lower returns for dividend-paying stocks during periods of high dividend demand.
positioning_statement: This paper identifies a systematic behavioral bias in how investors perceive dividends versus capital gains, contributing to the behavioral finance literature by documenting that trading patterns and analyst forecasts reflect a fundamental misunderstanding of the mechanical relationship between dividend payments and stock prices.

author: Samual Hartzmark
title: Do Investors Value Sustainability? A Natural Experiment Examining Ranking and Fund Flows
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Examining a shock to the salience of the sustainability of the U.S. mutual fund market, we present causal evidence that investors marketwide value sustainability: being categorized as low sustainability resulted in net outflows of more than $12 billion while being categorized as high sustainability led to net inflows of more than $24 billion. Experimental evidence suggests that sustainability is viewed as positively predicting future performance, but we do not find evidence that high‐sustainability funds outperform low‐sustainability funds. The evidence is consistent with positive affect influencing expectations of sustainable fund performance and nonpecuniary motives influencing investment decisions.</jats:p>
research_question: Do investors value sustainability in mutual fund investments?
answer: Yes, investors marketwide value sustainability - funds categorized as low sustainability experienced net outflows of more than $12 billion while high sustainability funds had net inflows of more than $24 billion, driven by positive affect influencing performance expectations and nonpecuniary motives rather than actual performance differences.
positioning_statement: This paper provides causal evidence of investor valuation of sustainability by examining a natural experiment involving a shock to sustainability salience in the U.S. mutual fund market, complemented by experimental evidence to understand the underlying mechanisms behind investor behavior.

author: Samual Hartzmark
title: Efficiency and the Disposition Effect in NFL Prediction Markets
abstract: <jats:p>Examining NFL betting contracts at Tradesports.com, we find mispricing consistent with the disposition effect, where investors are more likely to close out profitable positions than losing positions. Prices are too low when teams are ahead and too high when teams are behind. Returns following news events exhibit short-term reversals and longer-term momentum. These results do not appear driven by liquidity or non-financial reasons for trade. Finding the disposition effect in a negative expected return gambling market questions standard explanations for the effect (belief in mean reversion, prospect theory). It is consistent with cognitive dissonance, and models with time-inconsistent behavior.</jats:p>
research_question: Do NFL prediction markets exhibit mispricing consistent with the disposition effect, where investors are more likely to close out profitable positions than losing positions?
answer: Yes, NFL betting contracts show mispricing consistent with the disposition effect - prices are too low when teams are ahead and too high when teams are behind, with returns following news events exhibiting short-term reversals and longer-term momentum.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges standard explanations for the disposition effect (belief in mean reversion, prospect theory) by finding evidence of the effect in a negative expected return gambling market, instead supporting cognitive dissonance and time-inconsistent behavior models as explanations.

author: Samual Hartzmark
title: Educating Investors about Dividends
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
                  <jats:p>We educate investors about the benefits of dividend reinvestment and costs of misperceiving dividends as free income. The intervention increases planned dividend reinvestment in survey responses. Using trading records, we observe a causal increase in dividend reinvestment in the field of roughly 50 cents for every euro received. This holds relative to investors’ prior behavior and various control samples. Investors who learned the most from the intervention update their trading the most. The results suggest the free dividends fallacy is a significant source of dividend demand. Our study demonstrates that simple, targeted, and focused educational interventions can affect investment behavior.</jats:p>
research_question: Can educating investors about the benefits of dividend reinvestment and costs of misperceiving dividends as free income change their actual investment behavior?
answer: Yes, the educational intervention causally increases dividend reinvestment behavior by roughly 50 cents for every euro received, with investors who learned the most updating their trading behavior the most, demonstrating that the free dividends fallacy is a significant source of dividend demand.
positioning_statement: This study contributes to the literature by demonstrating that simple, targeted, and focused educational interventions can effectively change investment behavior, specifically addressing the gap in understanding how investor education can correct behavioral biases like the free dividends fallacy.

author: Samual Hartzmark
title: Rolling Mental Accounts

author: Samual Hartzmark
title: Reconsidering Returns
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Investors’ perception of performance is biased because the relevant measure, returns, is rarely displayed. Major indices ignore dividends, thereby underreporting market performance. Newspapers are more pessimistic on ex-dividend days, consistent with mistaking the index for returns. Market betas should track returns, but track prices more than dividends, creating predictable returns. Mutual funds receive inflows for “beating the S&P 500” price index based on net asset value (also not a return). Investors extrapolate market indices, not returns, when forming annual performance expectations. Displaying returns by default would ameliorate these issues, which arise despite high attention and agreement on the appropriate measure.</jats:p>
research_question: How does the common practice of displaying price indices rather than total returns affect investor behavior and market outcomes?
answer: The failure to display total returns creates systematic biases in investor behavior, including misperception of market performance, predictable return patterns in market betas, suboptimal mutual fund flows, and biased performance expectations - all stemming from investors focusing on price movements rather than total returns including dividends.
positioning_statement: This paper identifies a fundamental but overlooked issue in how financial performance is communicated to investors, demonstrating that even in high-attention contexts where there is agreement on the appropriate performance measure (total returns), the simple failure to display this measure by default creates widespread behavioral biases and market inefficiencies.

author: Samual Hartzmark
title: Juicing the dividend yield: Mutual funds and the demand for dividends

author: Samual Hartzmark
title: A New Test of Risk Factor Relevance
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Textbook models assume that investors try to insure against bad states of the world associated with specific risk factors when investing. This is a testable assumption and we develop a survey framework for doing so. Our framework can be applied to any risk factor. We demonstrate the approach using consumption growth, which makes our results applicable to most modern asset‐pricing models. Participants respond to changes in the mean and volatility of stock returns consistent with textbook models, but we find no evidence that they view an asset's correlation with consumption growth as relevant to investment decisions.</jats:p>
research_question: Do investors actually try to insure against bad states of the world associated with specific risk factors when making investment decisions, as assumed by textbook asset pricing models?
answer: While participants respond to changes in mean and volatility of stock returns consistent with textbook models, there is no evidence that investors view an asset's correlation with consumption growth as relevant to investment decisions, contradicting a key assumption of modern asset pricing models.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a novel survey framework to test fundamental assumptions of textbook asset pricing models that have been widely accepted but not empirically validated through direct investor behavior, providing a new methodological approach that can be applied to any risk factor beyond the consumption growth factor demonstrated in this study.

author: Semyon Malamud
title: An Intermediation-Based Model of Exchange Rates
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We develop a continuous-time general equilibrium model with intermediaries at the heart of international financial markets. Global intermediaries bargain with households and extract rents from providing access to foreign claims. By tilting state prices, intermediaries’ market power breaks monetary neutrality and makes international risk-sharing inefficient. Despite having zero net positions, markups charged by intermediaries significantly distort international asset prices, affecting exchange rate dynamics and their response to shocks. Our model can reproduce patterns consistent with several well-known exchange rate puzzles, such as deviations from uncovered and covered interest parity. All equilibrium quantities are derived in closed form, allowing us to pin down the underlying economic mechanisms explicitly.</jats:p>
research_question: How do global financial intermediaries with market power affect exchange rate dynamics and international asset pricing?
answer: Intermediaries' market power breaks monetary neutrality and makes international risk-sharing inefficient by tilting state prices through rent extraction, which significantly distorts exchange rate dynamics and can explain well-known exchange rate puzzles like deviations from uncovered and covered interest parity, even when intermediaries hold zero net positions.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a new theoretical framework that places intermediaries with market power at the center of international financial markets, offering a novel explanation for established exchange rate puzzles through the lens of intermediary rent extraction and inefficient risk-sharing, rather than traditional approaches.

author: Semyon Malamud
title: The Virtue of Complexity in Return Prediction
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Much of the extant literature predicts market returns with “simple” models that use only a few parameters. Contrary to conventional wisdom, we theoretically prove that simple models severely understate return predictability compared to “complex” models in which the number of parameters exceeds the number of observations. We empirically document the virtue of complexity in U.S. equity market return prediction. Our findings establish the rationale for modeling expected returns through machine learning.</jats:p>
research_question: Do complex models with more parameters than observations provide better return predictability compared to simple models with few parameters?
answer: Complex models in which the number of parameters exceeds the number of observations significantly outperform simple models in predicting market returns, contrary to conventional wisdom that favors parsimonious models.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the conventional wisdom in the extant literature that favors simple models with few parameters for return prediction, and provides theoretical and empirical justification for using complex models and machine learning approaches in expected return modeling.

author: Semyon Malamud
title: Illiquidity and Higher Cumulants
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We characterize the unique equilibrium in an economy populated by strategic CARA investors who trade multiple risky assets with arbitrarily distributed payoffs. We use our explicit solution to study the joint behavior of illiquidity of option contracts. Option bid-ask spreads are proportional to risk aversion and risk-neutral variances of option payoffs. Spreads may decrease in risk aversion, physical variance, open interest, and increase after earnings announcements in a result contrary to conventional wisdom. All these predictions are confirmed empirically using a large panel data set of U.S. stock options.</jats:p>
               <jats:p>Authors have furnished an Internet Appendix, which is available on the Oxford University Press Web site next to the link to the final published paper online.</jats:p>
research_question: How does illiquidity in option markets relate to higher moments of return distributions, and what determines option bid-ask spreads in an economy with strategic CARA investors trading multiple risky assets?
answer: Option bid-ask spreads are proportional to risk aversion and risk-neutral variances of option payoffs, with counterintuitive findings that spreads may decrease in risk aversion, physical variance, and open interest, while increasing after earnings announcements contrary to conventional wisdom.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a unique equilibrium characterization for strategic CARA investors trading multiple risky assets with arbitrarily distributed payoffs, offering theoretical predictions about option illiquidity that challenge conventional wisdom and are empirically validated using a large panel dataset of U.S. stock options.

author: Semyon Malamud
title: Principal Portfolios
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We propose a new asset pricing framework in which all securities' signals predict each individual return. While the literature focuses on securities' own‐signal predictability, assuming equal strength across securities, our framework includes cross‐predictability—leading to three main results. First, we derive the optimal strategy in closed form. It consists of eigenvectors of a “prediction matrix,” which we call “principal portfolios.” Second, we decompose the problem into alpha and beta, yielding optimal strategies with, respectively, zero and positive factor exposure. Third, we provide a new test of asset pricing models. Empirically, principal portfolios deliver significant out‐of‐sample alphas to standard factors in several data sets.</jats:p>
research_question: How can asset pricing be optimized when all securities' signals predict each individual return, incorporating cross-predictability rather than just own-signal predictability?
answer: The optimal investment strategy consists of eigenvectors of a 'prediction matrix' called 'principal portfolios,' which can be decomposed into alpha and beta components and deliver significant out-of-sample alphas to standard factors.
positioning_statement: This paper extends beyond the existing literature's focus on securities' own-signal predictability (assuming equal strength across securities) by proposing a new framework that incorporates cross-predictability, where all securities' signals predict each individual return.

author: Snehal Banerjee
title: Disagreement and Learning: Dynamic Patterns of Trade
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>The empirical evidence on investor disagreement and trading volume is difficult to reconcile in standard rational expectations models. We develop a dynamic model in which investors disagree about the interpretation of public information. We obtain a closed‐form linear equilibrium that allows us to study which restrictions on the disagreement process yield empirically observed volume and return dynamics. We show that when investors have infrequent but major disagreements, there is positive autocorrelation in volume and positive correlation between volume and volatility. We also derive novel empirical predictions that relate the degree and frequency of disagreement to volume and volatility dynamics.</jats:p>
research_question: How can investor disagreement about the interpretation of public information explain the empirically observed patterns of trading volume and return dynamics that are difficult to reconcile in standard rational expectations models?
answer: When investors have infrequent but major disagreements about public information interpretation, the model generates positive autocorrelation in trading volume and positive correlation between volume and volatility, which matches empirical observations.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses limitations of standard rational expectations models by developing a dynamic model that can reconcile empirical evidence on investor disagreement and trading volume that existing models struggle to explain.

author: Snehal Banerjee
title: Strategic trading and unobservable information acquisition

author: Snehal Banerjee
title: Dynamics of Research and Strategic Trading
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We study how dynamic research affects information acquisition in financial markets. In our strategic trading model, the trader performs costly research to generate private information but does not always succeed. Optimal research activity responds to market conditions and generates novel implications. First, more frequent public disclosures can “crowd in” private information acquisition, increase price informativeness, and harm liquidity, instead of “leveling the playing field.” Second, observed research activity does not necessarily imply that traders are better informed. Finally, improvements in research effectiveness or higher market participation by uninformed investors can simultaneously increase price informativeness and liquidity.</jats:p>
research_question: How does dynamic research affect information acquisition in financial markets when traders perform costly research that does not always succeed?
answer: Optimal research activity responds to market conditions and generates three key findings: (1) more frequent public disclosures can crowd in private information acquisition and increase price informativeness while harming liquidity, (2) observed research activity does not necessarily indicate that traders are better informed, and (3) improvements in research effectiveness or higher uninformed investor participation can simultaneously increase both price informativeness and liquidity.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the conventional wisdom that public disclosures 'level the playing field' by showing they can actually crowd in private research, and provides a novel framework where research success is uncertain, leading to counterintuitive results about the relationship between research activity, information acquisition, and market outcomes.

author: Snehal Banerjee
title: The Cost of Short‐Selling Liquid Securities
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Standard models of liquidity argue that the higher price for a liquid security reflects the future benefits that long investors expect to receive. We show that short‐sellers can also pay a <jats:italic>net</jats:italic> liquidity premium if their cost to borrow the security is higher than the price premium they collect from selling it. We provide a model‐free decomposition of the price premium for liquid securities into the <jats:italic>net</jats:italic> premiums paid by <jats:italic>both</jats:italic> long investors <jats:italic>and</jats:italic> short‐sellers. Empirically, we find that short‐sellers were responsible for a substantial fraction of the liquidity premium for on‐the‐run Treasuries from November 1995 through July 2009.</jats:p>
research_question: How much do short-sellers contribute to the liquidity premium of liquid securities, and what is their net cost when borrowing costs exceed the price premium they collect?
answer: Short-sellers can pay a net liquidity premium when their borrowing costs exceed the price premium they collect from selling liquid securities, and empirically, short-sellers were responsible for a substantial fraction of the liquidity premium for on-the-run Treasuries from November 1995 through July 2009.
positioning_statement: This paper extends standard liquidity models that focus only on long investors' benefits by showing that short-sellers also contribute to liquidity premiums, providing a model-free decomposition that accounts for net premiums paid by both long investors and short-sellers.

author: Snehal Banerjee
title: Disclosing to Informed Traders
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We develop a model in which a firm's manager can voluntarily disclose to privately informed investors. In equilibrium, the manager only discloses sufficiently favorable news. If the manager is known to be informed but disclosure is costly, the probability of disclosure increases with market liquidity and the stock trades at a discount relative to expected cash flows. However, when investors are uncertain about whether the manager is informed, disclosure can decrease with market liquidity and the stock can trade at a premium relative to expected cash flows. Moreover, contrary to common intuition, public information can <jats:italic>crowd in</jats:italic> more voluntary disclosure.</jats:p>
research_question: How does voluntary disclosure by firm managers to privately informed investors affect market outcomes, particularly in relation to market liquidity and information uncertainty?
answer: The key finding is that disclosure behavior and market outcomes depend critically on whether investors know if the manager is informed. When the manager is known to be informed, disclosure increases with market liquidity and stocks trade at a discount. However, when there is uncertainty about the manager's information, disclosure can decrease with market liquidity and stocks can trade at a premium. Additionally, public information can actually increase voluntary disclosure, contrary to common intuition.
positioning_statement: This paper extends existing voluntary disclosure literature by incorporating the novel element of managers disclosing to privately informed (rather than uninformed) investors, and by distinguishing between scenarios where the manager's information status is known versus uncertain, leading to counterintuitive results that challenge conventional wisdom about disclosure and market liquidity relationships.

author: Snehal Banerjee
title: Choosing to Disagree: Endogenous Dismissiveness and Overconfidence in Financial Markets
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>The psychology literature documents that individuals derive current utility from their beliefs about future events. We show that, as a result, investors in financial markets choose to disagree about both private information and price information. When objective price informativeness is low, each investor dismisses the private signals of others and ignores price information. In contrast, when prices are sufficiently informative, heterogeneous interpretations arise endogenously: most investors ignore prices, while the rest condition on it. Our analysis demonstrates how observed deviations from rational expectations (e.g., dismissiveness, overconfidence) arise endogenously, interact with each other, and vary with economic conditions.</jats:p>
research_question: How do psychological motivations for deriving utility from beliefs affect investor behavior and information processing in financial markets, particularly regarding disagreement about private and price information?
answer: Investors endogenously choose to disagree about information based on price informativeness levels: when price informativeness is low, investors dismiss others' private signals and ignore prices; when prices are sufficiently informative, heterogeneous interpretations emerge with most investors ignoring prices while others condition on them.
positioning_statement: This paper demonstrates how commonly observed deviations from rational expectations (such as dismissiveness and overconfidence) arise endogenously from psychological utility derived from beliefs, showing how these behavioral biases interact with each other and vary with economic conditions, rather than treating them as exogenous behavioral assumptions.

author: Snehal Banerjee
title: Feedback Effects and Systematic Risk Exposures
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We model the “feedback effect” of a firm's stock price on investment in projects exposed to a systematic risk factor, like climate risk. The stock price reflects information about both the project's cash flows and its discount rate. A cash‐flow‐maximizing manager treats discount rate fluctuations as “noise,” but a price‐maximizing manager interprets such variation as information about the project's net present value. This difference qualitatively changes how investment behavior varies with the project's risk exposure. Moreover, traditional objectives (e.g., cash flow or price maximization) need not maximize welfare because they do not correctly account for hedging and risk‐sharing benefits of investment.</jats:p>
research_question: How does the feedback effect of a firm's stock price on investment decisions vary depending on whether projects are exposed to systematic risk factors, and how do different managerial objectives (cash flow maximization vs. price maximization) affect investment behavior in such projects?
answer: The feedback effect qualitatively changes investment behavior based on the project's systematic risk exposure and managerial objectives. Cash-flow-maximizing managers treat discount rate fluctuations as noise, while price-maximizing managers interpret such variation as information about net present value, leading to fundamentally different investment patterns. Additionally, traditional objectives like cash flow or price maximization do not maximize welfare because they fail to properly account for hedging and risk-sharing benefits.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the literature on feedback effects by specifically examining how they interact with systematic risk exposures in investment decisions, and challenges traditional managerial objectives by showing they may not be welfare-maximizing due to their inadequate treatment of hedging and risk-sharing considerations.
