author: Toni M. Whited
title: Agency Conflicts and Cash: Estimates from a Dynamic Model
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Which agency problems affect corporate cash policy? To answer this question, we estimate a dynamic model of finance and investment with three mechanisms that misalign managerial and shareholder incentives: limited managerial ownership of the firm, compensation based on firm size, and managerial perquisite consumption. We find that perquisite consumption critically impacts cash policy. Size‐based compensation also matters, but less. Firms with lower blockholder and institutional ownership have higher managerial perquisite consumption, low managerial ownership is a key factor in the secular upward trend in cash holdings, and agency plays little role in small firms' substantial cash holdings.</jats:p>
research_question: Which agency problems affect corporate cash policy?
answer: Perquisite consumption critically impacts cash policy, with size-based compensation also mattering but to a lesser extent. Low managerial ownership is a key factor in the secular upward trend in cash holdings, while agency plays little role in small firms' substantial cash holdings.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by estimating a dynamic model of finance and investment that incorporates three specific agency mechanisms (limited managerial ownership, size-based compensation, and managerial perquisite consumption) to quantify their relative importance in explaining corporate cash policy, providing empirical estimates of which agency problems matter most.

author: Todd Gormley
title: Standing on the Shoulders of Giants: The Effect of Passive Investors on Activism
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We analyze whether the growing importance of passive investors has influenced the campaigns, tactics, and successes of activists. We find activists are more likely to seek board representation when a larger share of the target company’s stock is held by passively managed mutual funds. Furthermore, higher passive ownership is associated with increased use of proxy fights, settlements, and a higher likelihood the activist achieves board representation or the sale of the targeted company. Our findings suggest that the recent growth of passive institutional investors mitigates free-rider problems and facilitates activists’ ability to engage in costly, value-enhancing forms of monitoring.</jats:p>
               <jats:p>Received September 28, 2016; editorial decision August 18, 2018 by Editor Andrew Karolyi.</jats:p>
research_question: Has the growing importance of passive investors influenced the campaigns, tactics, and successes of activist investors?
answer: Yes, higher passive ownership leads activists to more frequently seek board representation, use proxy fights and settlements, and achieve greater success in obtaining board seats or company sales. The growth of passive institutional investors mitigates free-rider problems and facilitates activists' ability to engage in costly, value-enhancing monitoring.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses how the recent growth of passive institutional investors affects activist investor behavior and outcomes, specifically examining whether passive investors help solve free-rider problems that typically hinder costly monitoring activities by activists.

author: Thomas Philippon
title: Optimal Mitigation Policies in a Pandemic: Social Distancing and Working from Home
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We study an economy’s response to an unexpected epidemic. The spread of the disease can be mitigated by reducing consumption and hours worked in the office. Working from home is subject to learning-by-doing. Private agents’ rational incentives are relatively weak and fatalistic. The planner recognizes infection and congestion externalities and implements front-loaded mitigation. Under our calibration, the planner reduces cumulative fatalities by 48$\%$ compared to 24$\%$ by private agents, although with a sharper drop in consumption. Our model can replicate key industry and/or occupational-level patterns and explain how large variations in outcomes across regions can stem from small initial differences.</jats:p>
research_question: How should an economy optimally respond to an unexpected epidemic through mitigation policies involving social distancing and working from home, and how do optimal planner policies compare to private agents' responses?
answer: The optimal planner implements front-loaded mitigation policies that reduce cumulative fatalities by 48% (compared to 24% by private agents), though with sharper consumption drops. Private agents have relatively weak and fatalistic incentives, while the planner accounts for infection and congestion externalities to achieve better outcomes.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by modeling epidemic response through a framework that incorporates both social distancing and working from home with learning-by-doing effects, comparing optimal planner policies against private agent responses while accounting for infection and congestion externalities that private agents fail to internalize.

author: Toni M. Whited
title: The Misallocation of Finance
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We estimate real losses arising from the cross‐sectional misallocation of financial liabilities. Extending a production‐based framework of misallocation measurement to the liabilities side of the balance sheet and using manufacturing firm data from the United States and China, we find significant misallocation of debt and equity in China but not the United States. Reallocating liabilities of firms in China to mimic U.S. efficiency would produce gains of 51% to 69% in real value‐added, with only 17% to 21% stemming from inefficient debt‐equity combinations. For Chinese firms that are large or in developed cities, we estimate lower distortionary financing costs.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the real economic losses arising from the cross-sectional misallocation of financial liabilities (debt and equity) across firms?
answer: There is significant misallocation of debt and equity in China but not the United States, with reallocating Chinese firms' liabilities to mimic U.S. efficiency producing gains of 51% to 69% in real value-added, where only 17% to 21% stems from inefficient debt-equity combinations.
positioning_statement: This paper extends existing production-based frameworks of misallocation measurement to the liabilities side of the balance sheet, filling a gap in the literature that has primarily focused on input misallocation rather than financial misallocation.

author: Toni M. Whited
title: Debt Dynamics
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We develop a dynamic trade‐off model with endogenous choice of leverage, distributions, and real investment in the presence of a graduated corporate income tax, individual taxes on interest and corporate distributions, financial distress costs, and equity flotation costs. We explain several empirical findings inconsistent with the static trade‐off theory. We show there is no target leverage ratio, firms can be savers or heavily levered, leverage is path dependent, leverage is decreasing in lagged liquidity, and leverage varies negatively with an external finance weighted average <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic>. Using estimates of structural parameters, we find that simulated model moments match data moments.</jats:p>
research_question: How do firms make dynamic decisions about leverage, distributions, and real investment when facing corporate income taxes, individual taxes, financial distress costs, and equity flotation costs, and can this explain empirical findings inconsistent with static trade-off theory?
answer: There is no target leverage ratio in a dynamic setting - firms can be savers or heavily levered, leverage is path dependent, decreases with lagged liquidity, and varies negatively with external finance weighted average Q, with simulated model moments matching empirical data moments.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as addressing limitations of static trade-off theory by developing a dynamic trade-off model that can explain several empirical findings that are inconsistent with existing static trade-off models.

author: Toni M. Whited
title: How Costly Is External Financing? Evidence from a Structural Estimation
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We apply simulated method of moments to a dynamic model to infer the magnitude of financing costs. The model features endogenous investment, distributions, leverage, and default. The corporation faces taxation, costly bankruptcy, and linear‐quadratic equity flotation costs. For large (small) firms, estimated marginal equity flotation costs start at 5.0% (10.7%) and bankruptcy costs equal to 8.4% (15.1%) of capital. Estimated financing frictions are higher for low‐dividend firms and those identified as constrained by the Cleary and Whited‐Wu indexes. In simulated data, many common proxies for financing constraints actually decrease when we increase financing cost parameters.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the magnitude of external financing costs for corporations?
answer: For large firms, marginal equity flotation costs start at 5.0% and bankruptcy costs equal 8.4% of capital, while for small firms these costs are 10.7% and 15.1% respectively. Financing frictions are higher for low-dividend firms and those identified as financially constrained.
positioning_statement: This paper uses structural estimation via simulated method of moments applied to a dynamic model with endogenous investment, distributions, leverage, and default to quantify financing costs, contributing to the literature by providing precise estimates of these costs and showing that common proxies for financing constraints may not behave as expected when financing costs increase.

author: Toni M. Whited
title: The Corporate Propensity to Save
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Why do corporations accumulate liquid assets? We show theoretically that intertemporal trade‐offs between interest income taxation and the cost of external finance determine optimal savings. Intriguingly, we find that, controlling for Tobin's <jats:italic>q</jats:italic>, saving and cash flow are negatively related because firms lower cash reserves to invest after receiving positive cash‐flow shocks, and vice versa. Consistent with theory, we estimate negative propensities to save out of cash flow. We also find that income uncertainty affects saving more than do external finance constraints. Therefore, contrary to previous evidence, saving propensities reflect too many forces to be used to measure external finance constraints.</jats:p>
research_question: Why do corporations accumulate liquid assets?
answer: Intertemporal trade-offs between interest income taxation and the cost of external finance determine optimal corporate savings, with firms exhibiting negative propensities to save out of cash flow when controlling for Tobin's q, and income uncertainty affecting saving more than external finance constraints.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges previous evidence by arguing that saving propensities reflect too many forces to be used as a reliable measure of external finance constraints, contrary to existing literature that has used saving propensities for this purpose.

author: Toni M. Whited
title: Threshold Events and Identification: A Study of Cash Shortfalls
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Threshold events are discrete events triggered when an observable continuous variable passes a known threshold. We demonstrate how to use threshold events as identification strategies by revisiting the evidence in Rauh (2006, Investment and financing constraints: Evidence from the funding of corporate pension plans, <jats:italic>Journal of Finance</jats:italic> 61, 33–71) that mandatory pension contributions cause investment declines. Rauh's result stems from heavily underfunded firms that constitute a small fraction of the sample and that differ sharply from the rest of the sample. To alleviate this issue, we use observations near funding thresholds and find causal effects of mandatory contributions on receivables, R&D, and hiring, but not on investment. We also provide useful suggestions and diagnostics for analyzing threshold events.</jats:p>
research_question: Do mandatory pension contributions cause investment declines in firms, and how can threshold events be used as identification strategies to better understand this relationship?
answer: Using observations near funding thresholds, mandatory pension contributions have causal effects on receivables, R&D, and hiring, but not on investment, contrary to previous findings that were driven by heavily underfunded firms representing a small fraction of the sample.
positioning_statement: This paper revisits and challenges the evidence in Rauh (2006) by demonstrating how threshold events can be used as identification strategies, showing that Rauh's results were driven by a small fraction of heavily underfunded firms that differed sharply from the rest of the sample, and proposes a more robust methodology using observations near funding thresholds.

author: Toni M. Whited
title: Relative Performance Evaluation and Strategic Competition
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
                  <jats:p>We examine how relative performance evaluation (RPE) affects industry competition—a question relevant for corporate boards interested in incentivizing executives. Using U.S. airline data, we estimate a dynamic game of competition between heterogeneous firms in an oligopolistic market, with managers incentivized by RPE contracts. While RPE can induce a firm to compete more intensely by smoothing compensation, it also amplifies a firm’s cost efficiency relative to its peers and can weaken competition from inefficient firms. The first effect dominates in small markets and the second in median-sized markets. RPE has little effect in large, highly profitable markets.</jats:p>
research_question: How does relative performance evaluation (RPE) affect industry competition?
answer: RPE has heterogeneous effects on competition that depend on market size: it intensifies competition in small markets by smoothing compensation, weakens competition in median-sized markets by amplifying cost efficiency differences between firms, and has little effect in large, highly profitable markets.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a question relevant for corporate boards interested in incentivizing executives by examining the competitive effects of RPE contracts, using a dynamic game framework applied to U.S. airline data to analyze competition between heterogeneous firms in oligopolistic markets.

author: Toni M. Whited
title: Bank Market Power and Monetary Policy Transmission: Evidence from a Structural Estimation
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We quantify the impact of bank market power on monetary policy transmission through banks to borrowers. We estimate a dynamic banking model in which monetary policy affects imperfectly competitive banks' funding costs. Banks optimize the pass‐through of these costs to borrowers and depositors, while facing capital and reserve regulation. We find that bank market power explains much of the transmission of monetary policy to borrowers, with an effect comparable to that of bank capital regulation. When the federal funds rate falls below 0.9%, market power interacts with bank capital regulation to produce a reversal of the effect of monetary policy.</jats:p>
research_question: How does bank market power affect the transmission of monetary policy through banks to borrowers?
answer: Bank market power explains much of the transmission of monetary policy to borrowers, with an effect comparable to that of bank capital regulation. When the federal funds rate falls below 0.9%, market power interacts with bank capital regulation to produce a reversal of the effect of monetary policy.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing a structural estimation approach to quantify the specific impact of bank market power on monetary policy transmission, positioning market power as a factor of comparable importance to bank capital regulation in explaining how monetary policy affects borrowers through the banking system.

author: Toni M. Whited
title: Information versus Investment
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We quantify the real implications of trade-offs between firm information disclosure and long-term investment efficiency. We estimate a dynamic equilibrium model in which firm managers confront realistic incentives to misreport earnings and distort their real investment choices. The model implies a socially optimal level of disclosure regulation that exceeds the estimated value. Counterfactual analysis reveals that eliminating earnings misreporting completely through disclosure regulation incentivizes managers to distort real investment. Lower earnings informativeness raises the cost of capital, which results in a 5.7$\%$ drop in average firm value, but more modest effects on social welfare and aggregate growth.</jats:p><jats:p>Authors have furnished an Internet Appendix, which is available on the Oxford University Press Web site next to the link to the final published paper online.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the real implications of trade-offs between firm information disclosure and long-term investment efficiency?
answer: The socially optimal level of disclosure regulation exceeds the estimated current value, and eliminating earnings misreporting completely through disclosure regulation incentivizes managers to distort real investment, leading to lower earnings informativeness, higher cost of capital, a 5.7% drop in average firm value, but more modest effects on social welfare and aggregate growth.
positioning_statement: This paper quantifies the real implications of disclosure-investment trade-offs using a dynamic equilibrium model that incorporates realistic managerial incentives for both earnings misreporting and real investment distortion, providing a comprehensive framework to evaluate optimal disclosure regulation.

author: Toni M. Whited
title: Collateral, Taxes, and Leverage
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We quantify the importance of collateral versus taxes for firms' capital structures. We estimate a dynamic model in which a taxable firm seeks financing for investment, and a dynamic contracting environment motivates endogenous collateral constraints. Optimal leverage stays a safe distance from the constraint, balancing the tax benefit of debt with the cost of lost financial flexibility. We estimate this flexibility cost to be 7.2% of firm assets, a percentage that is comparable to the tax benefit. Models with different tax rates fit the data equally well, and leverage responds to the tax rate only when taxes are low.</jats:p>
               <jats:p>Received January 20, 2015; accepted January 8, 2016 by Editor Itay Goldstein.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the relative importance of collateral constraints versus tax benefits in determining firms' capital structure decisions?
answer: The cost of lost financial flexibility from collateral constraints (7.2% of firm assets) is comparable in magnitude to tax benefits, and leverage responds to tax rates only when taxes are low, suggesting collateral constraints are as important as taxes in capital structure decisions.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the capital structure literature by developing a dynamic model that simultaneously incorporates both collateral constraints from dynamic contracting and tax considerations, quantifying their relative importance in a unified framework rather than examining these factors in isolation.

author: Turan Bali
title: Option Return Predictability with Machine Learning and Big Data
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Drawing upon more than 12 million observations over the period from 1996 to 2020, we find that allowing for nonlinearities significantly increases the out-of-sample performance of option and stock characteristics in predicting future option returns. The nonlinear machine learning models generate statistically and economically sizable profits in the long-short portfolios of equity options even after accounting for transaction costs. Although option-based characteristics are the most important standalone predictors, stock-based measures offer substantial incremental predictive power when considered alongside option-based characteristics. Finally, we provide compelling evidence that option return predictability is driven by informational frictions and option mispricing.</jats:p><jats:p>Authors have furnished an Internet Appendix, which is available on the Oxford University Press Web site next to the link to the final published paper online.</jats:p>
research_question: Can machine learning methods with big data improve the predictability of option returns using option and stock characteristics, and what drives this predictability?
answer: Allowing for nonlinearities significantly increases out-of-sample performance in predicting option returns, with machine learning models generating statistically and economically sizable profits even after transaction costs. Option-based characteristics are the most important standalone predictors, but stock-based measures provide substantial incremental predictive power. The predictability is driven by informational frictions and option mispricing.
positioning_statement: This paper extends existing option return predictability literature by applying machine learning methods to capture nonlinearities in a large dataset of over 12 million observations, demonstrating superior performance compared to traditional linear approaches and providing evidence for the underlying mechanisms driving predictability.

author: Turan Bali
title: Does Idiosyncratic Risk Really Matter?
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p><jats:ext-link xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="#b11">Goyal and Santa‐Clara (2003)</jats:ext-link> find a significantly positive relation between the equal‐weighted average stock volatility and the value‐weighted portfolio returns on the NYSE/AMEX/Nasdaq stocks for the period of 1963:08 to 1999:12. We show that this result is driven by small stocks traded on the Nasdaq, and is in part due to a liquidity premium. In addition, their result does not hold for the extended sample of 1963:08 to 2001:12 and for the NYSE/AMEX and NYSE stocks. More importantly, we find no evidence of a significant link between the value‐weighted portfolio returns and the median and value‐weighted average stock volatility.</jats:p>
research_question: Does idiosyncratic risk (measured by individual stock volatility) have a significant relationship with market portfolio returns?
answer: No, idiosyncratic risk does not really matter for market returns. The previously documented positive relationship between average stock volatility and market returns is driven by small Nasdaq stocks, partly reflects a liquidity premium, and does not hold in extended samples or when using alternative volatility measures (median and value-weighted average).
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the findings of Goyal and Santa-Clara (2003) who documented a significantly positive relation between equal-weighted average stock volatility and value-weighted portfolio returns, by showing their results are not robust to different samples, stock exchanges, and volatility measurement approaches.

author: Turan Bali
title: The Joint Cross Section of Stocks and Options
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Stocks with large increases in call (put) implied volatilities over the previous month tend to have high (low) future returns. Sorting stocks ranked into decile portfolios by past call implied volatilities produces spreads in average returns of approximately 1% per month, and the return differences persist up to six months. The cross section of stock returns also predicts option implied volatilities, with stocks with high past returns tending to have call and put option contracts that exhibit increases in implied volatility over the next month, but with decreasing realized volatility. These predictability patterns are consistent with rational models of informed trading.</jats:p>
research_question: How do option implied volatilities predict future stock returns, and how do past stock returns predict future option implied volatilities?
answer: Stocks with large increases in call (put) implied volatilities over the previous month tend to have high (low) future returns, with spreads of approximately 1% per month that persist up to six months. Additionally, stocks with high past returns tend to have call and put options with increasing implied volatility but decreasing realized volatility over the next month.
positioning_statement: These predictability patterns are consistent with rational models of informed trading, positioning the findings within the framework of informed trading theory rather than market inefficiency explanations.

author: Tyler Muir
title: Volatility‐Managed Portfolios
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Managed portfolios that take less risk when volatility is high produce large alphas, increase Sharpe ratios, and produce large utility gains for mean‐variance investors. We document this for the market, value, momentum, profitability, return on equity, investment, and betting‐against‐beta factors, as well as the currency carry trade. Volatility timing increases Sharpe ratios because changes in volatility are not offset by proportional changes in expected returns. Our strategy is contrary to conventional wisdom because it takes relatively less risk in recessions. This rules out typical risk‐based explanations and is a challenge to structural models of time‐varying expected returns.</jats:p>
research_question: Do managed portfolios that reduce risk exposure when volatility is high generate superior risk-adjusted returns and utility gains for investors?
answer: Yes, volatility-managed portfolios that take less risk when volatility is high produce large alphas, increase Sharpe ratios, and generate substantial utility gains for mean-variance investors across multiple factors including market, value, momentum, profitability, and currency carry trades.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges conventional wisdom and typical risk-based explanations by showing that volatility timing works because changes in volatility are not offset by proportional changes in expected returns, and the strategy takes relatively less risk in recessions, which poses a challenge to existing structural models of time-varying expected returns.

author: Toni M. Whited
title: Corporate Money Demand
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We document a hump-shaped relation between corporate cash and both real and nominal interest rates in both aggregate and firm-level data. We rationalize this result in a model where firms finance investment with cash and risky debt. The risky rate rises endogenously with the risk-free rate, spurring precautionary cash demand. Simultaneously, foregone interest lowers cash demand. The first mechanism dominates at low interest rates, and the second at high interest rates. The model matches several data moments and reproduces a nonmonotonic cash–interest relation. This nonmonotonicity implies that interest rates are unlikely to be behind the recent rise in corporate cash.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the relationship between corporate cash holdings and interest rates, and can this relationship explain the recent rise in corporate cash?
answer: There is a hump-shaped (nonmonotonic) relationship between corporate cash holdings and both real and nominal interest rates, where precautionary cash demand dominates at low interest rates and foregone interest costs dominate at high interest rates, implying that interest rates are unlikely to explain the recent rise in corporate cash.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a novel theoretical model that rationalizes the empirically observed hump-shaped relationship between corporate cash and interest rates by incorporating both precautionary motives (through endogenous risky debt rates) and opportunity costs, offering a new perspective on corporate cash demand that challenges simple monotonic relationships assumed in existing literature.

author: Tyler Muir
title: Should Long-Term Investors Time Volatility?

author: Tyler Muir
title: Do Intermediaries Matter for Aggregate Asset Prices?
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Poor financial health of intermediaries coincides with low asset prices and high risk premiums. Is this because intermediaries matter for asset prices, or because their health correlates with economy‐wide risk aversion? In the first case, return predictability should be more pronounced for asset classes in which households are less active. We provide evidence supporting this prediction, suggesting that a quantitatively sizable fraction of risk premium variation in several large asset classes such as credit or mortgage‐backed securities (MBS) is due to intermediaries. Movements in economy‐wide risk aversion create the opposite pattern, and we find this channel also matters.</jats:p>
research_question: Do intermediaries matter for aggregate asset prices, or does the correlation between poor intermediary financial health and low asset prices simply reflect economy-wide risk aversion?
answer: Both channels matter: intermediaries do have a quantitatively sizable impact on risk premium variation in asset classes where households are less active (such as credit and mortgage-backed securities), and economy-wide risk aversion also independently affects asset prices through a different pattern.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the identification problem in the intermediary asset pricing literature by distinguishing between two competing explanations for the observed correlation between intermediary health and asset prices - direct intermediary effects versus correlated economy-wide risk aversion - using differential predictions about return predictability across asset classes with varying household participation.

author: Tyler Muir
title: How Credit Cycles across a Financial Crisis
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We analyze the behavior of credit and output in financial crises using data on credit spreads and credit growth. Crises are marked by a sharp rise in credit spreads, signaling sudden shifts in expectations. The severity of a crisis can be predicted by the extent of credit losses (spread increases) and financial sector fragility (precrisis credit growth). This interaction is a key feature of crises. Postcrisis recessions are typically severe and prolonged. Notably, precrisis spreads tend to drop to low levels while credit growth accelerates, indicating that credit supply expansions often precede crises. The 2008 crisis aligns with these patterns.</jats:p>
research_question: How does credit behave across financial crises, particularly in terms of credit spreads and credit growth patterns before, during, and after crises?
answer: Financial crises are characterized by sharp rises in credit spreads that signal sudden expectation shifts, with crisis severity predictable through the interaction of credit losses and pre-crisis credit growth. Pre-crisis periods typically feature low spreads and accelerating credit growth, indicating credit supply expansions often precede crises, followed by severe and prolonged post-crisis recessions.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the financial crisis literature by providing empirical analysis of credit cycle patterns using credit spreads and growth data, demonstrating that the 2008 crisis aligns with identified historical patterns of credit behavior across financial crises.

author: Tyler Muir
title: Intermediaries and Asset Prices: International Evidence since 1870
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We study data on commercial banks and securities firms across multiple countries since 1870. Balance sheet expansion of leveraged intermediaries negatively predicts returns of stocks, bonds, currencies, and housing. The predictability is stronger at shorter horizons, is robust to macroeconomic controls, and holds outside distress periods, in contrast to models featuring nonlinearities during distress. Intermediaries in global financial centers predict international equity returns. A new data set on individual stock holdings of Japanese intermediaries since 1955 shows intermediaries affect returns of stocks directly held. Our results suggest a strong universal link between intermediaries and asset returns distinct from macroeconomic channels.</jats:p>
research_question: How does the balance sheet expansion of leveraged financial intermediaries relate to asset price returns across different countries, time periods, and asset classes?
answer: Balance sheet expansion of leveraged intermediaries (commercial banks and securities firms) negatively predicts returns across stocks, bonds, currencies, and housing, with this predictability being stronger at shorter horizons, robust to macroeconomic controls, and holding even outside distress periods.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges existing models that emphasize nonlinearities during financial distress periods by showing that the intermediary-asset return relationship holds universally across time periods, including non-distress periods, and establishes this relationship as distinct from macroeconomic channels through comprehensive international evidence spanning 150+ years.

author: Tyler Muir
title: Volatility Expectations and Returns
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We provide evidence that agents have slow‐moving beliefs about stock market volatility that lead to initial underreaction to volatility shocks followed by delayed overreaction. These dynamics are mirrored in the VIX and variance risk premiums, which reflect investor expectations about volatility, and are also supported in both surveys and firm‐level option prices. We embed these expectations into an asset pricing model and find that the model can account for a number of stylized facts about market returns and return volatility that are difficult to reconcile, including a weak or even negative risk‐return trade‐off.</jats:p>
research_question: How do investor beliefs and expectations about stock market volatility affect asset returns and the risk-return relationship?
answer: Agents have slow-moving beliefs about volatility that cause initial underreaction to volatility shocks followed by delayed overreaction, and when embedded in an asset pricing model, these expectation dynamics can explain stylized facts about market returns including the weak or negative risk-return trade-off.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses stylized facts about market returns and return volatility that are difficult to reconcile in existing literature, particularly the weak or even negative risk-return trade-off, by incorporating slow-moving volatility beliefs into asset pricing models.

author: Umit Gurun
title: Benefits of Publicity
abstract: <jats:p>We investigate whether corporate board members with media expertise influence firms’ media coverage and media slant. We find that firms with a media professional on the board of directors receive more media coverage, and articles written about them include fewer negative words compared with articles on control firms. These findings highlight the importance of the composition of the board of directors as a determinant of information disclosure mechanism.</jats:p>
research_question: Do corporate board members with media expertise influence firms' media coverage and media slant?
answer: Firms with media professionals on their board of directors receive more media coverage and more favorable coverage (with fewer negative words) compared to control firms without such board members.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on information disclosure mechanisms by highlighting the previously understudied role of board composition, specifically the presence of media professionals, as a determinant of how firms are covered in the media.

author: Tyler Muir
title: When Selling Becomes Viral: Disruptions in Debt Markets in the COVID-19 Crisis and the Fed’s Response
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We document extreme disruption in debt markets during the COVID-19 crisis: a severe price crash accompanied by significant dislocations at the safer end of the credit spectrum. Investment-grade corporate bonds traded at a discount to credit default swaps; exchange-traded funds traded at a discount to net asset value, more so for safer bonds. The Federal Reserve’s announcement of corporate bond purchases caused these dislocations to disappear and prices to recover. These facts inform potential theories of the disruption. The best explanation is an acute liquidity need for specific bond investors, such as mutual funds, leading them to liquidate large positions.</jats:p>
research_question: What caused the extreme disruptions in debt markets during the COVID-19 crisis, and how did the Federal Reserve's response affect these disruptions?
answer: The disruptions were caused by acute liquidity needs of specific bond investors (such as mutual funds) leading them to liquidate large positions in a viral selling pattern. The Federal Reserve's announcement of corporate bond purchases eliminated these dislocations and restored price recovery.
positioning_statement: This paper documents and explains previously unobserved market disruptions during COVID-19, specifically focusing on dislocations at the safer end of the credit spectrum and the effectiveness of Fed intervention, contributing new empirical evidence to the literature on crisis-period market functioning and central bank responses.

author: Umit Gurun
title: Advertising Expensive Mortgages
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Using information on advertising and mortgages originated by subprime lenders, we study whether advertising helped consumers find cheaper mortgages. Lenders that advertise more within a region sell more expensive mortgages, measured as the excess rate of a mortgage after accounting for borrower, contract, and regional characteristics. These effects are stronger for mortgages sold to less sophisticated consumers. We exploit regional variation in mortgage advertising induced by the entry of Craigslist and other tests to demonstrate that these findings are not spurious. Analyzing advertising content reveals that initial/introductory rates are frequently advertised in a salient fashion, where reset rates are not.</jats:p>
research_question: Does advertising help consumers find cheaper mortgages in the subprime lending market?
answer: No, advertising does not help consumers find cheaper mortgages. Lenders that advertise more within a region actually sell more expensive mortgages (measured as excess rates after accounting for borrower, contract, and regional characteristics), with these effects being stronger for less sophisticated consumers.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on advertising in financial markets by providing empirical evidence that contradicts the assumption that advertising helps consumers find better deals, specifically focusing on the subprime mortgage market and using regional variation in advertising exposure (induced by Craigslist entry) to establish causal relationships.

author: Tyler Muir
title: Financial Intermediaries and the Cross‐Section of Asset Returns
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Financial intermediaries trade frequently in many markets using sophisticated models. Their marginal value of wealth should therefore provide a more informative stochastic discount factor (SDF) than that of a representative consumer. Guided by theory, we use shocks to the leverage of securities broker‐dealers to construct an intermediary SDF. Intuitively, deteriorating funding conditions are associated with deleveraging and high marginal value of wealth. Our <jats:italic>single</jats:italic>‐factor model prices size, book‐to‐market, momentum, and bond portfolios with an <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sup>2</jats:sup> of 77% and an average annual pricing error of 1%—performing as well as standard multifactor benchmarks designed to price these assets.</jats:p>
research_question: Can the marginal value of wealth of financial intermediaries provide a more informative stochastic discount factor for pricing assets across different markets compared to traditional representative consumer models?
answer: Yes, a single-factor model based on shocks to securities broker-dealer leverage (representing intermediary marginal value of wealth) successfully prices size, book-to-market, momentum, and bond portfolios with 77% R-squared and 1% average annual pricing error, performing as well as standard multifactor benchmarks.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as an alternative to traditional representative consumer-based asset pricing models by arguing that financial intermediaries, who trade frequently across many markets using sophisticated models, should have a more informative marginal value of wealth for constructing stochastic discount factors than a representative consumer.

author: Umit Gurun
title: Educational Networks, Mutual Fund Voting Patterns, and CEO Compensation

author: Umit Gurun
title: Don't Believe the Hype: Local Media Slant, Local Advertising, and Firm Value
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>When local media report news about local companies, they use fewer negative words compared to the same media reporting about nonlocal companies. We document that one reason for this positive slant is the firms' local media advertising expenditures. Abnormal positive local media slant strongly relates to firm equity values. The effect is stronger for small firms; firms held predominantly by individual investors; and firms with illiquid or highly volatile stock, low analyst following, or high dispersion of analyst forecasts. These findings show that news content varies systematically with the characteristics and conflicts of interest of the source.</jats:p>
research_question: How does local media coverage bias affect firm value, and what drives local media to provide more positive coverage of local companies compared to nonlocal companies?
answer: Local media exhibit positive bias when reporting on local companies (using fewer negative words), which is driven by firms' local advertising expenditures, and this positive media slant significantly increases firm equity values, with stronger effects for smaller firms and those with less analyst coverage or higher information asymmetry.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by demonstrating that news content varies systematically based on media sources' characteristics and conflicts of interest, specifically showing how local advertising creates incentives for biased coverage that materially affects firm valuations.

author: Umit Gurun
title: Resident Networks and Corporate Connections: Evidence from World War II Internment Camps
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Using customs and port authority data, we show that firms are significantly more likely to trade with countries that have a large resident population near their firm headquarters, and that these connected trades are their most valuable international trades. Using the formation of World War II Japanese internment camps to isolate exogenous shocks to local ethnic populations, we identify a causal link between local networks and firm trade. Firms are also more likely to acquire target firms, and report increased segment sales, in connected countries. Our results point to a surprisingly large role of immigrants as economic conduits for firms.</jats:p>
research_question: Do local resident networks (immigrant populations) causally affect firms' international trade patterns and business connections?
answer: Firms are significantly more likely to trade with countries that have large resident populations near their headquarters, these connected trades are their most valuable international trades, and there is a causal relationship between local ethnic networks and firm trade behavior, including acquisitions and segment sales.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on immigrant networks and international trade by using a novel identification strategy (World War II Japanese internment camps) to establish causality, moving beyond previous correlational studies to demonstrate that immigrants serve as surprisingly important economic conduits for firms.

author: Umit Gurun
title: Don't Take Their Word for It: The Misclassification of Bond Mutual Funds
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We provide evidence that bond fund managers misclassify their holdings, and that these misclassifications have a real and significant impact on investor capital flows. The problem is widespread, resulting in up to 31.4% of funds being misclassified with safer profiles, compared to their true, publicly reported holdings. “Misclassified funds”—those that hold risky bonds but claim to hold safer bonds—appear to on‐average outperform lower risk funds in their peer groups. Within category groups, misclassified funds receive more Morningstar stars and higher investor flows. However, when we correctly classify them based on actual risk, these funds are mediocre performers.</jats:p>
research_question: Do bond fund managers misclassify their holdings, and if so, what impact does this misclassification have on investor capital flows and fund performance evaluation?
answer: Bond fund managers do systematically misclassify their holdings, with up to 31.4% of funds being misclassified with safer risk profiles than their actual holdings warrant. These misclassified funds appear to outperform within their claimed peer groups and receive higher Morningstar ratings and investor flows, but when correctly classified based on actual risk, they are mediocre performers.
positioning_statement: This paper identifies and quantifies a previously unexamined problem in the bond fund industry - the systematic misclassification of fund risk profiles - and demonstrates its material impact on investor decision-making and capital allocation, filling a gap in the literature on fund classification accuracy and its market consequences.

author: Umit Gurun
title: Trust Busting: The Effect of Fraud on Investor Behavior
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We study the importance of trust in the investment advisory industry by exploiting the geographic dispersion of victims of the Madoff Ponzi scheme. Residents of communities that were exposed to the fraud subsequently withdrew assets from investment advisers and increased deposits at banks. Additionally, exposed advisers were more likely to close. Advisers who provided services that can build trust, such as financial planning advice, experienced fewer withdrawals. Our evidence suggests that the trust shock was transmitted through social networks. Taken together, our results show that trust plays a critical role in the financial intermediation industry.</jats:p><jats:p>Received April 18, 2016; editorial decision March 8, 2017 by Editor Robin Greenwood.</jats:p>
research_question: How does fraud exposure affect investor trust and behavior in the investment advisory industry?
answer: Fraud exposure significantly reduces trust in investment advisers, leading investors to withdraw assets from advisers and shift deposits to banks, while advisers providing trust-building services like financial planning experience fewer withdrawals and the trust shock spreads through social networks.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on trust in financial intermediation by using the geographic dispersion of Madoff Ponzi scheme victims as a natural experiment to demonstrate the critical role of trust in the financial intermediation industry.

author: Umit Gurun

author: Umit Gurun
title: Do Wall Street Landlords Undermine Renters’ Welfare?
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We examine the recent rise of institutional investment in the single-family home rental market and its implications for renters’ welfare. Using institutional mergers to identify local exogenous variation in institutional landlords’ scale and market share, we show that rents increase in neighborhoods where both merging firms owned properties (i.e., overlapped neighborhoods) relative to other nonoverlapped neighborhoods. Meanwhile, the crime rate also significantly decreases in overlapped neighborhoods after mergers. Our findings suggest that while institutional landlords leverage their market power to extract greater surplus from renters, they also improve the quality of rental services by enhancing neighborhood safety.</jats:p>
               <jats:p>Authors have furnished an Internet Appendix, which is available on the Oxford University Press Web site next to the link to the final published paper online.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the implications of institutional investment in the single-family home rental market for renters' welfare?
answer: Institutional landlords have mixed effects on renters' welfare - they increase rents by leveraging market power to extract greater surplus from renters, but they also improve rental service quality by enhancing neighborhood safety (reducing crime rates).
positioning_statement: This paper examines the recent rise of institutional investment in single-family home rentals, using institutional mergers to identify exogenous variation in landlords' scale and market share, contributing to understanding of how Wall Street participation affects housing markets and renter outcomes.

author: Urban Jermann
title: Gold’s Value as an Investment
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>This paper presents an approach for pricing gold from investors’ perspective. The model is based on no-arbitrage principles with minimal structural assumptions. There is no need to specify investor preferences. When fitted to match 10-year real U.S. Treasury rates, the model can replicate the salient fluctuations in the time series of gold prices since 2007. The model is also able to capture key patterns of CME Comex gold futures prices. The model implies that the majority of the value of gold is due to its role as an investment asset.</jats:p>
research_question: How can gold be priced from an investor's perspective, and what drives its value as an investment asset?
answer: The majority of gold's value is due to its role as an investment asset, as demonstrated by a no-arbitrage pricing model that successfully replicates gold price fluctuations since 2007 and captures key patterns in gold futures prices when fitted to 10-year real U.S. Treasury rates.
positioning_statement: This paper presents a novel approach for pricing gold based on no-arbitrage principles with minimal structural assumptions that does not require specifying investor preferences, offering a more streamlined method compared to existing literature.

author: Urban Jermann
title: The Two‐Pillar Policy for the RMB
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>This paper studies China's recent exchange rate policy for the renminbi (RMB). We demonstrate empirically that a two‐pillar policy is in place, aiming to balance exchange rate flexibility and RMB index stability via <jats:italic>market</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>basket</jats:italic> pillars. We further extend and validate the formulation that incorporates the so‐called countercyclical factor. Theoretically, we develop a flexible‐price monetary model for the RMB in which the two‐pillar policy arises endogenously as an optimal response of the government. We estimate the model by generalized method of moments and quantitatively assess various policy trade‐offs.</jats:p>
research_question: How does China's recent exchange rate policy for the renminbi (RMB) work and what is the optimal policy framework?
answer: China operates a two-pillar policy that balances exchange rate flexibility and RMB index stability through market and basket pillars, with the countercyclical factor playing a key role, and this policy emerges endogenously as an optimal government response in a flexible-price monetary model.
positioning_statement: This paper extends existing literature by providing both empirical validation of China's two-pillar RMB policy framework and theoretical justification through a flexible-price monetary model, incorporating the previously understudied countercyclical factor component.

author: Urban Jermann
title: Negative Swap Spreads and Limited Arbitrage
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Since October 2008, fixed rates for interest rate swaps with a 30-year maturity have been mostly below Treasury rates with the same maturity. Under standard assumptions, this implies the existence of arbitrage opportunities. This paper presents a model for pricing interest rate swaps, where frictions for holding bonds limit arbitrage. I analytically show that negative swap spreads should not be surprising. In the calibrated model, swap spreads can reasonably match empirical counterparts without the need for large demand imbalances in the swap market. Empirical evidence is consistent with the relation between term spreads and swap spreads in the model.</jats:p>
               <jats:p>Received April 16, 2017; editorial decision Januray 3, 2019 by Editor Stijn Van Nieuwerburgh.</jats:p>
research_question: Why have 30-year interest rate swap spreads been negative since October 2008, and how can this phenomenon be explained given that it appears to create arbitrage opportunities under standard assumptions?
answer: Negative swap spreads can be explained by frictions in holding bonds that limit arbitrage opportunities. The paper shows analytically that negative swap spreads should not be surprising when these frictions are considered, and demonstrates that swap spreads can match empirical observations without requiring large demand imbalances in the swap market.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the standard assumptions in swap pricing by introducing a model that incorporates frictions for holding bonds to limit arbitrage, providing an alternative explanation for negative swap spreads that does not rely on the conventional assumption of large demand imbalances in the swap market.

author: Vicente Cuñat
title: The Vote Is Cast: The Effect of Corporate Governance on Shareholder Value
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>This paper investigates whether improvements in the firm's internal corporate governance create value for shareholders. We analyze the market reaction to governance proposals that pass or fail by a small margin of votes in annual meetings. This provides a clean causal estimate that deals with the endogeneity of internal governance rules. We find that passing a proposal leads to significant positive abnormal returns. Adopting one governance proposal increases shareholder value by 2.8%. The market reaction is larger in firms with more antitakeover provisions, higher institutional ownership, and stronger investor activism for proposals sponsored by institutions. In addition, we find that acquisitions and capital expenditures decline and long‐term performance improves.</jats:p>
research_question: Do improvements in the firm's internal corporate governance create value for shareholders?
answer: Yes, passing governance proposals leads to significant positive abnormal returns, with adopting one governance proposal increasing shareholder value by 2.8%. The effect is stronger in firms with more antitakeover provisions, higher institutional ownership, and stronger investor activism for institution-sponsored proposals.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the endogeneity problem in corporate governance research by using a regression discontinuity design that analyzes market reactions to governance proposals that pass or fail by small margins, providing a clean causal estimate that previous literature could not establish due to endogeneity concerns.

author: Vicente Cuñat
title: Price and Probability: Decomposing the Takeover Effects of Anti‐Takeover Provisions
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We study the effects of anti‐takeover provisions (ATPs) on the takeover probability, the takeover premium, and target selection. Voting to remove an ATP increases both the takeover probability and the takeover premium, that is, there is no evidence of a trade‐off between premiums and takeover probabilities. We provide causal estimates based on shareholder proposals to remove ATPs and address the endogenous selection of targets through bounding techniques. The positive premium effect in less protected firms is driven by better bidder‐target matching and merger synergies.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the effects of anti-takeover provisions (ATPs) on takeover probability, takeover premium, and target selection?
answer: Voting to remove an ATP increases both the takeover probability and the takeover premium, with no evidence of a trade-off between premiums and takeover probabilities. The positive premium effect in less protected firms is driven by better bidder-target matching and merger synergies.
positioning_statement: The paper provides causal estimates based on shareholder proposals to remove ATPs and addresses the endogenous selection of targets through bounding techniques, contributing to the literature by decomposing the multiple effects of anti-takeover provisions on different aspects of the takeover process.

author: Victoria Ivashina

author: Victoria Ivashina
title: Disruption and Credit Markets
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We show that over the past half‐century, innovative disruptions were central to understanding corporate defaults. In a given year, industries experiencing abnormally high venture capital or initial public offering activity subsequently see higher default rates, higher segment exits by conglomerates, and higher yields on bonds issued by the firms in these industries. Overall, we find that disruption is a broad phenomenon, negatively affecting incumbent firms across the spectrum of age, valuation, and levers, with the exception of very large and low‐leverage firms, in line with our central hypothesis.</jats:p>
research_question: How do innovative disruptions affect corporate defaults and credit markets over time?
answer: Over the past half-century, innovative disruptions (measured by abnormally high venture capital or IPO activity) have been central to understanding corporate defaults, leading to higher default rates, more segment exits by conglomerates, and higher bond yields in affected industries, with negative effects on most incumbent firms except very large and low-leverage ones.
positioning_statement: This paper establishes disruption as a broad phenomenon affecting credit markets, providing empirical evidence that innovative disruptions systematically impact corporate defaults across different types of firms, filling a gap in understanding the relationship between innovation and credit risk.

author: Victoria Ivashina
title: The Private Equity Advantage: Leveraged Buyout Firms and Relationship Banking

author: Victoria Ivashina
title: Monetary Policy and Global Banking
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>When central banks adjust interest rates, the opportunity cost of lending in local currency changes, but—absent frictions—there is no spillover effect to lending in other currencies. However, when equity capital is limited, global banks must benchmark domestic and foreign lending opportunities. We show that, in equilibrium, the marginal return on foreign lending is affected by the interest rate differential, with lower domestic rates leading to an increase in local lending, at the expense of a reduction in foreign lending. We test our prediction in the context of changes in interest rates in six major currency areas.</jats:p>
research_question: How do domestic monetary policy changes (interest rate adjustments) by central banks affect global banks' lending decisions across different currencies and countries?
answer: When domestic interest rates are lowered, global banks with limited equity capital increase their local lending at the expense of reducing their foreign lending, as they must benchmark domestic and foreign lending opportunities against each other due to capital constraints.
positioning_statement: This paper extends existing monetary policy literature by showing that capital constraints create spillover effects from domestic interest rate changes to foreign currency lending, whereas previous theory suggested no such spillovers should exist absent frictions.

author: Victoria Ivashina
title: Reaching for Yield in the Bond Market
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>This paper studies reaching for yield—investors’ propensity to buy riskier assets to achieve higher yields—in the corporate bond market. We show that insurance companies reach for yield in choosing their investments. Consistent with lower rated bonds bearing higher capital requirements, insurance firms prefer to hold higher rated bonds. However, conditional on credit ratings, insurance portfolios are systematically biased toward higher yield, higher CDS bonds. This behavior is related to the business cycle being most pronounced during economic expansions. It is also characteristic of firms with poor corporate governance and for which the regulatory capital requirement is more binding.</jats:p>
research_question: Do insurance companies engage in reaching for yield behavior in the corporate bond market, and what factors drive this propensity to buy riskier assets to achieve higher yields?
answer: Insurance companies do reach for yield in the corporate bond market - while they prefer higher rated bonds due to capital requirements, they systematically bias their portfolios toward higher yield, higher CDS bonds within the same credit rating categories. This behavior is most pronounced during economic expansions and among firms with poor corporate governance and binding regulatory capital requirements.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the reaching for yield literature by providing empirical evidence of this behavior specifically in the corporate bond market among insurance companies, demonstrating how regulatory capital requirements interact with yield-seeking behavior and identifying the cyclical and firm-specific characteristics that drive this investment pattern.

author: Victoria Ivashina
title: High-Yield Debt Covenants and Their Real Effects
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>High-yield debt, including leveraged loans, typically features incurrence or ′′cov-lite'' financial covenants. Unlike traditional maintenance covenants, incurrence covenants preserve equity control rights but impose specific contractual restrictions on the borrower once certain financial thresholds are crossed. Contrary to the prevailing view that incurrence covenants have limited practical impact, we document a substantial decline in investment when these covenants are triggered. During economic downturns, these provisions can become binding well before default or bankruptcy. Our findings reveal a novel channel through which economic shocks propagate, driven by incurrence-based contractual restrictions that are widespread in the highly leveraged corporate sector.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the real effects of high-yield debt covenants, specifically incurrence or 'cov-lite' financial covenants, on corporate behavior and investment decisions?
answer: Incurrence covenants have substantial real effects, causing significant declines in investment when triggered, and can become binding during economic downturns well before default or bankruptcy, creating a novel channel for economic shock propagation.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the prevailing view that incurrence covenants have limited practical impact, documenting instead that these widespread contractual restrictions in the highly leveraged corporate sector create previously unrecognized mechanisms for economic shock transmission.

author: Victoria Vanasco
title: The Downside of Asset Screening for Market Liquidity
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>This paper explores the tension between asset quality and market liquidity. I model an originator who screens assets whose cash flows are later sold in secondary markets. Screening improves asset quality but gives rise to asymmetric information, hindering trade of the asset cash flows. In the optimal mechanism (second‐best), costly retention of cash flows is essential to implement asset screening. Market allocations can feature too much or too little screening relative to second‐best, where too much screening generates inefficiently illiquid markets. Furthermore, the economy is prone to multiple equilibria. The optimal mechanism is decentralized with two tools: retention rules and transfers.</jats:p>
research_question: How does asset screening by originators affect the trade-off between asset quality and market liquidity in secondary markets?
answer: Asset screening creates a fundamental tension where improving asset quality through screening generates asymmetric information that hinders secondary market trading, leading to reduced market liquidity. The optimal solution requires costly retention of cash flows, and market allocations can feature either excessive or insufficient screening relative to the social optimum, with excessive screening creating inefficiently illiquid markets.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by identifying and modeling the previously underexplored trade-off between asset quality improvement through screening and the resulting market liquidity problems caused by asymmetric information, showing that market outcomes can deviate from social optimality in either direction.

author: Victoria Vanasco
title: Investor experiences and financial market dynamics

author: Victoria Vanasco
title: Securitization, Ratings, and Credit Supply
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We develop a framework to explore the effect of credit ratings on loan origination. We show that ratings endogenously shift the economy from a<jats:italic>signaling</jats:italic>equilibrium, in which banks inefficiently retain loans to signal quality, toward an<jats:italic>originate‐to‐distribute</jats:italic>equilibrium with zero retention and inefficiently low lending standards. Ratings increase overall efficiency, provided that the reduction in costly retention more than compensates for the origination of some negative net present value loans. We study how banks' ability to screen loans affects these predictions and use the model to analyze commonly proposed policies such as mandatory “skin in the game.”</jats:p>
research_question: How do credit ratings affect loan origination behavior and the efficiency of credit markets?
answer: Credit ratings endogenously shift the economy from a signaling equilibrium (where banks inefficiently retain loans to signal quality) toward an originate-to-distribute equilibrium (with zero retention and inefficiently low lending standards). Ratings increase overall efficiency when the reduction in costly retention more than compensates for the origination of some negative net present value loans.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a new theoretical framework to analyze the relationship between securitization, credit ratings, and lending behavior, contributing to the literature by showing how ratings can simultaneously improve efficiency through reduced retention costs while creating inefficiencies through lowered lending standards, and by providing a model to evaluate policy interventions like mandatory 'skin in the game' requirements.

author: Victoria Vanasco
title: Designing Securities for Scrutiny
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We investigate the effect of scrutiny (e.g., credit ratings, analyst reports, or mandatory disclosures) on the security design problem of a privately informed issuer. We show that scrutiny has important implications for both the form of security designed and the amount of inefficient retention of cash flows. The model predicts that issuers will design informationally sensitive securities (i.e., levered equity) when scrutiny is sufficiently intense. Otherwise, issuers opt for a standard debt contract. Scrutiny increases efficiency by decreasing issuers’ reliance on retention to signal quality and, perhaps counterintuitively, decrease price informativeness.</jats:p>
research_question: How does scrutiny (such as credit ratings, analyst reports, or mandatory disclosures) affect the security design decisions of privately informed issuers?
answer: Scrutiny significantly influences both the type of security designed and the level of inefficient cash flow retention. When scrutiny is sufficiently intense, issuers design informationally sensitive securities (levered equity), otherwise they choose standard debt contracts. Scrutiny improves efficiency by reducing issuers' need to retain cash flows as a quality signal, while counterintuitively decreasing price informativeness.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the security design literature by introducing the role of external scrutiny as a key determinant of optimal security structure, extending beyond traditional models that focus primarily on asymmetric information between issuers and investors without considering the moderating effect of external monitoring and information production.

author: Victoria Vanasco
title: Does Momentum Trading Generate Extra Downside Risk?
abstract: <jats:p> Momentum strategies tend to provide low returns during market crashes, and they crash themselves when the market rebounds after significant crashes. This is reflected by positive downside market betas and negative upside market betas of zero-cost momentum portfolios. Such asymmetry in upside and downside risks is unfavorable for investors and requires a risk premium. It arises mechanically because of momentum portfolio rebalancing based on trailing asset performance. The asymmetry in upside and downside risks is a robust unifying feature of momentum portfolios in various geographical and asset markets. The momentum premium can be rationalized within a standard asset-pricing framework, where upside and downside risks are priced differently. </jats:p>
research_question: Does momentum trading generate extra downside risk, and how does this asymmetric risk profile affect the momentum premium?
answer: Yes, momentum strategies generate extra downside risk through asymmetric exposure to market movements - they have positive downside market betas (perform poorly during crashes) and negative upside market betas (underperform during rebounds). This unfavorable asymmetry requires a risk premium and can explain the momentum premium within standard asset-pricing frameworks that price upside and downside risks differently.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a unifying explanation for the momentum premium by identifying asymmetric upside and downside risk exposure as a robust feature across various geographical and asset markets, positioning this risk asymmetry as the key factor that rationalizes momentum returns within existing asset-pricing theory rather than requiring behavioral or alternative explanations.

author: Vincent Glode
title: Technological Progress and Rent Seeking
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We model firms’ allocation of resources across surplus-creating (ie, productive) and surplus-appropriating (ie, rent-seeking) activities. Our model predicts that industry-wide technological advancements, such as recent progress in data collection and processing, induce a disproportionate and socially inefficient reallocation of resources toward surplus-appropriating activities. As technology improves, firms rely more on appropriation to obtain their profits, thereby endogenously reducing the impact of technological progress on economic progress and inflating the price of the resources used for both types of activities. Our theoretical insights shed light on the rise of high-frequency trading.</jats:p>
research_question: How do industry-wide technological advancements affect firms' allocation of resources between surplus-creating (productive) activities and surplus-appropriating (rent-seeking) activities?
answer: Technological advancements induce a disproportionate and socially inefficient reallocation of resources toward surplus-appropriating activities, causing firms to rely more on appropriation rather than production to obtain profits, which endogenously reduces the impact of technological progress on economic progress.
positioning_statement: This paper provides theoretical insights that help explain contemporary phenomena such as the rise of high-frequency trading, offering a framework to understand how recent progress in data collection and processing technologies affects firm behavior and resource allocation.

author: Vincent Glode
title: Compensating Financial Experts
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We propose a labor market model in which financial firms compete for a scarce supply of workers who can be employed as either bankers or traders. While hiring bankers helps create a surplus that can be split between a firm and its trading counterparties, hiring traders helps the firm appropriate a greater share of that surplus away from its counterparties. Firms bid defensively for workers bound to become traders, who then earn more than bankers. As counterparties employ more traders, the benefit of employing bankers decreases. The model sheds light on the historical evolution of compensation in finance.</jats:p>
research_question: How are compensation levels determined for different types of financial workers (bankers vs. traders) when financial firms compete for scarce talent that can be employed in either role?
answer: Traders earn more than bankers because firms bid defensively for workers who will become traders (to prevent competitors from gaining advantage in surplus appropriation), while the value of hiring bankers decreases as more counterparties employ traders who help appropriate surplus away from trading partners.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to understanding compensation in finance by proposing a novel labor market model that explains wage differentials between financial roles through the lens of competitive dynamics and surplus appropriation, offering insights into the historical evolution of financial sector compensation.

author: Vincent Glode
title: Over-the-Counter versus Limit-Order Markets: The Role of Traders’ Expertise
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Over-the-counter (OTC) markets attract substantial trading volume despite exhibiting frictions absent in centralized limit-order markets. We compare the efficiency of OTC and limit-order markets when traders’ expertise is endogenous. We show that asymmetric access to counterparties in OTC markets yields increased rents from expertise acquisition for a few well-connected core traders. When the existence of gains to trade is uncertain, traders’ higher expertise in OTC markets can improve allocative efficiency. In contrast, when expertise primarily causes adverse selection, competitive limit-order markets tend to dominate. Our model provides guidance for policy makers and empiricists evaluating the efficiency of market structures.</jats:p>
research_question: How does the endogenous nature of traders' expertise affect the relative efficiency of over-the-counter (OTC) markets versus centralized limit-order markets?
answer: OTC markets can be more efficient than limit-order markets when gains to trade are uncertain because asymmetric access to counterparties incentivizes expertise acquisition among well-connected core traders, improving allocative efficiency. However, when expertise primarily causes adverse selection, competitive limit-order markets tend to dominate.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on market structure comparison by introducing endogenous trader expertise as a key factor, providing new theoretical insights that can guide policy makers and empiricists in evaluating market efficiency, addressing the puzzle of why OTC markets attract substantial volume despite apparent frictions.

author: Vincent Glode
title: Private Renegotiations and Government Interventions in Credit Chains
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We propose a model of strategic renegotiation in which businesses are sequentially interconnected through their liabilities. This financing structure, which we refer to as a credit chain, gives rise to externalities, as each lender’s willingness to provide concessions to its borrower depends on how this lender’s own liabilities are expected to be renegotiated. We highlight how government interventions aimed at preventing default waves should account for private renegotiation incentives and interlinkages. In particular, we contrast the consequences of targeted subsidy and debt reduction programs following economic shocks, such as pandemics and financial crises.</jats:p>
research_question: How do private renegotiation incentives and strategic interactions in credit chains affect the design and effectiveness of government interventions aimed at preventing default waves?
answer: Government interventions should account for private renegotiation incentives and interlinkages in credit chains, as each lender's willingness to provide concessions depends on expectations of how their own liabilities will be renegotiated, and targeted subsidy and debt reduction programs have different consequences in this context.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by proposing a novel model of strategic renegotiation in sequentially interconnected credit chains, highlighting externalities that arise from these financing structures and providing new insights on how government interventions should be designed to account for private renegotiation incentives following economic shocks.
