author: Vladimir Asriyan
title: Does Reputation Limit Opportunistic Behavior in the VC Industry? Evidence from Litigation against VCs
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We examine the role of reputation in limiting opportunistic behavior by venture capitalists towards four types of counterparties: entrepreneurs, investors, other VCs, and buyers of VC‐backed startups. Using a hand‐collected database of lawsuits, we document that more reputable VCs (i.e., VCs that are older, have more deals and funds under management, and syndicate with larger networks of VCs) are less likely to be litigated. We also find that litigated VCs suffer declines in future business relative to matched peers. These declines are larger for more reputable VCs, and for VCs that are defendants to multiple lawsuits or sued by entrepreneurs.</jats:p>
research_question: Does reputation limit opportunistic behavior in the venture capital industry?
answer: Yes, reputation does limit opportunistic behavior by VCs. More reputable VCs (older, with more deals and funds under management, and larger syndication networks) are less likely to be sued, and when VCs are litigated, they suffer declines in future business, with larger declines for more reputable VCs.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on reputation mechanisms in venture capital by providing empirical evidence through litigation data, examining VC behavior toward multiple counterparty types (entrepreneurs, investors, other VCs, and buyers), rather than focusing on a single relationship.

author: Vincent Glode
title: Financial Expertise as an Arms Race
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We show that firms intermediating trade have incentives to overinvest in financial expertise. In our model, expertise improves firms’ ability to estimate value when trading a security. Expertise creates asymmetric information, which, under normal circumstances, works to the advantage of the expert as it deters opportunistic bargaining by counterparties. This advantage is neutralized in equilibrium, however, by offsetting investments by competitors. Moreover, when volatility rises the adverse selection created by expertise triggers breakdowns in liquidity, destroying gains to trade and thus the benefits that firms hope to gain through high levels of expertise.</jats:p>
research_question: Do firms intermediating trade have appropriate incentives regarding investment in financial expertise, and how does this expertise affect market outcomes?
answer: Firms have incentives to overinvest in financial expertise because while expertise creates advantageous asymmetric information that deters opportunistic bargaining, this advantage is neutralized by competitors' offsetting investments, and high volatility can cause expertise-induced adverse selection to trigger liquidity breakdowns that destroy trading gains.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on financial intermediation and market microstructure by modeling expertise investment as a competitive arms race, showing how individually rational expertise investments can lead to collectively suboptimal outcomes, particularly during periods of high volatility when adverse selection effects dominate.

author: Wenxin Du
title: Sovereign Risk, Currency Risk, and Corporate Balance Sheets
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We provide a comprehensive account of the evolution of the currency composition of sovereign and corporate external borrowing by emerging markets from 2003 to 2017. We show that a higher reliance on foreign currency debt by the corporate sector is associated with higher sovereign default risk. We introduce local currency sovereign debt and private sector currency mismatch into a standard sovereign debt model to examine how the currency composition of corporate borrowing affects the sovereign’s incentive to inflate or default. A calibration of the model generates the empirical patterns of sovereign credit risk.</jats:p>
research_question: How does the currency composition of corporate borrowing affect sovereign default risk and the sovereign's incentive to inflate or default?
answer: Higher reliance on foreign currency debt by the corporate sector is associated with higher sovereign default risk, and the currency composition of corporate borrowing significantly affects the sovereign's incentives regarding inflation and default decisions.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the standard sovereign debt model literature by introducing local currency sovereign debt and private sector currency mismatch, providing a more comprehensive framework that accounts for the interaction between corporate balance sheet composition and sovereign risk.

author: Wenxin Du
title: Local Currency Sovereign Risk
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We introduce a new measure of emerging market sovereign credit risk: the local currency credit spread, defined as the spread of local currency bonds over the synthetic local currency risk‐free rate constructed using cross‐currency swaps. We find that local currency credit spreads are positive and sizable. Compared with credit spreads on foreign‐currency‐denominated debt, local currency credit spreads have lower means, lower cross‐country correlations, and lower sensitivity to global risk factors. We discuss several major sources of credit spread differentials, including positively correlated credit and currency risk, selective default, capital controls, and various financial market frictions.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the nature and magnitude of sovereign credit risk in local currency bonds of emerging markets, and how does it differ from foreign currency sovereign credit risk?
answer: Local currency credit spreads are positive and sizable, but have lower means, lower cross-country correlations, and lower sensitivity to global risk factors compared to foreign currency credit spreads.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces a new measure of emerging market sovereign credit risk by focusing on local currency bonds and constructing synthetic local currency risk-free rates using cross-currency swaps, filling a gap in the literature that has primarily focused on foreign-currency-denominated sovereign debt.

author: Wenxin Du
title: Deviations from Covered Interest Rate Parity
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We find that deviations from the covered interest rate parity (CIP) condition imply large, persistent, and systematic arbitrage opportunities in one of the largest asset markets in the world. Contrary to the common view, these deviations for major currencies are not explained away by credit risk or transaction costs. They are particularly strong for forward contracts that appear on banks' balance sheets at the end of the quarter, pointing to a causal effect of banking regulation on asset prices. The CIP deviations also appear significantly correlated with other fixed income spreads and with nominal interest rates.</jats:p>
research_question: Do deviations from covered interest rate parity (CIP) exist in major currency markets, and if so, what explains these deviations?
answer: Large, persistent, and systematic deviations from CIP exist in major currency markets that create arbitrage opportunities. These deviations are not explained by credit risk or transaction costs, but are particularly strong for forward contracts appearing on banks' balance sheets at quarter-end, suggesting banking regulation has a causal effect on asset prices.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the common view in existing literature by demonstrating that CIP deviations for major currencies cannot be explained away by traditional factors like credit risk or transaction costs, instead proposing banking regulation as a key explanatory factor.

author: Wenxin Du
title: Intermediary balance sheets and the treasury yield curve

author: Wenxin Du
title: Arbitrage Capital of Global Banks
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We study the impact of the U.S. money market fund reform implemented in October 2016 on global banks' funding supply and business activities. We show that the reform induced a large negative wholesale funding shock for global banks. In contrast to the conventional bank lending channel, the primary response of global banks to the reform was a cutback in arbitrage positions that relied on unsecured funding, rather than a reduction in loan provision. We discuss the role of postcrisis liquidity regulations and unconventional monetary policy in explaining our findings, and implications for banks' business models and deposit competition.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the impact of the U.S. money market fund reform implemented in October 2016 on global banks' funding supply and business activities?
answer: The reform induced a large negative wholesale funding shock for global banks, and their primary response was to cut back on arbitrage positions that relied on unsecured funding, rather than reducing loan provision, which contrasts with the conventional bank lending channel.
positioning_statement: This paper contrasts its findings with the conventional bank lending channel literature by showing that global banks primarily adjusted arbitrage activities rather than loan provision in response to funding shocks, and discusses how postcrisis liquidity regulations and unconventional monetary policy help explain these different responses compared to traditional banking models.

author: Wenxin Du
title: Sovereign Debt Portfolios, Bond Risks, and the Credibility of Monetary Policy
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We document that governments whose local currency debt provides them with greater hedging benefits actually borrow more in foreign currency. We introduce two features into a government's debt portfolio choice problem to explain this finding: risk‐averse lenders and lack of monetary policy commitment. A government without commitment chooses excessively countercyclical inflation ex post, which leads risk‐averse lenders to require a risk premium ex ante. This makes local currency debt too expensive from the government's perspective and thereby discourages the government from borrowing in its own currency.</jats:p>
research_question: Why do governments whose local currency debt would provide them with greater hedging benefits actually borrow more in foreign currency?
answer: Governments without monetary policy commitment choose excessively countercyclical inflation ex post, which leads risk-averse lenders to require a risk premium ex ante, making local currency debt too expensive and discouraging borrowing in their own currency.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces two novel features - risk-averse lenders and lack of monetary policy commitment - into the government's debt portfolio choice problem to explain the counterintuitive empirical finding that contradicts conventional wisdom about optimal hedging behavior.

author: Yiming Ma
title: Steering a Ship in Illiquid Waters: Active Management of Passive Funds
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Exchange-traded funds (ETFs) are typically viewed as passive index trackers. In contrast, we show that corporate bond ETFs actively manage their portfolios, trading off index tracking against liquidity transformation. In our model, ETFs optimally choose creation and redemption baskets that include cash and only a subset of index assets, especially if those assets are illiquid. Our evidence supports the model. We find that ETFs dynamically adjust their baskets to correct portfolio imbalances while facilitating ETF arbitrage. Basket inclusion improves bond liquidity in general, but worsens it in periods of large imbalance between creations and redemptions, such as the COVID-19 crisis.</jats:p>
research_question: How do corporate bond ETFs manage their portfolios and creation/redemption baskets when facing the trade-off between index tracking and liquidity transformation?
answer: Corporate bond ETFs actively manage their portfolios by optimally choosing creation and redemption baskets that include cash and only a subset of index assets (especially illiquid ones), dynamically adjusting these baskets to correct portfolio imbalances while facilitating ETF arbitrage.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the conventional view of ETFs as purely passive index trackers by demonstrating that corporate bond ETFs engage in active portfolio management, filling a gap in understanding how ETFs navigate the tension between passive tracking and liquidity provision in illiquid markets.

author: Wenxin Du
title: Are Intermediary Constraints Priced?
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Violations of no-arbitrage conditions measure the shadow cost of intermediary constraints. Intermediary asset pricing and intertemporal hedging together imply that the risk of these constraints tightening is priced. We describe a “forward CIP trading strategy” that bets on CIP violations shrinking and show that its returns help identify the price of this risk. This strategy yields the highest returns for currency pairs associated with the carry trade. The strategy’s risk substantially contributes to the volatility of the stochastic discount factor, is correlated with both other near-arbitrages and intermediary wealth measures, and appears to be consistently priced across various asset classes.</jats:p><jats:p>Authors have furnished an Internet Appendix, which is available on the Oxford University Press Web site next to the link to the final published paper online.</jats:p>
research_question: Are intermediary constraints priced in financial markets, and if so, how can we identify and measure the price of the risk associated with these constraints tightening?
answer: Yes, intermediary constraints are priced. The risk of these constraints tightening can be identified through a 'forward CIP trading strategy' that bets on CIP violations shrinking. This strategy yields the highest returns for currency pairs associated with the carry trade, and its risk substantially contributes to the volatility of the stochastic discount factor and appears to be consistently priced across various asset classes.
positioning_statement: This paper builds on intermediary asset pricing theory and intertemporal hedging models to provide empirical evidence that violations of no-arbitrage conditions (which measure the shadow cost of intermediary constraints) represent priced risk factors, extending the literature by demonstrating how this risk can be identified and measured across different asset classes.

author: Yufeng Wu
title: Collateral, Taxes, and Leverage
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We quantify the importance of collateral versus taxes for firms' capital structures. We estimate a dynamic model in which a taxable firm seeks financing for investment, and a dynamic contracting environment motivates endogenous collateral constraints. Optimal leverage stays a safe distance from the constraint, balancing the tax benefit of debt with the cost of lost financial flexibility. We estimate this flexibility cost to be 7.2% of firm assets, a percentage that is comparable to the tax benefit. Models with different tax rates fit the data equally well, and leverage responds to the tax rate only when taxes are low.</jats:p>
               <jats:p>Received January 20, 2015; accepted January 8, 2016 by Editor Itay Goldstein.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the relative importance of collateral constraints versus tax benefits in determining firms' capital structure decisions?
answer: The cost of lost financial flexibility from collateral constraints (7.2% of firm assets) is comparable in magnitude to tax benefits, and leverage responds to tax rates only when taxes are low, suggesting collateral constraints are as important as taxes in capital structure decisions.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the capital structure literature by developing a dynamic model that simultaneously incorporates both collateral constraints from dynamic contracting and tax considerations, quantifying their relative importance in a unified framework rather than examining these factors in isolation.

author: Yiming Ma
title: Mutual Fund Liquidity Transformation and Reverse Flight to Liquidity
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We identify fixed-income mutual funds as an important contributor to the unusually high selling pressure in liquid asset markets during the COVID-19 crisis. We show that mutual funds experienced pronounced investor outflows amplified by their liquidity transformation. In meeting redemptions, funds followed a pecking order by first selling their liquid assets, including Treasuries and high-quality corporate bonds, which generated the most concentrated selling pressure in these markets. Overall, the estimated price impact of mutual funds was sizable at a third of the increase in Treasury yields and a quarter of the increase in corporate bond yields during the COVID-19 crisis.</jats:p>
research_question: What role did fixed-income mutual funds play in creating selling pressure in liquid asset markets during the COVID-19 crisis?
answer: Fixed-income mutual funds were an important contributor to unusually high selling pressure in liquid asset markets during COVID-19, with their price impact accounting for approximately one-third of the increase in Treasury yields and one-quarter of the increase in corporate bond yields during the crisis.
positioning_statement: This paper identifies a previously underexplored mechanism where mutual funds' liquidity transformation and pecking order selling behavior (selling liquid assets first to meet redemptions) contributed significantly to the 'reverse flight to liquidity' phenomenon during the COVID-19 crisis, contrasting with traditional flight-to-quality narratives.

author: Yufeng Wu
title: Bank Market Power and Monetary Policy Transmission: Evidence from a Structural Estimation
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We quantify the impact of bank market power on monetary policy transmission through banks to borrowers. We estimate a dynamic banking model in which monetary policy affects imperfectly competitive banks' funding costs. Banks optimize the pass‐through of these costs to borrowers and depositors, while facing capital and reserve regulation. We find that bank market power explains much of the transmission of monetary policy to borrowers, with an effect comparable to that of bank capital regulation. When the federal funds rate falls below 0.9%, market power interacts with bank capital regulation to produce a reversal of the effect of monetary policy.</jats:p>
research_question: How does bank market power affect the transmission of monetary policy through banks to borrowers?
answer: Bank market power explains much of the transmission of monetary policy to borrowers, with an effect comparable to that of bank capital regulation. When the federal funds rate falls below 0.9%, market power interacts with bank capital regulation to produce a reversal of the effect of monetary policy.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing a structural estimation approach to quantify the specific impact of bank market power on monetary policy transmission, positioning market power as a factor of comparable importance to bank capital regulation in explaining how monetary policy affects borrowers through the banking system.

author: Zacharias Sautner
title: Carbon Tail Risk
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Strong regulatory actions are needed to combat climate change, but climate policy uncertainty makes it difficult for investors to quantify the impact of future climate regulation. We show that such uncertainty is priced in the option market. The cost of option protection against downside tail risks is larger for firms with more carbon-intense business models. For carbon-intense firms, the cost of protection against downside tail risk is magnified at times when the public’s attention to climate change spikes, and it decreased after the election of climate change skeptic President Trump.</jats:p>
research_question: How does climate policy uncertainty affect the pricing of downside tail risk protection in option markets for firms with different levels of carbon intensity?
answer: Climate policy uncertainty is priced in option markets, with carbon-intensive firms facing higher costs for downside tail risk protection, especially during periods of heightened climate attention, while these costs decreased after Trump's election.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by demonstrating that climate policy uncertainty creates a measurable risk premium in derivatives markets, specifically showing how carbon intensity affects option pricing for tail risk protection in ways that vary with political and public attention cycles.

author: Zacharias Sautner
title: The Importance of Climate Risks for Institutional Investors
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>According to our survey about climate risk perceptions, institutional investors believe climate risks have financial implications for their portfolio firms and that these risks, particularly regulatory risks, already have begun to materialize. Many of the investors, especially the long-term, larger, and ESG-oriented ones, consider risk management and engagement, rather than divestment, to be the better approach for addressing climate risks. Although surveyed investors believe that some equity valuations do not fully reflect climate risks, their perceived overvaluations are not large.</jats:p>
research_question: How do institutional investors perceive climate risks and their financial implications for portfolio firms, and what approaches do they take to address these risks?
answer: Institutional investors believe climate risks have financial implications for their portfolios and are already materializing (particularly regulatory risks). Long-term, larger, and ESG-oriented investors prefer risk management and engagement over divestment to address climate risks. While investors believe some equity valuations don't fully reflect climate risks, the perceived overvaluations are not large.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing direct survey evidence of institutional investors' climate risk perceptions and management approaches, offering empirical insights into how these sophisticated market participants view and respond to climate-related financial risks.

author: Zacharias Sautner

author: Zacharias Sautner
title: Opening the Black Box: Internal Capital Markets and Managerial Power
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We analyze the internal capital markets of a multinational conglomerate, using a unique panel data set of planned and actual allocations to business units and a survey of unit CEOs. Following cash windfalls, more powerful managers obtain larger allocations and increase investment substantially more than their less connected peers. We identify cash windfalls as a source of misallocation of capital, as more powerful managers overinvest and their units exhibit lower ex post performance and productivity. These findings contribute to our understanding of frictions in resource allocation within firms and point to an important channel through which power may lead to inefficiencies.</jats:p>
research_question: How does managerial power affect internal capital allocation decisions within multinational conglomerates, particularly following cash windfalls?
answer: More powerful managers obtain larger capital allocations and increase investment substantially more than less connected peers following cash windfalls, leading to overinvestment, lower ex post performance, and reduced productivity in their units.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to understanding frictions in resource allocation within firms by identifying an important channel through which managerial power leads to inefficiencies in internal capital markets, using unique panel data of planned versus actual allocations and CEO surveys to open the 'black box' of internal capital allocation decisions.

author: Zacharias Sautner
title: Climate Risk Disclosure and Institutional Investors
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Through a survey and analyses of observational data, we provide systematic evidence that institutional investors value and demand climate risk disclosures. The survey reveals the investors have a strong demand for climate risk disclosures, and many actively engage their portfolio firms for improvements. Empirical analyses of holdings data corroborate this evidence by showing a significantly positive association between climate-conscious institutional ownership and better firm-level climate risk disclosure. We establish further evidence of institutional investors’ influence on firms’ climate risk disclosures by examining a shock to the climate risk disclosure demand of French institutional investors (French Article 173).</jats:p>
               <jats:p>Authors have furnished an Internet Appendix, which is available on the Oxford University Press Web site next to the link to the final published paper online.</jats:p>
research_question: Do institutional investors value and demand climate risk disclosures from their portfolio companies?
answer: Yes, institutional investors have a strong demand for climate risk disclosures and actively engage portfolio firms for improvements, with climate-conscious institutional ownership being significantly positively associated with better firm-level climate risk disclosure.
positioning_statement: This paper provides systematic evidence through both survey data and observational analyses to establish the relationship between institutional investors and climate risk disclosure, using a natural experiment (French Article 173) to demonstrate causal influence of institutional investors on firms' climate risk disclosures.

author: Zacharias Sautner
title: Behind the Scenes: The Corporate Governance Preferences of Institutional Investors
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We survey institutional investors to better understand their role in the corporate governance of firms. Consistent with a number of theories, we document widespread behind‐the‐scenes intervention as well as governance‐motivated exit. These governance mechanisms are viewed as complementary devices, with intervention typically occurring prior to a potential exit. We further find that long‐term investors and investors that are less concerned about stock liquidity intervene more intensively. Finally, we find that most investors use proxy advisors and believe that the information provided by such advisors improves their own voting decisions.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the corporate governance preferences and mechanisms used by institutional investors, particularly regarding behind-the-scenes intervention and governance-motivated exit?
answer: Institutional investors widely engage in behind-the-scenes intervention and governance-motivated exit as complementary mechanisms, with intervention typically occurring before potential exit. Long-term investors and those less concerned about stock liquidity intervene more intensively, and most investors rely on proxy advisors to improve their voting decisions.
positioning_statement: This paper provides empirical evidence through direct survey of institutional investors to better understand their actual governance practices, documenting findings that are consistent with existing theories about institutional investor behavior in corporate governance.

author: Zhi Da
title: Cash Flow, Consumption Risk, and the Cross‐section of Stock Returns
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>I link an asset's risk premium to two characteristics of its underlying cash flow: covariance and duration. Using empirically novel estimates of both cash flow characteristics based exclusively on accounting earnings and aggregate consumption data, I examine their dynamic interaction in a two‐factor cash flow model and find that they are able to explain up to 82% of the cross‐sectional variation in the average returns on size, book‐to‐market, and long‐term reversal‐sorted portfolios for the period 1964 to 2002. This finding highlights the importance of fundamental cash flow characteristics in determining the risk exposure of an asset.</jats:p>
research_question: How do cash flow characteristics (specifically covariance and duration) explain the cross-sectional variation in stock returns?
answer: Cash flow covariance and duration can explain up to 82% of the cross-sectional variation in average returns on size, book-to-market, and long-term reversal-sorted portfolios, demonstrating that fundamental cash flow characteristics are crucial determinants of asset risk exposure.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by using empirically novel estimates of cash flow characteristics based exclusively on accounting earnings and aggregate consumption data, and by demonstrating the dynamic interaction of covariance and duration in a two-factor cash flow model to explain cross-sectional return variation.

author: Zacharias Sautner
title: Firm‐Level Climate Change Exposure
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We develop a method that identifies the attention paid by earnings call participants to firms' climate change exposures. The method adapts a machine learning keyword discovery algorithm and captures exposures related to opportunity, physical, and regulatory shocks associated with climate change. The measures are available for more than 10,000 firms from 34 countries between 2002 and 2020. We show that the measures are useful in predicting important real outcomes related to the net‐zero transition, in particular, job creation in disruptive green technologies and green patenting, and that they contain information that is priced in options and equity markets.</jats:p>
research_question: How can we systematically measure and quantify firm-level climate change exposure across different types of climate-related risks and opportunities?
answer: The authors develop a machine learning-based method using keyword discovery algorithms applied to earnings calls that successfully captures three types of climate exposures (opportunity, physical, and regulatory shocks), and demonstrate that these measures predict real economic outcomes like green job creation and patenting while being priced in financial markets.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing a novel, systematic approach to measuring firm-level climate exposure that goes beyond existing methods, offering comprehensive coverage across multiple countries and time periods, and demonstrating both real economic relevance and financial market pricing of climate risks.

author: Zhi Da
title: In Search of Attention
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We propose a new and direct measure of investor attention using search frequency in Google (Search Volume Index (SVI)). In a sample of Russell 3000 stocks from 2004 to 2008, we find that SVI (1) is correlated with but different from existing proxies of investor attention; (2) captures investor attention in a more timely fashion and (3) likely measures the attention of retail investors. An increase in SVI predicts higher stock prices in the next 2 weeks and an eventual price reversal within the year. It also contributes to the large first‐day return and long‐run underperformance of IPO stocks.</jats:p>
research_question: Can Google search frequency (Search Volume Index) serve as a direct and effective measure of investor attention, and how does this attention measure relate to stock price movements?
answer: Google Search Volume Index (SVI) is a valid, timely measure of retail investor attention that predicts short-term price increases (2 weeks) followed by long-term price reversals (within a year), and contributes to IPO pricing anomalies including large first-day returns and subsequent underperformance.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces a new and direct measure of investor attention using Google search data, positioning it as superior to existing proxies by being more timely and specifically capturing retail investor attention, thereby advancing the literature on investor attention and its market effects.

abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Fractional trading (FT)—the ability to trade less than a whole share—removes barriers to high-priced stocks and facilitates entry by capital-constrained retail investors. We observe a surge of tiny trades, measured using off-exchange one-share trades, among high-priced stocks compared to low-priced stocks after FT is introduced to the U.S. equity markets. These tiny trades, when coordinated during attention-grabbing events, are forceful enough to exert large price pressure on high-priced stocks. Further evidence suggests that FT can even fuel meme-stock-like trading frenzies and bubbles in high-priced stocks, for which the feedback effect likely plays a role. (JEL G10, G12, G14, G18, G32, G41)</jats:p>
research_question: How does fractional trading affect trading behavior and price dynamics, particularly for high-priced stocks and capital-constrained retail investors?
answer: Fractional trading leads to a surge in tiny trades among high-priced stocks, and when these trades are coordinated during attention-grabbing events, they create significant price pressure and can fuel meme-stock-like trading frenzies and bubbles in high-priced stocks.
positioning_statement: This paper examines the relatively new phenomenon of fractional trading in U.S. equity markets, focusing on its impact on retail investor participation and market dynamics for high-priced stocks, an area that appears to be underexplored in existing literature given the recent introduction of fractional trading capabilities.
